projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Second PART OF Modern Reports, BEING A COLLECTION Of Several SPECIAL CASES Mo≈øt of them ADJUDGED in the COURT OF Common Pleas, In the 26, 27, 28, 29, & 30th Years of the Reign OF King Charles II. When Sir Fra. North was Chief Ju≈øtice of the ≈øaid Court. To which are added, Several ≈øelect CASES in the Courts of Chancery, Kings-Bench, and Exchequer in the ≈øaid Years.

p.hi: Carefully Collected by a Learned Hand.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by the A≈ø≈øigns of Rich. and Edw. Atkins E≈øquires, for Charles Harper at the Flower de Luce over again≈øt St. Dun≈øtans Church in Fleet≈øtreet, 1698.

div.head: TO THE Right Honourable JOHN Lord SOMERS Baron of Eve≈øham, Lord High Chancellor OF ENGLAND.
div.p:
WHEN both the Favour and Severity of the Laws were by partial and unu≈øual Methods applyed to the Per≈øons, and not to the Ca≈øes of the accu≈øed; when the Life and Honour of an unfortunate Man depended on the Arbitrary Dictates of ≈øome Men in Authority, and when the Sentence pronounced was more Criminal than the Offence of which the Party was too ea≈øily convicted; then was your Lord≈øhip as far from any Advancement to a judicial Office, as your Judgment and Inclinations were from the Approbation of ≈øuch Proceedings: But no ≈øooner were places of Honour and Profit in the Law made the un≈øought Rewards of good and learned Men, but your Lord≈øhips Merits entituled you to both; who≈øe Moderation and Temper will make your Admini≈øtration ju≈øt and ea≈øie in that honourable
Court, to which Fortune had no ≈øhare in your Promotion; and who≈øe natural Abilities are ≈øo improved by a continued and inflexible Study, that your Knowledge is not alone confined to the municipal Laws of this Nation, but is generally exten≈øive to all humane Learning.

What Services may not a Prince expect from the Wi≈ødom and Vigilancy of ≈øuch a Coun≈øellor? And what Benefit may not a divided People find by your equal Di≈øpen≈øation of Ju≈øtice, who (if they can be united in any thing) it mu≈øt be in the general Satisfaction which all have in your Promotion, becau≈øe they know tho≈øe Cau≈øes which come before your Lord≈øhip will receive a due Hearing and Attention without Pa≈ø≈øion or Prejudice to Per≈øons; ≈øuch Emotions being as much beneath the Greatne≈øs of your Lord≈øhips Mind, as they are beyond the Duty of Ju≈øtice, and fit only for ≈øuch who will neither be guided by the Rules of Equity or Rea≈øon; ≈øo true is that Saying, Utitur animi motu, qui uti ratione non pote≈øt.

The Re≈øpect which is due to the Office of Magi≈øtrates challengeth an univer≈øal Obedience; but that particular Affection and E≈øteem which we have for their Per≈øons is due only to their Vertues and Merits: And ≈øuch is that which I have, and all Men (e≈øpecially tho≈øe of my Profe≈ø≈øion) ought to have for your Lord≈øhip and the pre≈øent Judges in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, who≈øe Learning and Integrity in judicial Determinations may bring the Laws nearer to Perfection; and who≈øe Examples are the ju≈øt Commendation of the pre≈øent, and I hope will be the Imitation of ≈øucceeding Ages.

I could never under≈øtand the right meaning of that Sentence, Boni Judicis e≈øt ampliare Juri≈ødictionem for if that be true, then to what purpo≈øe were tho≈øe Arguments at the Bar of the Hou≈øe of Peers again≈øt
≈øome late Judges for retaining Bills in Equity, the ≈øubject Matter whereof was only tryable at the Common Law? Such Complaints are now no more, becau≈øe your Lord≈øhip will not only ≈øupport the Honour and Dignity of that Court, wherein you pre≈øide, in the Beauty of Order, but will not enjoyn any other from exerci≈øing its proper Jurisdiction.

Thus will the Credit of the Laws of England be revived, and Men will acquie≈øce under the legal Determinations of each Court; very few Writs of Error will be brought for Error in Law, becau≈øe of the Ju≈øtice and Stability of the Judgment in that Court wherein it was given; and very few Appeals, becau≈øe your Lord≈øhip knows ≈øo well how to temper Equity with Ju≈øtice, that he mu≈øt be a very angry Man, who goes away di≈ø≈øatisfied with your Lord≈øhips Decree.

But ≈øince the Actions of Men in great Places are ≈øubject to the various Cen≈øures of Mankind, if any prejudiced Per≈øon ≈øhould revive tho≈øe Di≈øputes, or quarrel at your Lord≈øhips Admini≈øtration, ≈øuch Complaints would leave no other Impre≈ø≈øion upon the Minds of impartial Men than to convince them of the Wrong done to your Lord≈øhip, and the Folly of ≈øuch Mi≈øapprehen≈øions.

My Lord, I have prefixed your Lord≈øhips Name to this mean Performance, taking this occa≈øion to ≈øhew that great Honour and Re≈øpect, which I have for your Lord≈øhip; not that I am ≈øo vain to think any thing herein to be worthy of your Lord≈øhips Lei≈øure, neither do I think it Manners to beg your Lord≈øhips Patronage, becau≈øe a good Book will protect it ≈øelf at all times, and a bad one de≈øerves no Protection.

I know few Books are either prai≈øed or peru≈øed, but what are warranted by the common Repute and E≈øteem
of the Writer, which mu≈øt be imputed to the Prejudice and Partiality of Men, and which argues a Diffidence of our natural Parts, as if we did not dare to make a right u≈øe of our own Judgments: For this Rea≈øon I have concealed my Name, that a Judgment may not be made of the Book by the Repute of the Writer. But I hope your Lord≈øhip will not condemn my Ambition, when I ≈øay, I am not altogether unknown to your Lord≈øhip, who am

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips Mo≈øt humble Servant, J. W.

div.head: DE Termino Sancti Hill. Annis 26 & 27 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Coram Franci≈øco North Milite Capital Ju≈øtic'. Hugone Wyndham Milite, Ju≈øtic'. Roberto Atkins Milite, & Ju≈øtic'. Willielmo Ellis Milite, Ju≈øtic'.
The King ver≈øus the Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter and Sir Francis Clark.
div.p: IN a Quare Impedit a ≈øpecial Verdict was found,Quare Impedit. Mod. Rep. 195. Grant of the King, where the fir≈øt Clau≈øe is certain, and a mi≈øtake in another, yet the Grant is good. wherein the Ca≈øe was thus:

The Mannor of Laburn, to which the Advow≈øon of the Church of Laburn was appendant, did by the di≈ø≈øolution of Mona≈øteries Anno 31 H. 8. c. 13. 31 H. 8. come to the King, who granted the ≈øaid Mannor to the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury (excepting the Advow≈øon) and afterwards the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop regrants the ≈øame to King H. 8. and the Advow≈øon of the Church of Laburn afore≈øaid; and then King H. 8. grants the ≈øaid Mannor of Laburn & AdvocationÃÑ Eccle≈øiae de Laburn dicto Archiepi≈øcopo, (having named him before) dudum ≈øpectanÃÑ, and which was regranted to the ≈øaid King by the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop, and lately belonging to the Abbot of G. &c. adeo plene as the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop or Abbot had it, or as it was in our hands by any ways or means how≈øoever.
And whether the Advow≈øon pa≈ø≈øed by this la≈øt Grant was the Que≈øtion.
Three Iu≈øtices (ab≈øente North) gave Iudgment for the Defendant, that the Advow≈øon did pa≈øs by this Grant.

Iu≈øtice Ellis in his Argument ≈øaid, That it was plain that when the Mannor came to H. 8. the Advow≈øon was appendant, but when it was granted to the Archbi≈øhop, and the Advow≈øon excepted, it then became in gro≈øs, and therefore could never afterward be appendant:James and John≈øon's Ca≈øe Po≈øtea. As an Aere once di≈øunited from the Mannor can never after be part of that Mannor, Liford's Ca≈øe, 7 Co.

And 'tis as plain, that before the Statute de Praerogativa Regis cap. 15. That in the ea≈øe of the King, by the Grant of a Mannor, the Advow≈øon though not named pa≈ø≈øed, much more if it be named in any part of the De√©d, as if it be in the Habendum though not in the Premi≈ø≈øes; but that mu≈øt be intended of an Advow≈øon appendant.10 Co. 63.
And though Advow≈øons are excepted by that Statute, yet in ca≈øe of Re≈øtitution an Advow≈øon will pa≈øs by the Words Adeo plene & integre, though not named.

In this Ca≈øe there are general Words and the ≈øame as in10 Co. 63. Po≈øtea. Atturney General again≈øt Turner. Whi≈øtler's Ca≈øe; yet this differs from that, for here 'tis granted adeo plene, as the Abbot had it; by tho≈øe Words it doth not pa≈øs, for then it was appendant, but now it is in gro≈øs; and if the King intended to pa≈øs an Advow≈øon as appendant when 'tis in gro≈øs, the Grant is void, Hob. 303.

In Whi≈øtler's Ca≈øe there are the Words Adeo plene, as in this, and the Advow≈øon was appendant ≈øtill, but yet there are general Words here that will pa≈øs it: Adeo plene as the Archbi≈øhop had it, will not ≈øerve, becau≈øe he never had it; neither will Adeo plene as the Abbot had it pa≈øs this Advow≈øon, becau≈øe he had it in gro≈øs; but Adeo plene as the King had it by any ways or means what≈øoever, tho≈øe general Words are ≈øufficient to pa≈øs it.

The King grants the Mannor and the Advow≈øon of the Church of Laburn, which is certain and by particular Name, part of what follows (as ≈øpectan' to the Archbi≈øhop ) is fal≈øe, for it never belonged to him becau≈øe it was excepted in the Grant of the Mannor to him, but the fir≈øt di≈øcription being full and certain the fal≈øity of the other ≈øhall not avoid the Grant, e≈øpecially when the King is not deceived in his Title nor in the Value, and when there is a certainty of the thing granted.
Some fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtions may make his Grant void, as if he grant the Mannor of D. reciting that it came to him by Attainder, when it came by Purcha≈øe, Hob. 229.

Lane 11.But if the mi≈ø-recital concerns not the Kings Title or Profit, it doth not vitiate the Grant, 10 H. 2. 4. Sir John Le≈øtrange's Ca≈øe, where the King by Office found had the Ward≈øhip of a Mannor, and makes a Grant thereof reciting Quod quidem Manerium in
manus no≈øtras ≈øei≈øitÃÑ &c. which was not true, yet the Grant was held good, becau≈øe it was only to make that certain which was certain enough before by a particular de≈øcription. So in Legat's Ca≈øe, 10 Co. 113. wherein is cited the Ca≈øe of the Earl of Rutland and Markham, to whom the Que√©n had granted the Office of Parker≈øhip, &c. quod quidem Officium the late Earl of Rutland habuit, when in truth the Earl never had it before, yet the Grant was held good.

So al≈øo if he grants for and in con≈øideration of Service done, or Mony paid, if fal≈øe, it avoids not the Grant, becau≈øe ≈øuch Con≈øiderations (when pa≈øt) are not material whether they are true or fal≈øe, Cro. Jac. 34.

If the King let the Mannor of D. of the value of 4 l. per annum, if it be more it is ill, but if he let it by a particular Name, and then adds, Quod quidem Manerium is of ≈øuch a value 'tis good, becau≈øe the2 Cro. 34. Quod quidem is but the addition of another certainty; ≈øo here the Advow≈øon is granted by ≈øpecial and expre≈øs Name, but the Clau≈øe that follows, Dudum ≈øpectanÃÑ to the Archbi≈øhop, implies a mi≈øtake; and had there be√©n no more in the Ca≈øe this fal≈øity would never have avoided the Grant.

But when the King had enumerated ≈øeveral ways by which he thought he might be intitled, at la≈øt as a proof that he was re≈øolved to pa≈øs it, he adds the≈øe Words, viz. as it is in our hands by any way or means what≈øoever.

Atkins Iu≈øtice of the ≈øame Opinion: Where the thing is not granted by an expre≈øs Name, there, if a fal≈øity is in the de≈øcription of that thing, the Grant is void even in the ca≈øe of a common per≈øon, as if he grant Lands lately let to D. in ≈øuch a Pari≈øh, and the Lands were not let to D. were al≈øo in another Pari≈øh, the Grant is void, becau≈øe the Lands are not particularly named, Ander≈ø. 148. Heywood's Ca≈øe.

A fortiori in the Ca≈øe of the King, as if he grant omnia illa tenementa ≈øituata in Wells, when in truth the Lands did not lie there, for this rea≈øon the Grant was void, becau≈øe it was general, and yet re≈øtrained to a particular Town, and the Pronoun (illa) goes through the whole ≈øentence.
But if a thing is granted by an expre≈øs Name, though there is a Fal≈øity in the de≈øcription, yet in the Ca≈øe of a common per≈øon 'tis good.

As when the Subchantor and Vicars Choral of Lichfield made a Grant to Humfrey Peto of 78 Acres of Glebe, and of their Tythes Predial and Per≈øonal, and al≈øo of the Tythe of the Glebe, All which late were in the occupation of Margaret Peto,
which was not true, yet the Grant was adjudged good; for the Words All which are not Words of re≈øtriction unle≈øs when the Clau≈øe is general and the Sentence entire, but not when it is di≈øtinct, Cro. Car. 548.

But in the Ca≈øe of the King, if there is a fal≈øity by which the King hath a prejudice, and a Fal≈øity upon the ≈øugge≈øtion of the Party, it will make the Grant void, but every Fal≈øity will not avoid his Grant if it be not to his prejudice.

But let the Fal≈øity in this Ca≈øe be what it will the Adeo plene as it is in our hands helps it; and though it hath been objected, that the≈øe Words will not help the Grant, becau≈øe nothing new is granted, that being done before; 'tis true there is nothing new granted, but that which was before was not well granted till this Clau≈øe came which ≈øupplies and amends the Fal≈øity; for now 'tis apparent that the King intended to pa≈øs the Advow≈øon as well as the Mannor, and therefore at la≈øt grants it, be his Title what it will.

In all Ca≈øes where the Kings Grant is void becau≈øe of any mi≈øtake in his Title, 'tis to be intended the King would not make the Grant unle≈øs the Title were ≈øo as 'tis recited, but here 'tis apparent the King re≈øolved to grant it.
Judgment. Wyndham Iu≈øtice agre√©d, and Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: Wilcox ver≈øus the Servant of Sir Fuller Skipwith.
div.p: Replevin. Ju≈øtification for an Herriot.IN Replevin the Defendant ju≈øtifies the taking of the Cattle for a Herriot which he alledges to be due upon every Alienation without notice.
The Plaintiff denies the Herriot to be due upon Alienation. And thereupon I≈ø≈øue is joyned.

The Special Verdict finds the Tenure to be by Fealty and the Rent of 3 s. 1 d. (though the Defendant in his Avowry had alledged the Rent to be 12 s. 4 d. and the Plaintiff in his Barr to the Avowry had confe≈ø≈øed it to be ≈øo) Suit of Court and an Herriot, which was payable upon every Alienation with or without notice.
And whether upon this Special Verdict Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff or the Avowant was the doubt.

Ex parte Def.Vpon the point of Pleading Serjeant Jones for the Defendant ≈øaid it had b√©en objected that the Avowry was ill, for ut Ballivus, &c. bene cognÃÑ captionem in praedicto loco, &c. but doth not ≈øay tempore quo, &c. for a Herriot (tempore quo, &c. being
left out) and ≈øo doth not ≈øay a Herriot was due at the time of the taking of the Goods.
But he an≈øwered, That that was u≈øual and common, and of that Opinion were all the Iu≈øtices, and ≈øo it was held good.

It was farther objected, That here is a variance between the Avowry and the finding in the Special Verdict; The Avowant ≈øays that the Rent was 12 s. and 4 d. and the Iury find that it was but 3 s. and 1 d. He al≈øo ≈øaith, that the Herriot was due upon every Alienation without notice, and they find it due with or without notice.

But to that he ≈øaid, the Iury have doubted only of the la≈øt Point, for the Avowry was not for Rent but for the Herriot, ≈øo the ≈øub≈øtance is whether he had good cau≈øe to di≈øtrein for the Herriot or not.Po≈øtea.

And as to that, the Sub≈øtance is ≈øufficiently found, like the Ca≈øe in Dyer 115. Debt upon Bond for performance of Covenants, and not to do wa≈øte, the Breach a≈ø≈øigned was that the Defendant felled twenty Oakes, who pleads Non ≈øuccidit viginti quercus praed' nec earum aliquam, the Iury find he cut down ten, yet the Plaintiff recovered; for though the intire Allegation of the Breach was not found, becau≈øe ten did not prove the i≈ø≈øue of twenty literally, yet the Sub≈øtance is found, which is ≈øufficient to make the Bond forfeited.

So in Tre≈øpas, where the Plaintiff makes a Title under a Lea≈øe which commenced on Lady-day, Habendum √† Fe≈øto, &c. and the I≈ø≈øue was non demi≈øit modo & forma, the Iury found the Lea≈øe to be made upon Lady-day, Habendum √† confectione, and ≈øo it commenced upon Lady-day, and not √† Fe≈øto, &c. which mu≈øt be the day after the Fea≈øt, yet 'twas adjudged for the Plaintiff, becau≈øe theMoor 868. Yelv. 148. Sub≈øtance was whether or no the Plaintiff had a Lea≈øe to intitle him≈øelf to commence an Action, Hob. 27.

But in Ejectment or Replevin ≈øuch a Declaration had been naught, becau≈øe therein you are to recover the Term, and therefore the Title mu≈øt be truly ≈øet out, and in Replevin you are to have a RetornÃÑ habend', but in Tre≈øpas 'tis only by way of excu≈øe. Sed quaere.
A ≈øecond Rea≈øon is becau≈øe both Plaintiff and Defendant in pleading have agr√©ed the matter in this particular, for both ≈øay the Rent was 12 s. and 4 d.

'Tis a Rule in Law, That what the Parties have agreed in pleading ≈øhall be admitted though, the Iury find otherwi≈øe, 2 A≈ø≈ø. pl. 17. 18 E. 3. 13. b. 2 Co. 4. Goddard's Ca≈øe. Iurors are not bound by E≈øtoppel ad dicend' veritatem, for they are ≈øworn ≈øo to do unle≈øs the E≈øtoppel be within the ≈øame Record, but here
that which is confe≈ø≈øed cannot be matter of I≈ø≈øue not being Lis conte≈øtata.
It has be√©n objected, that in 33 H. 6. 4. b. the Plaintiff brought Debt for 20 l. the Iury found the Defendant only owed 10 l. and the Plaintiff could never recover.
But that mu≈øt be intended of a Debt due upon Contract, and there the lea≈øt variance will be fatal, 38 H. 6. 1.

As to the ≈øecond variance 'tis not material, for 'tis not true as the Avowant hath ≈øaid, for if the matter in i≈ø≈øue be found, the finding over is but ≈øurplu≈øage; both the Verdict and the Avowry agree that the Defendant may take a Di≈øtre≈øs in ca≈øe of Alienation without notice: And ≈øo he prayed Iudgment for the Defendant.

Judgment for the Defendant.The Court were all of Opinion that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Defendant; for what is agr√©ed in pleading, though the Iury find contrary, the Court is not to regard, and here the ≈øub≈øtance of the I≈ø≈øue as to the ≈øecond Point is well found for the Defendant.

Iudge Atkins told Serjeant Wilmot, who argued for the Plaintiff, that he had cited many Ca≈øes which came not up to the matter, and ≈øo did magno conatu nugas agere, for which rea≈øon I have not reported his Argument.

div.head: Smith ver≈øus Feverel.
div.p: Ca≈øe for ≈øurcharging a Common.THE Plaintiff brought an Action on the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Defendant, ≈øetting forth that he had right of Common in A. and that the Defendant put in his Cattel, viz. Hor≈øes, Cows, Hogs, &c. ita quod Communiam in tam amplo modo habere non potuit.
The Defendant pleads a Licence from the Lord of the Soil to put in Averia ≈øua, which was agre√©d to comprehend Hogs as well as other Cattle in the mo≈øt general ≈øen≈øe.

The Defendant demurs, and after Argument the Court were all of opinion that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff, becau≈øe the Defendant in his Plea hath not alledged that there was ≈øufficient Common left for the Commoners, for the Lord cannot let out to pa≈øture ≈øo much as not to leave ≈øufficient for the Commoners.

And though it was objected, that the Plaintiff might have replyed ≈øpecially and ≈øhewn there was not enough, yet it was agreed by the Court that in this Ca≈øe he need not, becau≈øe his Declaration
to that purpo≈øe was full enough, and that being the very Gi≈øt of the Action the Defendant ≈øhould have pleaded it.

It was held ind√©ed that in an Action upon the Ca≈øe by the Commoner again≈øt the Lord, he mu≈øt particularly ≈øhew the Surcharge; but if the Action be brought again≈øt a Stranger ≈øuch a ≈øhewing as is here is ≈øufficient.

North Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, and it was admitted, that the Licence being general ad ponend' averia it ≈øhould be intended only of Commonable Cattel and not of Hogs; Sed contra, if the Licence had been for a particular time.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: A Man devi≈øes Land to A. his Heir at Law,Devi≈øe. and devi≈øes other Lands to B. in Fee and ≈øaith, If A. mole≈øt B. by Suit or otherwi≈øe he ≈øhall lo≈øe what is devi≈øed to him, and it ≈øhall go to B. The Devi≈øor dies, A. enters into the Lands devi≈øed to B. and claims it, the Court were of Opinion that this Entry and Claim is a ≈øufficient breach to entitle B. to the Land of A.

It was al≈øo agreed that the≈øe words, If A. mole≈øt B. by Suit, &c. make a Limitation and not a Condition, Pl. Com. 420. the Devi≈øe being to the Heir at Law; for if it were a Condition, it de≈øcends to him and ≈øo 'tis void, becau≈øe he cannot enter for the breach, 3 Co. 22. Cro. Eliz. 204. Wellock and Hamonds Ca≈øe. Paying in the ca≈øe of the elde≈øt Son makes a Limitation, Owen 112.

So in the Ca≈øe of Williams and Fry in an Ejectione firmae in B. R. lately for Newport-Hou≈øe. A. devi≈øeth to his Grand-daughter, Provided and upon Condition that ≈øhe marry with the con≈øent of the Earl of Manche≈øter and her Grandmother, 'tis a Limitation.

2dly, It was agreed, That an Entry and Claim in this Ca≈øe was a ≈øufficient mole≈øtation, for when the Heir enters and claims generally it ≈øhall be intended as Heir, and the words, that he ≈øhall not mole≈øt by Suit or otherwi≈øe, are to be intended occa≈øione praemi≈ø≈øorum.

3dly, There is no n√©ed of Entry to avoid an E≈øtate in ca≈øe of a Limitation, becau≈øe thereby the E≈øtate is determined without Entry or Claim, and the Law ca≈øts it upon the Party to whom it is limited and in whom it ve≈øts till he di≈øagr√©es to it.

A. devi≈øes Land to B. and his Heirs and dies, 'tis in the Devi≈øee immediately, but indeed till Entry he cannot bring a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øory Action, as Tre≈øpa≈øs, &c. Pl. Com. 412, 413. 10 Co. 40. b.
where a Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ve≈øts without Entry a Rever≈øion will ve≈øt without Claim.Nota.

div.head: Curtis ver≈øus Davenant.
div.p: Prohibition A Bi≈øhop cannot appoint Commi≈ø≈øioners to tax the Pari≈øh for building or repairing a Church.IN a Prohibition the Que≈øtion was, whether if a Church be out of repair, or being ≈øo much out of order that it mu≈øt be re-edified whether the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈øs may direct a Commi≈ø≈øion to impower Commi≈ø≈øioners to tax and rate every Pari≈øhioner for the re-edifying thereof: The Court did unanimou≈øly agree ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øions were again≈øt Law, and therefore granted a Prohibition to the Spiritual Court to ≈øtop a Suit there commenced again≈øt ≈øome of the Pari≈øhioners of White-Chappel for not paying the Tax according to their proportions.

It was agr√©ed that the Spiritual Court hath power to compel the Pari≈øh to repair the Church by their Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cen≈øures, but they cannot appoint what Sums are to be paid for that purpo≈øe, becau≈øe the Churchwardens by the con≈øent of the Pari≈øh are to ≈øettle that.
As if a Bridge be out of repair, the Iu≈øtices of Peace cannot ≈øet Rates upon the per≈øons that are to repair it, but they mu≈øt con≈øent to it them≈øelves.

The≈øe Pari≈øhioners here who contribute to the charge of repairing the Church may be ≈øpared, but as for tho≈øe who are ob≈øtinate and refu≈øe to do it, the Spiritual Court may proceed to Excommunication again≈øt them; but there may be a Libel to pay the Rates ≈øet by the Church-wardens.

div.head: Nur≈øe ver≈øus Yearworth in Cancellaria.
div.p: Bill in Cancellaria for the A≈ø≈øignment of a Term. RIchard Yearworth being ≈øei≈øed of Lands in Fee makes a Lea≈øe to the Defendant Chri≈øtopher Yearworth for 99 years to ≈øuch u≈øe as by his la≈øt Will he ≈øhould direct.

Afterward he makes his Will in writing (having then no I≈ø≈øue but his Wife gro≈ø≈øement en≈øeint) and thereby devi≈øes the ≈øame Land to the Heirs of his Body on the Body of his Wife begotten, and for want of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue to the ≈øaid Chri≈øtopher the Defendant and his Heirs.

Richard dies and about a month after a Son is born, the Son by vertue of this Devi≈øe enjoys the Land, but when he attains his full age of one and twenty years, he ≈øuffers a Common Recovery, and afterwards devi≈øes the Land to the Complainant Nur≈øe, and dies.
The Complainant exhibits a Bill again≈øt the Defendant to have the Lea≈øe for 99 years a≈ø≈øigned to him, and whether he ≈øhould have it a≈ø≈øigned or not, was the Que≈øtion.
1. It was pretended that an E≈øtate in F√©e being limited by the Will to Chri≈øtopher, who was Le≈ø≈øee for 99 years, the Term is thereby drowned.

2. It was objected, that the Devi≈øe by Richard to the Infant in ventre la mere was void, and then the Complainant, who claimed by a Devi≈øe from the Po≈øthumus, could have no Title, but that the Defendant to whom an E≈øtate was limited by the Will of Richard in Remainder ≈øhould take pre≈øently.
But notwith≈øtanding what was objected the Lord Keeper Finch decr√©ed that the Lea≈øe which was in Tru≈øt, ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øigned to the Complainant Nur≈øe.

He ≈øaid that at the Common Law without all que≈øtion a Devi≈øe to an Infant in ventre ≈øa mere of Lands devi≈øable by Cu≈øtom was good, ≈øo that the doubt ari≈øes upon the Statute of H. 8.Roll. Abr. tit. Devi≈øe 609. lit. H. pl. 2. Godb. 385. 11 H 6. 13. dubitatur. which enacts, That it ≈øhall be lawful for a Man by his Will in writing to devi≈øe his Lands to any per≈øon or per≈øons, for in this Ca≈øe the Devi≈ø√©e not being in rerum natur√¢, in ≈øtrictne≈øs of ≈øp√©ech is no per≈øon, and therefore it hath be√©n taken that ≈øuch a Devi≈øe is void, Moor's Rep. and 'tis left as a Quaere in the Lord Dyer 304.

But in two Ca≈øes in the Common Pleas, one in the time when the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Hale was Iudge there, the other in the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Bridgman's time, it hath been re≈øolved that if there were ≈øufficient and apt words to de≈øcribe the Infant, though in ventre ≈øa mere, the Devi≈øe might be good.

But in the King's Bench the Iudges ≈øince have been divided upon this Point, that as the Law ≈øtands now adjudged, this Devi≈øe in our Ca≈øe ≈øeems not to be good: But ≈øhould the Ca≈øe come now in que≈øtion, he ≈øaid he was not ≈øure that the Law would be ≈øo adjudged; for 'tis hard to disinherit an Heir for want of apt Words to de≈øcribe him; and 'tis all the rea≈øon in the World, that a Mans intent, lying in extremis, when mo≈øt commonly he is de≈øtitute of Council, ≈øhould be favoured.

div.head: Whitrong ver≈øus Blaney.
div.p: Proce≈øs into Wales. THIS Term the Court delivered their Opinions in this Ca≈øe, North Chief Iu≈øtice, who had heard no Arguments herein, being ab≈øent.

The Ca≈øe was this: The Plaintiff upon a Iudgment in this Court ≈øues out a Scire facias again≈øt the Heir and the Tertenants, which was directed to a Sheriff of Wales; the Defendant is returned Tertenant, but he comes in and pleads Non tenure generally, and traver≈øes the Return; the Plaintiff demurs.
Two Points were ≈øpoke to in the Ca≈øe.
1. Whether the Defendant can traver≈øe the Sheriffs Return? And all the three Iu≈øtices agre√©d that he cannot.
2. Whether a ScirÃÑ FacÃÑ, Ca. Sa. Fi. Fa. &c. would lie into Wales on a Iudgment here at We≈øtmin≈øter, And they agr√©ed it would well lie.

An Indictment may be removed. 2 Cro. 484. Ellis Iu≈øtice agre√©d, If Iudgment be given in Wales it could not be removed into the Chancery by Certiorari, and ≈øent hither by Mittimus, and then Execution taken out upon that Iudgment here, becau≈øe ≈øuch Iudgments are to be executed in their proper Iurisdictions, and ≈øuch was the Re≈øolution of the Iu≈øtices and Barons, Cro. Car. 34.

But on a Iudgment obtained here Execution may go into Wales. No Execution can go into the I≈øle of Man, becau≈øe 'tis no part of England, but Wales is united to England by the Statute of 27 H. 8. c. 26. And therefore in Bedo and Piper's Ca≈øe, 2 Bul≈øtr. 156. it was held that ≈øuch aHet. 20. 2 Cro. 484. The Opinion of Dodderidge. Roll. 395. 2 Sand. 194. Twi≈øden denied it. Writ of Execution goes legally into Wales.
He ≈øaid he had a Report of a Ca≈øe in 11 Car. 2. where a Motion was made to qua≈øh an Elegit into Wales; but it was denied, for the Court agr√©ed the Writ well i≈ø≈øued.
Some have made a difference between the King's Bench and the Common Pleas, as if an Execution might go into Wales upon a Iudgment obtained in the King's Bench, but aliter if in the Common-Pleas.

But the Law is the ≈øame in both Courts, Mich. 1653. betw√©en Wyn and Griffith this very Ca≈øe came in que≈øtion, and there it was held that Execution goes into Wales as well as into any part of England upon a Iudgment in the Courts of We≈øtmin≈øter.
In 2 Bul≈øtr. 54. Hall ver≈øus Rotheram it was held that a Ca. ≈øa. ≈øhall go into Wales again≈øt the Bail upon a Iudgment recovered in the Kings-Bench here again≈øt the Principal.

Of the ≈øame Opinion was Iu≈øtice Atkins, and that the Defendant cannot averr again≈øt the Sheriffs Return, nor a Bi≈øhops Certificate; and the true rea≈øon is given by my Lord Coke in 2 In≈øt. 452. for the Sheriff is but an Officer and hath no day in Court to ju≈øtifie his Return.

In ≈øpecial Ca≈øes Exception may be made to the Sheriffs Return; but this is by rea≈øon of the ≈øpecial provi≈øion that is made for the doing of it by the Statute of W. 2. cap. 39. as in ca≈øe too ≈ømall I≈ø≈øues be returned, or that the Sheriff return a Re≈øcous; the Party in his Averment mu≈øt alledge of what value the I≈ø≈øues are.

2dly. That notwith≈øtanding the common ≈øaying Breve Domini Regis non currit in Walliam, yet a Fi. Fa. Ca. Sa. or any Execution what≈øoever may i≈ø≈øue into Wales upon a Iudgment obtained here: And to prove this he con≈øidered,
1. How Wales formerly ≈øtood in relation to England.
2. How it ≈øtood before it was united by the Statute of H. 8.
3. How it now ≈øtands ≈øince the Vnion.

1. And as to the fir≈øt of the≈øe, England and Wales were once but one Nation, they u≈øed the ≈øame Language, Laws and Religion, and ≈øo continued till the time of the Roman Conque≈øt, before which they were both comprehended under one name, viz. The I≈øle of Great Britain.

But when the Romans came, tho≈øe Britains, who would not ≈øubmit to their yoak, betook them≈øelves to ≈øuch places where they thought them≈øelves mo≈øt ≈øecure, which were the Mountains in Wales, and from whence they came again, ≈øoon after the Romans were drove away by their di≈ø≈øentions here, and then the≈øe Britains enjoyed their ancient Rights, as before.

After this came the Saxons and gave them another di≈øturbance, and then the Kingdom was divided into an Heptarchy; and then al≈øo, and not till then, began the Wel≈øh to be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Engli≈øh; but yet at that time they had great Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions in England, viz. Glouce≈øter, part of Worce≈øter, Hereford, Shrew≈øbury, which they kept till King Offa drove them out of the plaine Countries, and made them fly for ≈øhelter into tho≈øe Mountainous parts in Wales, where they now continue, Cambden 15. And 'tis ob≈øervable that though Wales had Kings and Princes, yet the King of England had Superiority over them, for to him they were Homagers, Cambden
67. The Word Princeps implying a Subordinate Dignity, Selden's Titles of Honor 593.

2dly. During the time of the Separation Wales had di≈øtinct Laws and Cu≈øtoms from tho≈øe in England, whence that ≈øaying took its effect, viz. Breve Domini Regis non currit in Walliam; yet the Parliament of England before that time made Laws to bind Wales; As the Act of 25 Edw. 1. for confirmation of the old great Charter of the Liberties of England and of the Fore≈øts, which enacts, That certain Duties ≈øhall be paid for every Sack of Wool, &c. exported out of Wales, 2 In≈øt. 531.

So the Statute 3 Edw. 1. cap. 17. which gives remedy if a Di≈øtre≈øs be taken and detained in a Ca≈øtle, and upon deliverance demanded by the Sheriff, if the Lord of the Ca≈øtle ≈øhould refu≈øe, he might rai≈øe the Po≈ø≈øe Comitatus, and beat down the Ca≈øtle; and if ≈øuch detainer or refu≈øal be in the Marches of Wales, the King, as the Statute ≈øaith, is Soveraign Lord of all, and ≈øhall do right upon complaint; and the Conque≈øt was not made till 9 E. 1. ≈øo that at that time likewi≈øe though Wales had Princes of its own,Vaugh. 400. yet the Kings of England were Sovereigns to tho≈øe Princes; and though they had Laws of their own, yet were they bound by tho≈øe that were made here; and though their Princes had ordinary remedial Writs, yet in Ca≈øes extraordinary the Kings Writs here run into Wales; and it was not for want of power, but becau≈øe there was no need, for that it went ≈øo ≈øeldom; and when the Kings Writ did i≈ø≈øue it was nece≈ø≈øary to direct it to the Sheriff of an Engli≈øh County, for Wales was not then divided into Shires; but afterwards by the Act called Statutum Walliae 12 Edw. 1. 2 In≈øt. 195. 4 In≈øt. 239. it was divided into ≈øix Counties, and then again by the Act of 27 H. 8. cap. 26. it was divided into the other ≈øix Counties.
But during this time there were frequent Ho≈øtilities between England and Wales, until by the Conque≈øt in Edw. 1. time they were united.

It was objected, That by expre≈øs provi≈øion in 1 E. 6. cap. 10. Exigent and Proclamations ≈øhall be awarded out of the Courts of We≈øtmin≈øter into Wales, which if they might before, this Law was then needle≈øs.

'Tis true, the Opinion of the Parliament ≈øeems to be, that had it not be√©n for this particular provi≈øion, ≈øuch Proclamations might not have i≈ø≈øued; for by 6 H. 8. cap. 4. Vaugh. 414. ≈øuch Proclamations went but to the next County, but they do not declare ≈øo, and perhaps they might ground them≈øelves upon that vulgar Error, Breve Domini Regis non currit in Walliam, which is not true unle≈øs the Clau≈øe be limited to original Writs only.

Objection. That the Statute of 5 El. cap. 23. which enacts, that the Excommunicato Capiendo ≈øhall be returned in the Kings-Bench, and takes notice that this Writ is not returnable into that Court from Wales, and therefore orders that the Significavit ≈øhall be ≈øent by Mittimus out of the Chancery to the Chief Iu≈øtice there, and gives them power to make Proce≈øs to inferior Officers returnable before them at their Se≈ø≈øions for the due Execution of this Writ, all which had be√©n in vain, if the Capias might go into Wales before the making this Act.
An≈øw. But that is an original Writ, and ≈øo comes not up to this Ca≈øe.

Wyndham Iu≈øtice agreed in omnibus, and ≈øaid that the Statute of 1 Ed. 6. was very needful; for if a Man ≈øhould be outlawed, if the Proce≈øs ≈øhould be ≈øent to the Sheriff of the next adjoining County in England, he could not have any notice that he was outlawed, and ≈øo could not tell when oulawed or at who≈øe Suit.

Vaughan late Lord Chief Iu≈øtice held ≈øtrongly,Vaugh. 395. 2 Saund. 194. that no Execucution would go into Wales when this Ca≈øe was argued before him; and of the ≈øame Opinion was Iu≈øtice Twi≈øden.

div.head: William≈øon ver≈øus Hancock.
div.p: Collateral Warranty. Mod. Rep. 192. A Special Verdict was found in an Ejectment, where the Ca≈øe was:

Richard Lock the Father was Tenant for Life, with Remainder in Tail to Richard his Son, Remainder to the right Heirs of the Father, who levies a Fine with Warranty to the u≈øe of Su≈øan and Hannah Prinn in Fe√©; they by Bargain and Sale convey their E≈øtate to the Defendant: The Son in his Fathers life time, before the Warranty attached, comes of full age; the Father dies; The Que≈øtion was whether the Sons Entry was barred by this collateral Warranty thus di≈øcended?
And the thr√©e Iu≈øtices, ab≈øente North Chief Iu≈øtice, were clear of Opinion, that the collateral Waranty was a barr to the Son, and ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

Ellis Iu≈øtice held that his Entry is taken away; for in every Warranty two things are implied, a Voucher and Rebutter; he that comes in by Voucher calleth the per≈øon into Court, who is bound in the Warranty to defend his Right or yield him other Land in recompence, and mu≈øt come in by Privity; but if a Man have the E≈øtate, though he comes in the Po≈øt he may rebut, that is, he may repel the Action of the Heir by the Warranty of his Ance≈øtor without ≈øhewing how the E≈øtate came to him, Fitzh. Nat. Br. 135.
In a Formedon in the Di≈øcender to ≈øay the Ance≈øtor enfeoffed J.S. with Warranty without ≈øhewing how J. S. came by his E≈øtate, is good.
Object. It was objected by Serjeant Maynard, that no per≈øon can take advantage of a Warranty, who comes in by way of u≈øe, as in this Ca≈øe.

An≈øw. But 'tis expre≈øly re≈øolved otherwi≈øe in Lincoln Colledge Ca≈øe, 3 Co. 62. b. and the Prinns in this Ca≈øe came in by Limitation and Act of the Party, and the Defendant, who hath the Rever≈øion likewi≈øe by Limitation of V≈øe, though he be in the Po≈øt, ≈øhall take benefit of the Warranty as A≈ø≈øignee within the Statute of 32 H. 8. Mod. Rep. 181. c. 34. and ≈øo it was re≈øolved in Fowl and Dobles Ca≈øe in this Court, that he who comes in by way of u≈øe may rebut; and Iu≈øtice Jones in his Report fol. 199. affirms the fourth re≈øolution in Lincoln Colledge Ca≈øe to be Law.

It was formerly objected by the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Vaughan, that this Warranty goes only to the Heirs, not to the A≈ø≈øigns, and here the E≈øtate was conveyed by the two Prinns before the Warranty attached.

An≈øw. But when the E≈øtate pa≈ø≈øeth, the Warranty and Covenant followeth, and the A≈ø≈øign√©e ≈øhall have the benefit thereof though not named, and ≈øo is the Authority of 38 E. 3. 26. if a Warranty be made to a Man and his Heirs, the A≈ø≈øigne√© though not named ≈øhall Rebutt, but he cannot Vouch.
So if A. enfeoff B. with Warranty, and B. enfeoff C. without D√©ed, C. ≈øhall vouch A. as A≈ø≈øigne√© of the Land of B. for the Warranty cannot be a≈ø≈øigned.

In this Ca≈øe, though the Warranty did not attach before the E≈øtate in the Land was transferred, yet if it attach afterwards 'tis well enough, and he who hath the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øhall Rebutt the Demandant without ≈øhewing how he came by the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

If a Warranty be to one and his Heirs without the word A≈ø≈øigns, the A≈ø≈øign√©e inde√©d cannot Vouch, but he may1 In≈øt. 265. a 384. Rebutt; for Rebutter is ≈øo incident to a Warranty that a Condition not to Rebutt is void in Law: But 'tis otherwi≈øe of a Condition not to Vouch, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe you may Rebutt.

'Tis true, it hath b√©en an Opinion that he who claimeth above the Warranty, if it be not attached, cannot take benefit of it by way of Voucher or Rebbutter; as if Tenant in Dower maketh a Feoffment to a Villain with Warranty, and the Lord entreth upon him before the de≈øcent of the Warranty, the Villain can never take advantage of this Warranty by way of Rebutter, becau≈øe the Lords Title is paramount the Warranty, and he cometh not under his E≈øtate to whom the Warranty was made.

If Land be given to two Brothers in Fe√©, with Warranty to the elde≈øt and his Heirs, the elde≈øt dies without I≈ø≈øue, the Survivor ≈øhall not take benefit by this Warranty for the rea≈øon afore≈øaid.

But in the Ca≈øe at Barr the Warranty being collateral and annexed to the Land, goeth with the E≈øtate, and whil≈øt that continues the Party may Vouch or Rebutt; ≈øo here the Defendant though he be only Tenant at Will, for the E≈øtate is in the Bargainors, and their Heirs (there being no Execucution of it either by Livery or Enrolment) yet he may Rebutt.

Iu≈øtice Atkins was of the ≈øame Opinion, that by this collateral Warranty the Entry of the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff was taken away, for 'tis the nature of a collateral Warranty to be a Barr; aJones Rep. 199, 200. 1 In≈øt. 366, 385. 25 H. 6. 63. Bro. Gar. 4. Right is bound by it; it extingui≈øhes a Right, 'tis annexed to the Land and runs with it.

If then a collateral Warranty be of this nature, 'tis again≈øt all rea≈øon, that he who is thus bound ≈øhould make any Title to the Land; but 'tis very rea≈øonable that he who comes in qua≈øi by that E≈øtate ≈øhould defend his Title.

The Opinions of Iu≈øtice Jones and Iu≈øtice Crook in the Ca≈øe ofCro. Car. 368. Spirt and Bence has occa≈øioned this doubt: The Ca≈øe was ≈øhortly thus: Cann being ≈øei≈øed in F√©e had thr√©e Sons, Thomas, Francis and Henry and devi≈øed Lands to the two elde≈øt in Tail, and to Henry the Meadow called Warhay (which was the Land in que≈øtion) but doth not limit what E≈øtate he ≈øhould have in it; then he adds the≈øe Words, viz. Al≈øo I will that he ≈øhall enjoy all Bargains I had of Webb to him and his Heirs, and for want of Heirs of his Notwith≈øtanding the word Body he had but an E≈øtate for Life in Warhay, for that word extends to no other than Webbs Bargains. Body, to his Son Francis, and that Margaret ≈øhould have it for Life. Cann dies, the Meadow was not one of Webb's Bargains, Thomas had I≈ø≈øue Thomas the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, Henry made a Feoffment in F√©e to A. and B. to the u≈øe of him≈øelf and his Wife, and to the Heirs of their two Bodies, Remainder to his own right Heirs, with Warranty again≈øt all per≈øons, and died without I≈ø≈øue; the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff enters, being his Cou≈øin and Heir and of full age when Henry died. In this Ca≈øe it was held, that if it had b√©en found that Margaret had an E≈øtate for Life, and that Henry entred in her Life time, that it had be√©n then a Warranty commenced by Di≈ø≈øei≈øin and would not have bound Thomas the Rever≈øioner. But as it was, tho≈øe two Iudges held it no Barr, becau≈øe the Warranty began with the Feoffment to u≈øes, and Henry being him≈øelf the Feoffe√©, it returned in≈øtantly to him, and was extinct as to the Rever≈øion, becau≈øe that was reve≈øted in him in F√©e, and therefore they held he could have no benefit either by Voucher or Rebutter, it being de≈øtroyed at the ≈øame time it was created: But Berkly and Richard≈øon Iu≈øtices held, that quoad the E≈øtate of Henry's Wife the Warranty had a Continuance, and the ground of the contrary opinion might be becau≈øe Iu≈øtice Jones ≈øaid there was no ≈øuch Re≈øolution, as is mentioned to be the fourth in Lincoln Colledge Ca≈øe; yet he affirmeth that very Re≈øolution in his own Reports fol. 199.

There is a Clau≈øe in the27 H. 8. c 10. Statute of V≈øes, difficult to be under≈øtood, by which 'tis Enacted, That every Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe may take ≈øuch Advantage of vouching, &c. as the Feoffees them≈øelves might, ≈øo that Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe have the E≈øtate executed in him before the fir≈øt day of May, 1536. which was a year after the making that Statute; ≈øo that the Clau≈øe ≈øeems to be exclu≈øive of all others who ≈øhall come in afterwards.

An≈øw. But he ≈øuppo≈øed, the Intention of the Law Makers to be, That there ≈øhould be no more Conveyances to V≈øes: But becau≈øe they pre≈øumed, that at fir≈øt Men might not know of it, therefore, le≈øt the Parties ≈øhould be any ways prejudiced, they gave liberty till ≈øuch a time to Vouch or Rebutt, within which time they might have ≈øome knowledge of the Statute, and then it was ≈øuppo≈øed, they would make no more Limitations to V≈øes.

But though they imagined them to be left expiring, yet they revived. Since then, the Parliament gave leave to Vouch or Rebutt, whil≈øt they could in rea≈øon think there would be any Conveyance to V≈øes, 'tis but rea≈øonable, whil≈øt they do continue, that the Parties ≈øhould Rebutt, e≈øpecially ≈øince mo≈øt Conveyances at this day are made to V≈øes.
Windham Iu≈øtice accord in omnibus, and ≈øo Iudgment was given as afore≈øaid.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: DOwer, The Tenant pleads, That a Lea≈øe was made by the Husband for 99 years, before any title of Dower did accrue, which Lea≈øe was yet in being, and ≈øhews, that the Le≈ø≈øor afterwards granted the Rever≈øion to J. S. and died, and that J. S. devi≈øed to the Tenant for Life.
The Demandant replies, That the Le≈ø≈øor made a Feoffment in Fee, ab≈øque hoc, that the Rever≈øion was granted prout, &c.
The Tenant Demurrs.
Newdigate Serjeant, for the Demandant, argued, That the Plea was not good, to which he tooke ≈øeveral Execeptions.
1. Except. The Tenant by his Plea confe≈ø≈øeth, That the Demandant ought to have Iudgment of the Rever≈øion expectant upon the Lea≈øe for 99 years, de tertia, but doth not ≈øay, parte.
2. Except. Here is the Grant of a Rever≈øion pleaded, and 'tis not hic in Curia prolat'.

Then for the Matter, as 'tis pleaded, 'tis not good: He agreed, if Dower be brought again≈øt Le≈ø≈øee for years, he may di≈øcharge him≈øelf, by pleading the continuance of his Lea≈øe, during which time, the Demandant can have no Execution; but here the Tenant is no ways concerned in the Lea≈øe; 'tis Littleton's Ca≈øe, None ≈øhall take advantage of a Relea≈øe, but he who is party or privy, and therefore the Le≈ø≈øee in this Ca≈øe, being party, might have pleaded this, but the Tenant is altogether a Stranger.

Before the Statute of Glouce≈øter, cap 11. If the Demandant had recovered, in a real Action again≈øt the Tenant, the Termor had been bound, becau≈øe, at the Common Law, no body could fal≈øifie the Recovery of a Free-hold, but he who had a Free-hold him≈øelf; this Statute prevents that Mi≈øchief, and Enacts, That the Termor ≈øhall be received before Judgment, to defend the Right of his Term, upon the default of the Tenant, and though the Iudgment cannot be hindred thereby, yet Execution ≈øhall be ≈øu≈øpended, during the Term; and therefore in Dyer 263. b. The Lady Arundel brought Dower again≈øt the Earl of Pembroke, who made default, and before Iudgment the Termor prays to be received upon this Statute, and pleads a Lea≈øe made by the Husband, after Coverture, which was a≈ø≈øigned to him, and that Dower de tertia parte, of the Rent of this Lea≈øe, was a≈ø≈øigned to the Demandant, by the Court of Augmentations, which was afterwards confirmed by Letters Patents; that ≈øhe accepted it, and concludes, That the Plea of the Tenant was by Collu≈øion, between him and her, to make him lo≈øe his Term; And this was held ill, for the Rea≈øon given by my LordHob 316. Not for that rea≈øon, but becau≈øe that Court could not a≈ø≈øign Dower, and ≈øo the Letters Patents of Confirmation could not make that good which was void before. Hobart, That it is ab≈øurd to admit two Per≈øons to di≈øpute the Intere≈øt of a third Man.
But whether the Traver≈øe is good or not, if the Plea is naught, Iudgment ought to be given for the Demandant.
Jones Serjeant contra: The Pleading is well enough.

1. The Tenant confe≈ø≈øeth, That the Demandant ought to have Iudgment of the Rever≈øion de tertia, which is well enough, omitting the word (parte) becau≈øe he claims a third part of ≈øuch Tenements; and the Tenant confe≈ø≈øes ≈øhe ought to have Iudgment, which is full enough, if the words de tertia parte were wholly omitted.

2. He agreed, That whoever Claims under a Deed, mu≈øt ≈øhew it; but the Tenant, in this Ca≈øe, did not defend him≈øelf
by any Title from the Deed, for the ≈øub≈øtance of the Plea, which ≈øecured him, was, That a Lea≈øe of 99 years was in being, and by his alledging the Devi≈øe of an E≈øtate to him for Life, made by the Grantee of the Rever≈øion, he did but allow the Demandant's Writ to be true, which mentions him as Tenant of the Free-hold.
Then for the Matter of the Plea, he ≈øays it was good, and that the Tenant might well plead the Lea≈øe for years.

By the3 In≈øt. 32. b. Statute of Merton, Damages are given in Dower, where the Husband died ≈øei≈øed, which he did in this Ca≈øe; but yet no Damages ought to be paid here, but for the third part of the Rent, and the third part of the Rever≈øion, and therefore to acquit him≈øelf thereof, he may well plead, as here, for which there is a Pre≈øident in Hern's Pleader 335.

Then he ≈øaid, That the Traver≈øe was ill, for the principal Point in the Plea which he ought to have traver≈øed, was the continuance of the Term; and 'tis not material who granted the Rever≈øion, or to whom it was granted; for if there is a Lea≈øe in being, the Demandant cannot have Execution.

The Court were all of Opinion, That the ≈øub≈øtance of the Plea was good, becau≈øe there was a privity in the Grantee, and it was for his benefit to avoid the Demandants Sei≈øin, he being thereby entituled to the Rent, and he may plead this Plea, to ≈øave him≈øelf from Damages given by the Statute of Merton: But as to the Traver≈øe,

North Chief Iu≈øtice, and Wyndham Iu≈øtice, inclined, That the Traver≈øe was well taken; for if a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor pleads the like Plea, as here, 'tis not good, and therefore when the Tenant alledges a Grant of the Rever≈øion, the Demandant may well traver≈øe it.
But Iu≈øtice Ellis and Atkyns were of Opinion, That the Traver≈øe was immaterial, for it was the Lea≈øe and not the Grant that was traver≈øable.

But becau≈øe it was alledged by the Demandants (who offered to refer it to the Council on the other ≈øide) that this Lea≈øe ≈øo pleaded, was an old Mortgage, long ≈øince ≈øatisfied; it was referred accordingly.

div.head: Wil≈øon ver≈øus Drake.
div.p: Prohibition Feme Sole hath Debts due by Specialty, ≈øhe marries, and dies, the Husband ≈øhall have Admini≈øtration; Quaere, whether he may make di≈øtribution to her Kindred. A Prohibition being granted upon the late Statute for di≈øpo≈øing of Inte≈øtates E≈øtates: The Defendant demurred; and the Ca≈øe was no more than this. Whether the Husband being Admin≈øtrator of the Wives E≈øtate be compellable to make di≈øtribution among≈øt her Kindred or not?
This Ca≈øe was argued by Serjeant Seys for the Defendant, and by Serjeant Jones for the Plaintiff.
The circum≈øtances of the Ca≈øe were:

A Feme ≈øole had divers Debts owing to her by Specialty, ≈øhe marries the Plainiff, and died, (the Bonds being not put in ≈øuit during the Coverture) the Plaintiff admini≈øters, and her Brother ≈øues to have a di≈øtribution; and it was in≈øi≈øted for him, that a Con≈øultation ought to go becau≈øe the22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 10. Statute extendeth to all per≈øons, and therefore the Husband, though not named, ≈øhall make di≈øtribution, like the Statute de Donis which only mentions ≈øome E≈øtates Tail; but it has been held that there are ≈øeveral other E≈øtates Tail be≈øides tho≈øe particular in≈øtances there mentioned.

The Title of this Act is general, and there is no Preamble to reduce it to particulars; the enacting and provi≈øional Clau≈øe ≈øpeaks in thre√© places of all per≈øons dying inte≈øtate, within which general words a Feme Covert, as well as others, is contained.
Ex parte Quer.But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid that this Ca≈øe is not in≈øtanced in that Act which provides only where the Husband dies inte≈øtate.

As to what was objected, that this Act is a general provi≈øion and extends to all Ca≈øes of the like nature, the Title of it al≈øo being general, For ≈øetling of Inte≈øtates E≈øtates; to that it was ≈øaid, that before the making this Act there were many doubts in tho≈øe Ca≈øes again≈øt which a Provi≈øion was thereby made, and therefore it well became the Prudence of that Parliament to take away all Scruples, and to ≈øettle tho≈øe things which were ≈øo apt to be que≈øtioned: But no doubt was ever made before this Statute to whom Admini≈øtration of the Wives E≈øtate ≈øhould be committed; for by the Statute of 31 Ed. 3. cap. 11. Power was given to the Ordinary to commit Admini≈øtration to
the be≈øt Friend of the Inte≈øtate; and therefore it has be√©n agr√©ed that the4 Co. 51. Ognel's Ca≈øe. Cro. Car. 106. Johns ver≈øus Row. Husband as being the be≈øt Friend of the Wife was intituled to the Quaere, For Admini≈øtration is not granted to the Husband de jure, the Ordinary may grant it to whom he plea≈øe. Admini≈øtration.

And 'tis agr√©ed on all ≈øides, that no Di≈øtribution is to be made by an Admini≈øtrator; for if any Suit had been commenced in the Spiritual Court to that purpo≈øes, a Prohibition was pre≈øently granted. What need was there to ≈øettle this Matter by Act of Parliament, which was ≈øo clear before?

And 'tis the more unlikely that the E≈øtates of Feme Coverts ≈øhould be intended to be di≈øpo≈øed by this Act, when 'tis con≈øidered that all their E≈øtates con≈øi≈øt only in things in Action, which the Husband might relea≈øe during the Coverture (for all the Goods in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion are by Law ve≈øted in the Husband by the intermarriage) and therefore ≈øuch incon≈øiderable things may be well intended not worthy the care and provi≈øion of a Parliament.

Be≈øides, the Husband and Wife are but one per≈øon in Law, and this Act provides for the ≈øettling Inte≈øtates E≈øtates; now the Wife cannot be ≈øaid to die inte≈øtate, when her Husband (the better part) ≈øurvives.

Before the making tho≈øe Acts of 31 Ed. 3. cap. 11. and 21 H. 8. cap. 5. the Ordinary might have granted Admini≈øtration to a Stranger; but now by the fir≈øt of tho≈øe Laws he is re≈øtrained to the next Friend, and by the other to the Widow or next of Kin; ≈øo that the power which he had at the Common Law, and which was too often by him abu≈øed, being now re≈øtrained, Admini≈øtration mu≈øt be granted as pre≈øcribed by this Law, and no equitable con≈øtruction can take it from the Husband; for how can it be intended that the Parliament would take from him that Right which he had by tho≈øe former Laws, and prefer the Relations of his Wife before him?

But if the Wife ≈øhall be adjudged an Inte≈øtate within this Act then the Husband mu≈øt lo≈øe all her E≈øtate in Action, and he will be then al≈øo within the rules of di≈øtribution; ≈øo that he mu≈øt be at all the labour and pains of Admini≈øtration (which mu≈øt be granted to him) to defend and get in the E≈øtate, and receive no benefit, for he mu≈øt only deduct his Expences out of the Profits, and di≈øtribute the overplus.

He is intituled to the Admini≈øtration within the Statute of Edw. 3. He is al≈øo intituled to it within the Clau≈øe of the Statute of H. 8. which Enacts, That 'tis to be granted to the Wife or next of Kin; and it ≈øeems very unrea≈øonable that he ≈øhould have no profit for his labour.

La≈øtly, A Feme Covert can never be intended to dye inte≈øtate within the meaning of this Act; for that Clau≈øe which directs what Bond the Ordinary ≈øhall take of the Admini≈øtrator is very remarkable to this purpo≈øe, which provides, That if it appear the decea≈øed made any Will, &c. which a Feme Covert cannot do without her Husbands con≈øent, and therefore ≈øhe is not a per≈øon dying inte≈øtate within the intent of this Law. Curia advi≈øare vult.

div.head: DE Termino Pa≈øchae Anno 27 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Naylor ver≈øus Sharple≈øs and other Coroners of Lanca≈øhire.
div.p: AN Action on the Ca≈øe was brought for a Fal≈øe Return in which the Plaintiff ≈øets forth,Ca≈øe for a fal≈øe Return Mod. Rep. 198. that upon a Writ i≈ø≈øuing out of this Court to the Chancellor of the Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, Proce≈øs was directed to ≈øix Coroners being the Defendants, which was delivered to one of them, being then in the pre≈øence of the Party who was to be arre≈øted, but he did not execute it, and afterwards at the Return of the Writ they all returned Non e≈øt inventus.
This Action was laid in Middle≈øex, and upon Not-Guilty pleaded, the Cau≈øe came to Tryal, and there was a Verdict for the Plaintiff.
Baldwyn Serjeant moved in arre≈øt of Iugdment.
1. Except. That the Action ought not to be laid in Middle≈øex, but in Lanca≈øhire, where the Tort was committed.

But as to that it was an≈øwered by Serjeant Turner, when two Matters, both of which are material and are laid in two Counties, the Action may be brought in either, as if two libel in the Admiralty for a Contract made at Land in Dor≈øet≈øhire, and for which the Plaintiff brings an Action in London again≈øt one of them, it has been adjudged the Action lies in either County.
2. Except. The Action will not lie again≈øt the ≈øix Coroners, for the Tort was done by one alone.

As to that it was ≈øaid, all the Coroners are but one Officer; ≈øo if one Sheriff ≈øuffer an E≈øcape, both are liable; but in this Ca≈øe it had been ill to have brought the Action only again≈øt one, becau≈øe
the ground of it is the fal≈øe Return, which was made by ≈øix Coroners.
And as to the fir≈øt Exception, there could be no doubt now, ≈øince after Verdict 'tisStat. 16 & 17 Car. 2. c. 8. helped though the Trial be in a wrong County.

But the Court ≈øaid that Statute helps a Mi≈øtrial in the proper County, but not where the County is mi≈øtaken; and inclined likewi≈øe that this Action was well brought again≈øt the ≈øix for this Tort committed by one Coroner; but if it had b√©en for not arre≈øting the Party, in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe it ought to have been brought again≈øt the Coroner who was pre≈øent with the per≈øon to be arre≈øted; for that had b√©en a per≈øonal Tort which could not have been charged upon the re≈øt.

div.head: Edwards ver≈øus Roberts.
div.p: That he did totally forbear and doth not ≈øay hucu≈øque, good.THE Plaintiff declares that the Defendant promi≈øed to pay him ≈øo much Mony, in con≈øideration that he would forbear to ≈øue him, and then he avers that he did extunc totaliter ab≈øtinere, &c. Vpon Non A≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded a Verdict was found for the Plaintiff. And it was now moved by Turner Serjeant in Arre≈øt of Iudgment.

1. Except. The con≈øideration intends a total forbearance, and the averment is that from the making of the promi≈øe he did totally forbear, but doth not ≈øay hucu≈øque: Sed non allocatur, for that ≈øhall be intended. And it was the Opinion of the whole Court, that if the Con≈øideration be (as in this Ca≈øe) wholly to forbear, the Plaintiff by an Averment that from the making the promi≈øe hucu≈øque he did forbear, is well entituled to an Action.

A like Ca≈øe was this Term, where the Con≈øideration was as before, and the Averment was, that he forbore ≈øeven Months; and being moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment by Serjeant Baldwyn becau≈øe 'tis not ≈øaid hucu≈øque, which implies that after the ≈øeven Months he did not forbear, it was notwith≈øtanding held good, it being a rea≈øonable time; and the rather, becau≈øe if the Action had been brought within the ≈øeven Months, and the Plaintiff had averred that hucu≈øque he forbore, it had been good enough. Quaere.

div.head: Reed ver≈øus Hatton.
div.p: IN a ≈øpecial Verdict in Ejectment the Que≈øtion did ari≈øe upon the con≈øtruction of the Words in a Will;Devi≈øe paying 5 l. per annum, 'tis a Fee. The Ca≈øe being this: John Thatcher was ≈øei≈øed in Fe√© of the Hou≈øes in que≈øtion, and did devi≈øe them to his Son Robert; in which Will there was this Clau≈øe, viz. Which Hou≈øes I give to my Son Robert upon this Condition, that he pay unto his two Si≈øters five pounds a year, the fir≈øt payment to begin at the fir≈øt of the four mo≈øt u≈øual Fea≈øts that ≈øhall next happen after the death of the Te≈øtator, ≈øo as the ≈øaid Fea≈øt be a Month after his death, with a Clau≈øe of Entry for Non-payment. The Te≈øtator dies; the Hou≈øes are worth 16 l. per annum; and whether Robert the Son ≈øhall have an E≈øtate for Life only or in Fee was the Que≈øtion.
This was argued by Jones Serjeant for the Plaintiff, and by Seys Serjeant for the Defendant.

And for the Plaintiff it was ≈øaid,Ex parte Quer. that Robert had but an E≈øtate for Life: 'Tis true in mo≈øt Ca≈øes the Word paying makes a Fee, where there is no expre≈øs Fee limited; but the difference is, viz. where the Mony to be paid is a Sum in gro≈øs, let it be equivalent or not to the value of the thing devi≈øed, the Devi≈øee ≈øhall have a Fee, though the E≈øtate be not devi≈øed to him and his Heirs; but if it be an annual payment out of the thing devi≈øed, as in this Ca≈øe, it will not create a Fee without apt words, becau≈øe the Devi≈ø√©e hath no lo≈øs, and therefore it hath be√©n held that if a Devi≈øe be made to two Sons, to the intent that they ≈øhall bear equal ≈øhare towards the payment of 40 l. to his Wife for Life; the Sons had only an E≈øtate for Life becau≈øe 'tis qua≈øi an annuel Rent out of the Profits and no Sum in gro≈øs,Jones 211. Cro. Car. 157. Broke Abr. tit. E≈øtate 78.
And6 Co. 16. Colliers Ca≈øe was much relied on where this very difference was taken, and allowed that paying 25 l. in gro≈øs makes a Fee, but paying 50 s. per annum creates only an E≈øtate for Life.

All Devi≈øes are intended for the benefit of the Devi≈øe√©, and therefore where a Sum in gro≈øs is devi≈øed to be paid which is done accordingly, in ≈øuch Ca≈øe if the Devi≈øe√© ≈øhould die ≈øoon after, the Mony would be lo≈øt, if he ≈øhould have only an E≈øtate for Life; but in the Ca≈øe at Bar the Te≈øtator by a nice calculation had appointed when the fir≈øt payment ≈øhould be made, viz.
not until a Month after his decea≈øe, which hath prevented that damage which otherwi≈øe might have happened to the Devi≈øee, if no ≈øuch provi≈øion had b√©en made, Vide Hob. 65. Green's Ca≈øe.
Ex parte Def.But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that Robert had a F√©e, for though here is a Sum to be paid annually 'tis a Sum in gro≈øs, and Collier's Ca≈øe was al≈øo relied upon on this ≈øide.

It was agreed, where payment is to be made by which the Devi≈øee can ≈øu≈øtain no lo≈øs, the Word Paying there will not make a F√©e, but if there be any po≈ø≈øibility of a lo≈øs there it will create a Fee, which is the expre≈øs re≈øolution in Collier's Ca≈øe.

Here the five pounds is payable quarterly, and the fir≈øt payment is to be made the next Quarter after the death of the Te≈øtator, ≈øo as it be a Month after his decea≈øe; if then he ≈øhould die a Month before Chri≈øtmas, the Devi≈øe√© is to pay the whole quarterly payment at Chri≈øtmas: So that if he ≈øhould dye the next day after, in≈øtead of having any benefit, he would lo≈øe by this Devi≈øe in ca≈øe it ≈øhould be con≈øtrued that he had an E≈øtate only for Life.

The Court were of Opinion that a Legacy or Devi≈øe is always intended for the benefit of the party; ≈øo that 'tis rea≈øonable to make ≈øuch con≈øtruction of the Will, that he may have no po≈ø≈øibility of a lo≈øs. And it hath been re≈øolved where a Devi≈øe was to A. upon Condition to pay a Sum of Mony to B. and in ca≈øe of failure that B. may enter, 'tis no Condition but an Executory Devi≈øe, and that10 Co. 36. Mary Portington's Ca≈øe was denyed to be Law in the Re≈øolution of Fry and Porter's Ca≈øe in the King's Bench.

Judgment.And afterwards in this Term Iudgment was given for the Defendant. For if there be a Devi≈øe to one upon Condition to pay a Sum of Mony, if there be a po≈ø≈øibility of a lo≈øs, though not very probable that the Devi≈øee may be damnified, it ≈øhall be con≈øtrued a Fee, and ≈øuch Con≈øtruction hath been always allowed in Wills. If A. devi≈øe 100 l. per annum to B. paying 20 s. 'tis not likely that the Devi≈øee ≈øhould be dampnified, but 'tis po≈ø≈øible he may; and therefore the E≈øtate in this Ca≈øe being limited to Robert, and charged with payments to the Si≈øters during their Lives, doth plainly prove the intent of the Te≈øtator, was that the Devi≈øee ≈øhould have an E≈øtate in Fee ≈øimple; and Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: Bridges ver≈øus Bedingfield.
div.p: DEBT was brought upon a Bond of Award,Arbitrament Where the thing awarded is hindred to be done by the Act of a Stranger. and the breach a≈ø≈øigned was for not delivering of quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to the Plaintiff of Seats in a Church.

The Defendant craves Oyer of the Bond and Condition which was for performance of an Award to be made de praemi≈ø≈øis vel aliqu√¢ parte inde; and if there ≈øhould be no Award made, then for the performance of an Umpirage, and pleads that the Arbitrators made no Award de praemi≈ø≈øis, but the Vmpire awarded that the Plaintiff ≈øhould abinde upon all occa≈øions hold two Seats quietly and peaceably in ≈øuch a Church without any di≈øturbance made by the Defendant; and that on the fir≈øt day of November following the Defendant ≈øhould deliver up the Seats to the Plaintiff, and that each ≈øhould bear his own charge; and by his Plea he farther ≈øets forth that the Plaintiff enjoyed the Seats prout till the 30th day of October next following, on which day the Seats were pulled down without his knowledge or con≈øent, per quod he could not deliver them to the Plaintiff on the ≈øaid fir≈øt day of November.

The Plaintiff demurred,Ex parte Quer. and Serjeant Jones maintained the Demurrer, and ≈øaid, that the Pleading of nullum fecerunt Arbitrium is not good; for 'tis ≈øaid de praemi≈ø≈øis only, whereas it ≈øhould have been nec de aliqua parte inde; for if a Bond be to perform an Award of two per≈øons or either of them, it will not be ≈øufficient to plead that tho≈øe two per≈øons made no Award, without adding nec eorum aliquis.
But if an Award be to be made of the Mannors of Dale and Sale or either of them, and the Award is made only of Dale, 'tis well enough.
2. Except. Viz. The Vmpirage is that the Plaintiff ≈øhould hold the Seats abinde, which is for ever; and the Defendant pleads that the Plaintiff enjoyed them till the thirtieth day of October.

3. Except. Viz. The Seats were to be delivered to the Plaintiff on the fir≈øt day of November, and the Defendant pleads that they were pulled down before that day without his privity, which is not a good Plea by way of excu≈øe; for being bound to deliver the Seats, he is to prevent what may hinder the performance of the Condition.

'Tis agreed, that if a thing be po≈ø≈øible, and afterwards by the Act ofJones 179. Win's Ca≈øe. God becomes impo≈ø≈øible to be done, that will be a good excu≈øe; as if I promi≈øe to deliver a Hor≈øe at ≈øuch a day, and he dies before the day, I am excu≈øed, 21 E. 4. 70. b.

So if a Scire FacÃÑ be brought again≈øt the Bail, and they plead that before the Writ brought the Principal was dead, this was held not good upon Demurrer, unle≈øs he is alledged to be dead before the Capias awarded again≈øt him, Cro. Jac. 97.

But if the Action of a Stranger interpo≈øe, which makes the thing impo≈ø≈øible, that is no excu≈øe, 22 E. 4. 27. And therefore 'tis no Plea for the Bail to ≈øay, that the Principal was arre≈øted at another Mans Suit and had to Pri≈øon, for which rea≈øon he could not render him, Cro. Eliz. 815.

So if I deliver Goods to the Defendant, and in Action of Detinue brought, he pleads they were ≈øtole, 'tis no good Plea, becau≈øe the delivery charges him at his peril, unle≈øs he undertake to keep them as his own, 4 Co. Cro. El. 815. Southcot's Ca≈øe. So if an E≈øcape be brought again≈øt a Goaler, he is not excu≈øed by alledging that Traitors broke the Pri≈øon, Roll. Abr. 1. part 808. Et ≈øic de ≈øimilibus.

Ex parte Def. Seys Serjeant contra. As to the fir≈øt Exception nullum fecerunt Arbitrium de praemi≈ø≈øis is well enough; for that implies nec de aliqua inde parte, e≈øpecially if the contrary is not ≈øhewn in the Replication, and therefore it ≈øhall never be intended that an Award was made of ≈øome part.
2. 'Tis ≈øaid, he enjoyed the Seats till the thirtieth of October, and then they were taken down, ≈øo not being in rerum natura they could not be enjoyed longer.
3. And this is a good excu≈øe for not delivering them to the Plaintiff on the fir≈øt day of November, and ≈øo a good performance of the Award, Co. Lit. 206. b.

If A. be bound to B. that C. ≈øhall marry Jane ≈øuch a day, and B. the Obligee doth marry her him≈øelf before that day, the Obligor is excu≈øed; becau≈øe by his means the Condition could not be performed.

There is a difference taken where a Man is bound to deliver things which are in his Cu≈øtody, and other things which are not in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; as in the fir≈øt Ca≈øe, to deliver my Hor≈øe or Dog, for ≈øuch I may ≈øecure in my Stable from ca≈øualties: But in this Ca≈øe it is expre≈øly ≈øaid in the Award, that the Property of the Seats was in the Plaintiff, and that they were fixed in the Church, ≈øo that he could not po≈ø≈øibly ≈øecure them in his own Hou≈øe without ≈øubjecting him≈øelf to an
Action; and an Award that one Man ≈øhall take the Goods of another, is void.
But if the Plea is not good, yet if the Vmpirage be naught, Iudgment is to be given for the Defendant, for the advantage is ≈øaved to him upon the Demurrer.
And as to that, the Vmpirage is but of one ≈øide, for the Plaintiff is to do nothing, nor is the Defendant to be acquitted of all Suits.

To which it was an≈øwered by the Plaintiff's Council, That the Vmpirage was of both ≈øides; for there being Suits depending, 'tis awarded, that each ≈øhall bear his own Charges, which is a benefit to the Defendant, for otherwi≈øe (≈øeing the right was in the Plaintiff) the Defendant ≈øhould have paid the Plaintiffs Co≈øts as well as his own, for which he cannot now ≈øue without forfeiting his Bond: Curia advi≈øare vult.

div.head: Squibb ver≈øus Hole.
div.p: THE Plaintiff brought an Action of E≈øcape, E≈øcape. Action of E≈øcape; the Proce≈øs was upon Bond, not made within the Juri≈ødiction of an Inferiour Court, and therefore no E≈øcape. and declares That he pro≈øecuted one J. S. in the court of Ely, upon a Bond made infra Juri≈ødictionem of that Court, upon which he was taken, and the Defendant ≈øuffered him to E≈øcape.

Vpon Not Guilty pleaded, the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict to this effect, viz. That there was ≈øuch a Bond, upon which there was ≈øuch a pro≈øecution, and ≈øuch an E≈øcape as in the Declaration, but they find farther, that this Bond was not made infra Juri≈ødictionem Curiae.

Maynard Serjeant, who Argued for the Plaintiff, ≈øaid that this Action was commenced in an Inferiour Court, upon a Bond which the Plaintiff ≈øets forth to be infra Juri≈ødictionem Curiae; and that the Defendant was Arre≈øted and ≈øuffered to E≈øcape; and whether (if in truth the Bond was not made infra Juri≈ødictionem) an Action of E≈øcape would lye, or whether all the proce√©dings are coram non Judice, was the doubt.

He took a difference, where an Inferiour Court hath an Original Iuri≈ødiction of the Cau≈øe, and hath conu≈øance of ≈øuch a Suit as is brought there; for in ≈øuch Ca≈øes the proceedings are not extra-judicial; but if an Action is brought where properly no Action doth lye, all the proceedings there are coram non Judice.

At the Common Law, one who had a particular Iuri≈ødiction to hold Pleas within a Liberty, could not hold any Plea of a thing which did ari≈øe out of the Liberty, for though it was tran≈øitory in its nature, yet being alledged not within his Iuri≈ødiction, it was ill, 2 In≈øt. 231.

But when the cau≈øe of Action ari≈øes infra Juri≈ødictionem, that gives them Authority to proceed; and therefore it would be hard that the Iudge and Officer ≈øhould be puni≈øhed by a con≈øtruction to make all extra judicial, when they have no po≈ø≈øible way of finding, whether in truth the Cau≈øe did ari≈øe within thePo≈øt. Crowder and Goodwin. Iuri≈ødiction of the Court or not: But the Officer is bound to obey the Proce≈øs of the Court, if it appear (as in this Ca≈øe,) that they had conu≈øance of it; the Iudge is likewi≈øe bound to grant the Proce≈øs, otherwi≈øe he is ≈øubject to the Plantiffs Action for his refu≈øal.

In ≈øome Ca≈øes, the Plaintiff him≈øelf may not know where the Bond was made; as if he be Executor of the Obligee, &c. Be≈øides, in this Ca≈øe 'tis ≈øet forth, That in the Action below, the Defendant pleaded non e≈øt factum, and ≈øo had admitted the Iuri≈ødiction, or at lea≈øt had waived it; and it would be an in≈øufferable mi≈øchief, if after all this labour and charge the Defendant might avoid all again.

North Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, That if this Cau≈øe had been tryed before him, he would have Non-≈øuited the Plaintiff, becau≈øe he had not proved the truth of what he laid down in his Declaration, viz. That the Bond was made infra Juri≈ødictionem Curiae. But as to the Matter as it ≈øtood upon the ≈øpecial Verdict, he inclined, that as to the Plaintiff (who knew where the Bond was made) all the proceedings were coram non Judice; but as to the Officer it was otherwi≈øe, for the Pleint and Proce≈øs would be a good Excu≈øe for him, in an Action of fal≈øe Impri≈øonment

Judgment.And afterwards, by the Opinion of three Iudges, viz. the Chief Ju≈øtice, Wyndham and Atkyns Iu≈øtices, Iudgment was given for the Defendant, That this was no E≈øcape, and that though the Party had admitted the Iuri≈ødiction, by his Plea of non e≈øt factum below, yet that could not give the Court any Iuri≈ødiction, which had not any originally in the Cau≈øe; and the Ca≈øe ofRoll. Abt. tit. E≈øcape 809 pl. 45. Richard≈øon ver≈øus Bernard was cited as an Authority in point, where the Plaintiff in an Action brought again≈øt an Officer, declared in Hull, upon a Bond made at Hallifax, and had Iudgment
and Execution, and the Defendant e≈øcaped: And in an Action brought for this E≈øcape, the Declaration was held ill, becau≈øe it did not alledge the Bond to be made infra Juri≈ødictionem Curiae.
Ellis Iu≈øtice, of a contrary Opinion in omnibus.

div.head: Sams ver≈øus Dangerfield.
div.p: THE Plaintiff being Collector of the Hearth-Mony,Departure. brought an Action of Debt, upon a Bond, again≈øt his Sub-Collector, conditioned to pay ≈øuch Sums as he ≈øhould receive (within 14 days after receipt) at ≈øuch a place in the City of Worce≈øter, as the Plaintiff ≈øhould appoint.
The Defendant pleads payment.
The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns a breach, in non-payment of ≈øuch a Sum received at a place by him appointed.
The Defendant rejoyns, that the Plaintiff appointed no place; and the Plaintiff demurr'd.

And after Argument for the Plaintiff, by Jones Serjeant, this was adjudged a departure, becau≈øe the Defendant ought to have pleaded fir≈øt, that he had paid all but ≈øuch a Sum, for which as yet, the Plaintiff had appointed no place of payment; and Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: Smith ver≈øus Hall.
div.p: IN an Action brought again≈øt the Defendant for fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, he ju≈øtified by virtue of a Latitat, Fal≈øe Impri≈øonment doth not lye, but an Action on the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Sheriff for refu≈øing ≈øufficient Bail. which the Plaintiff agreed in his Replication; but farther ≈øet forth, that after the Arre≈øt, and before the Return of the Writ, he tendered ≈øufficient Bail, which the Defendant refu≈øed; and I≈ø≈øue was joyned upon the tender, which was found for the Plaintiff.
Newdigate Serjeant, moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment.

1. Though it was an Offence in the Defendant, who was the Sheriff's Bayliff, to refu≈øe good Bail, when tendred, yet 'tis not an Offence within the Statute 23 H. 6. cap. 10. becau≈øe a Sheriffs Bayliff is not an Officer intended in that Statute, neither will this Offence make him a Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øer, ab initio, becau≈øe
the taking was by lawfull Proce≈øs, Cro. Car. 196. Roll. Abr. 2 part 561. pl. 9. Salmon ver≈øus Percival.

The Defendant, as Bayliff to the Sheriff, is not the proper Officer to take Bail, but the Sheriff him≈øelf mu≈øt do it, and therefore an Action on the Ca≈øe mu≈øt lye again≈øt the Bayliff, for not carrying the Party before the Sheriff, in order to put in Bail; but an Action of fal≈øe Impri≈øonment will not lye.

2. The action is laid, quare vi & armis, &c. in ip≈øum (the Plaintiff) in≈øultum fecit & ip≈øum impri≈øonavit & ut Pri≈øonat √† tali loco ad talem locum adducebat & detinuit contra con≈øuetudinem Angliae & ≈øine cau≈øe rationabili per ≈øpacium trium dierum.

The Defendant pleaded quoad venire vi & armis necnon totam tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionem, praeter the taking and deteining him three days, non Culp. and as to that, he pleaded the Latitat, Warrant and Arre≈øt, ut ≈øupra; but the Verdict being only again≈øt the Defendant, upon the ≈øecond I≈ø≈øue, and nothing appearing to be done upon this, and entire Damages given; 'tis for that rea≈øon ill.

North Chief Iu≈øtice, If the Writ and Warrant were good, then the refu≈øing Bail is an Offence within the Statute, of 23 H. 6. And as 'tis an Oppre≈ø≈øion, ≈øo 'tis an Offence al≈øo at the Common Law; but an Action on the Ca≈øe, and not of fal≈øe Impri≈øonment lyeth again≈øt the Officer; for it would be very unrea≈øonable, by the refu≈øal of Bail to make the Arre≈øt tortious ab initio

A ≈øpecial Action on the Ca≈øe, had therefore been the proper remedy again≈øt the Sheriff, but not again≈øt the Officer; for an E≈øcape will not lye again≈øt him, but it mu≈øt be brought again≈øt the Sheriff.

div.head: Kren ver≈øus Kirby.
