div.p: Surrender by a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, not good.IN Ejectment, the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff claimed under a Surrender made to him by William Kirby, who had an E≈øtate in the Land, after the decrea≈øe of his Father, but entred during his Life, and thereby became a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor; and his E≈øtate being now turned into a Right, he made the Surrender to the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff; all which was found by ≈øpecial Verdict at the Tryal; and it was adjudged that the Surrender was void.

It was pretended at the Trial, that the Father, who was Tenant for Life, had ≈øuffered a Common Recovery in the Lords Court, and ≈øo his E≈øtate was forfeited, for which the Son might enter, and then his Surrender is good.

But the Court an≈øwered, that without a particular Cu≈øtom for the purpo≈øe, the ≈øuffering a Recovery would work no Forfeiture of the E≈øtate; but if it did, 'tis the Lord and none el≈øe who can enter: And ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Duck ver≈øus Vincent.
div.p: DEBT upon Bond conditioned to perform Covenants,Plea to debt upon bond not good. one of which was for payment of ≈øo much Mony upon making ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurances.

The Defendant pleaded he paid the Mony ≈øuch a day, but doth not mention when the A≈ø≈øurance was made, that it might appear to the Court the Mony was immediately paid pur≈øuant to the Condition; and for that rea≈øon the Court were all of Opinion that the Plea was not good: And Iudgement was given for the Plaintiff upon Demurrer.

div.head: Smith ver≈øus Shelberry.
div.p: IN A≈ø≈øump≈øit the Plaintiff declared that he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a Term of 80 years,A≈ø≈øump≈øit upon a mutual promi≈øe. and it was agreed between him and the Defendant, that he ≈øhould a≈ø≈øign all his intere≈øt therein to the Defendant, who proinde ≈øhould pay 250 l. and that he promi≈øed, that in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff at his reque≈øt had likewi≈øe promi≈øed to perform all on his part, that he would al≈øo perform all on his part; and then ≈øets forth that the Defendant had paid a Guinea in part of the ≈øaid 250 l. and that he, viz. the Plaintiff obtulit ≈øe to a≈ø≈øign the Premi≈ø≈øes by Indenture to the Defendant, which was written and ≈øealed and woud have delivered it to him, but he refu≈øed, and a≈ø≈øigns the breach in Non-payment of the Mony, to which the Defendant demurred.

And it was ≈øaid for him by Baldwin Serjeant,Ex parte Def. that this was not a good Declaration, becau≈øe the A≈ø≈øignment ought to precede the Payment, and that it was not a mutual promi≈øe, neither was the obtulit ≈øe well ≈øet forth; but this was a Condition precedent on the Plaintiffs ≈øide without the performance whereof
no Action would lie again≈øt the Defendant, Vide 7 Co. Ughtreds Ca≈øe, fol. 10. b. becau≈øe it was apparent by the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing, that the Mony was not to be paid till the A≈ø≈øignment made; for the Plaintiff is to a≈ø≈øign, and the Defendant proinde, which is as much as to ≈øay, pro a≈ø≈øignatione, is to pay the Mony: Like the Ca≈øe in Dyer 76. a. A≈ø≈øump≈øit again≈øt the Defendant that he promi≈øed pro 20 Marks to deliver 400 Weight of Wax to the Plaintiff, the Pronoun Pro makes the Contract conditional.

Ex parte Quer.But Pemberton Serjeant for the Plaintiff held the Declaration good, and that it was a mutual promi≈øe, and that the Plaintiff need not averr the performance;Hill & Thorn Po≈øtea. for in ≈øuch Ca≈øes each has remedy again≈øt the other; and 'tis as rea≈øonable that the Plaintiff ≈øhould have his Mony before he make the A≈ø≈øignment, as that the Defendant ≈øhould have the Term a≈ø≈øigned before he paid the Mony: And of that Opinion was the Court, only Iu≈øtice Atkins doubted.

Ellis Iu≈øtice cited a Ca≈øe adjudged in the King's Bench which was, as he thought,Stiles Rep. 186 Po≈øtea. very hard, viz. An A≈ø≈øignment was made between A. and B. that A. ≈øhould rai≈øe Souldiers, and that B. ≈øhould tran≈øport them beyond Sea, and reciprocal promi≈øes were made for the performance (as in this Ca≈øe) that A. who never rai≈øed any Souldiers may yet bring his Action upon this promi≈øe again≈øt B. for not tran≈øporting them, which is a far ≈øtronger Ca≈øe than this at Barr.

It was agr√©ed here that the Tender and Refu≈øal (had it be√©n well pleaded) would have amounted to, and have been equivalent with a full performance, but the Plaintiff hath not done as much as he might, for he ≈øhould have delivered the Indenture to the Defendants u≈øe, and then have tendered it. But Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Hays ver≈øus Bicker≈øtaffe.
div.p: Covenant not conditional by the words paying and performing. IN Covenant brought by the Le≈ø≈øee, who declared that the Le≈ø≈øor covenanted with him, that he paying the Rent and performing the Covenants on his part to be performed ≈øhall quietly enjoy.

The breach a≈ø≈øigned was a di≈øturbance by the Le≈ø≈øor, who pleads, that till ≈øuch a time the Plaintiff did quietly enjoy the thing demi≈øed without di≈øturbance; but then he cut down Wood,
which was contrary to his Covenant, and then and not before he entred; and ≈øo by the Plaintiffs not performing his Covenant the Defendants Covenant cea≈øes to oblige him; whereunto the Plaintiff demurred.

The Que≈øtion was, Whether the Defendants Covenant was conditional or not? For if it amount to a Condition, then his Entry is lawful; but if it be a Covenant, 'tis otherwi≈øe, for then he ought to bring his Action.

Pemberton Serjeant for the Plaintiff.Ex parte Quer. That this Covenant is not conditional, for the words paying and performing ≈øignifie no more than that he ≈øhall enjoy, &c. under the Rents and Covenants, and 'tis a Clau≈øe u≈øually in≈øerted in the Covenant for quiet Enjoyment: Indeed the word paying in ≈øome Ca≈øes may amount to a Condition; but that is where without ≈øuch con≈øtruction the party could have no remedy.
But here are expre≈øs Covenants in the Lea≈øe, and a direct re≈øervation of the Rent, to which the party concerned may have recour≈øe when he hath occa≈øion.
A liberty to take Pot-water paying ≈øo many Turns, &c. 'tis a Condition.

The Words paying and yielding make no Condition,Cook and Herle, Po≈øtea. Vaugh. 32. nor was it ever known that for ≈øuch Words the Le≈ø≈øor entred for Non-payment of Rent; and there is no difference between the≈øe Words and the Words paying and performing, Bennet's Ca≈øe in B. R. ruled no Condition, Duncomb's Ca≈øe, Owen Rep. 54.

Barrel Serjeant for the Defendant ≈øaid,Ex parte Def. that the Covenant is to be taken as the parties have agre√©d; and the Le≈ø≈øor is not to be ≈øued if the Le≈ø≈ø√©e fir≈øt commit the breach: Modus & Conventio qualifie the general Words concerning quiet Enjoyment.
The Court took time to con≈øider, and afterwards in this Term Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff,Sid. 266, 280. that the Covenant was not conditional.
Atkins Iu≈øtice doubted.

div.head: Simp≈øon ver≈øus Ellis.
div.p: Debt by a Bailiff of a Liberty. DEBT upon Bond by the Plaintiff, who was chief Bailiff of the Liberty of Pontefract in York≈øhire, but he did not declare as Capital Ballivus, but yet by the whole Court it was held good; for otherwi≈øe the Defendant might have craved Oyer, and have it entred in haec verba, and then have pleaded the Statute of 23 H. 6. that it was takenSand. 161. Sid. 383. Latch. 143. colore Officii, but now it ≈øhall be intended good upon the Demurrer to the Declaration.
And Ellis Iu≈øtice ≈øaid that ≈øo it was lately re≈øolved in this Court in the Ca≈øe of one Conque≈øt. And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Ma≈øon ver≈øus Stratton, Executor, &c.
div.p: Judgment kept on foot per Fraudem. 2 Cro. 35, 102. Vaugh. 103, 104. DEBT upon Bond. The Defendant pleads two Iudgments had again≈øt his Te≈øtator, and ≈øets them forth, and that he had but 40 s A≈ø≈øets towards ≈øatisfaction.
The Plaintiff replies, that the Defendant paid but ≈øo much upon the fir≈øt Iudgment, and ≈øo much upon the ≈øecond, and yet kept them both on foot per Fraudem & Covinam.
And the Defendant demurred ≈øpecially.

1 Roll. Abr. 802. 2 Cro. 626Becau≈øe the Replication is ≈øo complicated that no di≈øtinct I≈ø≈øue can be taken upon it; for the Plea ≈øets forth the Iudgments ≈øeverally, but the Plaintiff puts them both together, when he alledges them to be kept per Fraudem.

But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that all the Pre≈øidents are as in this Ca≈øe,Sid. 333. 8 Co. Turner's Ca≈øe 132. 9 Co. Meriel Tre≈øham's Ca≈øe 108 And of that Opinion was all the Court, that the Replication was good: And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Suffeild ver≈øus Baskervil.
div.p:
No Breach can be a≈ø≈øigned upon a Promi≈øe.DEBT upon Bond for performance of all Covenants, Payments, &c. In an Indenture of Lea≈øe wherein the Defendant for and in con≈øideration of 400 l. lent him by the Plaintiff, granted the Land to him for 99 years, if G. ≈øo long lived, provided if he pay 60 l. per annum quarterly during the
Life of G. or ≈øhall within two years after his death pay the ≈øaid 400 l. to the Plaintiff, then the Indenture to be void, with a Clau≈øe of Reentry for Non-payment.
The Defendant pleads performance.
The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigns for breach, that 30 l. for half a year was not paid at ≈øuch a time during the Life of G.
The Defendant demurrs.
For that the breach was not well a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe there is no Covenant to pay the Mony, only by a Clau≈øe Liberty is given to re-enter upon Non payment.
The Court inclined, that this Action would not lie upon this Bond, in which there was a Provi≈øo and no expre≈øs Covenant, and therefore no Breach can be a≈ø≈øigned.

div.head: Ben≈øon ver≈øus Idle.
div.p: AUdita Querela, The Ca≈øe upon Demurrer was,E≈øtoppel not well pleaded with a Traver≈øe. That before the Kings Re≈øtauration the now Defendant brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt the Plaintiff for taking his Cloath, who then pleaded, that he was a Souldier and compelled by his Fellow Souldiers, who threatned to hang him as high as the Bells in the Belfry if he refu≈øed; To this the Plaintiff then replied de injuri√¢ ≈øu√¢ propri√¢, &c. And it was found for him, and an Elegit was brought, and the now Plaintiffs Lands extended.

Then comes the Act of12 Car. 2. cap. 11. Indempnity which pardons all Acts of Ho≈øtility done in the Times of Rebellion, and from thenceforth di≈øcharges per≈øonal Actions for or by rea≈øon of any Tre≈øpas comitted in the Wars, and all Iudgments and Executions thereon before the fir≈øt day of May, 1658. but doth not re≈øtore the party to any Sums of Mony, mean Profits or Goods taken away by virtue of ≈øuch Execution, or direct the party to give any account for the ≈øame; which Act made by the Convention was confirmed by 13 Car. 2. cap. 7.
And upon the≈øe two Acts of Parliament the Plaintiff (expre≈øly averring in his Writ that the former Recovery again≈øt him was for an Act of Ho≈øtility) now brought this Audita Querela.

The Defendant pleads the former Verdict by way of E≈øtoppel, and concludes with a Traver≈øe ab≈ø
que hoc that the taking of his Goods was an Act of Ho≈øtility.

This was argued by Holloway Serejant for the Plaintiff, and by Jones Serjeant for the Defendant, who chiefly in≈øi≈øted, That the Defendant having pleaded the ≈øub≈øtance of this Matter before, and being found again≈øt him, that he being now Plaintiff could not averr any thing again≈øt that Record.

But the Court were all of Opinion, that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff; for his remedy was very proper upon the Convention, and without the Statute of Confirmation; and here is no E≈øtoppel in the Ca≈øe; for whether this was an act of Ho≈øtility or not, is not material; neither was it or could it be an I≈ø≈øue upon the former Tryal, becau≈øe all the Matter then in Que≈øtion was concerning the Tre≈øpa≈øs, which, though found again≈øt the now Plaintiff, yet it might be an act of Ho≈øtility; but if it were an E≈øtoppel, 'tis not well pleaded with a Traver≈øe, and the Court hath ≈øet it at large.

div.head: DE Term. Sanctae Trin. Anno 27 Caroli II. in Communi Banco.
Mayor and Cominalty of London, ver≈øus Gatford.
div.p: IN an Action of Debt brought by the Plaintiffs,Con≈øtruction of an Act of Parliament. for a Fine of 13 l. 6 s. 8 d. ≈øet upon the Defendant, by the Steward of the Burrough of Southwark, for that he refu≈øed to take the Oath and ≈øerve as a Scavenger in the ≈øaid Burrough, though duly Elected according to Cu≈øtom there; and upon nil debt pleaded, the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict, the ≈øub≈øtance of which was,

Viz. They find the Act of 14 Car. 2. cap. 2. And the Provi≈øo therein, which governed this Ca≈øe, viz. That all Streets and Lanes in London, We≈øtmin≈øter, and the Liberties thereof ≈øhall be Paved as they have alwayes u≈øed to be,

Then follows another Clau≈øe, by which it is Enacted, That Scavengers ≈øhall be Cho≈øen in the City of London, and the Liberties thereof, according to the Ancient U≈øage and Cu≈øtom; ≈øo likewi≈øe in the City of We≈øtmin≈øter; but nothing is therein mentioned of Southwark. And in all other places a new form of choo≈øing is pre≈øcribed.

Viz. In the other Pari≈øhes the Con≈øtables, Church-Wardens, &c. ≈øhall meet in the Ea≈øter-Week, and choo≈øe two Scavengers in every re≈øpective Pari≈øh: ≈øo that the intent of the Act mu≈øt be (though Southwark is not named) that ≈øtill Scavengers ≈øhall be cho≈øen there, as formerly; becau≈øe London and the Liberties thereof are to follow their Ancient Cu≈øtom in the choice of this Officer: and Southwark is within the City Liberties
But whether the Cu≈øtom of choo≈øing of him was not taken away by this Statute, and ≈øo the Fine not well A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, was the Que≈øtion.

Ex partte Quer. Baldwyn for the Plaintiffs argued, That admitting in Southwark a Scavenger may be cho≈øen, according to the new form pre≈øcribed in the Act; yet this Statute was only in theHob. 173. Dyer 341. b. Affirmative, and did not thereby take away the cu≈øtom of choo≈øing him at the Leet.

Like the Ca≈øe in Dyer 50. An Act that the Younge≈øt Son ≈øhall have an Appeal of the death of his Father;Hob. 17. yet that doth not exclude the Elde≈øt, becau≈øe 'tis the Common Law, and there are no words to re≈øtrain him.

In the 11 Co. 63. Doctor Fo≈øter's Ca≈øe: By the Statute of 35 Eliz. again≈øt Recu≈øants, which gives the Penalty of 20 l. Íùì Month again≈øt the Offender; the 12 d. for the neglect of every Sunday, given by a former1 Eliz. Statute is not taken away.

But where there is a Negative Clau≈øe in an Act of Parliament, the Law is otherwi≈øe: as an Act that the Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace ≈øhall be kept at Beaumarris tantum, & non alibi infra ComÃÑ, &c. and the Iu≈øtices kept it at another place, and ≈øeveral were Indicted before them at that time; but the Iu≈øtices were fined, and all their proceedings held Coram non Judice, by rea≈øon of the Negative Prohibition, Dyer 135.

1 In≈øt. Sect. 500. 2 In≈øt. 68.By the Statute of Magna Charta, cap. 34. a Woman ≈øhall bring no Appeal but for the death of her Husband, which ≈øhe might at Common Law, before the making of this Statute; if therefore ≈øhe is Heir to her Father, the Appeal which ≈øhe might have brought for his death, by the≈øe Negative words is taken away.

Ex parte Def. Barrell for the Defendant; though this Law be in the Affirmative; yet ≈øince it doth not prejudice any per≈øon, neither can it be injurious if Scavengers are cho≈øen as directed by the Act, it ≈øhall be taken as a Negative Clau≈øe; and for this many In≈øtances may be given; as, the Statute for devi≈øing part of the Te≈øtators Land, doth not take away the cu≈øtom to devi≈øe the whole, for that would be an apparent prejudice to the Parties; but not ≈øo in this Ca≈øe, where 'tis not found that the Lord of the Mannor ≈øu≈øtains any lo≈øs, for he is to have nothing when a Scavenger is cho≈øen in the Leet; nor are the Inhabitants prejudiced, for by this New choo≈øing their Streets ≈øhall be kept as clean as before.
The Form here e≈øtabli≈øhed doth not con≈øi≈øt with the Cu≈øtom, and ≈øo hath the Effect of a Negative Clau≈øe, Hob. 298.

It appears by the Scope of the Act, That the intent of the Parliament was to take away tho≈øe old Cu≈øtoms of choo≈øing,
becau≈øe the Cu≈øtoms are expre≈ø≈øly ≈øaved in London and We≈øtmin≈øter; but in all other places a new way is appointed.

The pavement of the Streets in Southwark ≈øhall be as before; but that Clau≈øe goes no farther, and therefore concerns not the Ca≈øe of a Scavenger, who≈øe duty is not to pave, but clean≈øe the Streets.

And the words, viz. Liberties of the City of London, will not help, becau≈øe Southwark is not comprehended under them, in that Clau≈øe, no more than are the Lands which they have in York≈øhire; for the word Liberties Po≈øtea 48. there, is taken for Limits, and can admit of no other Con≈øtruction.

La≈øtly, that the Plaintiff cannot have Iudgment, becau≈øe he hath no alledged the Cu≈øtom to be, That the Steward may Fine, in ca≈øe of the refu≈øal to take the Oath, &c. and Cu≈øtoms are to be taken ≈øtictly.
The Chief Iu≈øtice and Iu≈øtice Atkins ≈øaid, That 'tis true, Scavengers are under the power of the Court Leet, by Cu≈øtom, and in ca≈øe of refu≈øal may be fined, as well as an Ale-Ta≈øter.

But this Act of Parliament having taken notice, that there were Scavengers before that time, and Southwark being therein named as di≈øtinct from the Liberties of London; for 'tis provided, That We≈øtmin≈øter, London, and the Liberties thereof, and Southwark are to have the Streets paved, as before, which doth not belong to the Office of a Scavenger; and ≈øo that Clau≈øe in the Act concerns not this Ca≈øe.

But where it Enacts, That in London and We≈øtmin≈øter, Scavengers ≈øhall be cho≈øen as before; but in all other places appoints a new way; this is as much as if it had ≈øaid, That Scavengers ≈øhall be cho≈øen in every place as by the Act pre≈øcribed, and no other way, except in London and We≈øtmin≈øter; and ≈øo great is the incon≈øi≈øtency between the Cu≈øtom and the Act, that they cannot ≈øtand both together; therefore, though the Act is but temporary, the Cu≈øtom is ≈øu≈øpended, and though it may be ≈øome damage to the Lord to make ≈øuch Con≈øtruction, yet that will not alter the Ca≈øe; for Law-Makers are pre≈øumed to have re≈øpect to the publick Good more than to any private Mans profit; and the Lord may be ≈øaid in this ca≈øe to have di≈øpen≈øed with his Intere≈øt, being a Party to the Act, and con≈øenting thereunto.

But Wyndham and Ellis Iu≈øtices, inclined, That the Cu≈øtom did continue, becau≈øe the Act was in the Affirmative; and therefore
they would not con≈øtrue it to take away a Mans Right and Intere≈øt, or a Cu≈øtom where he hath a benefit, as the Lord of the Mannor had in this Ca≈øe, who is prejudiced by the lo≈øs of his Fees; and the intent of the Statute ≈øeemed to them to be, That Scavengers ≈øhould be cho≈øen where none were before, but not to take away Cu≈øtoms for chu≈øing of them: But another Argument was de≈øired by Serjeant Howel, the Recorder of London.

div.head: Rozal ver≈øus Lampen.
div.p: Variance in the Actions no Barr.COn≈øpiracy. Rozal declares, That a Replevin was brought again≈øt him and others, and that the Defendant Lampen appeared for him without any Warrant, and avowed in his Name, and ≈øuffered Iudgment to pa≈øs again≈øt him, and that 22 l. 10 s. Damages were recovered again≈øt him, at ≈øuch a place.

Lampen pleads a Recovery in a former Action brought by the now Plaintiff, the Record of which being recited in the Plea, appears to be the ≈øame with this; but only here the place is mentioned where the Damages were recovered, which was omitted in the former Action, to which Lampen had pleaded a Reteiner, by one of the then Defendants in Replevin, and upon a Demurrer had Iudgment. But the truth of the Ca≈øe was, That Iudgment was not then given for him that his Plea was good; for the Court were all of Opinion, that it was naught; but becau≈øe the Declaration was not good, for want of mentioning the place where, the Damages were recovered, which the Plaintiff had amended now.
The Plaintiff demurred again; becau≈øe of this Variance between the two Actions upon the Defendants own ≈øhewing.
So in this Ca≈øe, The Plaintiff had not declared right in his fir≈øt Action, which he had amended now, and therefore the former Iudgment ≈øhall be no barr to him.

In Robin≈øon's Ca≈øe, there was a Mi≈øtake in the Writ, viz. A Formedon in Remainder, for that in Reverter; and held no barr; ≈øo by a parity of rea≈øon there ≈øhall be no barr here, becau≈øe the fir≈øt Declaration was mi≈øtaken,Stat. 3 H. 7. c. 1. Syd. 316. and it was vitium Clerici; Vide 2 Cro. 284. Level ver≈øus Hall.

Barton Serjeant contra; This is no new Action;Ex parte Def. for the ground of it is, not where the Damages was done, or recovered, but the appearing without a Warrant; and ≈øo having pleaded a Reteiner and had Iudgment, and now pleading that Iudgment to this Action, and averring 'twas for one and the ≈øame thing, 'tis a good barr, which the Plaintiff by his Demurrer hath confe≈ø≈øed. Adjornatur.

div.head: Milward ver≈øus Ingram.
div.p: INdebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit for 50 l. and quantum meruit, One promi≈øe pleaded in di≈øcharge of another, good before the breach. Mod. Rep. 205. the Defendant confe≈ø≈øes both; but pleads, That after the promi≈øe made, and before the Action brought, they came to an Accompt concerning divers Sums of Money, and that he was found in arrear to the Plaintiff 30 s. whereupon, in con≈øideration the Defendant promi≈øed to pay him the ≈øaid 30 s. the Plaintiff likewi≈øe promi≈øed to relea≈øe and acquit the Defendant of all Demands.
The Plaintiff demurred.

Seys Serjeant argued for the Plaintiff;Ex parte Quer. that though one promi≈øe may be di≈øcharged by another, yet a duty certain cannot, (as in this Ca≈øe) where a demand was of a Sum certain, by the Indebitatus; be≈øides, this Plea is in nature of an Accord, which cannot be good without an averment of ≈øatisfaction given, Broke Accompt 46, 48.
Neither is it ≈øaid, that the Plaintiff promi≈øed in con≈øideration that the Defendant ad in≈øtantiam of the Plaintiff had promi≈øed.

Ex parte Def.But it was an≈øwered by Serjeant Hopkins, and admitted to be true, That where a Matter is pleaded by way of accord, it mu≈øt be averred to be executed in all Points but that was not the pre≈øent Ca≈øe.
‚Ä¢ Cro. 100.
The Defendant hath pleaded, that he and the Plaintiff had accounted together, and ≈øo the Contract is gone by the Accompt.
2. That he was di≈øcharged of the Contract by parol, both which the Plaintiff had now admitted by his Demurrer.

And it will not be denied that a Parol di≈øcharge of an A≈ø≈øump≈øit is good; as if A. promi≈øes to perform ≈øuch a Voiage within a time limited, and the breach a≈ø≈øigned was that he did not go the Voiage: The Defendant pleads, that the Plaintiff exoneravit eum, and upon Demurrer it was held good, 22 Ed. 4. 40. 3 H. 6. 37.
Object. If it be objected, that 'tis no Con≈øideration to pay a ju≈øt Debt; for if 30 s. were due, of right it ought to be paid, and that can be no rea≈øon upon which to ground a Promi≈øe.
An≈øw. 'Tis a good Con≈øideration to pay Mony on the day which the party is bound to upon Bond, becau≈øe it is paid without Suit or Trouble, which might be otherwi≈øe a lo≈øs to the Plaintiff.
But in this Ca≈øe here is an expre≈øs Agr√©ement, and before there was only a Contract in Law, Cro. Car. 8. Flight ver≈øus Cra≈øden.

Curia. North Chief Iu≈øtice. It has b√©en always taken that if there be an A≈ø≈øump≈øit to do a thing, and there is no breach of the promi≈øe, that it may be di≈øcharged by Parol; but if it be once broken, then it cannot be di≈øcharged without Relea≈øe in a writing.

In this Ca≈øe there are two Demands in the Declaration, to which the Defendant pleads an Accompt ≈øtated, ≈øo that the Plaintiff can never after have recour≈øe to the fir≈øt Contract which is thereby merged in the Accompt. If A. ≈øells his Hor≈øe to B. for 10 l. and there being divers other dealings between them; if they come to an accompt upon the whole, and B. is found in arrear 5 l. A. mu≈øt bring his in≈øimul computa≈ø≈øet, for he can never recover upon an Indebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit; and of the ≈øame Opinion were the other three Iu≈øtices; and though it was not ≈øaid ad in≈øtantiam of the Plaintiff that he promi≈øed, yet it was adtunc & ibidem, and ≈øo ≈øhould be intended that the Defendant made the Promi≈øe at the in≈øtance of the Plaintiff, and ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Daws ver≈øus Sir Paul Pindar.
div.p:
COvenant to pay a Sum of Mony within a year after one Nokes ≈øhall be admitted to the Office of Secretary to the Governour of Barbadoes.
Barbadoes, whether governed by the Laws of England, ≈øo that the Statute of buying Offices extends to it.

The Defendant pleads that that the Governour of Barbadoes and the Council there have power of probate of Wills, and granting of Admini≈øtration; that the Secretary belongs and is an Officer to the ≈øaid Governour and Council as Regi≈øter, and is concerned about the regi≈øtring the ≈øaid Wills, and ≈øo his Office concerns the Admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice; and then ≈øets forth that this Covenant, upon which the Plaintiff brought his Action, was entred into upon a corrupt Agr√©ement, and for that rea≈øon void.

The Plaintiff replies (prote≈øtando) that this Office concerned not the Admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice; and prote≈øtando that here was no corrupt Agr√©ement; pro placito he ≈øaith, that Barbadoes is extra quatuor Maria, and was always out of the Allegeance and power of the Kings of England till King Charles the Fir≈øt reduced that I≈øland to his Obedience, which is now governed by Laws made by him, and not by the Laws of England.

The Defendant rejoyns prote≈øtando that this I≈øland was governed by the Laws of England long before the Reign of King Charles the Fir≈øt, and confe≈ø≈øes it to be extra quatuor Maria, but pleads that before King Charles had that I≈øland, King James was ≈øei≈øed thereof, and died ≈øuch a day ≈øo ≈øei≈øed; after who≈øe death it de≈øcended to King Charles the Fir≈øt, as his Son and Heir; and that he being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, 2 Julii in the third year of his Reign granted it under the great Seal of England to the Earl of Carli≈øle and his Heirs at ≈øuch a Rent, ab≈øque hoc that King Charles the Fir≈øt acquired this I≈øland by Conque≈øt.

Baldwyn Serjeant demurred, for that the Traver≈øe is ill;Ex parte Quer. for the mo≈øt material thing in the Pleadings was, whether Barbadoes was governed by the Laws of England, or by particular Laws of their own? And if not governed by the Laws of England then the Statute made 5 E. 6. cap. 16. concerning the Sale of Offices doth not extend to this place.

He ≈øaid that it was but lately acquired, and was not governed by the Laws of England, that it was fir≈øt found out in King James his Reign, which was long after the making of that Statute, and therefore could not extend to it.

The Statute of 1 E. 6. cap. 7. Enacts, That no Writ ≈øhall abate if the Defendant (pending the Action) be created a Duke or Earl, &c. And it has b√©en doubted whether this Act extended to a Baronet, being a Dignity created after the making thereof, Sir Simon Bennets Ca≈øe, Syd. 40. Cro Car. 104.

Statutes of England extend no more to Barbadoes than to Scotland or Virginia, New England, I≈øles of Jer≈øey and Gern≈øey; 'tis true, an Appeal lies from tho≈øe I≈ølands to the King in Council here, but that is by Con≈øtitutions of their own. No Statute did extend to Ireland till Poyning's Law, nor now unle≈øs named. In Barbadoes they have Laws different from ours, as, That a Deed ≈øhall bind a Feme Covert, and many others.

Ex parte Def. Seys Serjeant contra. He agreed that the Traver≈øe was ill, and therefore did not indeavour to maintain it, but ≈øaid there was a departure betw√©en the Declaration and the Replication; for in the Declaration the Plaintiff ≈øets forth that Nokes was admitted Secretary apud In≈øulam de Barbadoes, viz. in Parochia Sancti Martini in Campis; and in the Replication he ≈øets forth, that this I≈øle was not in England, which is in the nature of a departure; as Debt ≈øur obligat' 1 Maii, the Defendant pleads a Relea≈øe 3 Maii; the Plaintiff replies primo deliberat' 4 Maii; 'tis a departure; for he ≈øhould have ≈øet forth that the Bond was 4 Maii primo deliberat', Quaere, Bro. Departure 14.

So in a Quare Impedit the Bi≈øhop pleaded that he claimed nothing but as Ordinary. The Plaintiff replies Quod tali die & anno he pre≈øented his Clerk, and the Bi≈øhop refu≈øed him; the Bi≈øhop rejoyns, that at the ≈øame day another pre≈øented his Clerk, ≈øo that the Church became litigious; and the Plaintiff ≈øurrejoyns that after that time the Church was litigious he again pre≈øented, and his Clerk was refu≈øed; this was a Departure, Bro. Departure.

So likewi≈øe as to the place, the Tenant pleads a Relea≈øe at C. The Demandant ≈øaith that he was in Pri≈øon at D. and ≈øo would avoid the Relea≈øe as given by Dure≈øs; and the Tenant ≈øaith that he gave it at L. after he was di≈øcharged and at large, 40 E. 3. Bro. 32. 1 H. 6.3.

The Plaintiff might have ≈øaid that Nokes was admitted here in England, without ≈øhewing it was at Barbadoes; for the Grant of the Office of Secretary might be made to him here under the Great Seal of England, as well as a Grant of Admini≈øtration may be made by the Ordinary out of his Dioce≈øs.

2. Except. Viz. By the Demurrer to the Rejoynder; the Plaintiff hath confe≈ø≈øed his Replication to be fal≈øe in another re≈øpect, for by that he hath owned it: The Defendant hath pleaded
that King James was ≈øei≈øed of this I≈øland, and that it de≈øcended to King Charles, &c. and ≈øo is a Province of England; whereas before he had only alledged that it was reduced in the time of King Charles, his Son, and ≈øo he hath fal≈øified his own Replication.

And be≈øides, this is within the Statute of 5 Ed. 6. for the Defendant ≈øaith, that the Plaintiff hath admitted Barbadoes to be a Province of England; and it doth not appear that ever there was a Prince there, or any other per≈øon, who had Dominion except the King and his Predece≈ø≈øors; and then the Ca≈øe will be no more than if the King of England take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of an I≈øland, where before there was vacua po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øio, by what Laws ≈øhall it be governed? certainly by the Laws of England.

This I≈øland was granted to the Earl of Carli≈øle and his Heirs under a Rent payable at the Exchequer, for which Proce≈øs might i≈ø≈øue, and it de≈øcends to the Heirs of the Earl at the Common Law. And if it be objected, that they have a Book of Con≈øtitutions in Barbadoes; that is ea≈øily an≈øwered; for 'tis no Record, neither can the Iudges take any notice of it.

'Tis rea≈øonable that ≈øo good a Law as was in≈øtituted by this Statute of Edw. 6. ≈øhould have an exten≈øive con≈øtruction, and that it ≈øhould be interpreted to extend as well to tho≈øe Plantations as to England,; for if another I≈øland ≈øhould be now di≈øcovered it mu≈øt be ≈øubject to the Laws of England. Curia advi≈øare vult.

div.head: Lever ver≈øus Ho≈øier.
div.p: THIS was a ≈øpecial Verdict in Ejectment.Recovery ≈øuffered of Lands in a Liberty, pa≈ø≈øeth Lands in a Vill di≈øtinct within that Liberty. Mod. Rep. 206. Po≈øtea. The Ca≈øe upon the Pleading was: viz. Sir Samuel Jones being Tenant in Tail of Lands in Shrew≈øbury and Cotton being within the Liberties of Shrew≈øbury, ≈øuffers a Common Recovery of all his Lands lying within the Liberties of Shrew≈øbury; and whether the Lands in Cotton, which is a di≈øtinct Vill, though within the Liberties, ≈øhall pa≈øs, was the Que≈øtion.

And it was argued by Serjeant Jones, that they ≈øhould not pa≈øs; for though Lands would pa≈øs ≈øo by a Fine, becau≈øe it was the Agreement of the Parties; yet in a Recovery 'tis otherwi≈øe, becau≈øe more certainty is required therein.
But in Fines no ≈øuch Certainty is required, and therefore a Fine de Tenementis in Golden-Lane hath be√©n held good though neither Vill, Pari≈øh or Hamlet is mentioned.

Cro Eliz. 693. Cro. Jac. 574. Addi≈øon and Ottoway, Po≈øtea.But there being a Vill called Walton in the Pari≈øh of Street, and a Fine being levyed of Land in Street, the Lands in Walton did not pa≈øs, unle≈øs Walton had b√©en an Hamlet of Street, and the Fine had be√©n levied of Lands in the Pari≈øh of Street.

And the rea≈øon of this difference is, becau≈øe in Fines there are Covenants, which, though they are real in re≈øpect of the Land, yet 'tis but a per≈øonal Action, in which the Land is not demanded ex directo; but in a Recovery greater preci≈øene≈øs is required, that being a Praecipe quod reddat where the Land it ≈øelf is demanded, and the Defendant mu≈øt make An≈øwer to it, Cro. Jac. 574 5 Co. 40. Dormer's Ca≈øe.

The WordAntea 41. Liberty properly ≈øignifies a Right, Priviledge or Franchi≈øe, but improperly the extent of a place, Hill. 22 & 23 Car. 2. Rot. 225. B. R. Waldron's Ca≈øe, Hutton 106. Baker and John≈øon's Ca≈øe.
Liberties in Iudgment of Law are incorporeal, and therefore 'tis ab≈øurd to ≈øay that Lands which are corporeal ≈øhall be therein contained.

They are not permanent having their exi≈øtence by the Kings Letters Patents, and may be de≈øtroyed by Act of Parliament; they may al≈øo be extingui≈øh'd, abridged or increa≈øed, and a Vinire fac of aRa≈øt. Ent. 267. Liberty or Franchi≈øe is not good; 'tis an equivocal Word and of no ≈øignification, that is plain, and therefore is not to be u≈øed in real Writs, Ra≈øt. Entr. 382.

There is no Praecipe in the Regi≈øter to recover Lands within a Liberty, neither is there any authority in all the Law Books for ≈øuch a Recovery; and therefore if ≈øuch a thing ≈øhould be allowed many inconveniences would follow; for a good Tenant to the Praecipe would be wanting, and the intent of the Parties could not ≈øupply that.

But Barton Serjeant ≈øaid that this Recovery would pa≈øs the Lands in Cotton; for as to that purpo≈øe, there was no difference betwe√©n a Fine and a Recovery;Po≈øtea. 2 Roll. Abr. 20 Godb. 440. they are both become Common A≈ø≈øurances, and are to be guided by the agre√©ment of the Parties, Cro. Car. 270, 276.

'Tis true, a Fine may be good of Lands in an Hamlet, Lieu conus or Pari≈øh, 1 H. 5. 9. Cro. Eliz. 692. Jones 301. Cro. Jac. 574. Monk ver≈øus Butler. Yet in aGodb. 440. contra. Scire FacÃÑ to have Execution of ≈øuch Fine the Vill mu≈øt be therein mentioned, Bro. Brief 142.
The demand mu≈øt be of Lands in a Vill, Hamlet, or at farthe≈øt in a Pari≈øh, Cro. Jac. 574.

And of that Opinion was the whole Court (ab≈øente Ellis) who was al≈øo of the ≈øame Opinion at the Argument, and accordingly in Michaelmas Term following Iudgment was given, that by this Recovery the Lands in Cotton did well pa≈øs.

And North Chief Iu≈øtice denied the Ca≈øe in Hutton 106. Po≈øtea. to be Law, where 'tis ≈øaid, A Common Recovery of Lands in a Lieu conus is not good; and ≈øaid that it had b√©en long di≈øputed whether a Fine of Lands in a Lieu conus was good; and in King James his time the Law was ≈øettled in that Point, that it was good; and by the ≈øame rea≈øon a Recovery ≈øhall be good, for they are both amicable Suits and Common A≈ø≈øurances, and as they grew more in practice the Iudges have extended them farther.

A Common Recovery is held good of an Advow≈øon; and no Rea≈øons are to be drawn from the Vi≈øne, or the Execution of the Writ of Sei≈øin, becau≈øe 'tis not in the Ca≈øe of adver≈øary Proc√©edings, but by Agr√©ement of the Parties, where 'tis to be pre≈øumed each knows the others meaning.
Indeed the Cur≈øitors are to blame to make the Writ of Entry thus, and ought not to be ≈øuffered in ≈øuch practice.

Where a Fine is levied to two, the F√©e is always fixed in the Heirs of one of them; but if it be to them and their Heirs, yet 'tis good, though incertain; but a Liberty is in the nature of a Lieu conus, and may be made certain by Averment.
The Iury in this Ca≈øe have found Cotton to be a Vill in the Liberty of Shrew≈øbury, and ≈øo 'tis not incorporeal.

div.head: Alford ver≈øus Tatnel.
div.p: JVdgment again≈øt two, who are both in Execution,Mod. Rep. 170. and the Sheriff ≈øuffers one to e≈øcape; the Plaintiff recovers again≈øt the Sheriff, and hath ≈øatisfaction, the other ≈øhall be di≈øcharged by an Audita Querela.

div.head: Osba≈øton ver≈øus Stanhope.
div.p: General Replication good.DEBT upon Bond again≈øt an Heir, who pleaded that his Ance≈øtor was ≈øei≈øed of ≈øuch Lands in Fee, and made a Settlement thereof to Tru≈øte√©s, by which he limited the V≈øes to him≈øelf for Life, Remainder to the Heirs Males of his Body, Remainder in Fe√© to his own right Heirs, with power given to the Tru≈øte√©s to make Lea≈øes for thre√© Lives or 99 years.
The Tru≈øt√©es made a Lea≈øe of the≈øe Lands for 99 years, and that he had not A≈ø≈øets praeter the Rever≈øion expectant upon the ≈øaid Lea≈øe.
The Plaintiff replies prote≈øtando that the Settlement is fraudulent, pro placito ≈øaith that he hath A≈ø≈øets by di≈øcent ≈øufficient to pay him; and the Defendant demurrs.

Ex parte Def. Newdigate Serjeant. The Barr is good, for the Plaintiff ≈øhould not have replied generally that the Defendant hath A≈ø≈øets by di≈øcent, but ≈øhould have replyed to the praeter, Hob. 104.

Like the Ca≈øe of Goddard and Thorlton Yelv. 170. where in Tre≈øpas the Defendant pleaded that Henry was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, who made a Lea≈øe to Saunders, under whom he derived a Title, and ≈øo ju≈øtifies.
The Plaintiff replies, and ≈øets forth a long Title in another per≈øon, and that Henry entred and intruded.

The Defendant rejoyns, that Henry was ≈øei≈øed in F√©e and made a Lea≈øe ut prius, ab≈ø
que hoc that intravit & ≈øe ≈øic intru≈øit; and the Plaintiff having demurred, becau≈øe the Traver≈øe ought to have been direct, viz. ab≈ø
que hoc quod intru≈øit, and not ab≈ø
que hoc that Henry intravit, &c. it was ≈øaid the Replication was ill; for the Defendant having alledged a Sei≈øin in F√©e in Henry, which the Plaintiff in his Rejoynder had not avoided, but only by ≈øuppo≈øing an intru≈øion which cannot be of an E≈øtate in F√©e, but is properly after the death of Tenant for Life; for that rea≈øon it was held ill.

Ex parte Quer.But Pemberton Serjeant for the Plaintiff held the Replication to be good. The Defendants Plea is no more than Riens per de≈øcent; for though he pleads a Rever≈øion, 'tis not chargeable, becau≈øe 'tis a Rever≈øion after an E≈øtate Tail, and therefore the pleading the Lea≈øe is not material; for if it were a Lea≈øe expired yet the Plaintiff could not recover, and therefore the praeter is wholly idle and in≈øignificant, of which the Plaintiff ought not to
take notice, becau≈øe the Lands, which come under the praeter, are not chargeable.
The Plaintiff hath traver≈øed, as he ought, what is material, and is not bound to take notice of any thing more.
And of that Opinion was the whole Court, and held the praeter idle, and the general Replication good; and Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Prince ver≈øus Row≈øon, Executor of Atkin≈øon.
div.p: EXecutor de ≈øon tort cannot retain.Executor de ≈øon tort cannot retain. The Defendant in this Ca≈øe pleaded, that the Te≈øtator owed his Wife dum ≈øola 800 l. and that he made his Will; but doth not ≈øhew that he was thereby made Executor; and therefore having no Title he became Executor de ≈øon tort, for which cau≈øe his Plea was held ill; and Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Norris ver≈øus Palmer.
div.p: THE Plaintiff brought an Action on the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Defendant for cau≈øing him fal≈øo & malitio≈øe to be indicted for a Common Tre≈øpa≈øs in taking away one hundred Bricks,Ca≈øe after an acquittal upon an Indictment for Tre≈øpas. by which means he was compelled to ≈øpend great Sums of Mony, and that upon the Trial the Iury had acquitted him.

The Defendant demurred to the Declaration; and Barrel Serjeant ≈øaid for him, that the Action would not lie; and for a Pre≈øident in the Ca≈øe he cited a like Iudgment between Langley ver≈øus Clerk in the King's Bench, Trin. 1658. 2 Sid. 100. In which Action the Plaintiff was indicted for a Battery with an intent to ravi≈øh a Woman, and being acquitted brought this Action; and the Court after a long Debate gave Iudgment for the Plaintiff; but agr√©ed that the Action would not lie for a Common Tre≈øpa≈øs, as if it had be√©n for the Battery only; but the Ravi≈øhing was a great ≈øcandal, and for that rea≈øon the Plaintiff recoverd there; but this is an ordinary Tre≈øpa≈øs, and therefore this Action will not lie.

But Pemberton Serjeant held that the Action would lie becau≈øe it was in the nature of a Con≈øpiracy,Sid. 463, 464. 1 Cro. 291. and done fal≈øly and malitiou≈øly knowing the contrary, and thereby the Plaintiff was put to great Charges, all which is confe≈ø≈øed by the Demurrer.

And the Ca≈øe cited on the other ≈øide is expre≈øs in the Point; for the Court in that Ca≈øe could take notice of nothing el≈øe but the Battery; for the intent to ravi≈øh was not traver≈øable, and therefore it was idle to put it into the Indictment.

It is now ≈øettled that an Action on the Ca≈øe will lye for a malitious Arre≈øt where there is no probable cau≈øe of Action; and this Ca≈øe is ≈øtronger than that, becau≈øe in the one the party is only put to Charges, and in the other both to Charges and Di≈øgrace, for which he hath no remedy but by this Action.

The Court agre√©d that the Action would lie after an acquittal upon an Indictment for a greater or le≈ø≈øer Tre≈øpa≈øs: The like for citing another into the Spiritual Court without cau≈øe,3 A≈ø≈ø. 13. 1 Rol. Abr. 112. pl. 9. Po≈øtea. F. N. B. 116. D. 7 E. 4. 30. 10 H. 4. Fitz. Con≈øpiracy 21. 13. 3 E. 3. 19.
The Defendants Council con≈øented to wave the Demurrer, and plead and go to Tryal.

div.head: The King ver≈øus Turvil.
div.p: The King pre≈øented, being intituled by a Simoniacal Contract, his Pre≈øentee ≈øhall not be removed though the Symony is pardoned. QUare Impedit. The King was intituled to a Pre≈øentation by the Statute of 31 Eliz. cap. 6. becau≈øe of a Simoniacal Contract made by the rightful Patron, and he accordingly did pre≈øent.

Then comes the Act of General Pardon, 21 Jac. cap. 35. by which under general Words (it was now admitted) that Symony was pardoned: In which Act there is a beneficial Clau≈øe of Re≈øtitution: viz. The King giveth to his Subjects all Goods, Chattels, Debts, Fines, I≈ø≈øues, Profits, Amerciaments, Forfeitures and Sums of Mony forfeited by rea≈øon of any Offence, &c. done.
And whether the Kings Pre≈øente√© or the Patron had the better Title was the Que≈øtion.

This Ca≈øe was only mentioned now, but argued in Michaelmas Term following by Serjeant Jones, that the Kings Pre≈øente√© is intituled; he agreed that Symony was pardoned, but not the con≈øequences thereof; for 'tis not like the Ca≈øe where a Stroak is given at one time and death happens at another; if the Stroak, which is the fir≈øt offence, is pardoned before the death of the party, that is a Pardon likewi≈øe of the Felony; for 'tis true the Stroak being the cau≈øe of the death, and that being pardoned all the natural Effects are pardoned with the Cau≈øe.
But legal Con≈øequences are not thus pardoned; as if a Man is outlawed in Tre≈øpa≈øs, and the King pardons the Outlawry, the Fine remains, 6 E. 4. 9. 8 H. 4. 21. 2 Roll. Abr. 179.

In this Act of Pardon, there are words of Grant, but the Pre≈øentation is not within the Clau≈øe of Re≈øtitution; for 'tis an Intere≈øt and not an Authority ve≈øted in the King, and therefore a thing of another nature than what is intended to be re≈øtored; becau≈øe it is higher, and ≈øhall not be comprehended among≈øt the general words of Goods and Chattels, &c. which are things of a lower nature, and are all in the per≈øonality, Cro. Car. 354.
Conyers Serjeant, argued for the Title of the Patron,Ex parte Def. and ≈øaid, that there were three material Clau≈øes in this Act.
1. A Pardon of the Offences therein mentioned in general and particular words.
2. That all things not excepted ≈øhall be pardoned by general words, as if particularly named.

3. The Pardon to be taken mo≈øt favourably for the Subject; upon which Clau≈øes it mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily follow, that this Offence is pardoned, and then all the con≈øequences from thence deduced will be likewi≈øe pardoned; and ≈øo the Patron re≈øtored to his Pre≈øentation, for all Charters of Re≈øtitution are to be taken favourably, Pl. Com. 252.
The Pre≈øentation ve≈øts no legal Right in the Pre≈øentee; for in the Ca≈øe of the King, 'tis revocable after In≈øtitution and before Induction, Co. Lit. 344. b.

So likewi≈øe a ≈øecond Pre≈øentation will repeal the fir≈øt, Rolls 353. And if the Kings Pre≈øentee dies before Induction, that is al≈øo a Revocation; if therefore the Party hath no legal Right by this Pre≈øentation, and the King by the Simony had only an authority to pre≈øent, and no legal Intere≈øt ve≈øted, then by this Act he hath revoked the Pre≈øentation, and the right Patron is re≈øtored to his Title to pre≈øent.

The Court were all of Opinion (ab≈øente Ellis) That the Kings Pre≈øentee had a good Title, and by con≈øequence the Patron had no right to Pre≈øent this turn; for here was an Intere≈øt ve≈øted in the King; like the Ca≈øe where the King is intituled to the Goods of a Felo de ≈øe, by Inqui≈øition, and then comes an Act of Indempnity, that ≈øhall not dive≈øt the King of his Right.
But where nothing Ve≈øts before the Office found, a Pardon before the Inqui≈øition extingui≈øhes all Forfeitures, as it was re≈øolved in Tomb's Ca≈øe.
So if the Pardon in this Ca≈øe had come before the Pre≈øentation, the Party had been re≈øtored Statu quo, &c.

The King can do no more, the Bi≈øhop is to do the re≈øt; neither is the Pre≈øentation revoked by this Act; it might have been revoked by implication in ≈øome Ca≈øes; as where there is a ≈øecond Pre≈øentation; but ≈øuch a general revocation will not do it: and Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, and a Writ of Error brought, but the Cau≈øe was ended by Agreement.

div.head: Hill ver≈øus Phea≈øant.
div.p: Gaming at ≈øeveral meetings, whether within the Statute.AN Action of Debt was brought upon the Statute of 16 Car. 2. cap. 7. made again≈øt deceitful and di≈øorderly Gaming, which Enacts, That if any per≈øon ≈øhall play at any Game, other than for ready Mony, and ≈øhall lo≈øe any Sum, or other thing played for, above the Sum of 100 l. at any one time or meeting, upon Tick, and ≈øhall not then pay the ≈øame; that all Contracts and Securities made for the payment thereof ≈øhall be void, and the per≈øon winning ≈øhall pay treble the Mony lo≈øt.

It happened that the Defendant won 80 l. at one meeting, for whcih the Plaintiff gave Security; and another meeting was appointed, and the Defendant won 70 l. more of the Plaintiff; being in all above 100 l. And if this was within the Statute, was the Que≈øtion.

The like Ca≈øe was in the Kings-Bench, Trin. 25 Car. 2. Rot. 1230. between Edgberry and Ro≈øeberry; and in Michaelmas Term following, this Ca≈øe was argued, and the Court was divided, which the Plaintiff perceiving,Anonymus, Po≈øtea. de≈øired to di≈øcontinue his Action; but the better Opinion was, that it was not within the Statute, though if it had been pleaded, That the ≈øeveral meetings were purpo≈øely appointed to elude the Statute,Sid. 394. in might be otherwi≈øe.

div.head: Calthorp ver≈øus Heyton.
div.p:
Traver≈øe not good; viz. Ab≈ø
que hoc quod legitimo modo oneratus.IN Replevin; The Defendant avowed, for that the King being ≈øei≈øed in Fee of a Mannor, and of a Grange, which was parcel of the Mannor, granted the Inheritance to a Bi≈øhop, re≈øerving 33 l. Rent to be yearly i≈ø≈øuing out of the whole, and alledges a Grant of the Grange from Sir W. W. (who claimed under the Bi≈øhop) to his Ance≈øtors in Fee; in which Grant there was this Clau≈øe:

p.hi:
Viz. If the Grantee or his Heirs ≈øhall be legally charged by Di≈øtre≈øs, or with any Rent due to the King or his Succe≈ø≈øors,
upon account of the ≈øaid Grange, that then it ≈øhould be lawful for them to enter into Blackacre, and di≈øtrein till he or they be ≈øatisfied.

div.p: And afterwards the Grantee and his Heirs were, upon a Bill Exhibited again≈øt them in the Exchequer, decreed to pay the King 4 l. per Annum, as their proportion out of the Grange, for which he di≈øtreined, and ≈øo ju≈øtified the taking.
The Plaintiff pleads in barr to the Avowry, and traver≈øeth, that the Defendant was lawfully charged with the ≈øaid Rent; and the Defendant demurred.

Baldwyn Serjeant, maintained the Avowry to be good,Ex parte Def. having alledged a legal charge, and that the Barr was not good; for the Plaintiff traver≈øeth quod Defendens e≈øt ligitimo modo oneratus, which being part matter of Law, and part likewi≈øe matter of Fact is not good; and therefore if the Decree be not a legal charge, the Plaintiff ≈øhould have demurred.

But on the other ≈øide, it was argued by Seys Serjeant,Ex parte Quer. That the Avowry is not good; becau≈øe the Defendant hath not ≈øet forth a legal charge, according to the Grant, which mu≈øt be by Di≈øtre≈øs, or ≈øome other lawful way, and that mu≈øt be intended by ≈øome execution at Common Law; for the coactus fuit to pay, is not enough; a Suit in Equity is no legal di≈øturbance, Moor 559. The ≈øame Ca≈øe is Reported in 1 Brownl. 23. Selby ver≈øus Chute.
Be≈øides, the Defendant doth not ≈øhew any Proce≈øs taken out, or who were Parties to the Decree, and a Que e≈øtate in the Ca≈øe of a Bi≈øhop is not good, for he mu≈øt pa≈øs it by Deed.

North and the whole Court: A Rent in the Kings Ca≈øe lies in Render, and not in Demand, and after the Rent day is pa≈øt, he is oneratus, and the Decree is not material in this Ca≈øe; for the charge is not made thereby, but by the Re≈øervation, for payment whereof the whole Grange is chargeable.
The King may di≈øtrain in any part of the Land, he is not bound by the Decree to a particular place; that is in favour only to the Purcha≈øor, that he ≈øhould pay no more than his proportion.
As to the Que e≈øtate, the Defendant hath admitted that, by ≈øaying bene & verum e≈øt, that Sir W. W. was ≈øei≈øed.
The Traver≈øe is ill, and Iudgment was given for the Avowant.

div.head: Vaughan ver≈øus Wood.
div.p: Tre≈øpa≈øs ju≈øtified, for taking corrupt Victualls. Mod. Rep. 202. TRe≈øpa≈øs for taking Beef; The Defendant pleads a Cu≈øtom to choo≈øe Supervi≈øors of Victuals at a Court Leet; That he was there cho≈øen, and having viewed the Plaintiffs Goods, found the Beef to be corrupt, which he took and burned.

The Plaintiff demurrs, for that the Cu≈øtom is unrea≈øonable, and when Meat is corrupt and ≈øold, there are proper remedies at Law, by Action on the Ca≈øe, or pre≈øentment at a Leet, 9 H. 6. 53. 11 Ed. 3. 4. 6. Vide Stat. 18 Eliz. cap. 3.
But the Court held it a good Cu≈øtom, and Iudgment was given for the Defendant; the Chief Iu≈øtice being not clear in it.

div.head: Chapter of Southwel ver≈øus Bi≈øhop of Lincoln.
div.p: Grant of next Avoidance, not bind the Succe≈ø≈øor. Mod. Rep. 204.IN a Quare Impedit, the Que≈øtion upon pleading was, Whether the Grant of the next Avoidance by the Chapter, was good or not to bind the Succe≈ø≈øor.

The doubt did ari≈øe upon the Statute of 13 Eliz. cap. 10. which was objected not to be a publickYelv. 106. Act, becau≈øe it extends only to tho≈øe who are Eccle≈øia≈øtical per≈øons; or if it ≈øhould be adjudged a publick Law, yet this is not a good Grant to bind the Succe≈ø≈øor; for though the Grant of an Avoidance is not a thing of which any profit can be made, yet it is anCro. Eliz. 441. Hereditament within the meaning of that Statute, by which, among other things, 'tis Enacted, That all Grants, &c. made by Dean and Chapter, &c. of any Lands, Tythes, Tenements, or Hereditaments, being parcel of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Chapter, other than for the Term of 21 Years, or 3 Lives, from the time of the making the ≈øaid Grant, ≈øhall be void.

But it was agreed, by the Court, to be a general Law; like the Statute of Non Re≈øidency, which hath been ≈øo ruled; and that this Pre≈øentment or Grant of the next Avoidance, was not good, becau≈øe it was made by tho≈øe who were not Head of the Corporation, and it mu≈øt be void immediately, or not at all; and Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: Threadneedle ver≈øus Lynam.
div.p: THere being two Mannors u≈øually let for 67 l. 1 s. 5 d. by the year;Lea≈øe by a Bi≈øhop and more than the old Rent re≈øerved, good. Mod. Rep. 203. a Bi≈øhop lets one of them for 21 years re≈øerving the whole Rent, and whether this was a good Lea≈øe within the Statute of 1 Eliz. cap. 19. was the Que≈øtion, which depended upon the con≈øtruction of the Words therein, viz. All Lea≈øes to be void upon which the old accu≈øtomed Rent is not re≈øerved; and here is more than the old Rent re≈øerved; and this being a private Act is to be taken literally.

North Chief Iu≈øtice agreed that private Acts, which go to one particular thing are to be interpreted literally; but this Statute extends to all Bi≈øhops, and ≈øo may be taken according to Equity; and therefore he and Wyndham and Atkins Iu≈øtices held the Lea≈øe to be good: But this Ca≈øe was argued when Vaughan was Chief Iu≈øtice, and he and Iu≈øtice Ellis were of another Opinion.

div.head: DE Term. Sancti Mich. Anno 27 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Thorp ver≈øus Fowle.
div.p: No more Co≈øts than Damages. NOTA. In this Ca≈øe the Court ≈øaid that ≈øince the Statute, which gives no more Co≈øts than Damage, 'tis u≈øual to turn Tre≈øpa≈øs into Ca≈øe.

div.head: Cooper ver≈øus Hawke≈øwel.
div.p: Words. IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe for the≈øe Words: I dealt not ≈øo unkindly with you when you ≈øtole a Stack of my Corn: Per Curiam, the Action lies.

div.head: E≈øcourt ver≈øus Cole.
div.p: Words.IN an Action on the Ca≈øe for Words laid two ways; the la≈øt Count was Cumque etiam, which is but a recital, and dubitatur whether good.

div.head: Sharp ver≈øus Hubbard.
div.p: Six Months for proving of a Sugge≈øtion.THE ≈øix Months in which the Sugge≈øtion is to be proved mu≈øt be reckoned according to the Calendar Months, and 'tis ≈øo computed in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court.

div.head: Crowder ver≈øus Goodwin.
div.p: Ju≈øtification by Proce≈øs out of inferiour Court.IN A≈ø≈øault and Battery and fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, as to the A≈ø≈øault, &c. the Defendant pleads Not-Guilty; and as to the Impri≈øonment he ju≈øtifies by a Proce≈øs out an inferiour Court, and upon Demurrer the≈øe Exceptions were taken to his Plea.
1. The Defendant hath ≈øet forth a Precept directed Servienti ad Claven, and 'tis not ≈øaid Mini≈øtro Curiae.

2. 1 Rol. 484. Cro. Car. 254. Dyer 262. b. It was to take the Plaintiff and have him ad proximam Curiam, which is not good; for it ≈øhould have be√©n on a day certain, like Adams and Flythe's Ca≈øe, Cro. Jac. 571. Mod. Rep. 81. where a Writ of Error was brought upon a Iudgment in Debt by Nil dicit in an inferiour Court; and the Error a≈ø≈øigned was, That after Imparlance a day was given to the Parties till the next Court; and this was held to be a Di≈øcontinuance, not being a day certain.
3. 'Tis not ≈øaid ad re≈øpondend' alicui.
4. Nor that the Action aro≈øe infra Burgum.
5. The Precept is not alledged to be returned by the Officer.

To all which it was an≈øwered, That a Pleint is but a Remembrance and mu≈øt be ≈øhort, Ra≈øt. 321. and when 'tis entred the Officer is excu≈øed; for he cannot tell whether 'tis infra Squibb ver≈øus Hole antea 29. Juri≈ødictionem or not.
And as to the fir≈øt Exception, a Precept may be directed to a private per≈øon, and therefore Servienti ad Clavem is well enough.
Then as to the next Exception, 'tis likewi≈øe well ≈øet forth to have the Plaintiff ad proximam Curiam; for how can it be on a day certain when the Iudge may adjourn the Court de die in diem?
Then ad re≈øpondendum, though 'tis not ≈øaid alicui 'tis good, though not ≈øo formal; and 'tis no Tort in the Officer, but tis to be intended that he is to an≈øwer the Plaintiff in the Plaint.

As to the fourth Exception the Defendant ≈øets forth that he did enter his Plaint ≈øecundum con≈øuetudinem Curiae Burgi, and when the Plaintiff declared there, he ≈øhewed that the Cau≈øe did ari≈øe infra Juri≈ødictionem.

And as to the la≈øt, The Officer is not puni≈øhable though he do not return the Writ. The end of the Law is that the Defendant ≈øhould be pre≈øent at the day; and if the Cau≈øe ≈øhould be agreed, or the Plaintiff give a Relea≈øe when the Defendant is in cu≈øtody, no Action lies again≈øt the Officer if he be detained afterwards.
But the Chief Iu≈øtice doubted, that for the ≈øecond Exception the Plea was ill, for it ought to be on a day certain, and likewi≈øe it ought to be alledged infra Juri≈ødictionem.

But the other thre√© Iu≈øtices held the Plea to be good in omnibus, and ≈øaid that the inferior Court had a Iuri≈ødiction to i≈ø≈øue out a Writ, and the Officer is excu≈øable though the cau≈øe of Action did not ari≈øe within the Iurisdiction, which ought to be ≈øhewn on the other ≈øide: And ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Snow and others ver≈øus Wi≈øeman.
div.p: Traver≈øe nece≈ø≈øary where omitted, is ≈øub≈øtance.TRe≈øpa≈øs for taking of his Hor≈øe: The Defendant pleads that he was ≈øei≈øed of ≈øuch Lands, and intitles him≈øelf to an Herriot.
The Plaintiff replies that another per≈øon was jointly ≈øei≈øed with the Defendant, Et hoc paratus e≈øt verificare.
The Defendant demurs generally, becau≈øe the Plaintiff ≈øhould have traver≈øed the ≈øole Sei≈øin.
But it was ≈øaid for him that the ≈øole Sei≈øin n√©ed not be traver≈øed,Sid. 300. becau≈øe the matter alledged by him avoids the Barr without a Traver≈øe.

In a Sugge≈øtion upon a Prohibition for Tythes, the Plaintiff entituled him≈øelf by Pre≈øcription under an Abbot, and ≈øhews the Vnity of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by the Statute of 31 H. 8. by which the Lands were di≈øcharged of Tythes.

Yelv. 231. Pl. Com. 230. 231.The Defendant pleads that the Abbey was founded within time of Memory, and confe≈ø≈øeth the Vnity afterwards, and the Plea was held good; for he n√©ed not traver≈øe the Pre≈øcription, becau≈øe he had ≈øet forth the Foundation of the Abbey to be within time of Memory, which was a ≈øufficient avoiding the Plaintiffs Title, Yelv. 31.

The Plaintiff therefore having ≈øaid enough in this Ca≈øe to avoid the Barr; if he had traver≈øed it al≈øo it would have made his Replication naught,Cro. Jac. 221. like the Ca≈øe of * Bedel and Lull, where in an Ejectment upon a Lea≈øe made by Elizabeth, the Defendant pleads that before Elizabeth had any thing in the Lands, James was ≈øei≈øed thereof in Fee, and that it de≈øcended to his Son and ≈øo derives a Title under him, and that Elizabeth was ≈øei≈øed by Abatement.

The Plaintiff confe≈ø≈øes the Sei≈øin of James, but that he devi≈øed it to Elizabeth in Fee, and makes a Title under her ab≈ø
que hoc that ≈øhe was ≈øei≈øed by Abatement; and upon a Demurrer the Replication was held ill, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had made a good Title before the Devi≈øe to James; and ≈øo ne√©d not traver≈øe the Abatement.

The Chief Iu≈øtice held that the omitting of a Traver≈øe where nece≈ø≈øary is matter of ≈øub≈øtance, and the concluding with hoc paratus e≈øt verificare, when it ≈øhould be Et hoc petÃÑ quod inquiratur Íùë patriam, or de hoc ponit ≈øuper patriam or vice ver≈øa is matter of ≈øub≈øtance, and the wanting a Traver≈øe is of the ≈øame nature; and here the Traver≈øe of the ≈øole Sei≈øin is nece≈ø≈øary becau≈øe it is i≈ø≈øuable: And of the ≈øame Opinion were the other Iudges (ab≈øente Ellis) and therefore Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Wil≈øon ver≈øus Ducket.
div.p: TRe≈øpa≈øs for taking of his Corn;Di≈øtre≈øs not good of Corn in Shocks. the Defendant pleads Not-Guilty to all but 360 Sheaves made into Stacks, which the Defendant di≈øtrained for Rent and Services in arrear and due to him. The Plaintiff demurrs, for that they could not be di≈øtreined in Sheaves: A Di≈øtre≈øs of them is lawful damage fea≈øant or in a Cart for Rent, but not here.

Per Jones Serjeant, it is naught,Ex parte Quer. becau≈øe nothing is to be di≈øtrained, but what may be known and returned in the ≈øame condition as when taken; and therefore a Replevin will not lye of Mony out of a Bag or Che≈øt, and in this Ca≈øe theAltered by Statute 2 Will. & Mar. Corn cannot be returned in the ≈øame condition, becau≈øe a great deal may be lo≈øt in the carrying of it home, 18 H. 3. 4. 2 H. 4. 15. 22 E. 4. 50. 11 H. 5. 14. 1 In≈øt. 47. Roll. 667. pl. 17. And of that Opinion was all the Court.

div.head: Curtis ver≈øus Bourn.
div.p: IN Wa≈øt, Tenant in Common need not joyn in an Action of Wa≈øte. one Tenant in Common brings an Action of Wa≈øte alone; and the Que≈øtion upon the Pleadings was, whether he ≈øhould not have joyned with his Companion; and for an authority that they ≈øhould joyn in this Action, Scroggs Serjeant cited Rolls Abr. 2 part 825. pl. 11. where it is ≈øaid, that if a Rever≈øion be granted to two, and the Heirs of one of them, yet they mu≈øt joyn in an Action of Wa≈øte.

But it was an≈øwered by Pemberton Serjeant, That Rolls cited that Ca≈øe in his Abridgment, out of the 1 In≈øt. 53. which ≈øe√©med to be the Opinion of my Lord Coke, grounded upon the Authorities there cited in the Margin, which he ≈øaid did not warrant any ≈øuch Opinion.

The difference upon the Books is, where Tenant in Common demands an intirety, the Writ ≈øhall abate, and therefore in the Ca≈øe of Hill and Hart, Cro. Eliz. 357. where the Plaintiff had only a third part of a Rever≈øion in Common, it was held he ≈øhould not have an Action of Wa≈øte alone,Co. Lit. 197. b. Moor 374. becau≈øe it would be very inconvenient, that the third part ≈øhould be delivered in Execution.

Co. Lit. 198. Yelv. 161.'Tis true, they ≈øhall joyn in the per≈øonalty, where Damages are to be recovered, but they ≈øhall always ≈øever in the realty; and therefore in this Ca≈øe, Wa≈øte being a mixt Action, and ≈øavouring of the realty, that being the more worthy, draws over the per≈øonalty with it, and therefore the Action by one alone is good; but if they had made a Lea≈øe for years, then they ≈øhould have joyned in an Action of Wa≈øte: And of that Opinion was the whole Court.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: Tout temps pri≈øt, no good Plea after Imparlance.THE Que≈øtion was, whether tout temps pri≈øt was a good Plea, after a general Imparlance.
And it was in≈øi≈øted for the Plaintiff, That this Plea was repugnant, becau≈øe the imparlance proves the contrary.

'Tis true, in an Action of Debt upon a Bond, ≈øuch Plea is good after an Imparlance, becau≈øe 'tis to ≈øave the Penalty; and 'tis held in Dyer f. 300.Cro. Jac. 627. contra.
b. That uncore pri≈øt alone, without ≈øaying tout temps, in ≈øuch ca≈øe is good, though Leonard, the Cu≈øtos Brevium, and who was a Learned Man, was there of another Opinion.
But when a ≈øingle Duty is demanded, and the party is intituled to damages for non-payment, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Plea of tout temps pri≈øt is not good.

And though it was objected, that the difference is, that the Defendant after Imparlance ≈øhould not plead any thing contrary to the matter in the Declaration to which he had imparled; as Ba≈øtardy to an Action brought by an Heir, &c.

Yet the Court were all of Opinion, That the Plea was not good, becau≈øe 'tis incon≈øi≈øtent with the Imparlance; for petit licentiam interloquendi, is no more in Engli≈øh, than for the Defendant to ≈øay, I will take time and re≈øolve what to do; which is contrary, to be always ready.

div.head: DE Termino Sancti Hill. Anno 27 & 28 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Stubbins ver≈øus Bird & alios.
div.p: IN an Action of Trover and Conver≈øion; The Defendant concludes in Abatement, it ≈øhall be in his election to have it taken in Barr. Mod. Rep. 117. the Plaintiff declared for taking 600 Load of Oar.
The Defendant pleads, That the Plaintiff never had any thing in the ≈øaid 600 Load of Oar, ni≈øi conjunctim & pro in divi≈øo, with two others, and ≈øo concludes in Abatement.

The Plaintiff replies, That J. S. was ≈øei≈øed in Fee of a Clo≈øe, in which this Oar was digged; and being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, he dyed; after who≈øe death the ≈øaid Clo≈øe de≈øcended to A. and B. his two Daughters, and Co-heirs; and that the Plaintiff married one of them, and the other was al≈øo married: and ≈øo the Plaintiff and the other Husband and their Wives, were ≈øei≈øed in Right of their ≈øaid Wives of this Clo≈øe.

The afterwards, and before the Action brought, 2000 Load of Lead Oar digged out of the ≈øaid Clo≈øe, and laid there in heaps; and then a Partition was made by Deed, of the ≈øaid Clo≈øe and the Oar, and 1000 Load was allotted to one Si≈øter and her Husband, and the other 1000 Load was allotted to the Plaintiff, per quod he became ≈øolus po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionatÃÑ of the ≈øaid 1000 Load in ≈øeveralty; and being ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, the Defendant found 600 Load, parcel of the ≈øaid 1000 Load, and converted it, Ab≈øque hoc that the Plaintiff had any thing after the Partition conjunction with any other per≈øon.
The Defendant rejoyns, that at the time of the conver≈øion the Plaintiff had nothing but conjunction with the other, as before.

1. And the Plaintiff demurred,Ex parte Quer. for that the Defendant ought to have traver≈øed the Partition; for though the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was joynt, the Partition had made it ≈øeveral, by which the joynt Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion
was confe≈ø≈øed and avoided, and therefore the Traver≈øe good; like the Rule laid down in my Lord Hobert 104. in Digby and Fitzherberts Ca≈øe, Tre≈øpa≈øs, tali die; the Defendant confe≈ø≈øes it, but pleads a Relea≈øe of all Actions, and traver≈øeth all Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes after; ≈øo here the Plaintiff hath traver≈øed the joynt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion after the Partition.

2. The Rejoynder is a departure from the Plea, which is, that the Plaintiff never had any thing but joyntly with others; and the Rejoynder is, that at the time of the conver≈øion he was joyntly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed; which is a manife≈øt difference in point of time, and ≈øuch as will make a Departure, 33 H. 14. Bro. Departure 28. 13.

Ex parte Def.It was argued by Serjeant Hopkins for the Defendant, that the Replication was not good; for the Plaintiff therein had alledged a Partition by Deed, and doth not ≈øay, hic in Curia prolatÃÑ: And in all Ca≈øes where a Man pleads a Deed, by which he makes him≈øelf either party or privy, he mu≈øt produce it in Court: As where the Defendant ju≈øtifies in Tre≈øpa≈øs, that before the Plaintiff had any thing. One Purfrey was ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the place where, &c. And by Indenture, &c. demi≈øed it to Corbet, excepting the Wood, &c. Habendum, for the Life of Ann, and covenanted quod licitum foret for the ≈øaid Corbet to take Hou≈øe-boot, &c. That he a≈ø≈øigned his Intere≈øt to Ann, and that the Defendant, as her Servant, took the Trees; and upon Demurrer the Plea was held naught, becau≈øe (though a Servant) having ju≈øtified by force of a Covenant, he did not ≈øhew the Indenture, 2 Cro. 291. Purfrey ver≈øus Grimes. 6 Rep. Bellamy's Ca≈øe.
1 Leon. 309. Rol. Rep. 20.If a thing will pa≈øs without a Deed, yet if the Party pleads a Deed, and makes a Title thereby, he mu≈øt come with a * profert hic in Curia.

As to the Objection, That there was a Departure, he argued to the contrary: For the Defendant in his Rejoynder in≈øi≈øts only on that which was mo≈øt material; and the Plaintiff in his Replication had given him occa≈øion thus to Rejoyn; and though he had left out ≈øome of the time mentioned in the Bar, yet the would hurt the Pleadings, becau≈øe a fair I≈ø≈øue was tendred; for if at the time of the conver≈øion he was joyntly ≈øei≈øed, he could not be entituled to the Action alone.

Judgment.And afterwards, in Trinity-Term following, the Chief Iu≈øtice delivered the Opinion of the Court, That the Plea was good in Barr, though pleaded in Abatement, and the Defendant
hath election to plead either in Barr or Abatement; the nature of a Plea in Abatement, is to intitle the Plaintiff to a better Writ, but here the Defendant ≈øhews, that the Plaintiff hath no cau≈øe of Action, and ≈øo it ≈øhall be taken to be in Barr: And it hath been expre≈ø≈øly re≈øolved, That where the Plea is in Abatement, if it be of nece≈ø≈øity, that the Defendant mu≈øt di≈øclo≈øe matter of barr, he ≈øhall have his election to take it either by way of Barr or Abatement, 2 Roll. Rep. 64. Salkil ver≈øus Shilton.

So, where Wa≈øte was brought in the tenet, the Tenant pleads a Surrender to the Le≈ø≈øor, and demands Iudgment, if he ≈øhould be charged in the tenet, becau≈øe it ≈øhould have been in the tenuit, and this was held a good Plea, 10 H. 7.11. Whereupon Iudgment was given for the Defendant; the Chief Iu≈øtice at fir≈øt doubting about the Departure, and advi≈øed the Plaintiff to wave his Demurrer, and to take i≈ø≈øue upon payment of Co≈øts.

div.head: Daws ver≈øus Harri≈øon.
div.p: THE Plaintiff intitles him≈øelf, as Admini≈øtrator to Daws, Admini≈øtration pleaded, and not loci i≈øtius ordinarius, good. and ≈øhews that Admini≈øtration was granted to him by the Official of the Bi≈øhop of Carli≈øle, but did not alledge him to be loci i≈øtius Ordinarius; And

Jones Serjeant demurred to the Declaration, becau≈øe it did not appear that the Official had any Iuri≈ødiction, Pl. Com. 277. a. 31. H. 6. 13. Fitz. Judg. 35. 22 H. 6. 52. 36 H. 6. 32, 33. Sed non allocatur. For the whole Court were of Opinion, That the Declaration was good, and that he ≈øhall be intended to have Iuri≈ødiction; but if it had been in the Ca≈øe of a Peculiar, Cro Jac. 556. Palm. 97. Sid. 322. it cannot be intended that they have any authority, unle≈øs ≈øet forth: And ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Ma≈øon ver≈øus Cae≈øar.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs for pulling down of Hedges;Commoner may abate Hedges made upon his Common. the Defendant pleads that he had right of Common, in the place where, &c. and the Hedges were made upon his Common, ≈øo that he could not in ea parte enjoy his Common in tam amplo modo, &c. and ≈øo ju≈øtifies the pulling them down.

And they were at i≈ø≈øue, whether the Defendant could enjoy the Common in tam amplo modo, &c. and there was a Verdict for the
Defendant, and Iudgment being ≈øtaied 'till moved on the other ≈øide.

Scroggs Serjeant moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, becau≈øe the Plea was ill, and the I≈ø≈øue frivolous; for 'tis impo≈ø≈øible that he ≈øhould have Common where the Hedges are:5 Rep. 100. 9 Rep. 55. And therefore the Defendant ought to have brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe, or a quod permittat. He cannot abate the Hedges, though he might have pulled down ≈øo much as might have opened a Way to his Common.

2 Cro. 195, 229.The Lord hath an Intere≈øt in the Soil, and a Commoner hath no authority to do any thing but to enter and put in his Bea≈øts, and not to throw down Quick-Set Hedges, for that is a ≈øhelter to his Bea≈øts.

But the Court were of Opinion, That the Defendant might abate the Hedges, for thereby he did not meddle with the Soil, but only pulled down the erection; and the Book of 29 E. 3. 6. was expre≈øs in this point. Vide 17 H. 7. 10. 16 H. 7. 8. 33 H. 6. 31. 2 A≈ø≈ø. 12. And nothing was ≈øaid concerning the Plea, and ≈øo the Defendant had Iudgment.

div.head: Hocket and his Wife ver≈øus Stiddolph and his Wife.
div.p: Verdict cured a bad Declaration.IN an Action of A≈ø≈øault and Battery brought by the Plaintiff and his Wife, again≈øt the Defendant and his Wife; the Iury found quoad, the beating of the Plaintiffs Wife only, that the Defendants are Guilty, and quoad re≈øid' they find for the Defendants.

And it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, by Scroggs Serjeant, That the Declaration is not good, becau≈øe the HusbandYelv. 106. Drury ver≈øus Dennis. Sid. 376. joyns with the Wife, which he ought not to do upon his own ≈øhewing; for as to the Battery made upon him, he ought to have brought his Action alone; and the finding of the Iury will not help the Declaration, which is ill in ≈øub≈øtance, and thereupon Iudgment was ≈øtaied; but being moved again the next Term, the Court were all of Opinion, That the Declaration was cured by the Verdict, and ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Goodwin qui tam, &c. ver≈øus Butcher.
div.p: AN Information was brought upon the Statute of 32 H. 8.Buying a pretended Title. cap. 9. made again≈øt buying pretended Titles, which gives a Forfeiture of the value of the Land purcha≈øed, unle≈øs the Seller was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion within a year before the Sale.

After Verdict for the Plaintiff, it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, by Serjeant Barrell, becau≈øe the Information had ≈øet forth the right of the≈øe Lands purcha≈øed to be in J. S. and that the Son of J. N. had conveyed them by general words,2 Ander≈ø. 57. as de≈øcending from his Father; which Title of the Son, the Defendant bought; whereas, if in truth the Title was in J. S. then nothing de≈øcended from the Father to the Son, and ≈øo the Defendant bought nothing.

Sed non allocatur; for if ≈øuch con≈øtruction ≈øhould be allowed, there could be no buying of a pretended Title within the Statute, unle≈øs it was a good Title; but when 'tis ≈øaid, as here, that the Defendant entred and claimed colore of that Grant or Conveyance, which was void, yet 'tis within the Statute, ≈øo the Plaintiff had his Iudgment.

div.head: Wine ver≈øus Rider & al.
div.p: TRe≈øpa≈øs again≈øt five, Quare clau≈øum fregerunt, Traver≈øe immaterial. and took Fi≈øh out of the Plaintiffs Several and Free-Fi≈øhery.

Four of them pleaded Not Guilty, and the fifth ju≈øtified, for that one of the other Defendants is ≈øei≈øed in Fee of a Clo≈øe adjoyning to the Plaintiffs Clo≈øe; and that he and all tho≈øe &c. have had the ≈øole and ≈øeparate Fi≈øhing in the River which runs by the ≈øaid Clo≈øes, with liberty to enter into the Plaintiffs Clo≈øe, to beat the Water, for the better carrying on of the Fi≈øhing; and that he, as Servant to the other Defendant, and by his Command did enter, and ≈øo ju≈øtified the taking, ab≈øque hoc that he is Guilty aliter vel alio modo.
The Plaintiff replies, That he did enter de injuria ≈øua propria, ab≈øque hoc That the Defendants Ma≈øter hath the Sole Fi≈øhing.

The Defendant demurs;Ex parte Def. and Newdigate Serjeant argued for him, That the Iu≈øtification is good, for when he had made a local
ju≈øtification,2 Cro. 45, 372. he mu≈øt traver≈øe both before and after, as he has done in this Ca≈øe.

2. The Plaintiffs Replication is ill, for he ought not to have waved the Defendants Traver≈øe, and force him to accept of another from him; becau≈øe the fir≈øt is material to the Plaintiffs Title, and he is bound up to it, Hob. 104.
3. There was no occa≈øion of a Traver≈øe in the Replication; for where a Servant is Defendant, de injuria ≈øua propria is good, with a Traver≈øe of the Command.

Ex parte Quer.But on the Plaintiffs ≈øide Serjeant Baldwin held the Defendants Traver≈øe to be immaterial; for having an≈øwered the Declaration fully in alledging a Right to the ≈øole fi≈øhing, and an Entry into the Plaintiffs Clo≈øe,2 Cro. 372. 'tis in≈øignificant afterwards to traver≈øe that he is guilty aliter vel alio modo.

Then the matter of the Plea is not good, becau≈øe the Defendant ju≈øtifies by a Command from one of the other Defendants, who have all pleaded Not-guilty, and they mu≈øt be guilty if they did command him, for a Command will make a Man a Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øer.

Curia.The Court were all of Opinion, that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff: For as to the la≈øt thing mentioned, which was the Matter of the Plea, they held it to be well enough; for theMires and Solebay, Po≈øt. Servant ≈øhall not be ou≈øted of the advantage which the Law gives him by pleading his Ma≈øters Command.

Then as to the Replication 'tis good, and the Plea is naught with the Traver≈øe; for where the Iu≈øtification goes to a time and place not alledged by the Plaintiff, there mu≈øt be a Traver≈øe of both.

In this Ca≈øe the Defendant ought to have traver≈øed the Plaintiffs free fi≈øhing as alledged by him in his Declaration, which he having omitted, the Plea for that rea≈øon al≈øo is ill, and ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: DE Termino Pa≈øchae Anno 28 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Lee ver≈øus Brown.
div.p: IN a Special Verdict in Ejectment: The Ca≈øe was this:Where reputed Lands ≈øhall pa≈øs under general words. viz. There were Lands which re vera were not parcel of a Mannor, and yet were reputed as parcel.

A Grant is made of the Mannor and of all Lands reputed parcel thereof; and whether by this Grant and by the≈øe general Words tho≈øe Lands would pa≈øs, which were not parcel of the Mannor, was the Que≈øtion.

This Term the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice delivered the Opinion of the Court, That tho≈øe Lands would pa≈øs;Po≈øtea. Cro. Car. 308. and they grounded their Opinions upon two Authorities in Co. Entr. fol. 330, 384. The King ver≈øus Imber & Wilkins.

If the Iury had found that the Lands in que≈øtion had be√©n reputed parcel of the Mannor, it would not have pa≈ø≈øed, had they found no more; becau≈øe the Reputation ≈øo found might be intended a Reputation for a ≈ømall time, ≈øo reputed by a few, or by ≈øuch as were ignorant and unskilful.

But in this Ca≈øe 'tis found that not only the Lands were reputed parcel, but the rea≈øon why they were reputed parcel; for the Iury have found that they were formerly parcel of the Mannor, and after the divi≈øion they were again united in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of him who had the Mannor, which being al≈øo Copyhold, have ≈øince b√©en demi≈øed by Copy of Court Roll togethet with the Mannor; and the≈øe were all great marks of Reputation, and therefore Iudgment was given that the Lands did well pa≈øs, 2 Roll. Abr. 186. Dyer 350.

div.head: Wakeman ver≈øus Blackwel.
div.p: Common Recoveries how to be pleaded. QUare Impedit. The Ca≈øe was; The Plaintiff entituled him≈øelf to an Advow≈øon by a Recovery ≈øuffered by Tenant in Tail; in pleading of which Recovery he alledges two to be Tenants to the Praecipe, but doth not ≈øhew how they came to be ≈øo, or what Conveyance was made to them, by which it may appear that they were Tenants to the Praecipe; and after ≈øearch of Pre≈øidents as to the form of pleading of Common Recoveries, the Court inclined that it was not well pleaded, but delivered no Iudgment.

div.head: Searl ver≈øus Bunion.
div.p: Ju≈øtification where good.IN Tre≈øpa≈øs for taking of his Cattel: The Defendant pleads that he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Blackacre pro termino diver≈øorum annorum adtunc & adhuc venturÃÑ; and being ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Plaintiffs Cattle were doing damage, and he di≈øtrained them Damage fe≈øant, ibidem, and ≈øo ju≈øtifies the taking, &c.

The Plaintiff demurrs, and a≈ø≈øigns ≈øpecially for cau≈øe that the Defendant did not ≈øet forth particularly the commencement of the Term of years, but only that he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of an Acre for a Term of years to come; and regularly where a Man makes a Title to a particular E≈øtate, in pleading he mu≈øt ≈øhew the particular time of the Commencement of his Title, that the Plaintiff may replie to it.

Curia.The Chief Iu≈øtice and the whole Court held that the Plea was good, upon this difference; where the Plaintiff brings an Action for the Land or doing of a Tre≈øpa≈øs upon the Land, he is ≈øuppo≈øed to be in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; but if he will ju≈øtifie by vertue of any particular E≈øtate, he mu≈øt ≈øhew the Commencement of that E≈øtate, and then ≈øuch pleading as here will not be good.

But when the Matter isYelv. 75. Cro. Car. 138. collateral to the Title of the Land, and for any thing which appears in the Declaration the Title may not come in que≈øtion, ≈øuch a Iu≈øtification as this will be good.
