In this Ca≈øe no Man can tell what the Plaintiff will reply; 'tis like the Ca≈øes of Inducements to Actions, which do not require ≈øuch certainty as is nece≈ø≈øary in other Ca≈øes.

So where an Action is brought for a Nu≈øance, and he intitles him≈øelf generally by ≈øaying he is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionat' pro termino annorum, 'tis well enough, and he need not to ≈øet forth particularly the Commencement, becau≈øe he doth not make the Title his Ca≈øe; for which rea≈øon Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Cro≈øier ver≈øus Tomlin≈øon Executor.
div.p: IN an Action on the Ca≈øe:Statute of Limitations of per≈øonal Actions extends to Indebitatus, A≈ø≈øump≈øit. The Plaintiff declared that the Defendants Te≈øtator being in his Life time (viz. ≈øuch a day) indebted to the Plaintiff in the Sum of 20 l. for ≈øo much Mony before that time to his u≈øe had and received, did a≈ø≈øume and promi≈øe to pay the ≈øame when he ≈øhould be thereunto required; and that the Te≈øtator did not in his Life time, nor the Defendant ≈øince his death, pay the Mony though he was thereunto required.
The Defendant pleads that the Te≈øtator did not at any time within ≈øix years make ≈øuch promi≈øe.

The Plaintiff replies that he was an Infant at the time of the promi≈øe made, and that he came not to full Age till the year 1672. and that within ≈øix years after he attained the Age of one and twenty years he brought this Action, and ≈øo takes advantage of the promi≈øe in the Statute of21 Jac. c. 16. Limitations, that the Plaintiff ≈øhall have ≈øix years after the di≈øability, by Infancy, Coverture, &c. is removed.
And the Defendant demurred by Serjeant Rigby, Ex parte Def. and the rea≈øon of his Demurrer was, becau≈øe in the ≈øaid Provi≈øo Actions on the Ca≈øe on A≈ø≈øump≈øit are omitted.

This Act was made for quieting of E≈øtates and avoiding of Suits as appears by the Preamble, and therefore ≈øhall be taken ≈øtrictly; there is an enumeration of ≈øeveral Actions in the Provi≈øo, and this is Ca≈øus omi≈ø≈øus and ≈øo no benefit can be taken of the Provi≈øo.

In a Writ of Error upon a Iudgment brought 4 Car. 1. in the Court of Wind≈øor, the Iudges held that an Action on the Ca≈øe forCro. Car. 163, 513, 535. Debt upon E≈øcape is out of the Statute, 1 Sand 37. But an Action for E≈øcape is not, Sid. 305. So is Debt for not ≈øetting out of Tithes; for the≈øe are not grounded upon any Contract. Cro. Car. 513. Hut. 109. ≈ølandering of a Mans Title is out of this Act, becau≈øe ≈øuch an Action was rare, and not brought without ≈øpecial damages: But Hide Chief Iu≈øtice doubted, 1 Cro. 141.
The Law-makers could not omit this Ca≈øe unadvi≈øedly, becau≈øe 'tis within tho≈øe ≈øorts of Actions enumerated by this Act.
This Promi≈øe was made to the Plaintiff when he was but a day old, and it would be very hard now after ≈øo many years to charge the Executor.

Ex parte Quer.But Turner Serjeant argued, that though an IndebitatÃÑ a≈ø≈øump≈øit is not within the expre≈øs words of the Provi≈øo, yet 'tis within the intent and meaning thereof; and ≈øo the Rule is taken in 10 Co. 101. in Bewfages Ca≈øe, quando verba ≈øtatuti ≈øunt ≈øpecialia, ratio autem generalis, ≈øtatutum intelligendum e≈øt generaliter.

And this is a Statute which gives a general remedy, and the mi≈øchief to the Infant is as great in ≈øuch Actions of Indebitatus a≈ø≈øump≈øit, as other Actions, and therefore 'tis but rea≈øonable to intend, that the Parliament which hath ≈øaved their Rights in Debts, Trovers, &c. intended likewi≈øe, that they ≈øhould not be barred in an Indebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit.

In 2 Ander≈ø. 55. Smith ver≈øus Col≈øhil: Debt was brought upon a Bond; the Defendant there pleaded the Statute of the 5 E. 6. of ≈øelling of Offices; the words of which are, viz. That every Bond to be given, for money or profit for any Office, or Deputation of any Office mentioned in the Statute, ≈øhall be void again≈øt the Maker. In that ca≈øe the Bond was given to procure a Grant of the Office, and al≈øo to exerci≈øe the ≈øame: now though this was not within the expre≈øs words of the Statute, yet the Bond was held void; and if it ≈øhould be otherwi≈øe, the mi≈øchiefs which the Statute intended to remedy would ≈øtill continue; and therefore the intent of the Law-makers in ≈øuch ca≈øes, is to be regarded, for which rea≈øon if Actions of Indebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit are within the ≈øame mi≈øchief with other Actions therein mentioned,2 Ander≈ø. 123, 150. Cor. Car. 533. 19 H. 8. 11. ≈øuch al≈øo ought to be con≈øtrued to be within the ≈øame remedy.

But he took the Ca≈øe ofCro Car. 245. Swain ver≈øus Stephens to rule this Ca≈øe at Bar, in which Ca≈øe this very Statute was pleaded to an Action of Trover, and the Plaintiff replied, that he was beyond Sea; and upon a Demurrer to the Replication, the Court held Trover to be within the Statute, it being named in the Paragraph of Limitation of per≈øonal Actions, which directs it to be brought within the time therein limited; that is to ≈øay, all Actions on the Ca≈øe within ≈øix years; and then enumerates ≈øeveral other Actions, among≈øt which Trover is omitted, yet the Court were then of Opinion, that Trover is implied in tho≈øe general words.

Curia.And of that Opinion was the Chief Iu≈øtice, and Wyndham and Atkyns Iu≈øtices, That upon the whole frame of the Act, it was ≈øtrong again≈øt the Defendant; for it would be very ≈øtrange that the Plaintiff in this Ca≈øe, might bring an Action of Debt, and not an Indebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit.

When the Scope of an Act appears to be in a general ≈øen≈øe, the Law looks to the meaning, and is to be extended to particular Ca≈øes within the ≈øame rea≈øon; and therefore they were of Opinion, That Actions of Tre≈øpa≈øs, mentioned in the Statute, are comprehen≈øive of this Action, becau≈øe 'tis a Tre≈øpa≈øs upon the Ca≈øe, and the words of the Provi≈øo ≈øave the Infants Right in Actions of Tre≈øpa≈øs.

And therefore, though there are not particular words in the enacting Clau≈øe, which relate to this Action, yet this Provi≈øo re≈øtrains the ≈øeverity of that Clau≈øe, and re≈øtores the Common Law, and ≈øo is to be taken favourably; and this Action being within the ≈øame rea≈øon, with other Actions therein mentioned, ought al≈øo to be within the ≈øame remedy.

But Iu≈øtice Ellis doubted, whether Actions of Tre≈øpa≈øs could comprehend Actions on the Ca≈øe; and that when the Parliament had enumerated Actions of Tre≈øpa≈øs, Trover, Ca≈øe for Words, &c. If they had intended this Action, they would have named it; he ≈øaid he was for re≈øtoring the Common Law as much as he could, but doubted much, whether this Provi≈øo did help the Plaintiff: But Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Doctor Samways ver≈øus Eld≈øly.
div.p: COvenant. The Plaintiff declares,Where Covenants are mutual, and where not. That by Indenture made between him and the Defendant, reciting that there were divers Controver≈øies between them, as well concerning the right, title and occupation of Tythes, ari≈øing and renewing upon the Fr√©ehold of the Defendant, in T. and upon other Lands held by the Defendant, by a Lea≈øe for years from the Plaintiff, under the annual Rent of, &c. and concerning the arrearages of Rent due upon that demi≈øe, as concerning other matters; for the determination thereof, the ≈øaid Parties did by the ≈øaid Indenture bind them≈øelves, in con≈øideration of 12 d. given to each other, to ob≈øerve the Arbitration of an Arbitrator, indifferently to be cho≈øen between them, to arbitrate, order and judge between them, de & ≈øuper praemi≈ø≈øis; and the Plaintiff and Defendant mutually covenanted to do ≈øeveral other matters.

That the Arbitrator did thereupon afterwards Award, and the Defendant did Covenant with the Plaintiff, that in con≈øideration of the Plaintiffs ≈øealing and delivering (at the Defendants reque≈øt)
one part of a Lea≈øe for years (to the Award annexed) for the Rent therein re≈øerved, that the Defendant ≈øhould pay ≈øo much Mony for the Tythes.

That it was al≈øo Awarded by the ≈øaid Arbitrator, and the Defendant did covenant, that he would be accomptable to the Plaintiff for all ≈øuch arrearages of Rent, Tythes, and Compo≈øition-Mony for Tythes, as ≈øhould be ari≈øing and renewing upon the ≈øaid Land, &c. according to ≈øuch a value per Annum, whereof the Defendant could not lawfully di≈øcharge him≈øelf.

And the Plaintiff avers, That he hath ob≈øerved all the Covenants on his part, and that the Defendant hath not ob≈øerved all the Covenants on his part, and a≈ø≈øigns for breach, that he hath not accounted with him for all arrears of Tythes and Compo≈øition-Mony for Tythes ari≈øing upon the Lands in, &c. and that he hath reque≈øted him to accompt, which he hath refu≈øed.

The Defendant pleads Actio non: For he ≈øays, that 'tis true, there was ≈øuch an Indenture, as in the Declaration is ≈øet forth, and ≈øuch a Covenant to be accountable as, the Plaintiff hath declared.

But ≈øaith in eadem Indentura agreatum fuit ulterius & provi≈øum, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould allow and di≈øcount upon the Account, all Sums of Mony for Par≈øons Dinners, at the reque≈øt of the Plaintiff, and for his concerns laid out and disbur≈øed by the Defendant, and ≈øuch other Sums which he had direction to lay out; and that ≈øuch a day paratus fuit & obtulit ≈øe & adhuc paratus e≈øt, to account for all arrears of Rent, &c. if the Plaintiff would di≈øcount, &c.

That ≈øuch a day the Plaintiff would not, and often after refu≈øed, and yet doth refu≈øe to allow upon ≈øuch accompt all ≈øuch Sums of Mony as the Defendant, at the reque≈øt, and for the concerns of the Plaintiff, had laid out, and this he is ready to aver; and then he avers, that after, &c. on ≈øuch a day he did expend ≈øeveral Sums of Money for the Plaintiff, which were ju≈øt and rea≈øonable to be allowed by the Plaintiff, upon accompt made by him.
To this Plea the Plaintiff demurred, and the Defendant joyned in Demurrer which was argued by Turner Serjeant for the Plaintiff, and by Serjeant Seys for the Defendant.

This was a bad Plea, for 'tis a Rule in all Law Books, that every Plea ought to an≈øwer the matter which is charged upon the Defendant,Ex parte Quer. in the Declaration, which is not done here,
becau≈øe the Defendant doth neither aver that he did accompt, or confe≈øs or avoid, or traver≈øe it, which he ought to do, after the Plaintiff had alledged a reque≈øt to accompt, and a refu≈øal.

'Tis an ab≈øolute Covenant which charges him to be accomptable; and not if the Plaintiff would allow Par≈øons Dinners, &c. for 'tis impo≈ø≈øible that the Plainntiff can make any ≈øuch allowance, till the Defendant hath accompted; for how can there be a di≈øcounting without an Accompt?

If the Plaintiff had told him before the Accompt, that he would not allow any thing upon the Accompt, this would not have been prejudicial to bart him of his Action, ≈øo as it had been before the reque≈øt: For if a Man makes a Feoffment in Fee, upon condition that if the Feoffor pay 100 l. at Michaelmas, the Feoffment ≈øhall be void; and before Michaelmas the Feoffee tells him that he will not receive the Money at that time; this ≈øhall not prejudice him, becau≈øe tis no refu≈øal in Law.

The Defendant in this Ca≈øe is to do the fir≈øt act, viz. to Accompt; and when that is neglected by him, it ≈øhall never prejudice him who is to do a ≈øub≈øequent act, 5 Co. 19, 20. Higginbottoms Ca≈øe, 22 & 23 Hallin and Lambs Ca≈øe.
One Covenants to make an E≈øtate in fee, at the Co≈øts of the Covenantee; the Covenantor is to do the fir≈øt act, viz. to let him know what Conveyance he will make.

The like Ca≈øe was in this Court, between Twiford and Buckly, upon an Indenture of Covenants, wherein one of the parties did Covenant to make a Lea≈øe for the Life of the Covenantee, and for two other Lives, as he ≈øhould name, and the Covenantor was to give po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

The breach a≈ø≈øigned was, that the Defendant had not made Livery and Sei≈øin, and upon performance pleaded, the Plaintiff did demux, and upon great debate it was re≈øolved that the Covenant was not broken, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had not performed that which was fir≈øt to be done on his part, viz. to name the Lives.
It may be objected, that the≈øe Covenants have a relation one to the other; and ≈øo non-performance of the one, may be pleaded in bar to the other.

But to that he an≈øwered, they are di≈øtinct and mutual Covenants, and there may be ≈øeveral Actions brought again≈øt each other. The Ca≈øe ofStiles 186. 187. Ware and Chappel comes up to this point. Ware was to rai≈øe 500 Soldiers, and bring them to ≈øuch a Port, and Chappel was to find Shipping, for which he ≈øued upon the Covenant, though the other had not rai≈øed the Soldiers; for that can be only alledged in mitigation of Damages, and is
no excu≈øe for the Defendant, and it was adjudged, that this was not a condition precedent, but di≈øtinct and mutual Covenants, upon which ≈øeveral Actions might be brought.

This cannot be a Condition precedent, for the Defendant pleads, & ulterius agreatÃÑ & provi≈øum e≈øt that the Plaintiff ≈øhall di≈øcompt and reimbur≈øe the Defendant; and here the word provi≈øum e≈øt doth not make a Condition but a Covenant, 27 H. 8. 14, 15. Bro. Condition 7.

There is another fault in the Plea, for the Defendant averrs, that the Plaintiff hath not reimbur≈øed him ≈øeveral Sums of Mony, which is altogether incertain, for it doth not appear what is due, 28 H. 8. Dyer 28. 9 Ed. 4. 16. 12 H. 8. 6. a.
Ex parte Def.But it was argued for the Defendant, that he need not Traver≈øe the Accompt.

As to the fir≈øt Objection made, that the Plea is not good, becau≈øe it doth not an≈øwer the Declaration, the Rule as to that purpo≈øe is generally good; but then the Plaintiff mu≈øt tell all his Ca≈øe, which if he omits, he mu≈øt then give the Defendant leave to tell where his omi≈ø≈øion is.

Sometimes a thing which belongs properly to another, may be pleaded in bar, or di≈øcharge, to avoid circuity of Actions; as one Covenant may be pleaded to another, 1 H. 7. 15. 20 H. 7. 4. So where the Le≈ø≈øe√© is to be di≈øpuni≈øhable of wa≈øte, he may plead it to a Writ of wa≈øte.
The Books note a difference where the Covenant is one or two Sentences; for in the fir≈øt ca≈øe one Covenant may be pleaded in di≈øcharge of another, but not in the la≈øt, Keilway 34.

'Tis true, if the ≈øecond Covenant had been di≈øtinct and independent, it could not have been thus pleaded; but in this Ca≈øe 'tis not ≈øaid, that the Covenantor, for him≈øelf, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators doth Covenant, &c. but ulterius agreatÃÑ & provi≈øum e≈øt; ≈øo that as tis penned provi≈øum e≈øt makes a Condition, and then the ≈øen≈øe is, I will accompt if you will di≈øcompt, and if you refu≈øe to di≈øcompt, I cannot be charged, Dyer 6.

'Tis inutilis labor to make up an accompt If the other will not allow what he ought, if there be an Annuity pro con≈øilio impen≈øo, &c. and he will not pay the Mony, the other is not to be compelled to give his advice, Fitzh. Annuity 27. 25 E. 2. Annuity 44.

Curia.The Chief Iu≈øtice and the whole Court were of Opinion that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff; for Arbitrations, Wills and Acts of Parliament are to be taken according to the
meaning of the Parties, and Damages are to be given according to the merit of the Ca≈øe. In this Ca≈øe the Defendant is bound to accompt upon reque≈øt, and to pay what Mony is due upon the Accompt; and 'tis an impertinent que≈øtion for the Defendant to ask him to make allowance for Par≈øons Dinners before they come to accompt: 'Tis as if a Bailiff ≈øhould ≈øay to his Lord, I have laid out ≈øo much Mony, and I will not accompt with you unle≈øs you will allow it; this is a Capitulation beforehand, and is very in≈øignificant by way of di≈øcharge.
They have each a remedy upon the≈øe mutual Covenants, and the provi≈øum & agreatÃÑ e≈øt doth not amount to a Condition, but is a Covenant; and Iudgment was given accordingly.
Iu≈øtice Ellis ≈øaid he had a Manu≈øcript Report of the Ca≈øe of Ware and Chappel, which he ≈øaid was adjudged upon great Debate.

div.head: Stoutfil's Ca≈øe.
div.p: PRohibition. Tythes not to be paid for Brick or Pidgeons. It was agreed clearly that no Tythes ought to be paid for Brick, becau≈øe 'tis part of the Soil, and ≈øo it has been often adjudged: And it was al≈øo ≈øaid that Tythes ≈øhall not be paid for Pidgeons, unle≈øs it be by ≈øpecial Cu≈øtom.

div.head: Columbel ver≈øus Columbel.
div.p: THE Plaintiff brought an Action of Debt upon a Bond of 500 l. Award pleaded under Seal and not under Hand, not good. The Defendant demands Oyer of the Bond and Condition, which was to ob≈øerve an Award of A. B. Arbitrator indifferently cho≈øen to determine all manner of Controver≈øies, Quarrels and Demands concerning the Title of certain Lands; ≈øo as the ≈øaid Award were made and put into writing under the Hand and Seal of the Arbitrator, &c. and then he pleads, that the Arbitrator made no Award.
The Plaintiff replies an Award by which ≈øuch things were to be done, and ≈øets it forth (in haec verba) under the Seal of the Arbitrator.
The Defendant rejoyns that the Arbitrator made no Award under his Hand and Seal according to the Condition of the Bond.

The Plaintiff demurrs; for that the Defendant ought to plead the Award under the Hand as well as the Seal of the Arbitrator;
for when he produces it in Court, as he doth by a profert hic in Curia, he mu≈øt plead it formally, as well as produce it; and Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Norris ver≈øus Tri≈øt.
div.p: Livery ≈øecundum formam Chartae, where good. IN a Special Verdict in Ejectment: The Ca≈øe was, A De√©d is made to thre√©, Habendum to two for their Lives, Remainder to the third for his Life, and Livery and Sei≈øin is made to all thr√©e ≈øecundum formam Chartae.
And whether the Livery ≈øo made, as if they had all E≈øtates in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, whereas in truth one of them had but an E≈øtate in Remainder was good, was the Que≈øtion.

On the one ≈øide it was ≈øaid by Serjeant Seys that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in this Ca≈øe was delivered according to the form of the De√©d within mentioned, which mu≈øt be to two for Life, Remainder to the third per≈øon, and Livery and Sei≈øin being only to accompli≈øh and perfect the Common A≈ø≈øurances of the Land ought to be taken favourably, ut res magis valeat quam pereat; and therefore if a Feoffment be made of two Acres, and a Letter of Attorny to give Livery, and the Attorny only enters into one Acre, and gives Livery ≈øecundum formam Chartae both the Acres pa≈øs,Dyer 131 40. Coke Litt. 52. a.

But on the other ≈øide Serjeant Maynard ≈øaid that there was ≈øomething more in this Ca≈øe than what had b√©en opened; for there was a Letter of Attorney made to give Livery to two, and in≈øtead of doing that he makes Livery to them all, which is no good Execution of his Authority, and therefore no Livery was made, the Authority not being pur≈øued.

As to the Ca≈øe in the 1≈øt In≈øtitutes my Lord Coke errs very much there in that di≈øcour≈øe, for in ≈øaying, that if there be a Feoffment of two Acres, and a Letter of Attorney to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of both, and he maketh Livery of both, but taketh po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion but of one, and that both pa≈øs, 'tis not Law; but if the Authority be general, as to make Livery and Sei≈øin, and he take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one, and then makes Livery of more ≈øecundum formam Chartae, that is good; and this is the difference taken in the Books, 5 Ed. 3. 65. 3 Ed. 3. 32. 43 Ed. 3. 32. 27 H. 8. 6.
The Remainder Man in this Ca≈øe is a m√©er Stranger to the Livery.

There is al≈øo a manife≈øt difference betw√©en a Matter of Intere≈øt, and an Execution of an Authority; for in the fir≈øt Ca≈øe it ≈øhall be con≈øtrued according to the Intere≈øt which either hath, but an Authority mu≈øt be ≈øtrictly pur≈øued.

The Court were all of Opinion that the Livery in this Ca≈øe was good to two for their Lives, Remainder to the third per≈øon.Curia. And the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that whatever the ancient Opinions were about pur≈øuing Authorities with great exactne≈øs and nicety, yet this Matter of Livery upon Endor≈øements of Writing was always favourably expounded of later times, unle≈øs where it plainly appeared that the Authority was not pur≈øued at all;Sid. 428. as if a Letter of Attorney be made to thr√©e joyntly and ≈øeverally, two cannot execute it, becau≈øe they are not the Parties delegated, they do not agre√© with the Authority: And Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: Richards ver≈øus Sely.
div.p: THIS was a Special Verdict in Ejectione firmae for Lands in the County of Cornwal: The Ca≈øe was this; viz. Covenant made to enjoy a Copyhold de anno in annum 'tis a Lea≈øe, and ≈øo a Forfeiture.

Thomas Sely was ≈øei≈øed of the Lands in que≈øtion for life, according the Cu≈øtom of the Mannor of P. and he together with one Peter Sely were bound in a Bond to a third per≈øon for the payment of 100 l. being the proper Debt of the ≈øaid Thomas, who gave Peter a Counter-bond to ≈øave him≈øelf harmle≈øs.

And that Thomas being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed did execute a D√©ed to Peter as a Collateral Security to indempnifie him for the payment of this 100 l. by which De√©d after a recital of the Counterbond given to Peter, and the E≈øtate which Thomas had in the Lands, he did covenant, grant and agree for him≈øelf, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns with the ≈øaid Peter, that he, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators ≈øhould hold and enjoy the≈øe Lands from the time of the making of the ≈øaid D√©ed for ≈øeven years, and ≈øo from the end of ≈øeven years to ≈øeven years, for and during the term of 49 years, if Thomas ≈øhould ≈øo long live.2 Cro. 301.
In which D√©ed there was a Covenant, that if the ≈øaid 100 l. ≈øhould be paid, and Peter ≈øaved harmle≈øs according to the Condition of the ≈øaid Counterbond, then the ≈øaid D√©ed to be void.
The Que≈øtion was whether this being in the Ca≈øe of Copyhold Lands will amount to a Lea≈øe thereof, and ≈øo make a Forfeiture of the Copyhold E≈øtate, there being no Cu≈øtom to warrant it.

Ex parte Quer.This Ca≈øe was argued this Term by Serjeant Pemberton for the Plaintiff; and in Trinity Term following by Serjeant Maynard on the ≈øame ≈øide, who ≈øaid that this was not a good Lea≈øe to entitle the Lord to a Forfeiture. It hath b√©en a general Rule, that the Word Covenant will make a Lea≈øe, though the Word Grant be omitted; nay a Licence to hold Land for a time without either of tho≈øe Words will amount to a Lea≈øe, much more when the Words are to 2 Cro. 92, 398. Noy 14. 1 Roll. Abr. 848, 849. Cro. Car. 207. have, hold and enjoy his Land for a Term certain; for tho≈øe are Words which give an Intere≈øt, and ≈øo it hath b√©en ruled in Ti≈ødale and Sir William E≈ø≈øex's Ca≈øe, which is reported by ≈øeveral, and is in Hob. 35. and 'tis now ≈øetled that an Action of Debt may be brought upon ≈øuch a Covenant.

And all this is regularly true in the Ca≈øe of a Fr√©ehold: But if the con≈øtruing of it to be a Lea≈øe will work a Wrong, then 'tis only a Covenant or Agre√©ment and no Intere≈øt ve≈øts, and therefore it ≈øhall never be intended a Lea≈øe in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe 'tis in the Ca≈øe of a Copyhold E≈øtate; for if it ≈øhould, there would be a Wrong done both to the Le≈ø≈øor and Le≈ø≈ø√©e; for it would be a Forfeiture of the E≈øtate of the one, and a defeating of the Security of the other.

It has be√©n generally u≈øed in ≈øuch Ca≈øes to con≈øider what was the intention of the Parties, and not to intend it a Lea≈øe again≈øt their meaning, for which there is an expre≈øs Authority, 2 Cro. 172. in the Ca≈øe of Evans and Thomas, Noy 128. in which Howel covenants with Morgan to make a Conveyance to him of Land by Fine, provided that if he pay Morgan 100 l. at the end of thirt√©en years, that then the u≈øe of the Fine ≈øhall be to the Congni≈øor, and covenants that Morgan ≈øhall enjoy the ≈øaid Lands for thirt√©en years, and for ever after if the 100 l. be not paid.

The A≈ø≈øurance was not made, and this was adjuged no Lea≈øe for thirt√©en years, becau≈øe it was the intent of the Parties to make an A≈ø≈øurance only in the nature of a Mortgage, which is but a Covenant.
And this appears likewi≈øe to be the intention of the Parties here, becau≈øe in the very Deed 'tis recited that the Lands are Copihold.
It al≈øo ≈øounds directly in Covenant, for 'tis that Peter ≈øhall or may enjoy without the lawful let or interruption of the Le≈ø≈øor.

All Agreements mu≈øt be con≈øtrued ≈øecundum ≈øubjectam materiam if the Matter will bear it, and in mo≈øt Ca≈øes are governed by the intention of the Parties and not to work a Wrong; and therefore if Tenant in Tail makes a Lea≈øe for Life, it ≈øhall be taken for his own Life; and yet if before the Statute of Entails he made ≈øuch
Lea≈øe, he being then Tenant in F√©e-≈øimple, it had been an E≈øtate during the Life of the Le≈ø≈ø√©e; but when the Statute had made it unlawful for him to bind his Heir, then the Law con≈øtrues it to be for his own Life, becau≈øe otherwi≈øe it would work a Wrong,Hob. 276. Co. Lit. 42.
So in this ca≈øe it ≈øhall not amount to a Lea≈øe for the manife≈øt inconveniency which would follow, but it ≈øhall be con≈øtrued as a Covenant, and then no injury is done.

On the Defendants part it was argued by Serjeant Newdigate, that though this was in the Ca≈øe of a Copyhold,Ex parte Def. that did not make any difference; for the plain meaning of the Parties was to make a Lea≈øe: But where the Words are doubtful and ≈øuch as may admit of diver≈øe con≈øtructions, whether they will amount to a Lea≈øe or not, there they ≈øhall be taken as a Covenant to prevent a Forfeiture.
So al≈øo if they are only In≈øtructions, as if a Man by Articles ≈øealed and delivered is contented to demi≈øe ≈øuch Lands, and a Rent is re≈øerved, and Covenants to repair, &c.

Or if one covenants with another to permit and ≈øuffer him to have and enjoy ≈øuch Lands,1 Rol. Abr. 848. the≈øe and ≈øuch like Words will not amount to a Lea≈øe, becau≈øe (as hath b√©en ≈øaid) the intention of the Parties is only to make it a Covenant; but here the Words are plain and can admit of no doubt.

But for an Authority in the Point the Lady2 Cro. 301. Mountagues Ca≈øe was cited, where it was adjudged, that if a Copyholder make a Lea≈øe for a year warranted by the Cu≈øtom, & ≈øic de anno in annum during ten years, 'tis a good Lea≈øe for ten years and a Forfeiture of the Copyhold E≈øtate, Vide Hill. 15 & 16 Car. 2. Rot. 233. the Ca≈øe of Holt and Thomas in this Court.

The Court inclined that it was a good Lea≈øe,Curia. and by con≈øequence a Forfeiture of the Copihold, and that a Licence in this Ca≈øe could not be ≈øuppo≈øed to prevent the Forfeiture, becau≈øe if that had been, the Iury would have found it; the meaning of the Parties mu≈øt make a Con≈øtruction here and that ≈øeems very ≈øtrong that 'tis a good Lea≈øe; but they gave no Iudgment.

div.head: Wilkin≈øon ver≈øus Sir Richard Lloyd.
div.p: Where the Parties ≈øhall join in an Action, where not.THE Defendant covenanted that he would not agre√© for the taking the Farm of the Exci≈øe of Beer and Ale for the County of York without the Con≈øent of the Plaintiff and another, and the Plaintiff alone brought this Action of Covenant, and a≈ø≈øigns for breach, the Defendants agr√©eing for the ≈øaid Exci≈øe without his Con≈øent, upon which the Plaintiff had a Verdict and 1000 l. damages given.

And Serjeant Pemberton moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, for that an Action of Covenant would not lie in this Ca≈øe by the Plaintiff alone, becau≈øe he ought to have joined with the other, both of them having a joint Intere≈øt, and ≈øo is Sling≈øby's Ca≈øe 5 Co. If a Bond is made to two joyntly and ≈øeverally they mu≈øt both join in an Action of Debt, ≈øo here 'tis a joint contract, and both mu≈øt be Plaintiffs: So al≈øo if one covenants with two to pay each of them 20 l. they mu≈øt both join.

'Tis true, in Sling≈øbies Ca≈øe 'twas held if an A≈ø≈øurance is made to A. of White Acre, and to B. of Black Acre, and to C. of Green Acre, and a Covenant with them and every of them, the≈øe la≈øt Words make the Covenant ≈øeveral.

But here is nothing of a ≈øeveral intere≈øt, no more than that one covenants with two, that he will not join in a Lea≈øe without their Con≈øent, ≈øo that their Intere≈øt not being divided the Covenant ≈øhall be entire and taken according to the fir≈øt Words, to be a joint Covenant; and the rather, becau≈øe if the Plaintiff may maintain this Action alone, the other may bring a ≈øecond Action, and the Defendant will be ≈øubject to entire damages which may be given in both.

Judgment.But the Court was of another Opinion, that here was no joint Intere≈øt but that each of the Covenantees might maintain an Action for his particular damages, or otherwi≈øe one of them might be remedile≈øs; for ≈øuppo≈øe one of them had given his Con≈øent that the Defendant ≈øhould farm this Exci≈øe, and had ≈øecretly received ≈øome ≈øatisfaction or recompence for ≈øo doing, is it rea≈øonable that the other ≈øhould lo≈øe his remedy who never did con≈øent, For which rea≈øon the Plaintiff had his Iudgment.

div.head: Page ver≈øus Tul≈øe Mil' & alios Vic' Midd'.
div.p: THE Plaintiff brought an Action on the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Sheriff for a fal≈øe Return,Ca≈øe lies not again≈øt the Sheriff for returning a Cepi Corpus & paratum habeo, though the Party doth not appear. Mod. Rep. 239. Ellis and Yarborough, po≈øt. ≈øetting forth that he ≈øued a Capias out of this Court directed to the Sheriff of Middle≈øex, by vertue whereof he arre≈øted the Party, and took Bail for his appearance, and at the day of the Return of the Writ the Sheriff returned Cepi corpus & paratum habeo, but he had not the Body there at the Return of the Writ, but ≈øuffered him to e≈øcape.
The Defendant pleads the Statute of 23 H. 6. cap. 10. and ≈øaith that he took Bail, viz. two ≈øufficient Sureties, and ≈øo let him go at large, &c.
The Plaintiff demurrs; and whether this Action lies again≈øt the Defendant was the Que≈øtion, who refu≈øed to proceed again≈øt him by way of Amerciament, or to take an A≈ø≈øignment of the Bail-Bond.

This Ca≈øe depended in Court ≈øeveral Terms. It was argued by Serjeant Pemberton and Serjeant Coniers for the Plaintiff, and by Serjeant George Strode for the Defendant; and Iudgment was given in Ea≈øter Term in the 29th year of this King.
In the Argument for the Defendant that this Action would not lie it was con≈øidered,Ex parte Def.
1. What the Common Law was before the making of this Statute.
2. What alteration thereof the Statute had made.

At the Common Law Men were to appear per≈øonally to an≈ø≈øwer the Writ, the Form of which required it, and no Attorney could be made in any Action till Edw. 1. de gratia ≈øpeciali gave leave to his Subjects to appoint them and commanded his Iudges to admit them, 2 In≈øt. 377. After the Arre≈øt the Sheriff mighttie the Party to what Conditions he plea≈øed, and he might keep him till he had complied with ≈øuch Conditions, which often ended in taking extravagant Bonds, and ≈øometimes in other Oppre≈ø≈øions, for remedy whereof this Statute was made, in which the Clau≈øe that concerns this Ca≈øe is, viz. If the Sheriff return upon any per≈øon Cepi Corpus or Reddidit ≈øe, that he ≈øhall be chargeable to have the Body at the day of the Return of the Writ in ≈øuch form as before the making the Act; ≈øo that as to the Return of the Writ this Statute hath made no alteration, the Sheriff being bound to have the Party at a day as before.

All the alteration made of the Common Law by this Statute is that the Sheriff now is bound to let the Party out of Pri≈øon upon rea≈øonable Sureties of ≈øufficient per≈øons, which before he was not obliged to do; and it would be a Ca≈øe of great hard≈øhip upon all the Sheriffs of England, if they (being compellable to let out the Party to Bail) ≈øhould al≈øo be ≈øubject to an Action for ≈øo doing, becau≈øe they have him not at the day; ≈øo that the intent of the Law mu≈øt be (when it charges the Sheriff to have the Body at the Return) that he ≈øhould be liable to a Penalty if the Party did not then appear, not to be recovered by Action but by Amerciament.

Cro. Jac. 286.The Security directed by this Act is to be taken in the Sheriffs own Name; 'tis properly his bu≈øine≈øs and for his own Indempnity, and therefore it is left wholly in his power; for which rea≈øon no Action will lie again≈øt him for taking in≈øufficient Bail, that being to his own prejudice, in which the Plaintiff is no wi≈øe concerned; for if that had be√©n intended by the Act ≈øome Provi≈øion would have be√©n made as to his being ≈øatisfied in the ≈øufficiency of the Per≈øons.

When the Security is thus taken, if the Defendant doth not appear at the Return of the Writ, the Plaintiff by Amerciaments ≈øhall compel him to bring in the Body, or to a≈ø≈øign the Bond, either of which is a full ≈øatisfaction and as much as is required.

If the Sheriff refu≈øe to take2 Sand. 59, 154 1 Roll. Abr. 807, 808. Cro. Eliz. 460, 852. Noy 39. Moor 428. Sid. 23. ≈øufficient Sureties, when offered, he is liable to an Action on the Ca≈øe at the Suit of the Defendant for his refu≈øal; and it would be very unrea≈øonable to enforce him to have the Party in Court at the Return, when he is obliged under a Penalty to let him at large.

This Action is grounded upon a fal≈øe Return, when in truth there is no Return made, or if any, 'tis a very imperfect Return till the Body be in Court; and this is the rea≈øon why the Court will not allow it, but amerce the Sheriff till he make the Party appear; 'tis not like a compleat Return, as a Non e≈øt inventus, or the Return of Nulla Bona upon a Fi. Fa.

The Ca≈øe of
‚Ä¢ Roll Abr. 93 pl. 17. Po≈øtea. Bowls and La≈ø≈øels is full in the Point, where it was adjudged that this Action would not lie, becau≈øe the Sheriff had not done any thing unju≈øtly, but what he was commanded to do by the Statute, and therefore he is to be amerced if the Defendant doth not appear.
Ex parte Quer.But for the Plaintiff it was ≈øaid, that unle≈øs this Action lye he is remedile≈øs, and that for two Rea≈øons:
1. Becau≈øe the A≈ø≈øignment of the Bail Bond is at the di≈øcretion of the Court, and not demandable by the Plaintiff in foro.

2. The Plaintiff hath no benefit by the Amerciaments, becau≈øe they go to the King, and in ≈øome places are granted to Patente√©s; now 'tis agre√©d that the Sheriff may be amerced, and certainly if an Action be brought again≈øt him he is but in the ≈øame Ca≈øe, for ≈øtill he is to pay: And if it be objected, that the Amerciaments may be compounded cheaper, then the Plaintiff hath not ≈øo good remedy, nor is ≈øo likely to recover his Debt, as if the Action would lie, which would be a greater penalty upon him than the Amerciaments on the Sheriff.

Neither will it follow that becau≈øe the Sheriff may be amerced therefore no Action will lie again≈øt him; for in many Ca≈øes he may be amerced, and yet an Action on the Ca≈øe will lie again≈øt him at the Suit of the Party, 41 A≈ø≈ø. pl. 12. fol. 254. Latch 187.

That this Action will not lie is again≈øt the very end of the Statute, and the rea≈øonable con≈øtruction thereof in the la≈øt Clau≈øe, which Enacts, That if the Sheriff return a Cepi Corpus, he ≈øhall be charged to have the Body at the Return as before the making of the Statute; now before this Law he was lyable to an Action, if after ≈øuch a Return made the Party did not appear, and therefore this Action being grounded upon the Common Law, is ≈øtill pre≈øerved ≈øince no alteration hereof hath be√©n made by this Statute.

'Tis true an Action of E≈øcape is taken away, but not an Action on the Ca≈øe for a fal≈øe Return, and upon this difference are all the Authorities cited on the other ≈øide, as Cro. Eliz. 416, 621. Cro. Jac. 286. Moor 428. and the Ca≈øe of Bowls and La≈ø≈øels.

And for an Authority in Point is the Ca≈øe of Franklin and Andrews 24 Car. 1. where Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff in an Action brought for a fal≈øe Return of Cepi Corpus; and the Statute pleaded as in this Ca≈øe. It has b√©en objected that Iudgment was there given upon the defect of Pleading, becau≈øe the Traver≈øe was naught; 'tis true there was a Traver≈øe, ab≈øque hoc quod the Defendant retornavit aliter vel alio modo; but that was held good becau≈øe it an≈øwered the fal≈øo alledged in the Plaintiffs Declaration: In this Ca≈øe there is no Traver≈øe, but 'tis confe≈ø≈øed by the Demurrer that he did fal≈øly and deceitfully return Cepi Corpus, and ≈øo the Plaintiff is at apparent damage and hath no remedy without this Action, and the Defendant is at no prejudice but hath his remedy over on the Bail Bond.

North Chief Iu≈øtice, Wyndham and Atkins Iu≈øtices,Judgment. held that the Action would not lie; for when the Sheriff returns Cepi Corpus & paratum habeo, though he have him not in Court 'tis
no fal≈øe Return; for if he hath taken Bail, he hath done what by Law he ought to do; if he Arre≈øt a Man in York≈øhire, the Law will not compel him to bring the Party hither to the Bar, becau≈øe of the charge; if he make an in≈øufficient Return, neither the Party or the Court are deluded, becau≈øe the common method in ≈øuch ca≈øes mu≈øt be pur≈øued, by which the Party will have remedy. This Return is true; and Iu≈øtice Atkyns held, that the Sheriff was not obliged by the Statute to return only a Cepi Corpus & paratum habeo, but might return, that he took Bail; for the Statute provides, that if he return a Cepi Corpus, he ≈øhall be chargable as before, but doth not enjoyn him to make ≈øuch return; the Ca≈øe of Bowles and La≈ø≈øels is full in this point, and therefore Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

But Iu≈øtice Scroggs was of another Opinion; ≈øays he, this Action being brought becau≈øe the Defendant ≈øaid he had the Body ready, when in truth he had not, was an apparent injury to the Plaintiff, of whom the Statute mu≈øt have ≈øome con≈øideration; for it doth not require the Sheriff to ≈øay Cepi corpus & paratum habeo, but he mu≈øt make his Return good, or otherwi≈øe tho≈øe words are very in≈øignificant; and if the Statute obliges him to let the party to Bail, and nothing more is thereby intended for the benefit of the Plaintiff, why doth the Court amerce the Sheriff, and puni≈øh him for doing what the Statute directs? Therefore if the Plaintiff brings a Habeas Corpus upon the Cepi, and the Defendant doth not appear the Plaintiff, is then well entituled to this Action.

div.head: Hollis ver≈øus Carre, in Cancellaria.
div.p: Decree of the Execution of a Fine in ≈øpecie.THE Lord Chancellor Finch having called to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance Iu≈øtice Wild and Iu≈øtice Windham, to give their Opinions what relief the Plaintiff was to have for the recovering of 6000 l. which was his Ladys Portion. After tho≈øe Iudges had ≈øpoken ≈øhortly to the matter, he put the Ca≈øe: Viz. The Plaintiff by his Bill demands 6000 l. due to him for his Wives Portion, with Intere≈øt for non-payment, according to the purport of certain Articles of Agreement, dated in Augu≈øt 1661. and mentioned to be made between old Sir Robert Carr (the Defendants Father) his Lady and Son (the now Defendant) and Lucy Carr his Daughter, on the one part, and my Lord Hollis and Sir Francis his Son (the now Plaintiff) on the other part.

The Articles mention an Agreement of a Marriage to be had between the ≈øaid Sir Francis Hollis and Lucy Carr, with Covenants on the Plaintiffs ≈øide to ≈øettle a Ioynture, &c. and on the other ≈øide to pay 6000 l. and 'tis agreed in the Articles, that a Fine was intended to be levied of ≈øuch Lands, &c. for ≈øecuring the payment of 6000 l. &c.
The Marriage takes effect, but old Sir Robert Carr did never Seal the≈øe Articles; the Lady Carr Seals before, and the Defendant after Marriage.
Sir Francis had I≈ø≈øue on his Lady Lucy, one Child ≈øince dead; the Lady is likewi≈øe dead; the Ioynture was not made, nor the Portion paid.

Afterward, viz. Anno 1664. an Act of Parliament was made for ≈øetling old Sir Robert Carr's E≈øtate, whereby the Tru≈øte√©s therein named, are appointed to ≈øell it for payment of Debts, and rai≈øing this Portion; by which Act all Conveyances made by old Sir Robert Carr, ≈øince the year 1639. are made void, except ≈øuch as were made upon valuable con≈øiderations; but all tho≈øe made by him before the ≈øaid year, with power of revocation (if not actually revoked) are ≈øaved; and in the year 1636. he had executed a Conveyance, by which he had made a Settlement of his E≈øtate in Tayl, with a power of revocation; but it did not appear that he did ever revoke the ≈øame.

The greate≈øt part of the Lands appointed by this Act of Parliament, to be ≈øold by the Tru≈øtees, are the Lands compri≈øed in that Settlement; and now, after the death of Sir Robert Carr, the Plaintiff exhibits his Bill again≈øt the Son, (not knowing that ≈øuch a Settlement was made in the year 1636. till the Defendant had ≈øet it forth in his An≈øwer:) and by this Bill he de≈øires that the Tru≈øtees may execute their Tru≈øt, &c. and that he may have relief.

On the Defendants ≈øide it was urged,Ex parte Def. that after the Marriage there was a Bond given for an additional Ioynture, and it was upon that account that the Defendant was drawn in to execute the≈øe Articles: And if the very rea≈øon and foundation of his entring into them failed, then they ≈øhall not bind him in Equity; and in this Ca≈øe it did fail, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had di≈øabled him≈øelf to make any other Ioynture, by a Pre-conveyance made and executed by him, of his whole E≈øtate; and if this agreement will not bind him, then this Court cannot enlarge the Plaintiffs remedy, or appoint more than what by the Articles is agreed to be done; neither can the Defendants ≈øealing incumber the E≈øtate Tayl in Equity, becau≈øe the Lands were
not then in him, his Father being Tenant in Tayl, and then living; and the ≈øub≈øequent de≈øcent by which the Lands are ca≈øt upon him, alters not the Ca≈øe; for the very right which de≈øcends is ≈øaved by the Act from being charged.

But on the other ≈øide it was argued, that though the Marriage did proceed upon the Defendants ≈øealing, yet the A≈ø≈øurance which was to be made, was a principal Motive thereunto; and it being agreed before Marriage, though not executed, it was very ju≈øt that he ≈øhould Seal afterwards; and though the additional Ioynture was not made, yet there was no colour that the Defendant ≈øhould break his Articles, for that rea≈øon; becau≈øe if the Bond be not performed, 'tis forfeited and may be ≈øued; and nothing appeared in the ca≈øe, of any Conveyance made by Sir Francis, whereby he had di≈øabled him≈øelf to make an additional Ioynture, and he hath expre≈øly denied it upon his Oath. And though it was was objected, that the Money was rai≈øed by the old Lady Carr, and by the direction of the Tru≈øtees lodged in the hands of one Cook, who is become in≈øolvent; It was an≈øwered that there was no proof of the con≈øent of the Tru≈øtees, and therefore this payment cannot alter the ca≈øe.

After the matter thus ≈øtated, the Lord Chancellor delivered his Opinion, That the 6000 l. is doe to the Plaintiff, unpaid and un≈øatisfied; for though the Marriage had not taken effect, yet the Covenant binds the Defendant, becau≈øe a Deed is good for a Duty, without any con≈øideration.
2. The Plaintiff has remedy again≈øt the per≈øon of the Defendant at Law, for this 6000 l.
3. He has remedy again≈øt ≈øuch of the Defendants Lands, which are not compri≈øed in the Settlement made 1636. for as to them the Tru≈øtees may be enjoyned to execute the Tru≈øt.
And he de≈øired the Opinions of the two Iu≈øtices, if any thing more could be done in this ca≈øe.
Iu≈øtice Windham was of Opinion, that nothing more could be done, but to make a Decree to enforce the execution of the Tru≈øt.

And Iu≈øtice Wild ≈øaid, that the Plaintiff has his remedy at Law again≈øt the Defendant, and upon the Act of Parliament again≈øt the Tru≈øtees; but upon the≈øe Articles no Decree could be made to bind the Lands, for that would be to give a much better ≈øecurity than the Parties had agreed on. But if there had
been a Covenant in the Articles, that a Fine ≈øhould be levied, it might have been otherwi≈øe; 'tis only that a Fine is intended to be levied.

But as to that the Lord Chancellor was of Opinion, that it was a good Covenant to levy a Fine, for the words (Articles of Agreement, &c.) go quite through, and make that Clau≈øe a Covenant; but becau≈øe Iu≈øtice Wild was of another Opinion, he de≈øired the Attorny General to argue the≈øe three Points.
1. Whether this was a Covenant to levy a Fine or not.
2. If it was a Covenant, whether this Court can decree him to do it, for though the Party has a good remedy at Law; yet whether this Court might not give remedy upon the Land.

3. If it was a Covenant to levie a Fine, and the Court may decree the Defendant to do it, yet whether ≈øuch a Decree can be made upon the prayer of this Bill, it not being particularly prayed; for the Plaintiff concluded his Bill, with praying relief in the execution of the Tru≈øt, &c.

In Trinity-Term following the≈øe Points were argued by Serjeant Maynard, Sir John Churchil, and Sir John King for the Plaintiff; Mr. Attorny and Mr. Solicitor, and Mr. Keck for the Defendant, all in one day, and in the ≈øame order as named.

The Councel for the Defendant urged,Ex parte Def. that this was no Covenant in Law to enforce the Defendant to levy a Fine: 'Tis agre√©d that there is no need of the word (Covenant) to make a Covenant; but any thing under the Hand and Seal of the Parties, which imports an Agreement, will amount to a Covenant; ≈øo in 1 Roll. Abr. 518. the≈øe words in a Lea≈øe for years, viz. That the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall repair, make a Covenant; ≈øo in the Ca≈øe of Indentures of Apprenti≈øhip there are not the formal words of a Covenant, but only an Agreement that the Ma≈øter ≈øhall do this, and the Apprentice ≈øhall do that, and the≈øe are Covenants; but in all the≈øe Ca≈øes there is ≈øomething of an undertaking; as in 1 Roll 519. Walker ver≈øus Walker, If a Deed be made to another in the≈øe words, viz. I have a Writing in my cu≈øtody, in which W. ≈øtandeth bound to B. in 100 l. and I will be ready to produce it; This is a Covenant, for there is a pre≈øent engaging to do it, but there are no ≈øuch words here, 'tis only a recital, That whereas a Fine is intended to be levied to ≈øuch U≈øes, &c. 'Tis only Introductive to another Clau≈øe, without po≈øitive or affirmative words, and therefore can never be intended to make a Covenant, but are
recited to another purpo≈øe, viz. To declare the U≈øe of a Fine, in ca≈øe ≈øuch ≈øhould be levied.

If Articles of Agreement are executed in con≈øideration of an intended Marriage, and one ≈øide Covenants to do one thing, and the other ≈øide another thing; was it ever imagined that upon the≈øe words, (Whereas a Marriage is intended, &c.) that an Action of Covenant might be brought to enforce the Marriage: And yet there is as much rea≈øon for the one as the other; therefore ≈øince the Parties have neither made nor intended it for a Covenant, 'tis not nece≈ø≈øary that it ≈øhould be ≈øo con≈øtrued.

If this is a Covenant, the Parties at Common Law could only bring an Action of Covenant, and recover damages for not levying of the Fine, and that the Plaintiff may do now upon the expre≈øs Covenant for non-payment of the Money; but then the breach mu≈øt be a≈ø≈øigned according to the words, viz. That the Defendant did not levy a Fine as intended; who may plead that a Fine was never intended to be levied, and by what Iury ≈øhall this be tryed?
It may be objected, that every Article ≈øtands upon its own bottom, and the Title of them (being Articles of Agreement,) extends to every Paragraph.

But as to that, each of the≈øe Articles is to be con≈øidered by it ≈øelf; and every Paragraph begins, viz it is Covenanted, &c. which ≈øhews it was never intended to make it a Covenant, by the Title of the Articles, and the rather, becau≈øe 'tis unrea≈øonable to make ≈øuch a con≈øtruction; for it is not to be ≈øuppo≈øed that a Man will covenant that a Fine ≈øhall be levied, as in this Ca≈øe, by A. and B. and him≈øelf, when 'tis not in his power to compel another.

2. Admitting it to be a Covenant, yet it would be very hard to decree the execution of a Fine in Specie; for the Father of the Defendant was alive when he executed the Deed, and the Father being Tenant in Tayl, who never ≈øealed, the Son could have no pre≈øent Right, who did Seal; and if matters had ≈øtood now as then, how could a Court of Equity Decree a Fine, by which a Right might be extingui≈øhed, but could never be tran≈øferred, and by which no u≈øe could be declared? For though ≈øuch a Fine be good by E≈øtoppel, before the Tayl de≈øcends to the I≈ø≈øue; yet no u≈øe can be declared thereupon, nor upon any Fine by E≈øtoppel; and there is no rea≈øon why length of time ≈øhould put the Plaintiff into a better condition than he was when the Articles were executed.

3. And la≈øtly, ≈øince here is a particular relief prayed in no wi≈øe concerning the levying of this Fine, but only a Relief in the Execution of the Tru≈øt, this Court cannot Decree the Defendant to levy one, it being again≈øt the con≈øtant cour≈øe and rules thereof.

But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid by the Plaintiffs Council, that the words do declare the intent of the Parties,Ex parte Quer. that a Fine ≈øhall be levied; and 'tis the Intent which makes the Agreement; and where there is an Agreement an Action of Covenant will lye.

If a Man Covenant to do ≈øuch a thing in con≈øideration of a Marriage, and then there is this Clau≈øe, viz. Whereas it is intended that he ≈øhall Marry before Michaelmas, that then, &c. certainly upon the whole Deed here is a good Covenant to marry before Michaelmas.

In this Ca≈øe 'tis Covenanted, that 6000 l. ≈øhall be paid, and that it ≈øhall be ≈øecured as herein is after mentioned; then 'tis declared, that a Fine is intended to be levied for that purpo≈øe, this is a good Covenant to make a Security by a Fine.

But if the particular manner how the the Security was to be made had been omitted, yet upon the words (Covenant to ≈øecure it,) the Court hath a good ground to make a Decree to levy a Fine, that being the only way to ≈øecure it.

2. As to the Objection, that the Defendant had but a po≈ø≈øibility of having the E≈øtate when he entred into this Couenant, (admitting it to be ≈øo) yet why ≈øhould that be a rea≈øon to hinder him from making good the Security when he hath it; if Father and Son Covenant to make an A≈ø≈øurance, the Father who had the E≈øtate in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion dies, the Decree mu≈øt then operate upon that E≈øtate in the hands of the Son.
3. Here is a general prayer for a proper relief, in which the Plaintiffs Ca≈øe is included, and therefore prayed Iudgment for him.

The Lord Chancellor,Curia. pre≈øently after the Arguments on each ≈øide, delivered his Opinion, That upon the whole frame of the Articles there was a Covenant to levy a Fine; for wherever there is an Agreement under Hand and Seal, Covenant lies; that in this Ca≈øe there was a plain Covenant, if the fir≈øt Article of giving farther ≈øecurity, be coupled to that Paragraph of intending to levy a Fine, for that is the farther ≈øecurity intended, ≈øo that the meaning of the Parties runs thus; I do intend to levy a Fine, which is for the Securing of 6000 l. and this appears to be their Agreement. Now there are many Ca≈øes where words
will make a Covenant, becau≈øe of the Agreement, when the general words of Covenant, Grant, &c. are wanting; asHays ver≈øus Bicker≈øtaff. Antea & Po≈øtea. Cook ver≈øus Herl. Yielding and Paying will make a Covenant, for the rea≈øons afore≈øaid.

And therefore the Party having provided him≈øelf of real as well as per≈øonal Security, by the≈øe Articles, he ≈øaid he would not deprive him of it; e≈øpecially when it might be more trouble to bring an Action of Covenant for the not levying of the Fine, for upon that many Que≈øtions might ari≈øe, as who ≈øhould do the fir≈øt act, &c. for which rea≈øons he decreed the execution of the Fine in Specie.

div.head: DE Term. Sanctae Trin. Anno 28 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Ingram ver≈øus Tothill.
div.p: REplevin: The Ca≈øe was;Ju≈øtification ill. 1 Vent. 314. Mod. Rep. 216 Po≈øtea. A Man made a Lea≈øe for 99 years, if A. B. and C. ≈øhould ≈øo long live, rendring an Herriot after the death of each of them ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, as they are all three named in the Deed; the la≈øt named died fir≈øt; and if an Herriot ≈øhould be paid, was the Que≈øtion.

Stroud Serjeant urged, that it ≈øhould not, becau≈øe the re≈øervation is the Le≈ø≈øors Creature, and therefore to be taken ≈øtrongly again≈øt him: As if Rent be re≈øerved to him and hisPer North, a Devi≈øee is not A≈ø≈øignee to take. A≈ø≈øigns, or to him and his Executors, the Heir ≈øhall not have it: So is the Authority in 33 Eliz. Owen 9. Reddend to the Le≈ø≈øor, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators durante termino 21 Annorum &c. the Heir ≈øhall not have the Rent, becau≈øe 'tis not re≈øerved to him.5 Co. 35. Latch 274.

In this Ca≈øe the Herriot is re≈øerved if the three dye ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, and the Le≈ø≈øor is contented to tru≈øt to that Contingency. Reddend' annuatim duran' termino praedict' to the Le≈ø≈øor and his A≈ø≈øigns, the Heir ≈øhall have it, though not named, Latch 99. 2 Sand. 367.

As to this Point the Court gave no Opinion, but Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff upon the pleading, becau≈øe the Defendant had ju≈øtified the taking of a Di≈øtre≈øs, by vertue of a Lea≈øe for a Term of years, if three live ≈øo long, and did not aver that any of the Lives were in being.
2. He ≈øets forth that one of them was ≈øei≈øed, and being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed dyed, but doth not ≈øay obiit inde ≈øei≈øitÃÑ, and the≈øe were held incurable faults.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: Exceptions to the Count in a Formedon in Di≈øcender. Mod. Rep. 219. 8 Co. 88.IN a Formedon in Di≈øcender: The Tenants by Turner Serjeant, of Council with them, took three Exceptions to the Count.

1. The Demandant (being Brother to the Tenant in Tail who died without I≈ø≈øue) ≈øets forth that the Land belonged to him po≈øt mortem of the Tenant in Tail, without ≈øaying that he died without I≈ø≈øue: In the ancient Regi≈øter in a Formedon 'tis pleaded that the Tenant in Tail died without I≈ø≈øue, and ≈øo it is in Co. Entr. 254. b. Ra≈øt. Entr. 341. b. quae po≈øt mortem of the Donee reverti debeant, eo quod the Donee obiit ≈øine haerede; all the Pre≈øidents are ≈øo, 9 E. 4. 36.

2. The Demandant makes as if there were two Heirs of one Man, which cannot be pleaded, for he counts that his elde≈øt Brother was Heir to his Father, and that after his death he is now Heir, which cannot be, for none is Heir to the Father but the elde≈øt Son, and therefore when they are both dead without I≈ø≈øue the next Brother is Heir to him who was la≈øt ≈øei≈øed, and not to the Father, and then he ought to be named, which is not done in this Ca≈øe, Hern's Pleader fol.

'Tis true, in a Formedon in Reverter (the Tail being ≈øpent) the Donor ought not to name in his Count every I≈ø≈øue inheritable to the Tail, becau≈øe he may not know the Pedigree; and therefore 'tis well enough for him to ≈øay quae po≈øt mortem of the Donee ad ip≈øum reverti debeant, eo quod he died without I≈ø≈øue; but in a Formedon in Di≈øcender 'tis pre≈øumed that the Demandant knowns the de≈øcent, and therefore he ought to name every one to whom any Right did di≈øcend, Jenkins and Daw≈øon's Ca≈øe. Hetley 78. Dyer 216.

3. The Demandant hath not ≈øet forth that he is Heir of J. begotten on the Body of his Wife,1 In≈øt. 326. which he ≈øhould have done becau≈øe this being in the Di≈øcender he mu≈øt make him≈øelf I≈ø≈øue to the Tail.

Ex parte Def.The≈øe Exceptions were an≈øwered by Serjeant Seys; and as to fir≈øt he ≈øaid, that in a Formedon in De≈øcender he ne√©d not to ≈øet forth that the Tenant in Tail died without I≈ø≈øue, which he agreed mu≈øt be done in a Formedon in Remainder or Reverter, 39 E. 3. 27. Old Entr. tit. Formedon pl. 3. 7 H. 7. 7. b. a Ca≈øe expre≈øs in the Point.

To the ≈øecond Exception he ≈øaid, that it was no Repugnancy in Pleading to ≈øay that two were Heirs to one Man, for they may be ≈øo at ≈øeveral times, and ≈øo it appears to be in this Ca≈øe, ≈øince 'tis ≈øaid po≈øt mortem of his Brother who was Heir.

To the third Exception, 'Tis well ≈øet forth that the Demandant was the I≈ø≈øue of Ingram begotten of the Body of Jane; for he ≈øaith his Brother was ≈øo, and after his death he was Brother and Heir of him, which is impo≈ø≈øible to be unle≈øs he was begotten as afore≈øaid; and of this Opinion were all the Court, viz. Judgment. That 'tis well enough ≈øet forth, that the Tenant in Tail died without I≈ø≈øue; for if he had any Children alive it could not di≈øcend to the Demandant as Brother and Heir, which he hath alledged; and they all agreed the difference between a Formedon in the Di≈øcender, Remainder and Reverter. And as to the ≈øecond Exception there is no contradiction to ≈øay two are Heirs to one tempore divi≈øo. And the la≈øt Exception had no force in it. But then it was ob≈øerved that the Demandant in his Writ had ≈øet out his Title after the death of the Tenant in Tail, and in the Count 'tis only Quae po≈øt mortem, &c. But to that it was a≈øwered it relates to the Writ, and what is therein ≈øhall ≈øupply the Et caetera in the Count.

div.head: Woodward ver≈øus A≈øton in Banco Regis.
div.p: INdebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit for 10 l. in Mony received to the Plaintiffs u≈øe, and upon a Trial at Barr this Term:Joint Office for life and to the Survivor, one con≈øents that another ≈øhall be admitted, 'tis a Surrender. 1 Ventris 296. The Ca≈øe upon Evidence was, viz.

Sir Robert Henly Prothonotary of the Court of Kings Bench makes a Grant of the Office of Clark of the Papers (which of right did belong to him) unto Mr. Vidian and Mr. Woodward for their lives and the life of the longe≈øt liver of them.

Afterwards Mr. Vidian makes a parol Surrender of this Grant, and then Sir Robert Henley makes a new Grant to Mr. Woodward and Mr. A≈øton the Defendant for their Lives, and for the life of the Survivor: Mr. Vidian dies, and whether the Plaintiff Woodward ≈øhould have all the profits of the Office by Survivor≈øhip was the Que≈øtion.
It was agreed that this was one entire Office; and as one of them cannot make a Deputy ≈øo he cannot appoint a Succe≈ø≈øor.

But the doubt was whether the Plaintiff had not con≈øented that the Defendant ≈øhould be taken into the Office, and had agreed to the new Grant which was made afterwards; for it was
admitted that if he con≈øented before Mr. A≈øton came in, it mu≈øt then be found for the Defendant; for by his con≈øent he had barred him≈øelf of his Right and Benefit of Survivor≈øhip, and that by his con≈øenting to the new Grant that in Law was a Surrender of the fir≈øt Grant, and then the Defendant is jointenant with the Plaintiff, and if ≈øo, his Action is not maintainable.
And upon the≈øe two Points only it was left to the Iury, who found for the Defendant.

The Evidence to the fir≈øt Point was, that when Mr. Vidian propo≈øed to the Court that the Defendant might ≈øucceed him, after ≈øome oppo≈øition and unwillingne≈øs in the Plaintiff to agre√© to it; yet at length he declared that he did ≈øubmit to it, and accordingly the Defendant was admitted; but there was no formal Entry of his Admittance as an Officer, but only the Courts declaring their Con≈øent that he ≈øhould take his place.

Ex parte Quer.On the other ≈øide it was in≈øi≈øted on for the Plaintiff and proved that his Submi≈ø≈øion to the Court was with a ≈øalvo jure, and what he did was reluctante animo, thinking it was a hard≈øhip upon him, as he often ≈øince declared; ≈øo that it was qua≈øi a compul≈øory Con≈øent made in obedience to the Court with whom it was not good manners in him to contend.
Several Points were ≈øtirred at the Trial, as,
1. Whether a Surrender of the Grant of an Office by Parol was good.

2. Whether if a Grant be made of an Office or of any other thing which lies in Grant, and the Deed is lo≈øt or cancelled, the Office or the thing granted falls to the ground, for the Deed is the foundation; and a Ca≈øe was cited in the Lord Dyer; If there be two Iointenants and one cancels the Deed it hath de≈øtroyed the Right of the other, Quaere of the≈øe things: But it was agreed, that if two Men who have one Office for their Lives and the ≈øurvivor of them, if one ≈øurrenders to the other, and then a new Grant is made to this other and a Stranger, he hath debarred him≈øelf of the Survivor≈øhip, and he and the Stranger are jointly ≈øei≈øed.

div.head: Cro≈øsman ver≈øus Sir John Churchil.
div.p: IN a Quare Impedit the Plaintiffs Title was ≈øet forth in his Declaration, which was al≈øo found in a Special Verdict,Where an Agreement for a Pre≈øentation by turns is good. that Sir George Rodney was ≈øei≈øed of the Advow≈øon in F√©e, and died ≈øei≈øed, leaving two Si≈øters who were his Coheirs; that Sir John Rodney being al≈øo one of the ≈øame Family and pretending a Right to the E≈øtate, for preventing Suits that might happen, they all enter into an Agr√©ement by Indentures mutually executed, by which it was agreed, that Sir John Rodney ≈øhall hold ≈øome Lands in ≈øeveralty, and the Co-heirs ≈øhall hold other Lands in the like manner; and as for this Advow≈øon a temporary provi≈øion was made thereof, that each of them ≈øhould Pre≈øent by turns, and this was to continue till partition could be made; then comes an Act of Parliament and confirms the Indenture, and Enacts, That every Agreement therein contained ≈øhall ≈øtand, and that all the re≈øt of the Lands not particularly named and otherwi≈øe di≈øpo≈øed by the ≈øaid Indenture ≈øhould be held by the≈øe three in common; one of the three, who by Agr√©ement was next to Pre≈øent, grants the next Avoidance (the Church being then full) to the Plaintiff, and the Que≈øtion was, whether the≈øe thre√© per≈øons were not Tenants in Common of the Advow≈øon, and if ≈øo, then the Grant of the next Avoidance cannot be good by one alone, becau≈øe he hath not the whole Advow≈øon, but only a Right to the third part.
It was ≈øaid, that if Tenants in Common had made ≈øuch an Agre√©ment it would not have be√©n any divi≈øion of their intere≈øt; for there mu≈øt be a partition to ≈øever the Inheritance.

The Court were all of Opinion,Curia. that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff; for there was an Agr√©ement that there ≈øhall be a Pre≈øentation by turns, and therefore for one turn each hath a Right to the whole Advow≈øon by rea≈øon of the Act of Parliament by which that Agreement is confirmed, and thereby an Intere≈øt is ≈øetled in each of them till Partition made; but this Agreement would have ve≈øted no Intere≈øt in either of them without an Act of Parliament to corroborate it; therefore there had been no remedy upon it but by an Action of Covenant. This Ca≈øe was argued four times and not one Authority cited.

div.head: The Earl of Shaftsbury ver≈øus Lord Digby. In Banco Regis.
div.p: For Words upon the Statute of 2 R. 2. c. 5. Jones 49. SCandalum Magnatum. The Plaintiff declares upon the Statute of 2 R. 2. cap. 5. for the≈øe Words, viz. You are not for the King, but for Sedition and for a Common-wealth, and by God we will have your Head the next Se≈ø≈øions of Parliament.
After Verdict for the Plaintiff and 1000 l. damages given, it was moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, and ≈øeveral Exceptions taken.

1. As to the Recital of the Statute, the Words of which are, That no Man ≈øhall devi≈øe any Lies, &c. and the Plaintiff for the Word devi≈øe had u≈øed the Latin Word contrafacio in his Declaration, which was very improper, that being to counterfeit and not to devi≈øe; for it ≈øhould have b√©en machino or fingo, tho≈øe are more expre≈ø≈øive Words of Devi≈øe.
2. 'Tis alledged that the Defendant dixit mendacia of the Plaintiff, viz. haec Anglicana verba ≈øequenÃÑ, and doth not alledge that he ≈øpoke the Words.

3. The mo≈øt material Objection was a mi≈øtake in the Recital of the Statute, the Words of which are, That none ≈øhall ≈øpeak any ≈øcandalous Words of any Dukes, Earls, &c. the Ju≈øtices of either Bench nor, of any other great Officer of the Kingdom; but the Plaintiff in his Declaration recites it thus, viz. None ≈øhall ≈øpeak any ≈øcandalous Words of any Dukes, Earls, &c. Ju≈øtices of either Bench, great Officers of the Kingdom, and leaves out the Words (neque al) ≈øo that it mu≈øt be con≈øtrued thus, None to ≈øpeak of any Dukes, Earls, &c. being great Officers of the Kingdom; and then 'tis not enough that the Plaintiff is Comes, but he al≈øo ought to be a great Officer of the Kingdom which is not ≈øet out in this Ca≈øe.
But upon great Debate and Deliberation the≈øe Exceptions were overruled; and the whole Court gave Iudgment for the Plaintiff.
As to the fir≈øt Exception they ≈øaid, contrafacio is a legal Word and apt enough in this ≈øen≈øe, and ≈øo are all the Pre≈øidents, and thus it was pleaded in the Lord Cromwel's Ca≈øe.

As to the ≈øecond Exception it was ≈øaid, the Mendacia which were told were the Engli≈øh Words which were ≈øpoken; and the (viz. haec Anglicana verba ≈øequenÃÑ being in the Accu≈øative Ca≈øe) are governed by the ≈øame Verb which governs the Words precedent
(viz. horribilia mendacia) Be≈øides for the ≈øupporting of an Action the (viz.) may be tran≈øpo≈øed, and then it will be well enough, viz. the Defendant ≈øpoke haec Anglicana verba, viz. Lies of the Plaintiff.

As to the third Exception it was an≈øwered, that the Plaintiff ne√©d not recite the Statute it being aSid. 348. general Law; and admitting there was no nece≈ø≈øity, yet if he will undertake to recite it and mi≈øtake in a material Point, 'tis incurable; but if he recites ≈øo much as will ≈øerve to maintain his own Action truly and mi≈øtakes the re≈øt, this will not vitiate his Declaration; and ≈øo he hath done here by reciting ≈øo much of the Statute which Enacts, That no Man ≈øhall ≈øpeak any ≈øcandalous Words of an Earl, which is enough (he being an Earl) to entitle him to an Action, and he concludes prout per eundem Actum plenius liquet; and the Court grounded them≈øelves principally upon a Iudgment given in this Court which was thus, viz. There was a Robbery committed, and the Party brought an Action upon the Statute of Huy and Cry, in which he recited incendia domorum, 13 E. 1. cap. 1. the ≈øaid Statute beginning Fora≈ømuch as from day to day Robberies, Murders, burning of Hou≈øes, &c. and the Pre≈øidents are all ≈øo: But the Parliament Roll is Incendia generally without domorum; and it was ≈øtrongly urged, that it was a mi≈ørecital, which was fatal: But the Court were all of Opinion, that the Plaintiffs Ca≈øe being only concerning a Robbery, for which the Statute was well recited, and not about burning which was mi≈øtaken, it was for that rea≈øon good enough; and Iudgment was given accordingly.

When this Cau≈øe was tried at the Barr which was in Ea≈øter-Term la≈øt, the Lord Mohun offered to give his Te≈øtimony for the Plaintiff, but refu≈øed to be ≈øworn, offering to ≈øpeak upon his Honour; but Iu≈øtice Wyld told him in Cau≈øes between Party and Party he mu≈øt be upon his Oath.

The Lord Mohun asked him whether he would an≈øwer it: The Iudge replyed, that he delivered it as his Opinion, and becau≈øe he knew not whether it might cau≈øe him to be que≈øtioned in another place, he de≈øired the re≈øt of the Iudges to deliver their Opinions, which they all did, and ≈øaid he ought to be ≈øworn; and ≈øo he was, but with a ≈øalvo jure; for he ≈øaid there was an Order in the Hou≈øe of Peers, That 'tis again≈øt the Priviledge of the Hou≈øe for any Lord to be ≈øworn.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: DEBT upon the Statute for not coming to Church, and concludes Per quod Actio accrevit eidem Domino Regi & querÃÑ ad exigend' & habend'. The Exception after Iudgment was taken, that it ought to have been only Actio accrevit eidem the Plaintiff, qui tam, &c. and not exigend' & habend' for the King and him≈øelf; Sed non allocatur: For upon ≈øearch of Pre≈øidents the Court were all of Opinion that it was good either way.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: Factor, where he cannot ≈øell but for ready Mony.IN Accompt: Iudgment was given quod computet; and the Defendant pleads before the Auditors that the Goods whereof he was to give a rea≈øonable accompt were bona peritura; and though he was carefull in the keeping of them, yet they were much the wor≈øe; that they remained in his hands for want of Buyers, and were in danger of being wor≈øe, and therefore he ≈øold them upon Credit to a Man beyond Sea.

The Plaintiff demurred; and after Argument by Barrel Serjeant for the Plaintiff, and Baldwin Serjeant for the Defendant, the whole Court were of Opinion that the Plea was not good.Curia. For if a Merchant deliver Goods to his Factor ad merchandizand', he cannot ≈øell them upon Credit, but for ready Mony, unle≈øs he hath a particular Commi≈ø≈øion from his Ma≈øter ≈øo to do; for if he can find no Buyers he is not an≈øwerable; and if they are bona peritura and cannot be ≈øold for Mony upon the delivery, the Merchant mu≈øt give him authority to ≈øell upon Tru≈øt. If they are burned or he is robbed without his own default, he is not lyable; and in this Ca≈øe it was not pleaded that he could not ≈øell the Goods for ready Mony; and the Sale it ≈øelf was made beyond Sea, where the Buyer is not to be found; like the Ca≈øe of1 Bul≈øt. 103. Yelv. 202. Sadock and Burton, where in Accompt again≈øt a Factor he pleads that he ≈øold the Iewel to the King of Barbary for the Plaintiffs u≈øe; and upon a Demurrer the Plea was held naught; for when a Factor hath a bare Authorty to ≈øell, in ≈øuch Ca≈øe he hath no power to give a day of payment, but mu≈øt receive the Mony immediately upon the Sale.

Therefore in the Ca≈øe at Barr, if the Ma≈øter is not bound by the Contract of the Servant without his Con≈øent, or at lea≈øt the Goods coming to his u≈øe; neither ≈øhall the Servant have Authority to ≈øell without ready Mony, unle≈øs he hath a particular Order for that purpo≈øe.

There was another thing moved in this Ca≈øe for the Plaintiff that the Plea ought to be put in upon Oath; for having pleaded that he could not ≈øell without lo≈øs, he ought to ≈øwear it, Fitzh. Accompt 47. But no Opinion was delivered herein, only the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that the Plaintiff ought to have required the Plea upon Oath, for otherwi≈øe it was not nece≈ø≈øary: But for the ≈øub≈øtance of the Plea it was held ill, and Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Harris's Ca≈øe.
div.p: SErjeant Hopkins moved for a Prohibition. The Ca≈øe was:Husband dies, his Wife Executrix, ≈øhe dies before Probate, Admini≈øtration mu≈øt be to the next of kin of the Husband. 22 & 23 Car. 2. cap. 10. A Man makes a Will and appoints his Wife to be Executrix, and devi≈øes a Shilling to his Daughter for a Legacy, and dies; the Executrix, before Probate of the Will, dies al≈øo inte≈øtate; and whether the Goods ≈øhall be di≈øtributed by the Act for ≈øettling Inte≈øtates E≈øtates among≈øt the next of kin to the Executrix or to the next of kin to the Te≈øtator her Husband, was the Que≈øtion: Since ≈øhe dying before Probate her Husband in Iudgment of Law died al≈øo inte≈øtate.
This Ca≈øe ≈øeems to be out of the Statute, the Husband having made a Will, and the Act intermeddles only where no Will is made.

The Court delivered no Iudgment in it, but ≈øeemed to incline that the Statute did extend to this very Ca≈øe, and that Admini≈øtration mu≈øt be committed to the next of kin of the Husband; but if there ≈øhould be no di≈øtribution, it mu≈øt then be according to the Will of the Te≈øtator.

div.head: Reder ver≈øus Bradley.
div.p:
IT was moved to rever≈øe a Iudgment given in an Honour Court upon a Writ of fal≈øe Iudgment brought here:Judgment rever≈øed in an inferior Court where the damage was laid to 30 l. The Plaintiff declared in the Action below that there was a Communication between him and the Defendant concerning the Service of his Son; and it was agre√©d between them that in con≈øideration
the Plaintiff would permit his Son to ≈øerve him, the Defendant promi≈øed to pay the Plaintiff 30 s. The Plaintiff avers that he did permit his Son to ≈øerve him, and that the Defendant hath not paid him the 30 s. There was a Verdict for the Plaintiff, and the Exceptions now taken were:
1. 'Tis not ≈øaid that the Iurors were electi ad triand', &c.

2. He lays his damage to 30 l. of which a Court Baron cannot hold Plea; for the difference taken by my Lord Coke is where Damages are laid under 40 s. Co≈øts may make it amount to more; but where 'tis laid above, in ≈øuch Ca≈øe all is coram non Judice; for which rea≈øon Iudgment was rever≈øed; but in this Court the Iudge doth not pronounce the Rever≈øal as 'tis done in the Kings Bench.

div.head: Lane ver≈øus Robin≈øon.
div.p: Inferior Court.TRe≈øpa≈øs for taking of his Cattel; the Defendant ju≈øtifies by vertue of an Execution in an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs brought in a Hundred Court; and the Plaintiff demurred.
Serjeant Pemberton took two Exceptions to the Plea.

2 Cro. 443, 526. Hob. 180. Sid. 348.1. Becau≈øe the inferior Court not being of Record cannot hold Plea of a Tre≈øpa≈øs quare vi & armis & contra pacem, but it was not allowed; for Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes are frequently brought there, and the Plaintiff may declare either vi & armis or contra pacem.

Po≈øtea.2. The Defendant reciting the Proceedings below ≈øaith taliter proce≈ø≈øum fuit; whereas he ought particularly to ≈øet forth all that was done, becau≈øe not being in a Court of Record the Proceedings may be denied and tryed by Iury.

But the Court inclined that it was pleaded well enough, and that it was the ≈øafe≈øt way to prevent mi≈øtakes; but if the Plaintiff had replied de injuria ≈øua propria ab≈øque tali cau≈øa, that had traver≈øed all the Proceedings. Quaere whether ≈øuch a Replication had been good, becau≈øe the Plaintiff mu≈øt an≈øwer particularly that Authority which the Defendant pretended to have from the Court; but no Iudgment was given.

div.head: Sherrard ver≈øus Smith.
div.p: TRe≈øpa≈øs Quare clau≈øum fregit, and for taking away his Goods; the Defendant ju≈øtifies the taking by the command of the Lord of the Mannor, of which the Plaintiff held by Fealty and Rent, and for non-payment thereof, the Goods were taken nomine Di≈øtrictionis.

The Plaintiff replies, that the locus in quo e≈øt extra,
Hors de ≈øon Fee, when to be pleaded. ab≈ø
que hoc quod e≈øt infra feodum: The Defendant demurrs ≈øpecially, becau≈øe the Plaintiff pleading hors de ≈øon fee, ≈øhould have taken the Tenancy upon him, 9 Co. Bucknal's Ca≈øe, 22 H. 6. 2, 3. Keilway 73. 14 A≈ø≈ø. pl. 13. 1 In≈øt. 1. b. where this is given as a Rule by my Lord Cook.

Serjeant Pemberton on the other ≈øide agreed,Ex parte Quer. 13 A≈ø≈øize 28. 28 A≈ø≈øi≈øe 41. that in all ca≈øes of A≈ø≈øize, hors de ≈øon fee is no Plea, without taking the Tenancy upon him, 2 A≈ø≈ø. placito 1. And in 5 E. 4. 2. 'tis ≈øaid, that in Replevin the Party cannot plead this Plea, becau≈øe he may di≈øclaim; but Brook placito 15. tit. hors de ≈øon fee ≈øaith, this is not Law, and ≈øo is 2 H. 6. 1. and many Ca≈øes afterwards were again≈øt that Book of Ed. 4. and that a Man might plead hors de ≈øon fee, as if there be a Lord and Tenant holding by Fealty and Rent; and he makes a Lea≈øe for years, and the Lord di≈øtrains the Cattel of the Le≈ø≈øee, though the Tenant hath paid the Rent and done Fealty, there if the Le≈ø≈øee alledge that his Le≈ø≈øor was ≈øei≈øed of the Tenancy in his deme≈øn, as of fee, and held it of the Lord by Services, &c. of which Services the Lord was ≈øei≈øed by the hands of his Le≈ø≈øor, as by his true Tenant, who hath lea≈øed the Lands to the Plaintiff; and the Lord to charge him hath unju≈øtly avowed upon him who hath nothing in the Tenancy, 'tis well enough, 9 Co. Ca≈øe of Avowries; and the rea≈øon given in 5 Edw. 4. about di≈øclaimer, will not hold now, for that cour≈øe is quite altered, and is taken away by the Statute of the 21 H. 8. cap. 19. which Enacts, That Avowries ≈øhall be made by the Lord upon the Land, without naming his Tenant.

But in ca≈øe of Tre≈øpa≈øs there was never any ≈øuch thing objected as here; for what Tenancy can the Plaintiff take upon him in this ca≈øe? He cannot ≈øay tenen' liberi tenementi, for this is a bare Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, in which, though the pleading is not ≈øo formal, yet it will do no hourt; for if it had been only extra
feodum, without the Traver≈øe, it had been good enough, and of that Opinion was the Court in Hillary-Term following, when Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff (ab≈øente Scroggs) And the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, That the Rule laid down by my Lord Coke, in 1 In≈øt. 1. b. that there is no pleading hors de ≈øon fee, without taking the tenancy upon him, is to be intended in ca≈øes of A≈ø≈øize; and ≈øo are all the Ca≈øes he there cites for proof of that Opinion, and therefore ≈øo he is to be under≈øtood; but this is an Action of Tre≈øpas brought upon the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and not upon the Title. In the Ca≈øe of Avowry, a Stranger may plead generally hors de ≈øon fee, and ≈øo may Tenant for years; and this being in the Ca≈øe of a Tre≈øpa≈øs, is much ≈øtronger, and if the Plaintiff de≈øtroys the Defendants ju≈øtification; 'tis well enough.

div.head: Sir William Hickman ver≈øus Thorne & alios.
div.p: Pre≈øcription again≈øt another Pre≈øcription, not good, without a Traver≈øe.IN a Replevin: The Defendant ju≈øtifies the taking, for that the locus in quo was his Freehold, and that he took the Cattel there damage fe≈øant.

The Plaintiff in bar to the Avowry replies, that the locus in quo, &c. is parcel of ≈øuch a Common Field, and pre≈øcribes to have right of Common there, as appendant to two Acres which he hath in another place.

The Defendant rejoyns, that there is a Cu≈øtom, that every Free-holder who hath Lands lying together in the ≈øaid Common Field may enclo≈øe again≈øt him who hath right of Common there, and that he had Lands there, and did enclo≈øe: The Plaintiff demurs, and Serjeant Newdigate took Exceptions to the Rejoynder.

Ex parte Quer.1. For that he did not averr, that the Lands which he enclo≈øed did lye together, and therefore had not brought his ca≈øe within the Cu≈øtom alledged: Sed non allocatur, becau≈øe he could not enclo≈øe if the Lands had not laid together.

2. He gives no an≈øwer to the Plaintiffs right of Common, but by argument, which he ≈øhould have confe≈ø≈øed, with a bene & verum e≈øt, and then ≈øhould have avoided it, by alledging the Cu≈øtom of Enclo≈øure; like the Ca≈øe of2 Leon. 209. Ru≈ø≈øel and Broker, where in Tre≈øpa≈øs for cutting Oaks, the Defendant pleads, that he was ≈øei≈øed of a Me≈ø≈øuage in Fee, and pre≈øcribes to have rationabile e≈øtoverium ad libitum capiend' in bo≈øcis; the Plaintiff replies, that the locus in quo was within the Fore≈øt, and that
the Defendant and all tho≈øe, &c. habere con≈øueverunt rationabile e≈øtoverium, &c. per liberationem Fore≈øtarii; and upon a Demurrer the Replication was held naught, becau≈øe the Plaintiff ought to have pleaded the Law of the Fore≈øt, viz. Lex Fore≈øtae talis e≈øt; or to have traver≈øed the Defendants Pre≈øcription, and not to have ≈øet forth another Pre≈øcription in his Replication without a Traver≈øe.

3. The Defendant ≈øhould have pleaded the Cu≈øtom, and then have traver≈øed the Pre≈øcription of the Right of Common; for he cannot plead a Cu≈øtom again≈øt a Cu≈øtom, 9 Co. 58. Aldred's Ca≈øe, where one pre≈øcribes to have a Light, the other cannot pre≈øcribe to ≈øtop it up.

Serjeant Pemberton contra. Ex parte Def. He ≈øaid that which he took to be the only Que≈øtion in the Ca≈øe was admitted, viz.
