That ≈øuch a Cu≈øtom as this to enclo≈øe was good; and ≈øo it has b√©en adjudged in Sir Miles Corbet's Ca≈øe, 7 Co. But as to the Objections which have been made, the Defendant admits the Pre≈øcription for Right of Common, but ≈øaith, he may enclo≈øe again≈øt the Commoners, by rea≈øon of a Cu≈øtom, which is a Barr to his very Right of Common, and therefore need not confe≈øs it with a bene & verum e≈øt, neither could he traver≈øe the Pre≈øcription, becau≈øe he hath admitted it. 'Tis true, where one pre≈øcribes to have Lights in his Hou≈øe, and another pre≈øcribes to ≈øtop them up; this is not good, becau≈øe one Pre≈øcription is directly contrary to the other; and for that rea≈øon one mu≈øt be traver≈øed; but here the Defendant hath confe≈ø≈øed, that the Plaintiff hath a Right of Common, but tis not an ab≈øolute, but a qualified Right, again≈øt which the Defendant may Enclo≈øe; and here being two Pre≈øcriptions pleaded, and one of them not being confe≈ø≈øed, it mu≈øt from thence nece≈ø≈øarily follow, that the other is the I≈ø≈øue to be tryed, which in this Ca≈øe is, whether the Defendant can enclo≈øe or not.

The Chief Iu≈øtice, and the whole Court were of Opinion,Curia. that where there are ≈øeveral Free-holders, who have Right of Common in a Common Field, that ≈øuch a Cu≈øtom as this of enclo≈øing is good, becau≈øe the remedy is reciprocal; for as one may enclo≈øe, ≈øo may another. But Iu≈øtice Atkyns doubted much of the Ca≈øe at Bar, becau≈øe the Defendant had pleaded this Cu≈øtom to Enclo≈øe in barr to a Freeholder, who had no Land in the Common Field, where he claimed Right of Common, but pre≈øcribed to have ≈øuch Right there, as appendant to two Acres of Land he had alibi, for which rea≈øon he prayed to amend upon payment of Co≈øts.

div.head: Attorny General ver≈øus Sir Edward Turner, in Scaccario.
div.p: Expo≈øition of the Kings Grant. INformation. The Ca≈øe was, Viz. The King by Letters Patents granted ≈øeveral Lands in Lincoln≈øhire, by expre≈øs words; and then this Clau≈øe is added, upon which the Que≈øtion did ari≈øe, Nec non totum illud fundum & ≈øolum & terras ≈øuas contigue adjacen' to the Premi≈ø≈øes, quae ≈øunt aqua cooperta vel quae in po≈øterum de aqua po≈ø≈øunt recuperari; and afterwards a great quantity of Land was gained from the Sea; and whether the King or the Patentee was intituled to tho≈øe Lands, was the Que≈øtion.

Devi≈øe of a po≈ø≈øibility good by a common per≈øon. 2 Cro. 509. pl. 21. 1 Bul≈øt. 194. Sawyer for the King argued, that he had a good Title, becau≈øe the Grant was void, he having only a bare po≈ø≈øibility in the thing granted at the time.

But Levins on the other ≈øide in≈øi≈øted, that the Grant of tho≈øe Lands was good, becau≈øe the King may Grant what he hath not in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but only a po≈ø≈øibility to have it. But admitting that he could not make ≈øuch a Grant; yet in this Ca≈øe there is ≈øuch a certainty as the thing it ≈øelf is capable to have, and in which the King hath an Intere≈øt; and it is hard to ≈øay that he hath an Intere≈øt in a thing, and yet cannot by any means di≈øpo≈øe of it.

If it ≈øhould be objected, that nothing is to pa≈øs but what is contigue adjacen' to the Premi≈ø≈øes granted, and therefore an Inch or ≈øome ≈øuch ≈ømall matter mu≈øt pa≈øs and no more; certainly that was not the intention of the King, who≈øe Grants are to be con≈øtrued favourably, and very bountifully for his Honour, and not to be taken by Inches.

Po≈øtea, Company of Ironmongers and Naylor. If there are two Mar≈øhes adjoyning, which are the Kings, and he grants one of them by a particular name and de≈øcription, and then he grants the other contigue adjacen' ex parte au≈øtrali, certainly the whole Mar≈øh will pa≈øs; and 'tis very u≈øual in pleading to ≈øay a Man is ≈øei≈øed of a Hou≈øe or Clo≈øe, and of another Hou≈øe, &c. contigue adjacen', that is to be intended of the whole Hou≈øe.

In this Ca≈øe the King intended to pa≈øs ≈øomething when he granted totum fundum, &c. but if ≈øuch con≈øtruction ≈øhould be made as in≈øi≈øted on, then tho≈øe words would be of no ≈øignification. 'Tis true, the word illud is a Relative, and re≈øtrains the general words, and implies that which may be ≈øhewn, as it were
with a Finger; and therefore in Doddington's Ca≈øe,2 Co. 32. a Grant of omnia illa Me≈øuagia, ≈øcituate in Wells, and the Hou≈øes were not in Wells, but el≈øewhere; the Grant in that Ca≈øe, was held void, becau≈øe it was re≈øtrained to a certain Village, and the Pronoun illa hath reference to the Town; but in this Ca≈øe there could be no ≈øuch certainty, becau≈øe the Land at the time of the Grant made, was under Water.

But if the Patent is not good by the very words of the Grant, the non ob≈øtante makes it good, which in this Ca≈øe is ≈øo particular, that it ≈øeems to be de≈øigned on purpo≈øe to an≈øwer tho≈øe Objections of any mi≈øtake or incertainty, in the value, quantity, or quality of the thing granted, which al≈øo ≈øupplies the defects for want of right in≈øtruction given the King, in all ca≈øes where he may lawfully make a Grant at the Common Law, 4 Co. 34.Moor pl. 571. Bozuns Ca≈øe.

And there is another very general Clau≈øe in the Patent, viz. Damus praemi≈ø≈øa adeo plene, as they are or could be in the Kings hands, by his Prerogative or otherwi≈øe.Ante Adeo plene are operative words, Whi≈øtlers Ca≈øe 10 Co. And there is al≈øo this Clau≈øe omnes terras no≈øtras infra fluxum & refluxum maris. 'Tis true,Sid. 149. the≈øe words praemi≈ø≈øis praed' ≈øpectan' do follow; from whence it may be objected, that they neither did or could belong to the Premi≈ø≈øes; and admitting it to be ≈øo, yet the Law will reject tho≈øe words, rather than avoid the Grant in that part.

In the Ca≈øe of the Abbot of9 Co. 27. b. Strata Marcella, the King granted a Mannor Et bona & catalla felonum dicto Manerio ≈øpectan'; now though ≈øuch things could not be appendant to a Mannor, yet it was there adjudged that they did pa≈øs.

Such things as the≈øe the King hath by his Prerogative, and ≈øome things the Subject may have by Cu≈øtom or Pre≈øcription; as Wrecks, &c. and in this very Ca≈øe 'tis ≈øaid, that there is a Cu≈øtom in Lincoln≈øhire, that the Lords of Mannors ≈øhall have derelict Lands, and 'tis a rea≈øonable Cu≈øtom; for if the Sea wa≈øh away the Lands of the Subject, he can have no recompence, unle≈øs he ≈øhould be entituled to what he gains from the Sea; and for this there are ≈øome Authorities, as Sir Henry Con≈øtable's Ca≈øe,2 Roll. 168. 5 Co. Land between High-Water and Low-Water Mark may belong to a Mannor:
But no Iudgment was given.

div.head: Morris ver≈øus Philpot in B. R.
div.p: Relea≈øe by an Executor before Probate.THE Plaintiff as Executor to T. brings an Action of Debt again≈øt the Defendant, as Admini≈øtrator to S. for a Debt due from the ≈øaid inte≈øtate, to the Plaintiffs Te≈øtator. The Defendant pleads, that the Plaintiff relea≈øed to him all Brewing Ve≈ø≈øels, &c. and all other the E≈øtate of S. lately decea≈øed (this Relea≈øe was before probate of the Will,) to which Plea the Plaintiff demurred; and whether this Relea≈øe was a good Barr to the Plaintiffs Action was the Que≈øtion.

Ex parte Quer.It was ≈øaid for the Plaintiff, that it was not; for if a Conu≈øee relea≈øe to the Cogni≈øor all his right and title to the Lands of the Cogni≈øor, and afterwards ≈øues out Execution, yet he may extend the very Lands ≈øo relea≈øed; ≈øo if the Debtee relea≈øe to the Debtor all his right and title which he hath to his Lands, and afterwards gets a Iudgment again≈øt him, he may extend a Moiety of the ≈øame Lands by Elegit; the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe at the time of the≈øe Relea≈øes given, they had no title to the Land, but only an inception of a right, which might happen to take place in futuro; ≈øo here a Relea≈øe by the Executor of the Debtee to the Admini≈øtrator of the Debtor, before Probate of the Will, is not good; becau≈øe by being made Executor, he had only a po≈ø≈øibility to be entituled to the Te≈øtators E≈øtate, and no Intere≈øt 'till Probate, for he might refu≈øe to prove the Will, or renounce the Executor≈øhip. It is true, a Relea≈øe of allGodol. 145. pl. 4. Actions had been good by the Executor before Probate, becau≈øe a right of Action is in him, and a Debt which con≈øi≈øts meerly in Action is thereby di≈øcharged; but in ≈øuch ca≈øe a Relea≈øe of all right and title would not be good, for the rea≈øons afore≈øaid.

Ex parte Def.But for the Defendant it was in≈øi≈øted, that this Relea≈øe was a good Plea in Barr, for if a Relea≈øe be made by an Executor of all his right and title to the Te≈øtators E≈øtate, and then the Executor ≈øues the Party Relea≈øed (as the Admini≈øtrator is ≈øued in this Ca≈øe) for a Debt due to the Te≈øtator, the Relea≈øe is good; becau≈øe if he had recovered, in this Ca≈øe the Iudgment mu≈øt be de bonis Te≈øtatoris, which is the ≈øubject matter, and that being relea≈øed, no Action can lye again≈øt the Admini≈øtrator. Adjornatur.

div.head: DE Term. Sancti Mich. Anno 28 Car. II. in Banco Regis.
Piggot Le≈ø≈øee of Sir Thomas Lee ver≈øus the Earl of Salisbury. Intrat' Pa≈øch. 26 Car. 2. Rot. 609.
div.p: IN Ejectment for fourte√©n Hou≈øes and ≈øome Gardens in the Pari≈øh of St. Martin in the Fields; Warranty where by di≈øplacing of a Right by a Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øit, it ≈øhall barr the Heir. Jones 68. the Iury find as to all but one Moiety for the Defendant, as for the other Moiety they find that the≈øe were formerly the Hou≈øes of one Nightingale, who was ≈øei≈øed thereof in F√©e, and made a Lea≈øe of them which commenced 1 Apr. 7 Jac. yet in being.
That the Rever≈øion de≈øcended to Briget his Daughter and Heir, who married William Mitton, by whom ≈øhe had a Daughter named Elizabeth.

That upon the Marriage of the ≈øaid Elizabeth with Francis the Son of Sir Oliver Lee, by Fine and other Settlements the≈øe Hou≈øes were ≈øettled to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Bridget for Life, then to the u≈øe of Francis Lee and the ≈øaid Elizabeth, and the Heirs on the Body of the ≈øaid Elizabeth to be begotten by Francis.
And for want of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue to William Mitton for Life, and afterwards to the right Heirs of Bridget Mitton for ever.

William Mitton and Bridget his Wife before the expiration of the Term levy a Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øerunt to two Cogni≈øees, wherein the ≈øaid Husband and Wife conced' tenementa praed' & totum & quicquid habent in tenementis praed' cum pertinÃÑ for the Life of the ≈øaid Husband and Wife, and the Survivor of them with Proclamations.

They find that the Le≈ø≈øee for years attorned, and that the Fine thus levied was in Tru≈øt for the Earl of Salisbury, and that before
the fir≈øt day of February before the Action brought he entred by the direction of the two Cognizees, and that he was ≈øei≈øed prout Lex po≈øtulat.

That 1 Febr. 7 Jac. Sir Oliver Lee, Francis Lee his Son and Heir, and Elizabeth his Wife, William Mitton and Bridget his Wife, by Bargain and Sale convey the Premi≈øes to the Earl and his Heirs, which was enrolled in Chancery, in which De√©d there was a Warranty again≈øt Sir Oliver and his Heirs.
That in the ≈øame Term, viz. Octab. Purificationis, William Mitton and Bridget his Wife, levyed a Fine ≈øur Cogni≈øance de droit come ceo, &c. to the Earl.
That Francis Lee was Son and Heir of Sir Oliver Lee.
That Sir Oliver and Elizabeth died in the Life-time of Francis, and that Francis died leaving I≈ø≈øue Sir Thomas Lee, the now Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff.
That the Warranty di≈øcended upon him being inheritable to the E≈øtate Tail.
That the E≈øtate of the Earl of Salisbury de≈øcended to the pre≈øent Earl, who was the Defendant.
That Sir Thomas Lee entred and made a Lea≈øe to the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff.

Que≈øtion.The Que≈øtion upon this Special Verdict was, if by the Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øerunt levied 7 Jac. the E≈øtate which the Husband and Wife had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion only pa≈ø≈øed, or whether that and the E≈øtate for Life, which the Husband had after the Tail ≈øpent, pa≈ø≈øed likewi≈øe.

If the latter, then they pa≈ø≈øed more than they could lawfully grant, becau≈øe of the intervention of the E≈øtate Tail; and then this Fine wrought aCo. Lit. 338. b di≈øplacing or dive≈øting the E≈øtate of William Mitton for Life in Rever≈øion and turned it into a Right; and if ≈øo, then this collateral Warranty of Sir Oliver Lee will di≈øcend on Sir Francis, and from him to the Plaintiff, and will barr his Entry; But if the E≈øtate was not di≈øplaced and turned into a Right at the time of the Warranty, then the Heir is not barred by this collateral Warranty of his Ance≈øtor.
This Ca≈øe was argued by Serjeant Pemberton for the Plaintiff, and by Sir William Jones the Attorny General for the Defendant.

Ex parte Quer.And for the Plaintiff it was ≈øaid, that this Fine pa≈ø≈øed only the E≈øtate which William Mitton and his Wife had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and no other, and therefore worked no dive≈øting; and his Rea≈øons were:
1. Such a Con≈øtruction ≈øeems mo≈øt agreeable to the intention of all the Parties to the Fine.
2. It may well ≈øtand with the Nature and the Words of the Fine.
3. It will be mo≈øt agreeable both to the Iudgments and Opinions which have formerly b√©en given in the like Ca≈øes.

And as to the fir≈øt of the≈øe it will be nece≈ø≈øary to con≈øider what will be the effect and con≈øequence of levying this Fine both on the one ≈øide and the other. It cannot be denyed but that there was a Purcha≈øe intended to be made under this Fine, and that the Parties were willing to pa≈øs away their E≈øtate with the lea≈øt hazard that might be to them≈øelves; neither can it be imagined that they intended to defeat this Purcha≈øe as ≈øoon as it was made, which they mu≈øt do if this Fine works a Forfeiture; for then he in Remainder in Tail is entituled to a pre≈øent Entry, and ≈øo the E≈øtates for Life which the Baron and Feme had are lo≈øt, and there was a po≈ø≈øibility al≈øo of lo≈øing the Rever≈øion in Fe√©, which the Tenant in Tail after his Entry might have barred by a Common Recovery.

And had not the Parties intended only to pa≈øs both the E≈øtates, which they lawfully might pa≈øs, why did they levy this Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øit? They might have levyed a Fine ≈øur Cogni≈øance de droit come ceo, &c. and that had be√©n a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin.

Be≈øides what need was there for them to mention any E≈øtate which they had in the≈øe Hou≈øes, if they had intended a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin? But this being done, ≈øuch a Con≈øtruction is to be made as may ≈øupport the intent of the Parties; and it would be very unrea≈øonable, that what was intended to pre≈øerve the E≈øtate ≈øhould now be adjudged to work a Di≈ø≈øe≈øin ≈øo as to forfeit it; and ≈øuch a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin upon which this collateral Warranty ≈øhall operate and barr the E≈øtate in Remainder.

And therefore no more ≈øhall pa≈øs by this Fine than what lawfully may; and rather than it ≈øhall be con≈øtrued to work a Wrong, the E≈øtate ≈øhall pa≈øs by fractions; for both the E≈øtates of William Mitton for Life, are not ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarily joyned and united by this Fine that no room can be left for ≈øuch a Con≈øtruction.

2. Such a Con≈øtruction will not agre√© with the Nature and Words of this Fine. 'Tis true, a Fine as it is of the mo≈øt ≈øolemn and of the greate≈øt Authority, ≈øo 'tis of the greate≈øt force and efficacy to convey an E≈øtate, and the mo≈øt effectual Feoffment of Record where 'tis a Feoffment, and likewi≈øe the mo≈øt effectual Relea≈øe, where 'tis to be a Relea≈øe.

But on a bare Agre√©ment made in Actions betw√©en the Demandant and Tenant at the Barr, and drawn up there, the Iudges will alter and amend ≈øuch Fines, if they did not in all things an≈øwer the intention of the Parties.24 Ed. 3. 36.

Po≈øtea.'Tis agreed that Fines can work a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin when they can have no other Interpretation, as if Tenant pur auter vie levy a Fine to a Stranger for his own Life, 'tis more than ≈øuch a Tenant could do, becau≈øe his E≈øtate was during the Life of another and no longer.
So a Fine ≈øur Cogni≈øance de droit, &c. implies a F√©e, which being levyed by any one who has but a particular E≈øtate will make a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin.

But this Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øit has be√©n always taken to be the mo≈øt harmle≈øs of all others, and can be compared to nothing el≈øe than a Grant of totum ≈øtatum ≈øuum & quicquid habet, &c. by which no more is granted than what the Cogni≈øor had at the time of the Grant, and ≈øo it hath been always con≈øtrued.

Ind√©ed there is a Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øit which expre≈ø≈øes no E≈øtate of the Grantor, and this is properly levyed by Tenant in F√©e or Tail; but when particular Tenants pa≈øs over their ≈øeveral E≈øtates they generally grant totum & quicquid habent in tenementis praedictis, being very cautious to expre≈øs what E≈øtate they had therein.

When this Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øit was fir≈øt invented the Iudges in tho≈øe days looked upon the Words quicquid habent, &c. to be in≈øignificant, and for that rea≈øon in Anno 17 E. 3. 66. they were refu≈øed: The ca≈øe was; Two Husbands and their Wives levied ≈øuch a Fine to the Cogni≈øee, and thereby granted totum & quicquid habent, &c. which Words were rejected, and the Iudge would not pa≈øs the Fine, becau≈øe if the Party had nothing in the Land then nothing pa≈ø≈øed; and ≈øo is 44 Ed. 3. 36. By which it appears that the Iudges in tho≈øe times thought the≈øe Fines did pa≈øs no more than what the Cogni≈øor had; and for this there are multitude of Authorities in the Year Books.

Now the≈øe Words cannot have a ≈øignification to enlarge the E≈øtate granted, they ≈øerve only to explain what was intended to pa≈øs; for in the Ca≈øe at the Barr, if the Grant had b√©en totum & quicquid habent in tenementis praedictis there would have been no que≈øtion of the E≈øtate granted; but the Cogni≈øors having granted tenementa praedicta, they ≈øeem by the≈øe ≈øub≈øequent Words to recollect them≈øelves, viz. totum & quicquid habent in tenementis praedictis.

Object. But it may be objected that the Limitation of the E≈øtate, viz. durante vita eorum & alterius eorum diutius viventis works a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin, becau≈øe by tho≈øe Words two E≈øtates for Life pa≈øs entire in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, whereas in truth there was but one E≈øtate for Life of the Husband, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; and therefore this was more than they could grant, becau≈øe the E≈øtate Tayl came between the E≈øtate which the Husband and Wife had for their Lives and for the Survivor of them, and the E≈øtate which the Husband had for his own Life.
And this is farther enforced by that Rule in Law, That E≈øtates ≈øhall not pa≈øs by fractions; for otherwi≈øe there can be no rea≈øon why they ≈øhould not thus pa≈øs.

An≈øw. But this Rule is very fallible, and not ≈øo much to be regarded; 'tis true, the Rule is ≈øo far admitted to be true, where without inconveniency E≈øtates may pa≈øs without fraction; but where there is an inconveniency it may be di≈øpen≈øed withal, it being ≈øuch an inconveniency as may appear to the Iudges to make the thing granted, to go contrary to the intent of the Parties.

And that ≈øuch Interpretations have been made, agrees with the third Rea≈øon propo≈øed in this Ca≈øe, viz. That it hath received countenance by judicial Opinions and determinations in former Iudgments, 14 E. 4. 4. 27 H. 8. 13. 1 Co. 67. Bredons Ca≈øe, which was thus; Tenant for life, remainder in tayl to A. remainder in tayl to B. Tenant for life, and he in the fir≈øt remainder levied a Fine ≈øur cogni≈øance de droit come ceo; 't was adjudged that this was no Di≈øcontinuance of either of the Remainders,1 Roll. Abr. lit. I. pl. 4. 1 In≈øt. 45. a. Cro. Car. 406. becau≈øe each of them gave what he might lawfully, viz. The Tenant for Life granted his E≈øtate, and the Remainder-man pa≈ø≈øed a Fee-≈øimple determinable upon his E≈øtate Tail, and yet each of their E≈øtates were ≈øtill divided.

On the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that in all Ca≈øes where the per≈øon who hath a particular E≈øtate, takes upon him either by Feoffment in pais or by Fine, which is a Feoffment on Record, to grant a greater E≈øtate than he hath (as in this Ca≈øe is done) though po≈ø≈øibly the E≈øtate of the Grant√©e may determin before that of the Grantor, yet 'tis a di≈øplacing the Rever≈øion; as if a Man has an E≈øtate for ten Lives, and makes a Grant for the Life of another; here is a po≈ø≈øibility, that the E≈øtate which he granted may be longer than the E≈øtate he had in the thing granted, becau≈øe one Man may ≈øurvive the Ten, and for that rea≈øon 'tis a dive≈øting.
1. In this Ca≈øe the E≈øtate which the Husband and Wife had is to be con≈øidered.
2. What they granted.

And by comparing of the≈øe together it will appear whether they granted more than they had: The Husband and Wife had an E≈øtate for the Life of the Wife, and (after the E≈øtate Tail) the Husband had an E≈øtate for his own Life, now they grant an E≈øtate for the Life of the Husband and Wife and the Survivor; What is this but one entire E≈øtate in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion? No other Interpretation can be agr√©eable to the ≈øen≈øe of the Words; for if it had been granted according to the true E≈øtate which each had, then it ≈øhould have been, fir≈øt for the Life of the Wife, and after the Tail ≈øpent, then for the Life of the Husband.

The next thing to be con≈øidered is, Whether the E≈øtate ≈øhall pa≈øs entire or by fractions? And as to that I need ≈øay no more than only to quote the Authority of that Iudgment given in Garret and Blizard's Ca≈øe, 1 Roll. Abr. 855. which is ≈øhortly thus, viz. Tenant for Life, Remainder for Life, Remainder in Tail, Remainder in Fee to the Tenant for Life in Remainder; this Tenant for Life in Remainder levies a Fine come ceo, &c. it was adjudged a Forfeiture of his E≈øtate for Life; ≈øo that the Remainder Man in Tail might enter after the death of the Tenant for Life in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; for it ≈øhall not be intended that he pa≈ø≈øed his E≈øtate by fractions, viz. an E≈øtate in Remainder for Life and a Remainder in Fe√© expectant upon the E≈øtate Tail, but one entire E≈øtate in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; and 'tis not like the Authority in Bredon's Ca≈øe, for there the E≈øtate for Life and the E≈øtate Tail followed one another.
Next it is to be con≈øidered, whether after they granted omnia illa tenementa, the ≈øub≈øequent Words & totum ≈øtatum ≈øuum, &c. do not come in by way of Re≈øtriction, and qualifie what went before.
But tho≈øe ≈øub≈øequent Words are placed in this Fine, not by way of Re≈øtriction but of Accumulation.

Litt. 345In Littleton Sect. 613. 'tis ≈øaid, that if Tenant in Tail grants all his E≈øtate in the Tenements, Habendum all his E≈øtate, &c. in this Ca≈øe the Alienee hath but an E≈øtate for the Life of the Tenant in Tail; and 'tis ob≈øervable that totum ≈øtatum in the Ca≈øe put by Littleton is both in the Premi≈ø≈øes and the Habendum: But if I will grant tenementa praedicta in the Premi≈ø≈øes, and then make another Limitation in the Habendum, there totum ≈øtatum & quicquid, &. can make no Re≈øtriction, if it ≈øhould, it will ≈øpoil mo≈øt Conveyances.

It is agr√©ed, that if tho≈øe Words had b√©en omitted in this Ca≈øe, then by this Fine the Rever≈øion would be di≈øplaced, and therefore much weight is laid upon the≈øe Words to explain the meaning of the Parties thereby, and that when they granted tenementa praedicta they meant totum ≈øtatum, &c.

But here is no ground for ≈øuch an Interpretation; 'tis an entire Grant of the Hou≈øes by the Words Tenementa praedicta; and the ≈øub≈øequent Words ≈øhall never be allowed to make ≈øuch a Re≈øtriction which ≈øhall overthrow the frame of the D√©ed.

If a Man, who has no E≈øtate in the Land, pa≈ø≈øes it by De√©d, this ≈øhall work again≈øt him by way of E≈øtoppel; and the≈øe Words totum & quicquid, &c. which are u≈øual in all Conveyances, ≈øhall make no alteration of the Law; for if ≈øuch con≈øtruction ≈øhould be made of the≈øe Words, as hath b√©en objected, then in all D√©eds where they are in≈øerted, if it happen that the Party hath no E≈øtate, or a void E≈øtate, nothing pa≈ø≈øes; and then Covenants, E≈øtoppels, and Warranties would be no Securities in the Law.

2. The≈øe Words totum & quicquid, &c. come in a di≈øtinct Clau≈øe of the Grant; the precedent Words are, Tenementa praedicta & totum ≈øtatum & quicquid, &c. reddiderunt, which are two parts, a Grant and a Relea≈øe, and have no dependance upon each other, being di≈øtinct Clau≈øes, and therefore the≈øe Words ≈øhall not be any Re≈øtriction of the former; but if one Clau≈øe be carried on with a connexion, ≈øo as 'tis but an entire ≈øentence; in ≈øuch Ca≈øe a Man may re≈øtrain either general or particular Words, Hob. 171. in Stukely and Butler's Ca≈øe.

3. Admitting the≈øe Words are a Re≈øtriction of the former, yet the E≈øtate is ≈øo limited, that if the fir≈øt Words were out of the Ca≈øe, this later Clau≈øe he ≈øaid was enough for his purpo≈øe, for the Grant is not in the u≈øual Words by which E≈øtates pa≈øs, viz. E≈øtate, Right, Title, Intere≈øt, but Totum & quicquid, &c. for the Lives of the Grantors and the Survivor, which ≈øhews that they took upon them≈øelves to grant for a longer time than they had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; if they had only granted it for both their Lives, they might have ≈øome colourable pretence.

4. 'Tis apparent from the Clau≈øe of the Warranty that the intent of the Parties was to grant an E≈øtate expre≈øly in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion for the Lives both of the Husband and his Wife; for 'tis that which the Grant√©e ≈øhall hold, &c. during their Lives and the longe≈øt Liver.

An≈øw. It would not be a Que≈øtion in that Ca≈øe, whether the≈øe Words were re≈øtrictive or not, for nothing was granted but what might lawfully pa≈øs, viz. during the Life of the Wife the other Ioyntenant; neither was there any ≈øtre≈øs laid on tho≈øe Words; for Mr. Iu≈øtice Jones, who was a Learned Man and reported the ≈øame Ca≈øe fol. 55. hath made no mention thereof, but hath wholly omitted tho≈øe Words, which he would not have done, if the Ca≈øe had depended upon them.
2. Object. Next, the Form of this Fine has been objected, and a Pre≈øident was cited Ra≈øt. Entr. 241. where ≈øuch a Fine was levied and nothing pa≈ø≈øed but for the Life of the Conu≈øor.

An≈øw. But no Authority can be produced, where a Man that had an E≈øtate for Life in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and another in Remainder, and granted by the ≈øame Words, as in this Ca≈øe, but that it was a Forfeiture.
3. Object. That the Law will not make a Con≈øtruction to work a Wrong, and therefore if Tenant for Life grant generally for Life, it ≈øhall be interpreted during the Life of the Grantor.

An≈øw. That Ca≈øe is without expre≈øs Words, or ≈øhewing any time for which the Grantee ≈øhall have the thing granted; and therefore the Law re≈øtrains it to the Life of the Grantor, becau≈øe it will not make Words which are doubtful and of incertain ≈øignification to do any Wrong: But where there are expre≈øs Words as in this Ca≈øe, no other Con≈øtruction can be made of them but that an E≈øtate in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was thereby intended to pa≈øs.
4. Object. That this Fine and Grant mu≈øt be con≈øtrued to enure according to the intent of the Parties, ut res magis valeat, and they never intended to make a Forfeiture.

An≈øw. Certainly no Man ever intended to make a Forfeiture of his own E≈øtate, tho≈øe are generally the effects of Ignorance and not of the Will, as the Ca≈øe of Gimlet and Sands, Cro. Car. 1 Roll. Abr. 856. 391. where Tenant in Fee makes a Feoffment to two to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for Life, then to the u≈øe of his Wife for Life, Remainder in Tail to his Son and Heir, Remainder to his own right Heirs; and afterwards he made another Feoffment to Smith with Warranty; the Mother and Son join in another Feoffment, adjudged that this was a Forfeiture of her E≈øtate for life, though ≈øhe had no notice of the Warranty made by her Husband; for the Feoffment made by him was a publick Act upon the Land, and ≈øhe ought to have taken notice of it; and though by her joining in the Feoffment with her Son, ≈øhe did not intend to forfeit her
E≈øtate, yet the Law adjudges according to what is done: But in the Ca≈øe at Barr, the intention of the Parties may be collected by the Act done; and there is great rea≈øon to pre≈øume, that the Parties thereby intended to di≈øplace the Rever≈øion; for the Husband joyning in the Fine, and in the Warranty (if it was no dive≈øting) the Warranty is of no u≈øe.

Another Objection has been only mentioned, which is, that admitting this ≈øhould amount to a di≈øplacing, if the E≈øtate had been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; yet in this Ca≈øe it would not, becau≈øe it was prevented by the Lea≈øe for years in being.

But that cannot hinder the execution of this Fine; 'tis a Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øit, which is executory in its nature, and doth not pa≈øs any E≈øtate, or take any effect 'till executed, and ≈øo is the Book, 41 5. 3. 14. b.

But in this Ca≈øe the Fine was executed, which may be by matter in pais, as well as by Scire facias, and as to this purpo≈øe, may be executed by the entry of the Conu≈øor,1 Rep. 106. Dyer 376. b. without ≈øuing out any Execution, 38 Ed. 3. Brook tit. Scire facias 199.

If there had been a Fine executed, there would have be√©n little doubt left in this Ca≈øe; and by the Attornment of the Le≈ø≈øee for years, it mu≈øt be admitted that this Fine was executed, as 8 Ed. 3. f. 44. For a Fine of a Rever≈øion may be executed to all purpo≈øes by the Attornment of the Le≈ø≈øee for years; and if ≈øo, when a Fine executory is once executed, 'tis as good as a Fine ≈øur Conu≈øance de droit come ceo, to make a forfeiture of the particular E≈øtate.

Where a Feoffment is made, and a Lea≈øe for years is in being, the Feoffment is not good; becau≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øe there mu≈øt be a pre≈øent tran≈øpo≈øition of the E≈øtate,Po≈øtea, Moor and Pitt. which is hindred by the Lea≈øe.

But in ca≈øe of a Fine, which is a Feoffment upon Record, a Lea≈øe for years is no impediment or di≈øplacing of the Rever≈øion; for if Tenant in Tayl, expectant upon a Lea≈øe for years, levy a Fine, 'tis a di≈øcontinuance of the Tayl, and notwith≈øtanding this Lea≈øe, the Fine has ≈øuch an operation upon the Free-hold, that it di≈øplaces the Rever≈øion in Fee, Co. Lit. 332. And therefore if a Lea≈øe for years prevents not a Di≈øcontinuance, it will much le≈øs hinder a di≈øplacing in this ca≈øe.

But no Iudgment was given now in this Ca≈øe; another matter being debated, whether the Plaintiff could have Iudgment, becau≈øe he was barred by the Statute of Limitations; for it did not appear that he had been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion for twenty years pa≈øt, and
the Verdict hath not found any Claim, or that the Plaintiff was within the Provi≈øo of the Act.

div.head: Waterfield ver≈øus the Bi≈øhop of Chiche≈øter.
div.p: Oath Ex Officio not to be admini≈øtred. A Prohibition was granted la≈øt Ea≈øter-Term, to the Bi≈øhop of Chiche≈øter, upon a Sugge≈øtion made by Waterfield, that he being cho≈øen Churchwarden of the Pari≈øh Church of Arundel in the County of Su≈ø≈øex, the Bi≈øhop tendered him an Oath ex officio, which was, that he ≈øhould Pre≈øent every Pari≈øhioner, who had done any Offence, or neglected any Duty mentioned in certain Articles, contained in a printed Book delivered to him; ≈øome of which Articles concern the Church-warden him≈øelf, and ≈øo in effect he was to ≈øwear again≈øt him≈øelf, in ca≈øe of any default, which is expre≈øsly again≈øt the Statute of 13 Car. 2.Sid. 232 cap. 12. which prohibits any per≈øon having Eccle≈øia≈øtical Iuri≈ødiction, to admini≈øter the Oath ex officio, or any other Oath, whereby the per≈øon to whom 'tis admini≈øtred, may be charged to accu≈øe him≈øelf of any criminal matter, whereby he may be lyable to any Cen≈øure or puni≈øhment; and becau≈øe the Bi≈øhop had Excommunicated him for refu≈øing ≈øuch Oath, he prayed a Prohibition, which was granted, quoad the compelling him to make any an≈øwer to the ≈øaid Articles concerning him≈øelf, and the Excommunication was di≈øcharged.

But now upon the motion of Serjeant Bramp≈øton a Con≈øultation was awarded, becau≈øe it appeared by the Affidavit of the Commi≈ø≈øary who tendred this Oath, and likewi≈øe by the act of the Court, that he was Excommunicated for refu≈øing to take the Oath of a Church warden, according to Law, which was the only Oath tendred, and therefore the ground of the Prohibition being fal≈øe, a Con≈øultation was awarded.

In this Prohibition it was recited, That the Bi≈øhop cannot give an Oath but in two ca≈øes, viz. in matters Te≈øtamentary, and Matrimonial, whereas they have authority in many ca≈øes more; 'tis true al≈øo, that until his Iuri≈ødiction was increa≈øed by Act of Parliament, he could hold Plea in none but tho≈øe two cau≈øes,2 In≈øt. 487, 537. but by the Statute De circum≈øpecte agatis, and of Articuli Cleri, he may now hold Plea in many other ca≈øes.

The Bi≈øhop informed the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice, that the Plaintiff Waterfeild had cau≈øed 2000 of the Prohibitions to be printed in Engli≈øh, and had di≈øper≈øed them all over the Kingdom,
intituling them a true tran≈ølated Copy of a Writ of Prohibition, granted by the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice, and other the Iu≈øtices of the Court of Common Pleas, in Ea≈øter-Term, 1676. again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Chiche≈øter, who had proceeded again≈øt and Excommunicated one Thomas Waterfield, a Churchwarden, for refu≈øing to take the Oath u≈øually tendred to per≈øons in ≈øuch Office; by which Writ the Illegality of all ≈øuch Oaths is declared, and the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop commanded to take off his Excommunication: And this was declared by the Court to be a mo≈øt ≈øeditious Libel, and gave order to enquire after the Printer that he might be pro≈øecuted.

div.head: Eleanor Plummer ver≈øus Sir Jeremy Whitchot, Intr. Trin. 27 or 28 Car. 2. Rot. 301. in B. R.
div.p: IN an Action of Debt for an E≈øcape; Vpon Nil debet pleaded,Debt for E≈øcape lies again≈øt the Warden of the Fleet, as ≈øuperior, the Grantee for life being in≈øufficient. Jones 60. 1 Vent. 314. the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict; upon which the Ca≈øe was this, Viz. That Sir Jeremy Whitchot was ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the Office of Warden of the Fleet, and of ≈øeveral Me≈øuages thereunto belonging, and being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, did make a Grant thereof to one Duckenfield for life, and for the lives of three more. Duckenfield by Rule of Court was admitted into the ≈øaid Office, being approved by the Court, and e≈øteemed a Man of an E≈øtate. He ≈øuffers a Pri≈øoner afterwards to E≈øcape, and being not able to make the Plaintiff ≈øatisfaction, this Action was brought again≈øt Sir Jeremy Whitchot, the now Defendant; and whether he was chargeable or not with this Action was the Que≈øtion.

Wallop, who argued for the Plaintiff ≈øaid,Ex parte Quer. That he would not take up any of their time to make a Narrative of Impri≈øonment for Debt, or what remedy there was for E≈øcapes at Common Law, and what remedy by the Statute; but ≈øuppo≈øing an Action of Debt will lye, whether it be by the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. cap. 11. (for at the Common Law before the making of that Act,Sid. 306, 397. an Action of Debt would not lye again≈øt the Goaler for an E≈øcape, but a ≈øpecial Action on the Ca≈øe, grounded on a Tre≈øpa≈øs) or whether this Action lay again≈øt the Defendant by the Statute of 1 R. 2. 2 In≈øt 382. cap. 12. which gives it again≈øt the Warden of the Fleet, who in this ca≈øe had not the actual Free-hold in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but the inheritance, and not the immediate E≈øtate, but the Rever≈øion, is in Que≈øtion.

The Office of the Warden of the Fleet, may be taken in two capacities, either as an E≈øtate or common Hereditament, wherein
a Man may have an Inheritance, and which may be tran≈øferred from one to another; or as a publick Office, wherein the King and the People may have a ≈øpecial Intere≈øt.

As 'tis an Inheritance transferrable, 'tis ≈øubject to the Rules of Law in point of De≈øcent, and is demi≈øable for Life, in Fee, Tayl, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or Rever≈øion, and in many things is common, and runs parallel with other E≈øtates of Inheritance. 'Tis true, he cannot grant this Office for years, not for any di≈øability in the Grantor, but in re≈øpect of the matter and nature of the thing granted, it being an Office of Tru≈øt and Per≈øonal, for otherwi≈øe it would go to the Executor, which is inconvenient, 9 Co. 96. Sir George Reynell's Ca≈øe.

To enquire what ≈øuperiority the rever≈øioner hath over the particular E≈øtate is not to the point in Que≈øtion; but there is ≈øuch an intimacy and privity between them, that in Iudgment of Law they are accounted as one E≈øtate.

And therefore Littleton Sect. 452, 453, ≈øaith, that a Relea≈øe made to a Rever≈øioner ≈øhall aid and benefit him who hath the particular E≈øtate, and likewi≈øe a Relea≈øe made to the Tenant of the Freehold, ≈øhall enure to him in Rever≈øion, becau≈øe they are privies in E≈øtate; ≈øo that the≈øe two E≈øtates in the Ca≈øe at Bar make but one Office.

This is a publick Office of great Tru≈øt, and concerns the Admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice; and therefore 'tis but rea≈øonable to admit the Rule of Re≈øpondeat Superior, le≈øt the Party ≈øhould be without remedy; and the rather, becau≈øe Execution is the life of the Law, 39 H. 6. 33.
He who is in the Office as Superiour, whether it be by droit or tort is accountable to the King and his People, and this brings him within the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. cap. 11. or 1 R. 2.

If the Defendant had granted the Office in Fee to Duckenfeild before any E≈øcape had been, and the Grantee had been admitted, the Defendant then had been di≈øcharged; or if he dye before or after the Action brought and before Iudgment, moritur actio cum per≈øona, for if he had not re≈øerved ≈øomething he could not be charged, and if he had parted with the Inheritance, the privity had been gon, but by re≈øerving that, he hath made him≈øelf liable; for now he is Superiour, he may exact Homage and Fealty, and the particular Tenant is ≈øaid to be attendant upon the Rever≈øion, and the≈øe are marks of Superiority.

And this Rule of re≈øpondeat ≈øuperior holds not only between the principal Officer and his Deputy, and between the Ma≈øter and his Servant; but in many other Ca≈øes one is to be an≈øwerable for another, as

1. Where a Man has power to elect an Officer, he is chargeable; ≈øo the County hath power to elect Coroners, and if they fail in their Duty, the County ≈øhall be charged, for by rea≈øon of the power they had to elect, they are e≈øteemed Superiours,4 In≈øt. 314. 2 In≈øt. 175.

2. Where one Man recommends another to an Office concerning the Kings Revenue, the per≈øon who recommends is liable, if the other prove in≈øufficient; and for this there is a notable Ca≈øe 30 E. 3. 6. 'Tis Porter's Ca≈øe, cited in the Ca≈øe of the Earl of Devon≈øhire, 11 Co. 92. b. Where Porter being Ma≈øter of the Mint, covenanted with the King to deliver him Mony within 8 days for all the Bullion delivered ad Cambium Regis to Coyn, which he did not perform, Et quia Walwyn & Picard duxerunt & prae≈øentaverunt the ≈øaid Porter, ideo con≈øideratum e≈øt quod onerentur ver≈øus Dominum Regem: 4 In≈øt. 466. And why not the Defendant in this Ca≈øe, who prae≈øentavit the ≈øaid Duckenfeild to the Court tanquam ≈øufficientem, the rea≈øon being the ≈øame? and the King is as much concerned in the ordering this Court of Iu≈øtice, as in the ordering of his Coffers; for as the Trea≈øure is Nervus Belli, ≈øo the execution of the Law is Nervus Pacis.

3. In the Ca≈øe of a dependant Officer, though he is a proper Officer and no Deputy, the per≈øon who hath the Rever≈øion ≈øhall an≈øwer, as in 32 H. 6. 34. 2 In≈øt. 382. 9 Rep. 98. Dyer 278. b. The Duke of Norfolk who had the Inheritance of the Mar≈øhal≈øea, was charged for an E≈øcape ≈øuffered by one Brandon, who was Tenant for Life, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Office; and there is great rea≈øon it ≈øhould be ≈øo; for when a principal Officer may make an inferiour Officer, who afterwards commits a Forfeiture, the ≈øuperiour ≈øhall take advantage of this Forfeiture, and 'tis as rea≈øonable he ≈øhould he an≈øwerable for his Mi≈øcarriage, Cro. Eliz. 384. Poph. 119 The Earl of Pembrook again≈øt Sir Henry Berkley.

And therefore admitting the Defendant is out of the Statute, yet he is within the Maxim of Re≈øpondeat Superior, which is not grounded upon any Act of Parliament, as appears in the Ca≈øe of the Coroner, and the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. And all other Acts which inculcate this Rule, are but in affirmance of the Common Law; and this is not only a Rule of the Common, but al≈øo of the Civil Law, which is ≈øerved with the Equity of this Maxim, in Ca≈øes of like nature; and ≈øince 'tis purely remedial, ≈øuch a Con≈øtruction ought to be made, as may mo≈øt advance the remedy, 2 In≈øt. 466.

In the Ca≈øe of Mor≈øe and Slue, lately in this Court,1 Ventr. 191, 238. the Que≈øtion was, whether a Ma≈øter of a Ship ≈øhould be charged upon
the Common Cu≈øtom of England, for negligently keeping Merchants Goods? And adjudged that he was, though robbed: Lex Mercatoria makes a provi≈øion for it; for the remedy again≈øt the Ma≈øter is mo≈øt direct and immediate; that again≈øt the Owner is collateral, in favour of the Merchant, to whom datur electio and therefore that the Intere≈øt of the Merchant might be ≈øerved, the Law in that ca≈øe provides a double Remedy.

And in Linwood, lib. 3. De Clerico non re≈øidente f. 73. verbo Vicarius; 'tis ≈øaid, that in the ≈øame Church there may be a Rector and a Vicar, and the Cure of the Church may be divided between them; the Vicar is not the Deputy of the Rector, but hath a di≈øtinct Office from him; and as the Temporalities of the Vicar are but a derivation from the Benefice of the Rector, ≈øo his Cure is derived from that of the Rector al≈øo.

In like manner, Duckenfield here is not a Deputy to the Defendant, but an immediate and proper Officer, and the habitual care and cu≈øtody is in him, which is enough to bring him within the Rule of Re≈øpondeat Superior.
The≈øe In≈øtances were given, becau≈øe this is not only a Maxim in England; but is of Foreign production, and adapted to the Rule of Common Law, Vide Bracton, Fleta, Selden.

The Statute de Scaccario 51 H. 3. Enacts, That if any man be received into Office in the Exchequer, without the Trea≈øurer's Licence, or if he hath ≈øuch Licence, and doth Tre≈øpa≈øs, he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed according to his Tre≈øpa≈øs, if he have whereof, and if he have not, then he who put him in the Office ≈øhall be charged, and if he be not ≈øufficient his Superiour ≈øhall be charged; ≈øo that they ≈øhall all an≈øwer in their ≈øeveral Stations. And this Statute was made in affirmance of the Common Law; if therefore the Superiour of a Superior ≈øhould an≈øwer, why ≈øhall not the Defendant in this ca≈øe an≈øwer for his ≈øub≈øtitute; for though the Warden is not ≈øworn to appoint one who is ≈øufficient to ≈øatisfie, he is bound to do it, and 'tis no argument to ≈øay that he is di≈øcharged, becau≈øe Duckenfield was appointed by the Court; for that is a work of ≈øupererrogation, which is left in the di≈øcretion of the Court, and may be done or omitted as they ≈øhall think nece≈ø≈øary, but is not conclu≈øive, 39 H. 6. 34. e≈øpecially ≈øince the Iury have not found that the Court took any examination whether he was ≈øufficient or not; but that he had forfeited his Office, having wilfully ≈øuffered a Pri≈øoner to E≈øcape, and then the Defendant is or may be the actual Officer, and having taken Security ought to be charged.

Sir William Jones, who argued on the other ≈øide,Ex parte Def. before he ≈øpoke to the Ca≈øe endeavoured to remove a doubt upon the Special Verdict, which found that the Defendant had taken Security from Duckenfield to indempnifie him from E≈øcapes.
This ≈øays he might be an Argument at a Ni≈øi Prius to induce a Iury to find Damages, but could not make a Man chargeable who was not ≈øo before.

2. Though the Defendant had a Covenant from Duckenfield to pay 1500 l. per annum to him, yet that will not make him more lyable than if nothing had been to be paid; neither did he lay any weight upon it, that the Defendant had any notice of the in≈øufficiency of Duckenfield, for if he is chargeable he is bound to take notice at his peril; and no Body can believe that the Court of Common Pleas is chargeable, for that was mentioned in the Argument for the Plaintiff, that the Superior of a Superior ≈øhall be charged where he is in≈øufficient; neither did he in≈øi≈øt upon the Rule in the Common Pleas, by which Duckenfield was admitted; but he con≈øidered,
1. Whether the Defendant was chargeable by the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. cap. 11.
2. If he could clear him from that Statute whether he was chargeable at the Common Law or by any other Statute.

And he ≈øaid that he was not chargeable by the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. which gives an Action of Debt again≈øt the Gaoler for an E≈øcape: Many Authorities might be cited to prove that where a Man is in Execution on an Action of Debt, that ≈øuch an Execution is not within that Statute, 7 H. 6. 5. Bro. tit. E≈øcape pl. 9. Pl. Com. 35. It was doubtful there how a Gaoler became chargeable for the E≈øcape of a Man who was in Execution for Debt; but were he in Execution for Matter of Accompt he is chargeable by the expre≈øs Words of the Statute, which are Caveat ≈øibi Vicecomes & Cu≈øtos Gaolae; and the Parliament in 1 R. 2. did not think the Warden chargeable, for if they did, to what purpo≈øe was it to make the Warden of the Fleet lyable to an Action of Debt for an E≈øcape of a Man in Execution for Debt, if he was chargeadle before by that Statute of We≈øtm. 2; This was urged to ≈øhew that at that time it was not clear.
But becau≈øe there are Authorities that ≈øeem another way, he did not affirm or deny it after ≈øuch varieties of Opinions, but proc√©eded to argue the≈øe two Points.
1. That the Rule of Re≈øpondeat Superior doth not extend to this Ca≈øe.
2. That a Rever≈øioner is not a Superior.

Po≈øtea. 1. The Statute de Donis is by ≈øome called the Statute of great Men, becau≈øe the intent of it was for the pre≈øervation of their E≈øtates; and this Statute being made in the ≈øame13 Ed. 1. year ≈øeems al≈øo to have a particular regard to the Lord to give him a quick and more ≈øevere remedy again≈øt his Servant and Bayliff than he had before; for it makes him in effect his own Iudge again≈øt him in Ca≈øes of Accompt, becau≈øe it gives him Authority to a≈ø≈øign Auditors, and ≈øuch as he appoints mu≈øt ≈øtand, and the Servant has no remedy but by WritF. N. B. 129. ex parte talis in the Exchequer; yet no Man ever thought that by the Equity of this Statute the ≈øame may be done in an Action of Debt, and therefore the difference in the Proceedings between Actions of Accompt and Debt ≈øeems to imply that an Action of Debt is not within the Rule of Re≈øpondeat Superior.

2. There is a great difference betwe√©n the Re≈øtraint of Pri≈øo≈øoners in Execution for Debt, and tho≈øe who are impri≈øoned by this Act for Arrear of Rent, which directs that they ≈øhall be arre≈øted &c. & carceri mancipentur in ferris; but this the Gaoler could not have done at the Common Law; neither was it ever practi≈øed or allowed by the Law that a Pri≈øoner ≈øhould be ≈øo u≈øed, who is in Execution for Debt, unle≈øs he be unruly and endeavour to e≈øcape; but 'tis expre≈øly again≈øt the Law to do it where there is no ≈øuch rea≈øon, becau≈øe a Pri≈øon is for the ≈øafe Cu≈øtody of Men and not to puni≈øh them, 1 In≈øt. 260. a. So that it appears by this that a ≈øtricter remedy was provided for Executions in Accompt than for tho≈øe in Debt.

2. Point. 1. Becau≈øe he in Rever≈øion is not in propriety of Speech a Superior; for 'tis not ≈øaid that a Rever≈øioner after an E≈øtate for Life is Superior and of more accompt in the Law than he who hath the particular E≈øtate, but on the contrary he who hath the Fr√©ehold is of greater accompt and regard in the Law than the Rever≈øioner after him; and if (as it hath been objected) both make but one E≈øtate then there can be no Superiority, and it would be very hard and difficult for any Man to prove that any Attendancy is made by the Tenant for Life upon him who hath the Rever≈øion.

2. Here is room enough within the Statute to ≈øatisfie that word Superior by a plain and clear con≈øtruction without bringing in the Rever≈øioner; for if the Sheriff makes a Deputy or a Lord makes Bayliff of a Liberty, the Sheriff and the Lord are properly the Superiors.

3. This word Superior is u≈øed in the Statute made the ≈øame year with this cap. 2. in ≈øignification agreeable with the Ca≈øe in que≈øtion; for it recites that where Lords of Fees di≈øtrain their Tenants for Rents and Services, and they having replevied their Cattle do alien or ≈øell them, ≈øo that a Return cannot be made; then it provides that the Sheriff or Bailiff ≈øhall take Pledges to pro≈øecute the Suit before they make deliverance of the Di≈øtre≈øs, and if the Bayliff be not able to re≈øtore (that is, if he take in≈øufficient Pledges) the Superior ≈øhall an≈øwer, by which the Parliament could mean no other than the Lord of that Liberty; for if it ≈øhould be otherwi≈øe there would be no end of Superiors; as if there is a Bailiwick in Fee of a Liberty, and the Bayliff thereof grants it for Life, in this Ca≈øe there are two Superiors, for the Lord of the Bayliff is one, and the Bayliff him≈øelf is another, which cannot be, 2 In≈øt. 382.
There is a Congruity in Law in ≈øaying the Sheriff and Lord are Superiors, but there can be none in making the Rever≈øioner a Superior.

The Lord may lo≈øe the Liberty if his Bayliff for Life or in Fee commit a Forfeiture, as by not attending the Iu≈øtices in Eyre; but a Rever≈øion cannot be lo≈øt by the Forfeiture of the Tenant for Life; if the Bayliff make an ill Execution of a Writ or ≈øuffer the Party to e≈øcape, the Lord ≈øhall an≈øwer; ≈øo if the Mar≈øhal of England appoint a Mar≈øhal there may be a Forfeiture of his Office, becau≈øe 'tis but ≈øtill the ≈øame Office; and therefore the Ca≈øe in Cro. Eliz. 386. where 'tis ≈øaid, If an Office be granted for Life, the Forfeiture of Tenant for Life ≈øhall be the Forfeiture of the whole Office, is mi≈øtaken; for in Moor pl. 987. 'tis held otherwi≈øe; and upon the true difference between a Deputy and a
Grante√© for Life; for in the fir≈øt Ca≈øe there may be a Forfeiture of the Superior, becau≈øe 'tis ≈øtill but the ≈øame Office; but in the other Ca≈øe the Superior ≈øhall not forfeit for any Misdemeanour of the Grant√©e for Life, becau≈øe he hath the Freehold of the whole Office, and the other nothing but the Rever≈øion, and therefore if the Defendant be liable in this Ca≈øe 'tis in re≈øpect,
1. That he hath granted the E≈øtate.
2. That he hath the Rever≈øion or Re≈øidue after the Life of the Grantee.

He cannot be charged in re≈øpect that he hath granted the E≈øtate, becau≈øe the Freehold is gone and in another; neither can he be charged in re≈øpect of the Rever≈øion, becau≈øe then not only his Heir but the A≈ø≈øigne√© of the Rever≈øion will be chargeable al≈øo, which cannot be.
As to the ≈øecond Point of this Argument; if the Defendant is not chargeable by this Statute he is not to be charged at the Common Law.
Sid. 306, 397. 2. Becau≈øe the Common Law doth not give an Action of Debt for an E≈øcape, but an Action on the Ca≈øe only; neither doth it give any Remedy but again≈øt the Party offending.

As to the Ca≈øe that hath be√©n objected upon the Statute de Scaccario, where the ≈øeveral Officers in the Exchequer ≈øhall an≈øwer in their degr√©es of Superiority, that cannot be applicable to this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe there can be no proportion betwe√©n things which concern the Kings Revenue and Prerogative, and tho≈øe of a common per≈øon.

The Ca≈øes of the Coroner and the Sheriff, and of the recommending of a Receiver to the King are not like this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe the King cannot inform him≈øelf of the ≈øufficiency of the Party recommended, and therefore 'tis but rea≈øonable that he who recommends ≈øhould be liable; and can it be ≈øaid that when the Defendant was about to ≈øell this Office to one Norwood (which he hath ≈øince done) that if a Stranger had recommended Norwood and he had proved in≈øufficient, that the Stranger would have b√©en liable?
As for the Civil Law and the Authorities therein cited to govern this Ca≈øe, he did not an≈øwer them becau≈øe they judge after their Law, and the Common Lawyers after another way.
This Office hath b√©en granted time out of mind for Life, and no doubt but many E≈øcapes have been made, but never was any Action brought again≈øt him in the Rever≈øion before now.

The Court of Common Pleas always examine the ≈øufficiency of the Grantee for Life, which ≈øhews that in all ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Ages the Opinions of Learned Men were, that no E≈øcape could be
brought again≈øt the Rever≈øioner; for if ≈øo, what need is there of ≈øuch Examination? This was urged to ≈øhew that the Proceedings of that Court did not alter, but interpret the Law.

But admitting the Ca≈øe of the Duke of Norkfolk to be Law, yet it concerns not this, becau≈øe the Sub Mar≈øhal there was taken as a Deputy, but there is no ≈øuch Officer as a Sub-Warden, for Duckenfield had it for Life.

And then a Deputy being a per≈øon removable at plea≈øure, will not be ≈øo con≈øidered in Law, as one who hath a more fixed E≈øtate; for having nothing to lo≈øe, it cannot be intended that he will be ≈øo careful in the execution of his Office, as the other; and therefore 'tis rea≈øonable in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, that the Superiour ≈øhould an≈øwer: But he who hath a Freehold for Life, hath an E≈øtate of ≈øome value in the Law, which he cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed ea≈øily to forfeit, and therefore 'tis rea≈øonable that he alone ≈øhould be lyable for his own Mi≈øcarriages; for if the Defendant ≈øhould be charged, by the ≈øame rea≈øon the Grantee of the Rever≈øion may be charged, who is altogether an innocent per≈øon, and ≈øo may be liable to a va≈øt Sum for the Fault of another; for which Rea≈øons he prayed Iudgment for the Defendant.

The Court delivered no Opinion this Term,Judgment. but took time to advi≈øe; and afterwards in Ea≈øter Term following Rainsford Chief Iu≈øtice delivered the Opinions of Twi≈øden, Wild and Jones Iu≈øtices, who ≈øaid they were all agre√©ing in the main Point, but thought the Verdict imperfect, and not to warrant the Plaintiffs Ca≈øe; for he declared that at the time when the Grant was made to Duckenfield, when the Commitment was, and when the E≈øcape was ≈øuffered, and ever ≈øince, that Duckenfield was in≈øufficient and not able to an≈øwer the Plaintiff; but the Iury in the Special Verdict do not find the in≈øufficiency at that time when this Action was brought.

But as to the main Que≈øtion they were of Opinion that the Defendant was Superior, and that he is chargeable for this in≈øufficiency of Duckenfield; but if he had b√©en ≈øufficient when the Plaintiff brought this Action, it might have been otherwi≈øe; but his Inability being fully averred in the Declaration; and the Defendant denying it, and the Iury having found nothing again≈øt it, but there being ≈øtrong Su≈øpicions of the truth of the Fact, the Court would not make an intendment to the contrary.

The Iury have found expre≈øly that Duckenfield was in≈øufficient at the time of the E≈øcape, which was within ≈øix Weeks of the time when the Action was commenced; ≈øo that having once found him di≈øabled, unle≈øs it appear that he was of Ability afterwards,
the Court will not intend him ≈øo; but rather that he was in≈øufficient at the time of the Action brought; for there being ≈øtrong ≈øurmi≈øes of it, and there being no ground within the Record to intend him ≈øufficient, a Fact may be collected that is not found in the Verdict, Fulwoods Ca≈øe, 4 Co.

div.head: The King ver≈øus Moor.
div.p: Difference between a prohibitory Clau≈øe, and a Clau≈øe which gives a Penalty in a Statute.AN Information was brought upon the Statute of the 4th & 5th of Philip and Mary, cap. 8. which Enacts, That if any Per≈øon, &c. above the Age of 14 ≈øhall after the fir≈øt day of April (next after the making the Statute) unlawfully take a Maid or Woman unmarried, being within the Age of 16 years, &c. the Party ≈øhall ≈øuffer two years Impri≈øonment, or pay ≈øuch Fine as ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in the Star Chamber, and that the Defendant exi≈øtens ≈øupra aetatem quatuordecim annorum did take a young Maid away unmarried, and kept her three days contra formam Statuti; upon which he was found Guilty, and now moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment.

1. It was ≈øaid for the Defendant, that this Court could not Fine him upon this Statute, becau≈øe when the Informer entitles him≈øelf by a Statute, he mu≈øt take the remedy therein pre≈øcribed; and ≈øo 'tis not like an Information at the Common Law, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe this Court might Fine the Plaintiff.
2. It is not averred, that the party offending was above the age of 14 years at the time of taking, but only that he being above the age of 14 ≈øuch a day did take.

Where there are not Negative Words, the Court of Kings Bench is not re≈øtrained. Mod. Rep. 34. Sid. 359.Sir William Jones contra. If the fir≈øt Objection hath any weight in it, 'tis to bring the Party to an Impri≈øonment for the ≈øpace of two years, which is a puni≈øhment directed by that Statute, but the Fine is limited to the Star Chamber, and tho≈øe Offences which were puni≈øhable there, are likewi≈øe to be puni≈øhed here, becau≈øe there are no Negative words in this Statute to abridge the authority of this Court, which is never re≈øtrained, but when the Statute directs before whom the Offence ≈øhall be Tried, and not el≈øewhere. It was the Opinion of my Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Hales, That where there is a prohibitory Clau≈øe in a Statute, and another Clau≈øe which gives a Penalty, if the Party will go upon the prohibitory Clau≈øe, Po≈øtea. he is not confined to the manner expre≈ø≈øed in the Statute, but if he will go upon the Penalty, he mu≈øt then pur≈øue what the Statute directs.

The fir≈øt part of this Statute is but a Declaration of the Common Law; the ≈øecond Clau≈øe is introductive of a new Law as to the Court of Star Chamber, but is not a re≈øtriction as to this Court, which might have puni≈øhed the Defendant if there had been no ≈øuch Law. The fir≈øt Clau≈øe is prohibitory, viz. That it ≈øhall not be lawful for any per≈øon to take away a Maid unmarried, and upon this Clau≈øe this Information is brought: The ≈øecond Clau≈øe is di≈øtinct, and directs the puni≈øhment, viz. Upon Conviction to ≈øuffer Impri≈øonment for two years. Now by taking away the Court of Star Chamber, this prohibitory Clau≈øe is not repealed, upon which a Man may be Indicted without demanding the Penalty; and the Statute having directed that the Offence ≈øhall be heard and determined before the Kings Council in the Star Chamber, or before the Iudge of A≈ø≈øi≈øe, and no Negative words to re≈øtrain this Court; therefore the Chief Iu≈øtice, who is the Iudge ofCro. Car. 463. A≈ø≈øi≈øe in the County of Middle≈øex, may hear and determine this Offence, and by con≈øequence Fine the Party if he be found Guilty.

As to the ≈øecond Objection, That it is not averred, that the Party offending was above the age of 14 years at the time of the taking, it had been better if it had been ≈øaid tunc exi≈øten' ≈øupra aetatem quatuordecim annorum; but notwith≈øtanding 'tis well enough; for 'tis ≈øaid, that being above the age of 14 years, ≈øuch a day he did take, &c. ≈øo that it cannot be otherwi≈øe but that he was of ≈øuch an age at the time when the Maid was taken; and the Iury found him Guilty contra formam Statuti; which may likewi≈øe be an An≈øwer to the fir≈øt Objection; for he being found Guilty contra formam Statuti, if there be any other Statute which prohibits and puni≈øhes a Riot, this Information is as well grounded upon ≈øuch, as upon this Statute of Philip and Mary, for 'tis expre≈øly ≈øaid, that the Defendant and others did unlawfully a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelves together, and rioto≈øe & routo≈øe made an A≈ø≈øault upon her, ≈øo that it ≈øhall be intended to be grounded upon ≈øuch a Law, as ≈øhall be be≈øt for puni≈øhing the Offence.

The Court were of Opinion,Curia. That notwith≈øtanding the≈øe Exceptions, the Information was good, and was not like the Ca≈øe of an Indictment upon the Statute for a forceable Entry, That ≈øuch a day by force and arms the Defendant did Enter into ≈øuch a Hou≈øe,2 Cro. 14610 639. exi≈øten' liberum tenementum of J. N. and if he doth not ≈øay tunc exi≈øten' the Indictment is naught, becau≈øe the Iury may enquire of a thing before it is done; but here the exi≈øten being added to the per≈øon, carries the ≈øen≈øe to the time of the Offence committed.

The Statute of 1 R. 3. ≈øaith, that all Grants made by Ce≈øtui que u≈øe being of full Age, ≈øhall be good again≈øt him and his Heirs, and 'tis adjudged 16 H. 7. that he need not ≈øhew when and where, but generally exi≈øten' of full Age, and upon the Evidence it mu≈øt be ≈øo proved.

Where a thing relates to the Condition of a Man, it ≈øhall be tryed in the County where the Action is laid, and 'tis not nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øay in what County he is a Knight or an E≈øquire; any Citizen and Freeman may devi≈øe his Land in Mortmain, by the Cu≈øtom of London; 'tis enough to ≈øay in Pleading exi≈øten' a Citizen and Freeman without ≈øetting forth when and where.
If a Man be Indicted for not coming to Church, 'tis enough to ≈øay exi≈øten' of the Age of 16 years, he did not come to Church.

This is an Offence puni≈øhable at Common Law, 'tis malum in ≈øe. But admitting 'twas an Offence created by the Statute, there being no Negative words to prohibit, this Court hath a Iurisdiction to puni≈øh this Offence, if the Star Chamber had not been taken away; for the Party had his election to proceed in this Court upon the prohibitory Clau≈øe, and the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øe mu≈øt be intended the Iu≈øtices of Oyer and Terminer, Moor 564. Whereupon the Defendant was Fined 500 l. and bound to his good Behaviour for a Year.

div.head: Brown ver≈øus Waite.
div.p: Entailed Lands forfeited for Trea≈øon. Jones 57. 1 Ventr. 299.UPon a Special Verdict in Ejectment, The Ca≈øe was, viz. Sir John Danvers, the Father of the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, was in Anno Domini 1646. Tenant in Tail of the Lands now in Que≈øtion; and was afterwards in≈øtrumental in bringing the late King Charles to death, and ≈øo was guilty of High Trea≈øon, and dyed.

Afterwards the Act of Pains and Penalties, made 13 Car. 2. cap. 15. Enacts, That all the Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments, which Sir John Danvers had the 25th day of March, in the year 1646. or at any time ≈øince, ≈øhall be forfeited to the King.
And whether the≈øe entailed Lands ≈øhall be forfeited to the King by force of this Act, was the Que≈øtion.
Wallop, who argued for the Plaintiff ≈øaid, that the entailed Lands were not forfeited, his Rea≈øons were,
1. The≈øe Lands entailed are not expre≈øsly named in that Act.

2. Tenant in Tail hath but an E≈øtate for Life in his Lands, and therefore by the≈øe words (All his Lands) tho≈øe which are entailed cannot be intended; for if he grant totum ≈øtatum ≈øuum, only an E≈øtate for Life pa≈ø≈øeth.

3. The≈øe Lands are not forfeited by the Statute of 26 H. 8. cap. 13. which gives the forfeiture of entailed Lands, in ca≈øe of Trea≈øon; hecau≈øe Sir John Danvers was not convicted of it by Proce≈øs, Pre≈øentment, Confe≈ø≈øion, Verdict or Outlawry, which that Statute doth require, for he dyed before any ≈øuch Conviction.
Sir Francis Winnington the Kings Solicitor, argued contra, that entailed Lands are forfeited by the Act of Pains and Penalties; and in ≈øpeaking to this matter, he con≈øidered.
1. The words of that Act.
2. How E≈øtates Tail were created, and how forfeitable for Trea≈øon.
1. This Act recites the Act of general Pardon, which did not intend to di≈øcharge the Lands of Sir John Danvers and others from a Forfeiture.
2. It recites that he was Guilty of High Trea≈øon.

3. Then comes the enacting Clau≈øe, Viz. That all the Lands, Tenements, Rights, Intere≈øts, Offices, Annuities, and all other Hereditaments, Lea≈øes, Chattels, and other things of what nature ≈øoever, of him the ≈øaid Sir John Danvers and others, which they had on the 25th of March 1646. or at any time ≈øince, ≈øhall be forfeited to the King his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors.
2. As to the creation of Intails, there were no ≈øuch E≈øtates at the Common Law; they were all Fee-≈øimple Conditional, and po≈øt prolem ≈øu≈øcitatam the Condition was performed for three purpo≈øes.
Viz. To Alien, Co. Lit. 19. a. 2 In≈øt. 334.
To Forfeit.

Or to charge with a Rent; and thus the Law continued till 13 E. 1. and there having been frequent Warrs between King John and the Barons, the great Men then obtained the Statute De donis to pre≈øerve their E≈øtates, le≈øt the like occa≈øion ≈øhould happen again; in which 'tis only mentioned, that the Tenant in Tail ≈øhould not have power to alien; but it was well known, that if he could not alien, he could not forfeit, for before that Statute, as he might alien po≈øt prolem ≈øu≈øcitatam, ≈øo the Iudges always con≈øtrued that he might forfeit, 5 Edw. 3.14. for forfeiture
and alienation did always go hand in hand, 1 Co. 175. Mildmay's Ca≈øe.

And from the making of that Statute, it always continued a ≈øetled and received Opinion, That Tenant in Tail could not alien, until by the 12th of Ed. 4. a Recovery came in, by which the E≈øtate Tail may be docked, and which is now become a Common A≈ø≈øurance.

Then by the Statute of 4 H. 7. cap. 24. Tenant in Tail might bar his I≈ø≈øue by Fine and Proclamation, and all this while it was not thought that ≈øuch Lands could be forfeited for Trea≈øon; which Opinion continued during all the Reign of H. 7. for though by his Marriage the Hou≈øes of York and Lanca≈øter were united, yet the Great Men in tho≈øe days thought there might be ≈øome doubt about the Succe≈ø≈øion, after the death of H. 7. if he ≈øhould dye without I≈ø≈øue, and thereby tho≈øe differences might be again revived, and therefore no endeavours were u≈øed to make any alteration in the Law, till after the death of H. 7. And after his Son H. 8. had I≈ø≈øue, tho≈øe doubts were removed, and being never likely to ari≈øe again, then the Act of 26 H. 8. was made, which gives a Forfeiture of entailed Lands in ca≈øes of Trea≈øon.

The inference from this will be, that all the Ca≈øes put before the 26th year of H. 8. and ≈øo before entailed Lands were made forfeitable for Trea≈øon; and where by the general Words of Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments, 'twas adjudged entailed Lands did not pa≈øs, do not concern this Ca≈øe; but now ≈øince they are made forfeitable by that Statute, ≈øuch general words are ≈øufficient to ≈øerve the turn.

By the Statute of 16 R. 2. cap. 5. entailed Lands are not forfeited in a Praemunire but during the Life of Tenant in Tail; becau≈øe they were not then to be forfeited for Trea≈øon,2 In≈øt. 334. 1 In≈øt. 3. Co. Lit. 130.

If then it appears that the Crime of which Sir John Danvers was guilty, was Trea≈øon; and if entailed Lands are forfeited for Trea≈øon, then when the Act ≈øaith, That he ≈øhall forfeit all his Lands; by tho≈øe general Words his entailed Lands ≈øhall be forfeited: And though by the Common Law there can be no Attainder in this Ca≈øe, the Party being dead; yet by Act of Parliament that may be done, and the words in this Act amount to an Attainder.

The intent of it was to forfeit E≈øtates Tail, which may be collected from the general Words; for if a Fee-≈øimple is forfeited, though not named, why not an E≈øtate Tail? e≈øpecially ≈øince the word Hereditaments is very comprehen≈øive, and may take in both tho≈øe E≈øtates, Spelman's Glo≈ø≈øary 227. 2 Roll. Rep. 503.

In the very Act of 26 H. 8. cap. 13. E≈øtates Tail are not named, for the Words are, Every Offender convict of Trea≈øon, &c. ≈øhall forfeit all ≈øuch Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments which he ≈øhall have of any E≈øtate of Inheritance, in u≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or by any Right, Title or Means, &c. and yet a Con≈øtruction hath been made thereupon in favour of the Crown; ≈øo a Dignity of an Earldom intailed is forfeitable by this Statute by the Word Hereditament, 7 Co. 34.
Afterwards in Hillary Term Rainsford Chief Iu≈øtice delivered the Opinion of the Court,Judgment. That upon Con≈øtruction of the Act of Pains and Penalties this E≈øtate Tail was forfeited to the King.

He agreed the Series and progre≈øs of E≈øtates Tail to have been as argued by the Solicitor; and that the Que≈øtion now was whether by the Act of Pains, &c. E≈øtates Tail can be forfeited unle≈øs there are expre≈øs Words to take away the force of the Statute de donis conditionalibus; Preface to 3 Co. for by that Statute there was a ≈øettled perpetuity; Tenant in Tail could neither forfeit or alien his E≈øtate, no not in Ca≈øe of Trea≈øon, and Forfeiture is a kind of Alienation; but afterwards by the Re≈øolution in Ed. 4. an Alienation by a Common Recovery was con≈øtrued to be out of the ≈øaid Statute, and by the Statute of Fines 4 H. 7. which is expounded by a ≈øub≈øequent Statute of 32 H. 8. cap. 36. Tenant in Tail notwith≈øtanding his former re≈øtraint had power to alien the E≈øtate Tail and barr his I≈ø≈øue; but all this while his E≈øtate was not to be forfeited for Trea≈øon, till the Statute of 33 H. 8. cap. 20. which gives U≈øes, Rights, Entries, Conditions, as well as Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, Rever≈øions, Remainders, and all other things of a per≈øon attainted of Trea≈øon by the Common or Statute Law of the Realm to the King, as if ≈øuch Attainder had been by Act of Parliament.

Then by the Statute of 5 & 6 Ed. cap. 11. 'tis Enacted, That an Offender being guilty of High Trea≈øon and lawfully convict, ≈øhall forfeit to the King all ≈øuch Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments which he ≈øhall have of any E≈øtate of Inheritance in his own Right in U≈øe or Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; by which Statutes, that de donis conditionalibus was taken off in Ca≈øes of Trea≈øon, as it had been before by the re≈øolution in 12 E. 4. and by the Statute of Fines, as to the Alienation of an E≈øtate Tail by Fine and Recovery.

If therefore this Act of Pains, &c. will admit of ≈øuch a con≈øtruction as to make E≈øtates Tail forfeit; here is a Crime great
enough to de≈øerve ≈øuch a great puni≈øhment; a Crime for which the Parliament hath ordered an Anniver≈øary to be kept for ever with Fa≈øting and Humiliation to implore that the Guilt of that innocent Blood then ≈øhed may not be required of our Po≈øterity; this they e≈øteemed as another kind of Original Sin, which unle≈øs thus expiated might extend not only ad Natos ≈øed qui na≈øcantur ab illis.
And that this Act will admit of ≈øuch a Con≈øtruction the≈øe Rea≈øons were given.

1. From the general comprehen≈øive Words mentioning tho≈øe things which are to be forfeited, viz. Me≈ø≈øuages, Lands, Tenements, Rever≈øions and Intere≈øts, which la≈øt Word ≈øignifies the E≈øtate in the Land as well as the Land it ≈øelf, or otherwi≈øe the Word mu≈øt be con≈øtrued to have no effect.

2. E≈øtates Tail are not now protected by the Clau≈øe in the Statute de donis In≈øt. 334. Non habet pote≈øtatem alienandi, but are ≈øubject to the forfeiture by the Act of H. 8. which though it extends to Attainders only, yet 'tis a good Rule for the Iudges to make a Con≈øtruction of an Act of Parliament by, e≈øpecially in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe as this, wherein 'tis plain that the Law did look upon the≈øe Offenders, if not attainted, yet in pari gradu with ≈øuch per≈øons, and therefore may be a good Warrant to make the like Con≈øtruction as in Ca≈øes of Attainder.

3. Becau≈øe the Offenders are dead; for had they b√©en living there might have been better rea≈øon to have con≈øtrued this Act not to extend to E≈øtates Tail, becau≈øe then ≈øomething might be forfeited, viz. an E≈øtate for Life; and therefore the Act would ≈øignifie very little if ≈øuch Con≈øtruction could not be made of it to reach E≈øtates Tail of ≈øuch per≈øons who were dead at the time of the making the Law, e≈øpecially ≈øince 'tis well known that when Men engage in ≈øuch Crimes they give what Protection they can to their E≈øtates, and place them as far as they can out of danger.

4. It appears by the Act that the Law-makers did not intend that the Children of ≈øuch Offenders ≈øhould have any benefit of their E≈øtates, becau≈øe in the Provi≈øo there is a ≈øaving of all E≈øtates of Purcha≈øers for Mony bona fide paid, and therein al≈øo a particular Exception of the Wife and Children and Heirs of the Offenders; and if the Act would not protect the E≈øtate of the Children though they ≈øhould be Purcha≈øers for a valuable con≈øideration, it will never protect their E≈øtate under a voluntary Conveyance made by the Ance≈øtor, e≈øpecially in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe the Entail carries a ≈øu≈øpicion with it that it was de≈øigned with a pro≈øpect to commit this Crime; for Sir John Danvers was Tenant
in Tail before; and in the year 1647. levies a Fine to barr that Entail, and then limits a new E≈øtate Tail to him≈øelf, in which there is a Provi≈øion to make Lea≈øes for any number of years upon what Lives ≈øoever, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or Rever≈øion, with Rent or without it, and this was but the year before the Crime committed.

5. The Provi≈øo in the Act for ≈øaving the E≈øtates of Purcha≈øers doth protect all Conveyances and A≈ø≈øurances, &c. of Land not being the Lands of the late King, Queen, Prince, &c. and not being Land ≈øold for any pretended Delinquency ≈øince the fir≈øt of June, 1641. and all Statutes and Judgments ≈øuffered by the Offenders from being impeached; from which it appears that the Parliament lookt upon entailed Lands as forfeited; for if E≈øtates made to others upon a valuable con≈øideration had need of a Provi≈øo to ≈øave them from Forfeiture, √† fortiori, the E≈øtates out of which tho≈øe are derived have need of ≈øuch a ≈øaving, and therefore mu≈øt be forfeit by the Act; for which Rea≈øons the≈øe Lands are forfeited.

As to the great Objection which hath been made and in≈øi≈øted on the other ≈øide, and which is Trudgeons Ca≈øe, 22 Eliz. 1 In≈øt. 130. Where Tenant in Tail was attainted in a Praemunire, and it was adjudged that he ≈øhould forfeit his Land but during his Life; for though the Statue of 16 R. 2. cap. cap. 5. Enacts, That in ≈øuch Ca≈øe their Lands, Tenements, Goods and Chattels ≈øhall be forfeited to the King; yet that mu≈øt be under≈øtood of ≈øuch an E≈øtate as he may lawfully forfeit, and that is during his own life, and therefore being general Words they do not take away the force of the Statute de donis, ≈øo that his Lands in Fee-≈øimple, for life, &c. ≈øhall be forfeited, but the Land entailed ≈øhall not, during his life.

But the An≈øwer is plain: For in the Reign of R. 2. when the Statute of Praemunire was made, E≈øtates Tail were under a Perpetuity by the ≈øaid Statute de donis, which Statute is now much weakened in the Point of Alienation; and the Law is quite altered ≈øince that time; and 'tis apparent by multitude of Pre≈øidents that ≈øuch ≈øtrict Con≈øtructions have not been made ≈øince that time to pre≈øerve E≈øtates Tail from Forfeitures without ≈øpecial and particular Words;4 Co. 164. and therefore in the Ca≈øe of Adams and Lambert, which is a Ca≈øe in Point, the Iudges there con≈øtrued E≈øtates Tail to be forfeit for want of ≈øpecial Words in the Statute of 1 E. 6. cap. 14. to ≈øave it; and that was only a Law made for ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of ≈øuper≈øtitious V≈øes upon a politick con≈øideration; but this is a much greater Offence intended to be puni≈øhed by this Act, in which there are demon≈øtrations both from
the Words and intent of the Law-makers to make this E≈øtate forfeited to the Crown than in that Ca≈øe ≈øo much relied on: And Iudgment was given accordingly.
Wyld died before Iudgment was given; but Iu≈øtice Twi≈øden ≈øaid he was of that Opinion, and Jones Iu≈øtice concurred.

div.head: Ba≈ø≈øet ver≈øus Salter.
div.p: After an E≈øcape the Plaintiff may have a Ca. Sa. or Sci. Fa. again≈øt the Sheriff.IN an Action for an E≈øcape; the Que≈øtion was whether the Plaintiff may take out a Ca. Sa. or have a Fi. Fa. again≈øt the Defendant after the Sheriff or Gaoler voluntarily ≈øuffer him to e≈øcape; but the Court would not ≈øuffer it to be argued, becau≈øe it had been lately ≈øettled that it was at the Election of the Plaintiff to do either; and upon a Writ of Error brought in the Exchequer-Chamber the Iudges there were of the ≈øame Opinion: But in the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Vaughan's time the Court of Common Pleas were divided, but 'tis ≈øince ≈øettled, 1 Roll. Abridg. 901, 902.

If there be an E≈øcape by the Plaintiffs con≈øent, though he did not intend it, the Law is hard that the Debt ≈øhould be thereby di≈øcharged; as where one was in execution in the Kings Bench, and ≈øome Propo≈øals were made to the Plaintiff in behalf of the Pri≈øoner, who ≈øeeing there was ≈øome likelyhood of an Accomodation con≈øented to a Meeting in London, and de≈øired the Pri≈øoner might be there, who came accordingly, and this was held to be an E≈øcape with theIf it had been by the con≈øent of the Sheriff, he could never take him again, but the Plaintiff might. Sid. 330. con≈øent of the Plaintiff, and he could never after be in Execution at his Suit for the ≈øame Matter.

div.head: Peck ver≈øus Hill. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Bond good given in di≈øcharge of another Mod. Rep. 221.DEBT upon a Bond brought again≈øt the Defendant as Admini≈øtrator, who pleads that he gave another Bond in his own Name in di≈øcharge of the fir≈øt Bond; and upon I≈ø≈øue joined it was found for the Defendant; and it was moved that Iudgment might not be entred hereupon, becau≈øe it was a bad Plea.

But North Chief Iu≈øtice, and Wyndham and Scroggs Iu≈øtices, were of Opinion that it was a good Plea, becau≈øe there was other Security given than what the Plaintiff had before; for upon the fir≈øt Bond he was only lyable de bonis Inte≈øtatoris, but now he might be charged in his own Right,Co. Lit. 122. b. which may be well ≈øaid to be in full ≈øatisfaction of the fir≈øt Obligation; for where the Condition is for payment of Mony to the Party him≈øelf, there if he accept any collateral thing in ≈øatisfaction, 'tis good.

If a Security be given by a Stranger, it may di≈øcharge a former Bond, and this in effect is given by ≈øuch: And 'tis not like the Ca≈øe in Hobert, where a Bond was given by the ≈øame Party upon that very day a former Bond was payable, and adjudged not a good di≈øcharge; for the Obligee was in no better condition than he was before.

Iu≈øtice Atkins doubted, but inclined that one Bond cannot be di≈øcharged by giving another, though the Di≈øcharge be applied to the Condition of the Bond; and for this he cited,Cro. Car. 85. Cro. Eliz. 716, 727. which was a Ca≈øe adjudged ≈øo in Point; and therefore this Plea upon Demurrer ≈øhould have been over-ruled; yet ≈øince I≈ø≈øue was taken upon it, and a Verdict for the Defendant the Plea is helped by the Statute of Jeofails, 32 H. 8. here being a direct Affirmative and Negative.

But as to that, the Chief Iu≈øtice and Scroggs Iu≈øtice replied, that an immaterial I≈ø≈øue no ways ari≈øing from the Matter is not helped; as an Action of Debt upon a Bond laid to be made in London, and the Defendant ≈øaith that it was made in Middle≈øex, and this is tried, 'tis not aided by the Statute but there mu≈øt be a Repleader.

But becau≈øe it was ≈øworn that the Obligor (who was the inte≈øtate) was alive four years after the time that the ≈øecond Bond was given, and for that rea≈øon it could not be given upon the accompt of the Defendants being liable as Admini≈øtrator, but mu≈øt be intended a Bond to ≈øecure a Debt of his own, therefore a new Trial was granted

div.head: Cook and others ver≈øus Herle.
div.p: Covenant will lie in the per≈øonalty tho' the Grant be executed by the Statute of U≈øes, which makes a Di≈øtre≈øs the proper remedy. Mod.
