Rep. 223.IN Covenant; the Ca≈øe was this: Charles Cook made a Iointure to Mary his Wife for life, and died without I≈ø≈øue; the Land de≈øcended to Thomas Cook his Brother and Heir, who grants an Annuity or Rent Charge of 200 l. per annum to the Plaintiffs in Tru≈øt for Mary, and this was to be in di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid Iointure, Habendum to them, their Heirs, Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns in Tru≈øt for the ≈øaid Mary for Life, with a Clau≈øe of Di≈øtre≈øs and a Covenant to pay the 200 l. per annum to the ≈øaid Tru≈øtees for the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Mary; the Breach a≈ø≈øigned was that the Defendant had not paid the Rent to them for the U≈øe of Mary.

The Defendant demurred ≈øpecially for that it appears by the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing that here is a Grant of a Rent-Charge for life, which is executed by the Statute of V≈øes, and therefore there ought to have been a Di≈øtre≈øs for Non-payment, which is the proper remedy given by the Statute, and this Action will not lie in the per≈øonalty.
2. 'Tis ≈øaid the Defendant did not pay it to the Plaintiffs for the u≈øe of Mary, which is a Negative pregnant and implies that it was paid to them.
3. 'Tis not averred that the Mony was not paid to Mary, and if 'tis paid to her, then the Breach is not well a≈ø≈øigned.

Ex parte Quer.But Serjeant Baldwin for the Plaintiff replyed, that it was not a Que≈øtion in this Ca≈øe whether this Rent Charge was executed by the Statute or not, for quacun
que via data an Action of Covenant will lie; and that the Breach was a≈ø≈øigned according to the Words of the Covenant, and ≈øo prima facie 'tis well enough; for if the Defendant did pay the Mony to the Plaintiffs he may plead it, and ≈øo he may likewi≈øe if he paid it to Mary.

Curia.The Court were all of Opinion that this Rent-Charge was executed by the Statute of V≈øes by the expre≈øs Words thereof, which executes ≈øuch Rents granted for Life upon Tru≈øt, as this Ca≈øe is, and transfers all Rights and Remedies incident thereunto together with the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe; ≈øo that though the power of di≈øtraining be limited to the Tru≈øt√©es by this De√©d, yet by the Statute which transfers that power to Mary, ≈øhe may di≈øtrain al≈øo; but this Covenant being collateral cannot be tran≈øferred.

The Clau≈øe of Di≈øtre≈øs by the expre≈øs Words of the Act is given to the Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe; but here is a double Remedy, by Di≈øtre≈øs or Action; for if the Le≈ø≈ø√©e a≈ø≈øign his Intere≈øt, and the Rent is accepted of the A≈ø≈øignee, yet a Covenant lies again≈øt the Le≈ø≈ø√©e for Non-payment upon the expre≈øs Covenant toHayes and Bicker≈øtaff. Hollis and Carr, Antea. pay; ≈øo if a Rent be granted to S. and a Covenant to pay it to N. for his u≈øe, 'tis a good Covenant.

And it was agreed, that the a≈ø≈øignment of a Breach according to the Words of the Covenant is good enough, and that if any thing be done which amounts to a performance, the other ≈øide mu≈øt plead it; as in this Ca≈øe the Defendant might have pleaded that the Mony was paid to Mary, which is a performance in ≈øub≈øtance, but it ≈øhall not be intended without pleading of it; Whereupon Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Read ver≈øus Daw≈øon.
div.p: DEBT upon Bond again≈øt the Defendant as Executor:Repleader after an immaterial I≈ø≈øue. I≈ø≈øue was joyned whether the Defendant had A≈ø≈øets or not on the thirtieth day of November, which was the day on which he had the fir≈øt notice of the Plaintiffs original Writ, and it was found for the Defendant, that then he had not A≈ø≈øets.
It was moved for a Repleader, (becau≈øe it was ≈øaid) this was an immaterial I≈ø≈øue, for though he had not A≈ø≈øets then yet if he had any afterwards he is liable to the Plaintiffs Action.

But Barrel Serjeant moved for Iudgment upon this Verdict, by rea≈øon of the Statute of 32 H. 8. which helps in Ca≈øes of Mi≈øpleading or in≈øufficient Pleading. 'Tis true, there are many Ca≈øes which after Verdict are not aided by this Statute, as if there are two Affirmatives, which cannot make an I≈ø≈øue, or when after a Traver≈øe I≈ø≈øue is joyned with an hoc petit quod inquiratur per patriam; this is no I≈ø≈øue, 2 Ander≈ø. 6, & 7.Yelv. 210. Hob. 126. So if there be no Plea at all, as if an Action is brought again≈øt Baron and Feme, and ≈øhe pleads only, 2 Cro. 288. So if the Party puts him≈øelf ≈øuper patriam, where it ≈øhould be tried by Record, or if the Plea be nothing to the purpo≈øe, or lie not in the Mouth of the Parties, ≈øuch immaterial I≈ø≈øues as the≈øe cannot be good.

The difference in Moor 867. is, if the Plea on which the I≈ø≈øue is joyned, hath no colourable pretence in it to barr the Plaintiff, or if it be again≈øt an expre≈øs Rule in the Law, there the I≈ø≈øue is immaterial, and ≈øo as if there was no I≈ø≈øue; and therefore 'tis
not aided by the Statute; but if it hath the countenance of a legal Plea, though it want nece≈ø≈øary matter to make it ≈øufficient, there ≈øhall be no Repleader, becau≈øe 'tis helped after Verdict.

Here the Parties only doubt whether there were A≈ø≈øets at the time of the notice, and 'tis found there were none, and ≈øo Iudgment was to be given accordingly; and of that Opinion was the whole Court.

But Iu≈øtice Atkins was clear of Opinion, that if the Parties join in an immaterial I≈ø≈øue there ≈øhall be no Repleader, becau≈øe 'tis helped after Verdict by the≈øe Words in the Statute, viz. (any I≈ø≈øue;) 'Tis not ≈øaid an I≈ø≈øue joined upon a material Point; and the intent of the Statute was to prevent Repleaders; and that if any other Con≈øtruction ≈øhould be made of that Act he was of Opinion that the Iudges ≈øate there not to expound but to make a Law; for by ≈øuch an Interpretation much of the benefit intended by the Act to the Party, who had a Verdict, would be re≈øtrained.

Curia.The other Iu≈øtices were all of Opinion that ≈øince the making of this Statute it had been always allowed, and taken as a difference, that when the I≈ø≈øue was perfectly material there ≈øhould be no Repleader; but that it was otherwi≈øe where the I≈ø≈øue was not material.

And Iu≈øtice Scroggs asked merrily, If Debt be brought upon a Bond and the Defendant pleads Robin Hood dwelt in a Wood, and the Plaintiff joyns I≈ø≈øue that he did not, this is an immaterial I≈ø≈øue, and ≈øhall there not be a Repleader in ≈øuch Ca≈øe after Verdict? Ad quod non fuit re≈øpon≈øum.

div.head: Beaumont ver≈øus ........
div.p: Wager of Law.THE Plaintiff brings an Action of Debt upon a Iudgment obtained again≈øt the Defendant in a Court Baron, having declared there in an Action on the Ca≈øe upon an A≈ø≈øump≈øit, and recovered.

The Defendant came to wage his Law, and was ready to ≈øwear that he owed the Plaintiff nothing;Sid. 366. but the Court held that he was not well advi≈øed, for by the Recovery in the inferior Court it became now a Debt, and was owing; and being asked whether he had paid the Mony; he an≈øwered that he owed nothing: Whereupon the Court concluded that he had not paid it, and therefore they would not admit him to wage his Law without bringing ≈øufficient
Compurgators to ≈øwear that they believed he ≈øwore Truth; but ≈øuch not appearing, the Defendant defecit de Lege, and Iudgment had been given again≈øt him, but he offered to bring the Mony recovered and the Co≈øts into the Court, and to go to a new Tryal, it being a very hard Ca≈øe upon him at the former Trial, where the Demand was of a Quit-Rent of 18 d. per annum; the Defendant promi≈øed, that if the Plaintiff would ≈øhew his Title and ≈øatisfie him that he had a Right to demand it, he would pay him the Rent; and at the Tryal expre≈øs Oath was made of a Promi≈øe to pay, upon which the Verdict was obtained; whereas it was then urged that the Freehold would come in que≈øtion upon that Promi≈øe, and ≈øo the inferior Court could have no Iurisdiction.

And afterwards the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that it hath b√©en adjudged in the Kings Bench that an inferior Court cannot hold Plea on a quantum meruit for Work done out of the Iurisdiction though the Promi≈øe be made within; and that he knew where a Per≈øon of Quality intending a Marriage with a Lady, pre≈øented her with a Iewel, and the Marriage not taking effect, he brought an Action of Detinue again≈øt her, and ≈øhe taking it to be a Gift offered to wage her Law; but the Court was of Opinion that the property was not changed by this Gift, being to a ≈øpecifical intent, and therefore would not admit her to do it. Quod nota.

div.head: Styleman ver≈øus Patrick.
div.p: AN Action on the Ca≈øe was brought by the Plaintiff again≈øt the Defendant, for eating of his Gra≈øs with his Sheep,Co≈øts allowed. ≈øo that he could not in tam amplo modo enjoy his Common, there was a Verdict for the Plaintiff, and it was now moved, that he ≈øhould have no more Co≈øts than Damages, becau≈øe this was a Tre≈øpa≈øs in its own nature, and the Iudge of A≈ø≈øi≈øe had not certified that the Title of any Land was in que≈øtion.
Bur the Court were all of Opinion,Curia. that this Ca≈øe was not within the Statute.

For it was not a frivolous Action, becau≈øe a little damage done to one Commoner and ≈øo to twenty may in the whole make it a great Wrong; if the Cau≈øe were frivolous the Iudge of A≈ø≈øize may mark it to be ≈øuch by vertue of the Statute of 43 Eliz. cap. 6. and then there ≈øhall be no more Co≈øts than Damages; and though in this Ca≈øe the Plaintiff hath in his Declaration ≈øet out a Title to his Common, yet the Title of the
Land cannot po≈ø≈øibly come in que≈øtion, and therefore not to be certified as in Ca≈øes of Tre≈øpas; neither is there any need of a Certificate if it appears by the Pleading that the Title of the Land is in que≈øtion.

The Court being again≈øt the Defendant as to the Co≈øts; his Council then moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, becau≈øe the Plaintiff ≈øets forth his Right to the Common only by way of Recital with a cumque etiam, Po≈øtea. &c. that he had a Right to Common in ≈øuch a place, ≈øed non allocatur; for 'tis affirmative enough, and afterwards he is charged with doing the Plaintiff damage; and ≈øo the Ca≈øe is not like to an Action of Tre≈øpas quare cum he did a Tre≈øpa≈øs, for there the ≈øen≈øe is imperfect.

div.head: DE Term. Sancti Hill. Anno 28 & 29 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
James ver≈øus John≈øon.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs, Que E≈øtate, where 'tis pleadable. Mod Rep. 231. the Defendant ju≈øtified by a Pre≈øcription to have Toll, and I≈ø≈øue being joyned thereupon, the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict, in which the Ca≈øe upon the Pleadings was, viz. Before the di≈ø≈øolution of Priories, the Mannor now in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Defendant, was parcel of the Priory of B. which came to the Crown by the ≈øaid di≈ø≈øolution; and the King made a Grant thereof to Sir Jervas Clifton, in Fee, together with the ≈øaid Toll adeo plene as the Prior had it; and the Defendant having brought down a Title by ≈øeveral me≈øne A≈ø≈øignments, claims by vertue of a Lea≈øe from Sir Jervas, for ≈øeven years then in being, alledging that the ≈øaid Sir Jervas and all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtate he had might take Toll; and whether this Pleading by a Que E≈øtate to have Right of Toll was good in Law, the Iury doubted.

Baldwin Serjeant for the Plaintiff,Ex parte Quer. argued that the Iu≈øtification was not good, becau≈øe there are two ≈øorts of Toll, viz. Toll through and Toll traver≈øe, and is in the Kings High Way, and the other in a Mans own Soil, and it doth not appear for which the Defendant hath ju≈øtified. If it be for the fir≈øt, then he ought to ≈øhew that he did make a Cau≈øeway, or ≈øome other thing that might be an advantage to the Pa≈ø≈øengers, to entitle him≈øelf to a Pre≈øcription; but if it be for the other, then he mu≈øt al≈øo ≈øhew it was for pa≈ø≈øing upon his Soil, which implies a Con≈øideration, 22 A≈ø≈øize, Kelw. 148. Pl. Com. 236. Lord Berkley's Ca≈øe. 1 Cro. 710. Smith ver≈øus Sheppard; by which Ca≈øes it appears that the ju≈øtification ought to be certain.

Then as to the point in Que≈øtion, he ≈øaid, that Toll cannot be appurtenant to a Mannor, and ≈øo the Pleading by a Que e≈øtate is not good; but if that ≈øhould be admitted, yet the Mannor being ve≈øted in the Crown by the di≈ø≈øolution, the Toll then became in gro≈øs, and could never after be united to the Mannor, or appurtenant thereunto.

But it was argued for the Defendant by Maynard Serjeant, and the whole Court were clear of Opinion, that the I≈ø≈øue was upon a particular point, and the Title was admitted, and that nothing remained in que≈øtion but the Point in pleading. And as to what had been objected, That Toll cannot belong to a Mannor, 'tis quite otherwi≈øe; for an Advow≈øon, a Rent, a Toll, or any Profit apprender may be appurtenant to it. Tis true a Man cannot pre≈øcribe by a Que E≈øtate of a Rent, Advow≈øon, Toll, &c. but he may of a Mannor, to which the≈øe are appendant; 'tis likewi≈øe true, that if the Defendant had ≈øaid this was Toll for pa≈ø≈øing the Highway, he mu≈øt ≈øhew ≈øome cau≈øe to entitle him≈øelf to the taking of it, as by doing ≈øomething of publick advantage.

But this general way of pleading is the mo≈øt u≈øual, and ≈øo are the Pre≈øidents, and it ought to come on the other ≈øide, and to be alledged, that the Defendant pre≈øcribed for Toll in the High-way; and in this Ca≈øe, though the Mannor came to the Crown, the Toll remained appurtenant ≈øtill, and ≈øo it continued when it was granted out. The difference is between a thing which was originally a Flower of the Crown, and other things which are not, as Catalla Felonum, &c. if ≈øuch come again to the King, they are merged in the Crown; but 'tis otherwi≈øe in ca≈øes of a Leet, Park, Warren, Toll, &c. which were fir≈øt created by the King, 9 Co. Abbot de Strata Marcella's Ca≈øe. So that this Toll is not become in gro≈øs by the di≈ø≈øolution, whereupon Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Sir William Turner's Ca≈øe.
div.p:
Amendment not after i≈ø≈øue joyned.DEbt qui tam &c. for 100 l. again≈øt Sir William Turner, being a Iu≈øtice of Peace in London, for denying his Warrant to ≈øuppre≈øs a ≈øeditious Conventicle of one Mr. Turner in New-≈øtreet. This Cau≈øe was to be tried by Ni≈øi prius this Term, before the Chief Iu≈øtice. And now the Plaintiff moved to amend one Word in the Declaration, wherein he was mi≈øtaken, for he had laid the Meeting to be at Turner's Man≈øion
Hou≈øe, and upon Enquiry he under≈øtood the place of Meeting was not at his Man≈øion Hou≈øe, but at a little di≈øtance from it, and ≈øo prayed the word Man≈øion might be ≈øtruck out.

But the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that after I≈ø≈øue joyned,Curia. and the Cau≈øe ≈øet down to be tried, and this being a penal Statute, no Pre≈øident could be ≈øhewn of an Amendment in ≈øuch ca≈øe, and therefore would not make this the fir≈øt, and ≈øo Leave was given to the Plaintiff to di≈øcontinue upon payment of Co≈øts.

div.head: Brown ver≈øus John≈øon.
div.p: IN Accompt: The Plaintiff declares again≈øt the Defendant,Time where 'tis made parcel of the i≈ø≈øue not good. for that upon the fir≈øt of March 22 Car. 2. & abinde to the fir≈øt of May 27 Car. 2. he was his Bayliff, and Receiver of 80 Piggs of Lead.

The Defendant pleads, that from the ≈øaid fir≈øt day of March 22 Car. 2. to the fir≈øt day of May 27 Car. 2. he was not the Plaintiffs Bayliff or Receiver of the ≈øaid 80 Piggs of Lead, & hoc paratus e≈øt verificare. To this the Plaintiff demurred, and a≈ø≈øigned ≈øpecially for cau≈øe, that the times from the fir≈øt of March to the fir≈øt of May, are made parcel of the I≈ø≈øue, which ought not to be, becau≈øe the Plaintiff in his Declaration mu≈øt alledge a time for Form ≈øake, but the Defendant ought not to tye him up to ≈øuch time alledged, for he might have ≈øaid he was not Bayliff modo & forma.

And for this the Ca≈øe of Lane and Alexander was cited, where the Defendant by Ejectment makes a Title by Copy of Court Roll, granted to him 44 Eliz. and the Plaintiff replies his Title by the like Grant, 1 Junii 43 Eliz. The Defendant maintains his Barr, and traver≈øeth that the Queen 1 Junii 43 year of her Reign granted the ≈øaid Land by Copy; and upon Demurrer it was adjudged, that the traver≈øing of the day is matter of ≈øub≈øtance, which being made part of the I≈ø≈øue, is naught.

But on the other ≈øide it was objected, that time is material, and that in Actions of Accompt 'tis proper to make it parcel of the I≈ø≈øue; for a Man may be Bayliff for two, but not for three years, and a Relea≈øe may be pleaded from ≈øuch a time to ≈øuch a time, Fitz. Accompt 30. Ra≈øt. Entry f. 8. 19 pl. 1. f. 20. pl. 6. f. 22. pl. 2.

1. Then Exceptions were taken to the Plea, fir≈øt, for that the Plaintiff having charged the Defendant as Receiver of 80 Piggs of Lead; the Defendant pleads, and that he was not Receiver thereof, but doth not ≈øay of any part thereof; for which rea≈øon the Court held the Plea ill, becau≈øe he might retain 79, and yet not 80 Piggs, but to plead generally ne unques Receptor is well enough; though it was urged that if it had been found again≈øt him upon ≈øuch an I≈ø≈øue that he had received any parcel of the Lead, he ≈øhould have accompted, 24 H. 4. 21. 2 Roll. 3. 14. 32 H. 6. 33. Fitz. Accompt 16. Cro. Eliz. 850. Fitz. Accompt 14. Ra≈øt. Entry 18, 19, 20.
2. The Defendant concludes & hoc paratus e≈øt verificare, whereas it ≈øhould be & de hoc ponit ≈øe ≈øuper patriam; but the Court doubted of this, becau≈øe it was not ≈øpecially a≈ø≈øigned.

Po≈øtea.3. The Plaintiff charged the Defendant as his Bayliff upon the fir≈øt of March, and the Defendant pleads that he was not his Bayliff from the fir≈øt of March, ≈øo he excludes that day; and this the Court held to be incurable, and likewi≈øe that the time ought not to be made parcel of the I≈ø≈øue,2 Sand. 317, 318. and ≈øo Iudgment was given quod computer.

div.head: Abraham ver≈øus Cunningham.
div.p: Admini≈øtrator ≈øells a Term, afterwards an Executor appears and renounces, yet the Sale was adjudged void. Jones 72. 1 Vent. 303.IN a ≈øpecial Verdict in Ejectment, the Ca≈øe upon the Pleadings was, Viz. Sir David Cunningham being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a Term for years, made his Will, and therein appointed his Son Sir David Cunningham to be his Executor, and dyed. Sir David the Executor, in the year 1663. made his Will al≈øo, and therein appointed David Cunningham his Son, and two others to be his Executors, and dyed; tho≈øe two Executors dye, and B. a Stranger takes out Admini≈øtration, cum Te≈øtamento annexo, and continues this Admini≈øtration from the year 1665. to the year 1671. in which time he made an A≈ø≈øignment of this Term to the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, for which he had received a thou≈øand Pounds: And in the year 1671. the ≈øurviving Executor of Sir David the Executor, made Oath in the Archbi≈øhops Court, that he never heard of his Te≈øtators Will 'till then, nor ever ≈øaw it before, and that he had not medled with the E≈øtate, nor renounced the Executor≈øhip:6 Co. Packmans Ca≈øe. Then a Citation goes to ≈øhew cau≈øe why the Admini≈øtration ≈øhould not be repealed, and Sentence was given that it ≈øhould be revoked; upon which the Executor enters, and the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff entred upon him.

This Ca≈øe was argued by Saunders for the Plaintiff,Ex parte Quer. and Levints for the Defendant. And fir≈øt it was ≈øaid in behalf of the Plaintiff, that the Authorities in the Books were ≈øtrong on his ≈øide, that the fir≈øt Admini≈øtration was well granted; 'Tis true, if a Man make a Will, and Admini≈øtration is granted, and that Will is afterwards proved, ≈øuch Admini≈øtration is void, as in Greysbrook and Foxes Ca≈øe, Pl. Com.

But in this Ca≈øe, after the death of Sir David Cunningham the Executor, his Te≈øtator is dead Inte≈øtate; for to make an Executor there mu≈øt be fir≈øt the naming of him; then there mu≈øt be ≈øome concurring act of his own to declare his a≈ø≈øent, that he will take onus executionis upon him, for no man can make another Executor again≈øt his will; ≈øo that if after the death of the fir≈øt Executor, tho≈øe other Executors appointed by him, had made ≈øuch a Declaration, as this ≈øurviving Executor hath ≈øince done, their Te≈øtator had dyed Inte≈øtate, 7 E. 4. 12, 13.

The Executor is made by the Te≈øtator, and the Ordinary is empowered by the Statute to make the Admini≈øtrator where the per≈øon dies Inte≈øtate; ≈øo that 'tis plain there cannot be an Executor and Admini≈øtrator both together: If he who is made ≈øo taketh upon him long after the Will to be Executor, it ≈øhall make him ≈øuch by relation from the time of the death of the Te≈øtator; but here is no Executor nor ever was: 'Tis true, that one was named, but as ≈øoon as he heard of the Will he renounced; and therefore there being no Executor in this Ca≈øe, nothing now can hinder the Admini≈øtration to be granted cum Te≈øtamento annexo.

If the Te≈øtator ≈øhould dye indebted, or have Debts owing to him, and the Executor refu≈øes Probate, and renounces his Executor≈øhip, Admini≈øtration mu≈øt be granted, for Lex fingit ubi ≈øub≈øi≈øtit Aequitas, and the Executor having a po≈ø≈øibility to be ≈øuch, and by his refu≈øal becoming no Executor, why ≈øhould the bare naming of him to be an Executor, have relation to make ≈øuch Admini≈øtration void? ≈øince 'tis not the Name, but the doing of the Office which makes him Executor, Dyer 372.
If all the≈øe Executors had dyed after Admini≈øtration thus committed, it cannot be ≈øaid that they ever were Executors.
There can be no inconvenience that this Admini≈øtration ≈øhould be good; for 'tis ju≈øt that Creditors ≈øhould have their Debts, and Purcha≈øors ≈øhould be ≈øecure in the things purcha≈øed.

If the Te≈øtator was indebted, an Action will lie again≈øt an Executor de ≈øon tort, for ≈øuch Debt, which Executor is altogether as wrongfull as the Admini≈øtrator, to whom Admini≈øtraton is committed,
and the Will afterwards proved by the rightful Executor; and if ≈øuch Executor of his own wrong be po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a term for years, and a Creditor recovers again≈øt him, that Crecutor ≈øhall have the Term in ≈øatisfaction of his Debt; and by the ≈øame rea≈øon ≈øhall the Admini≈øtrator here have a good title to this Term which he ≈øold for the payment of a ju≈øt Debt, and there is no authority for making ≈øuch Admini≈øtration void, unle≈øs it be where the Executor proves the Will, but never when he renounceth.

Ex parte Def.But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that an Executor of an Executor hath all the Intere≈øt which the fir≈øt Executor had; ≈øo that being an Executor, the Admini≈øtration ganted by the Ordinary is void, and the renunciation afterwards ≈øhall never make it good; and this will appear by the different Intere≈øts which the Ordinary and the Executor have by Law.

1. The Ordinary originally had nothing to do with the E≈øtate of the Inte≈øtate, forGodolph. 59. bona inte≈øtati capi ≈øolent in manus Regis. Afterwards two Statutes were made, which e≈øtabli≈øh his power; the fir≈øt was We≈øtm. 1. cap. 19. and the other was 31 E. 3. c. 11. Yet no power was thereby given him to di≈øpo≈øe of the Goods to his own u≈øe, or to the u≈øe of any other; he had only a property ≈øecundum quid, and not an ab≈øolute and uncontroulable Right in the E≈øtate.

2. But the Executor hath a Right and Intere≈øt given to him by Law, when a Will is made, and may5 Co. Middleton's Ca≈øe. relea≈øe before probate; if he therefore hath an ab≈øolute Right, and the Ordinary hath only a qualified property, how can he grant the Admini≈øtration of the Goods, which at the ≈øame time are lawfully ve≈øted in another? Suppo≈øe the Executor ≈øells ≈øuch Goods to one Man, and the Admini≈øtrator to another,2 Ander≈ø. 150. Ca≈øe. 83. the Sale of one of them mu≈øt be void; and for the ≈øaid Rea≈øons, and by the con≈øtant cour≈øe of the Law it mu≈øt be the latter.

It hath been objected, that here was no Executor at all, only one named; or if it be admitted that there was an Executor, yet his refu≈øal ≈øhall relate to the time of the Admini≈øtration committed, and make that good which might not be ≈øo before.

But as to that, he ≈øaid that here was an Executor appointed by the Will, who had an Intere≈øt, and Admini≈øtration being granted to another, 'tis void ab initio, and what is once void cannot be made good by any ≈øub≈øequent act,Mod. Rep. 214. 10 Co. 62. a.

Here was a want of power in him who did this Act; for the Ordinary could not grant Admini≈øtration where there is an Executor, and therefore no relation ≈øhall be to make that good which was once void; but if it had b√©en only voidable it might have been otherwi≈øe.

A Relation may be to inable the Party to recover the Goods of the Inte≈øtate, and to puni≈øh Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes; as if a Man die po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Goods, and a Stranger convert them, and afterwards Admini≈øtration is granted to S. this Admini≈øtration ≈øhall2 Roll Abr. 399. relate to the time of the death of the Inte≈øtate, ≈øo that he may maintain Trover, before the Ordinary had committed it to him, but it will never aid the Acts of the Parties to avoid them by Relation; as if a Man makes a Feoffment to a Feme Covert, and afterwards devi≈øes the ≈øame Land, the Husband di≈øagr√©es, this ≈øhall have relation between the Parties, ≈øo as the Husband ≈øhall not be charged in damages, but it ≈øhall not make the void Devi≈øe good, 3 Co. 28. b. Butler and Baker's Ca≈øe.

So if a Man makes a Relea≈øe, and afterwards get Letters of Admini≈øtration, that ≈øhall not relate to make his Relea≈øe good to barr him, neither ≈øhall his refu≈øal of the Executor≈øhip do it, becau≈øe at the time of the Relea≈øe or the refu≈øal there was not any right of Action in him; for that commences in the one Ca≈øe after Admini≈øtration, and in the other after the Probate of the Will.

Notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch refu≈øal this Executor may afterwards admini≈øter at his plea≈øure,Godolph. 141. and intermeddle with the Goods of the Te≈øtator, and if the Admini≈øtration ≈øhould be good al≈øo, then they would have a power over the ≈øame E≈øtate by two Titles at the ≈øame time, which cannot be.

The greate≈øt Argument which can be brought again≈øt this is ab inconvenienti, becau≈øe it cannot be ≈øafe to purcha≈øe under an Admini≈øtrator, ≈øince a Will may be concealed for a time, and afterwards the lawful Executor therein appointed may appear; but this is more proper for the Wisdom of a Parliament to redre≈øs than that the Law ≈øhould be altered by a judicial determination of the Court, and therefore he prayed Iudgment for the Defendant.

The Court was of Opinion that the Ordinary cannot grant Admini≈øtration where there is an Executor named in the Will,Judgment. and therefore gave Iudgment for the Defendant again≈øt the Vend√©e of this Term.

div.head: The Lord Town≈øend ver≈øus Dr. Hughes. In C. B.
div.p: THE Plaintiff brought an Action of Scandalum Magnatum for the≈øe Words ≈øpoken of him by the Defendant,No new Trial in an Action of Scandalum Magnatum. Mod. Rep. 232. viz. He is an unworthy Man and acts again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon: Vpon Not Guilty pleaded, the Ca≈øe was tried, and the Iury gave the Plaintiff 4000 l. damages.

The Defendant before the Trial made all po≈ø≈øible ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to my Lord; he denied the ≈øpeaking the Words, and made Oath that he never ≈øpoke the ≈øame; after the Trial he likewi≈øe addre≈ø≈øed to my Lord as before, making ≈øeveral Prote≈øtations of his Innocency: But having once in a Pa≈ø≈øion ≈øaid, that he ≈øcorned to ≈øubmit; My Lord for that Rea≈øon would not remit the Damages; it was therefore moved for a new Tryal upon the≈øe Rea≈øons.

1. Becau≈øe the Witne≈ø≈øes, who proved the Words, were not Per≈øons of Credit, and that at the time, when they were alledged to be ≈øpoken, many Clergy-men were in Company with the Defendant and heard no ≈øuch Words ≈øpoken.

2. It was ≈øworn, that one of the Iury confe≈ø≈øed, that they gave ≈øuch great damages to the Plaintiff (not that he was damnified ≈øo much) but that he might have the greater opportunity to ≈øhew him≈øelf noble in the remitting of them.
3. And which was the principal Rea≈øon, becau≈øe the Damages were exce≈ø≈øive.
Curia.The Court delivered their Opinions ≈øeriatim; and fir≈øt,

The Chief Iu≈øtice North ≈øaid, In Ca≈øes of Fines for criminal Matters a Man is to be fined by Magna Charta with a ≈øalvo contenemento ≈øuo; and no Fine is to be impo≈øed greater than he is able to pay; but in Civil Actions the Plaintiff is to recover by way of compen≈øation for the damages he hath ≈øu≈øtained, and the Iury are the proper Iudges thereof.

This is a Civil Action brought by the Plaintiff for Words ≈øpoken of him, which if they are in their own nature actionable, the Iury ought to con≈øider the damage which the Party may ≈øu≈øtain; but if a particular Averment of ≈øpecial damages makes them actionable, then the Iury are only to con≈øider ≈øuch damages as are already ≈øu≈øtained, and not ≈øuch as may happen in futuro, becau≈øe for ≈øuch the Plaintiff may have a new Action: He ≈øaid that as a Iudge he could not tell what value to ≈øet upon the Honour
of the Plaintiff, the Iury have given 4000 l. and therefore he could neither le≈ø≈øen the Sum or grant a new Trial, e≈øpecially ≈øince by the Law the Iury are Iudges of the damages; and it would be very inconvenient to examine upon what account they gave their Verdict; they having found the Defendant guilty did believe the Witne≈ø≈øes, and he could not now make a doubt of their Credibility.
Wyndham Iu≈øtice accorded in omnibus.

Atkins Iu≈øtice contra. That a new Trial ≈øhould be granted, for 'tis every days practice, and he remembred the Ca≈øe of Gould≈øton and Wood in the Kings Bench, where the Plaintiff in an Action on the Ca≈øe for Words for calling of him Bankrupt recovered 1500 l. and that Court granted a new Tryal, becau≈øe the damages were exce≈ø≈øive.

The Iury in this Ca≈øe ought to have re≈øpect only to the damage which the Plaintiff ≈øu≈øtained, and not to do an unaccountable thing that he might have an opportunity to ≈øhew him≈øelf generous; and as the Court ought with one Eye to look upon the Verdict, ≈øo with the other they ought to take notice what is contained in the Declaration, and then to con≈øider whether the Words and Damages bear any proportion, if not, then the Court ought to lay their hands upon the Verdict: 'Tis true they cannot le≈ø≈øen the damages, but if they are too great the Court may grant a new Tryal.

Scroggs Iu≈øtice accorded with North and Wyndham, that no new Tryal can be granted in this Cau≈øe: He ≈øaid that he was of Council with the Plaintiff before he was called to the Bench, and might therefore be ≈øuppo≈øed to give Iudgment in favour of his former Client, being prepo≈ø≈øe≈øs'd in the Cau≈øe, or el≈øe (to ≈øhew him≈øelf more ≈øignally ju≈øt) might without con≈øidering the matter give Iudgment again≈øt him; but that now he had forgot all former relation thereunto, and therefore delivered his Opinion, that if he had been of the Iury he ≈øhould not have given ≈øuch a Verdict, and if he had been Plaintiff he would not take advantage of it, but would overcome with Forgivene≈øs ≈øuch Follies and Indi≈øcretions of which the Defendant had been guilty; but that he did not ≈øit there to give Advice, but to do Iu≈øtice to the People. He did agr√®e that where an unequal Tryal was, (as ≈øuch mu≈øt be where there is any Practice with the Iury) in ≈øuch Ca≈øe 'tis good rea≈øon to grant a new Tryal, but no ≈øuch thing appearing to him in this Ca≈øe a new Tryal could not be granted.

Suppo≈øe the Iury had given a ≈øcandalous Verdict for the Plaintiff, as a Penny Damages, he could not have obtained a new Trial in hopes to increa≈øe them, neither ≈øhall the Defendant in hopes to le≈ø≈øen them; and therefore by the Opinion of the≈øe three Iu≈øtices a new Tryal was not granted.

Afterwards in this Term Serjeant Maynard moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, and ≈øaid, that this Action was grounded upon the Statute of R. 2. Which con≈øi≈øts of a Preamble, reciting the Mi≈øchief, and of the Enacting part in giving of a Remedy, and that the Defendants Ca≈øe was neither within the Mi≈øchief or the Remedy.

This Statute doth not create any Action by way of particular de≈øign, and if the matter was now Res integra much might be ≈øaid that an Action for Damages will not lye upon this Statute; for the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. appoints that the Offender ≈øhall ≈øuffer impri≈øonment, until he produces the Author of a fal≈øe Report;Ca. 33. and the Statute of 2 R. 2. which recites that of We≈øtm. 2. gives the ≈øame puni≈øhment, and the Action is brought qui tam, &c. and yet the Plaintiff only recovers for him≈øelf: It was u≈øual to puni≈øh Offenders in this kind in the Star Chamber; as in the * Earl of Northampton's Ca≈øe, where one Goodrick ≈øaid of him, That he wrote a Book again≈øt Garnet, and a Letter to Bellarmine;
12 Co. 132. intimating, that what he wrote in the Book was not his Opinion, but only ad captandum populum, which was a great di≈øgrace to him in tho≈øe days, being as much as to ≈øay, he was a Papi≈øt, Cro. Eliz.

But the Serjeant would not in≈øi≈øt upon that now, ≈øince it hath been ruled that where a Statute prohibits the doing of a thing which if done might be prejudicial to another; in ≈øuch ca≈øe he may have an Action upon that very Statute for his Damages.
But the ground on which he argued was, that the≈øe words as ≈øpoken are not within the meaning of the Act, for they are not actionable.

1. Becau≈øe they are no ≈øcandal, and words which are actionable mu≈øt import a great Scandal, which no circum≈øtance or occa≈øion of ≈øpeaking can excu≈øe; and if they are ≈øcandalous and capable of any mitigation by the precedent di≈øcour≈øe, the pleading of that matter will make them not actionable; and for this the Lord4 Co. Cromwel's Ca≈øe is a plain Authority, the Words ≈øpoken of him were, You like tho≈øe that maintain Sedition again≈øt the King's Per≈øon; the occa≈øion of ≈øpeaking of which was to give an account of his favouring the Puritan Preachers, which was all that was intended by the former di≈øcour≈øe; for that Lord had approved a Sermon which was preached
by a Par≈øon again≈øt the Common Prayer Book, and the Defendant having forbid ≈øuch Preaching, the Lord told him that he did not like him, upon which he ≈øpoke tho≈øe Words; ≈øo that the ≈øubject matter explained the ≈øen≈øe, for which rea≈øon it was adjudged that the Action would not lie.

2. The ≈øcandal for which an Action may be brought within this Statute mu≈øt be fal≈øe, for that word goes quite through the whole Act, viz. fal≈øe News, fal≈øe Lyes, &c. and the words here are ≈øo general, that it cannot appear whether they are true or fal≈øe, for there can be no Iu≈øtification here; as in ca≈øe where a Man is charged with a particular Crime, my Lord Town≈øend is not charged with any particular Act of Inju≈øtice as a Subject, nor with any Misdemeanour as a Peer, nor with any Offence in an Office.

If therefore in all Actions brought upon this Statute the Defendant may ju≈øtifie and put the matter in I≈ø≈øue to try whether it be true or fal≈øe; and in this Ca≈øe the Defendant can neither ju≈øtifie nor traver≈øe, for this rea≈øon the Action will not lie.

That the Words are general and of a doubtful ≈øignification, it cannot be denied; for to ≈øay He is an unworthy Man imports no particular Crime; Unworthy is a term of Relation, as he is unworthy of my Friend≈øhip, Acquaintance or Kindred, and ≈øo may be applicable to any thing; and a Lord may in many things be unworthy of a particular Mans Friend≈øhip, as if he promi≈øes to pay a Sum of Mony at a day certain, and faileth in the payment, (as 'tis often ≈øe√©n,) ≈øuch is an unworthy Man, but that will not bear an Action: He is an unworthy Man who invites another to Dinner to affront him; but it will not bear an Action to ≈øay, That a Lord invited me to a Dinner to abu≈øe me; neither will it be actionable to ≈øay, He is an unworthy Man, becau≈øe ≈øuch in≈øtances may be given of his Vnworthine≈øs which will not bear an Action. If my Lord had be√©n compared to any ba≈øe and unworthy thing, the≈øe Words might have b√©en actionable; and that was the Ca≈øe of the Lord Marque≈øs of Dorche≈øter, it being ≈øaid of him, That there was no more value in him than in a Dog.

Then to ≈øay, A Man acts again≈øt Law, this is no Scandal, becau≈øe every Man who breaks a Penal Law, and ≈øuffers the Penalty, is not guilty of any Crime. The Statute commands the burying in Woollen, the Party buries one of his Family in Linnen; in this he acts again≈øt the Law, but if the Penalty is ≈øatisfied, the Law is ≈øo likewi≈øe.

A Man who acts again≈øt Law acts again≈øt Rea≈øon, becau≈øe Lex e≈øt ≈øumma ratio; but no in≈øtance is here given wherein he did thus act: 'Tis not ≈øaid, that he did act again≈øt Law wilfully, or that
he u≈øed to do any thing again≈øt Law; and ≈øo cannot be like the Ca≈øe of the Duke of Buckingham, who brought an Action for the≈øe Words, viz. You are u≈øed to do things again≈øt Law, and put Cattle into a Ca≈øtle where they cannot be replevied; for there was not only an V≈øage charged upon him, but a particular in≈øtance of Oppre≈ø≈øion.

This Action lies for Words ≈øpoken of a Iudge of either Bench, and of a Bi≈øhop, as well as of a Peer. Now if a Man ≈øhould ≈øay, A Judge acted again≈øt Law, will an Action lie? Becau≈øe a Iudge may do a thing again≈øt Law, and yet very ju≈øtly and hone≈øtly, unle≈øs all the Iudges were infallible, and could not be ≈øubject to any mi≈øtakes, which none will deny.

So if a Bi≈øhop return the Cau≈øe of his Refu≈øal to admit a Clerk quia crimino≈øus, this is a Return again≈øt Law, becau≈øe 'tis too general; but if J. S. ≈øhould ≈øay, A Bi≈øhop acted again≈øt Law, and ≈øhew that for Cau≈øe, an Action would not lye. If the the Lord Town≈øend had commanded his Bayliff to make a Di≈øtre≈øs without Cau≈øe, that had been acting again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon.
He agreed the Words to be uncivil, but not actionable; for if ≈øuch Con≈øtruction ≈øhould be made, a Man mu≈øt talk in Print, or otherwi≈øe not ≈øpeak any thing of a Peer for fear of an Action.
There are many Authorities where a P√©er ≈øhall not have an Action for every trivial and ≈ølight Expre≈ø≈øion ≈øpoken of him.

As to ≈øay of a P√©er, He keeps none but Rogues and Ra≈øcals about him like him≈øelf; by the Opinion of two Iu≈øtices, Yelverton and Flemming, the Action would not lie, becau≈øe they are Words of Scolding; and this was the Ca≈øe of the Earl of Lincoln, Cro. Jac. 196. But the Court was divided; the Defendant died, and ≈øo the Writ abated.

Actions for Words have b√©en of late too much extended; formerly there were not above two or three brought in many years; and if this Statute ≈øhould be much inlarged the Lords them≈øelves will be prejudiced thereby by maintaining Actions one again≈øt another.

Vpon this Statute of 2 R. 2 c. 5 there was no Action brought till 13 H. 7. which was above an hundred years after the making of that Law; and the occa≈øion of making the Law was, becau≈øe the Duke of Lanca≈øter, who was then the fir≈øt Prince of the Blood, took notice that divers were ≈øo hardy as to ≈øpeak of him ≈øeveral lying Words, 1 R. 2. num. 56. and therefore this Statute was made to puni≈øh tho≈øe, who devi≈øed fal≈øe News, and horrible and fal≈øe Lies of any Peer, &c. whereby Di≈øcords might ari≈øe between the Lords and Commons, and great Peril and Mi≈øchief
to the Realm and quick Subver≈øion thereof: Now from the natural intent and con≈øtruction of the≈øe Words in the Act, can it be ≈øuppo≈øed that if one ≈øhould ≈øay, Such a Peer is an unworthy Man, that the Kingdom would be pre≈øently in a flame and turned into a ≈øtate of confu≈øion and Civil War; and to ≈øay, That he acts again≈øt Law, that the Government would thereby be in danger to be lo≈øt, and quick Subver≈øion would follow? This cannot be the common and ordinary under≈øtanding of the≈øe Words.

If therefore the Plaintiff by ≈øpeaking the≈øe Words was in no hazard nor any wi≈øe damnified; if he was not touched in his Loyalty as a P√©er, nor in danger of his Life as a Subject; if he was not thereby ≈øubjected to any Corporal or Pecuniary Puni≈øhment; nor charged with any Breach of Oath, nor with a particular Mi≈øcarriage in any Office; if the Words are ≈øo general that they import no Scandal, and are neither capable of any Iu≈øtification; and la≈øtly, if they are not ≈øuch horrible Lies as are intended to be puni≈øhed by the Statute; for the≈øe Rea≈øons he concluded the Action would not lie, and therefore prayed, that the Iudgment might be arre≈øted.

Serjeant Baldwin and Serjeant Barrel argued on the ≈øame ≈øide for the Defendant, but nothing was mentioned by them which is not fully in≈øi≈øted on in the Argument of Serjeant Maynard, for which Rea≈øon I have not reported their Arguments.

But Pemberton Serjeant, who argued for the Plaintiff, ≈øaid,Ex parte Quer. that it would conduce much to the under≈øtanding of the Statute of 2 R. 2. cap. 5. upon which this Action of Scandalum Magnatum was grounded, to con≈øider the occa≈øion of the making of it.

In tho≈øe days the Engli≈øh were quite of another Nature and Genius from what they are at this time; the Con≈øtitution of this Kingdom was then Martial and given to Arms, the very Tenures were Military, and ≈øo were the Services as Knights Service, Ca≈øtleguard and E≈øcuage. There were many Ca≈øtles of defence in tho≈øe days in the hands of private Men; their Sports and Pa≈øtimes were ≈øuch as Tilts and Turnaments, and all their Imployments were tending to br√©ed them up in Chivalry.

Tho≈øe who had any dependency upon Noble Men were enured to Bows and Arrows, and to ≈øignalize them≈øelves in Valour it was the only way to Riches and Honour; Arts and Sciences had not got ≈øuch ground in the Kingdom as now; but the Commons had almo≈øt their dependance upon the Lords, who≈øe Power then was exce√©ding great, and their Practices were conformable
to their Power; and this is the true Rea≈øon why ≈øo few Actions were formerly brought for Scandals, becau≈øe when a Man was injured by Words he carved out his own Remedy by his Sword.

There are many Statutes made again≈øt riding privately armed, which Men u≈øed in tho≈øe days, to repair them≈øelves of any Injury done unto them, for they had immediately recour≈øe to their Arms for that purpo≈øe, and ≈øeldom or never u≈øed to bring any Actions for damages.

This was their Revenge; and having thus made them≈øelves Iudges in their own Ca≈øes, it was rea≈øonable that they ≈øhould do them≈øelves Iu≈øtice with their own Weapons; but this Revenge did not u≈øually end in private Quarrels, they took Parties, ingaged their Friends, their Tenants and Servants on their ≈øides, and by ≈øuch means made great Factions in the Commonwealth, by rea≈øon whereof the whole Kingdom was often in a flame, and the Government as often in danger of being ≈øubverted; ≈øo that Laws were then made again≈øt wearing Liverys or Badges, and again≈øt riding armed.

This was the mi≈øchief of tho≈øe times; to prevent which this Statute of R. 2. was made, and therefore all provoking and vilifying Words, which were u≈øed before to exa≈øperate the Peers and to make them betake them≈øelves to Arms, by the intent of this Act are clearly forbidden, which was made chiefly to prevent ≈øuch con≈øequences; for it was to no purpo≈øe to make a Law and thereby to give a P√©er an Action for ≈øuch Words as a common per≈øon might have before the making of the Statute; and for which the Peer him≈øelf had a Remedy al≈øo at the Common Law, and therefore needed not the help of this Act.

If then the de≈øign of this Statute was to hinder ≈øuch practices as afore≈øaid, the next thing to be con≈øidered is what was u≈øual in tho≈øe days to rai≈øe the Pa≈ø≈øions of Peers to that degre√©, and that will appear to be not only ≈øuch things as imported a great Scandal in them≈øelves, or ≈øuch for which an Action lay at the Common Law, but even ≈øuch things as ≈øavoured of any Contempt of their per≈øons; and ≈øuch as brought them into di≈øgrace with the Commons, for hereby they took occa≈øion of Provocation and Revenge.

'Tis true that very few Actions were brought upon this Statute in ≈øome con≈øiderable time after it was made, for though ≈øuch practices were thereby prohibited, the Lords did not pre≈øently apply them≈øelves to the Remedy therein given, but continued the Military way of Revenge to which they had b√©en accu≈øtomed.

As to the fir≈øt Objection that hath been made, he gave no an≈øwer to it, becau≈øe it was not much in≈øi≈øted upon on the other ≈øide, whether an Action would lye upon this Statute, for the very words of it are ≈øufficient ground for an Action; and 'tis very well known that whereever an Act prohibits an evil thing,Maxim. the per≈øon again≈øt whom ≈øuch thing is done, may maintain an Action.

This Statute con≈øi≈øts of two parts, the fir≈øt is prohibitory,Vide Ante. Viz. That no Man ≈øhall do ≈øo, &c. Then comes the additional Clau≈øe, and ≈øaith That if he do he ≈øhall incur ≈øuch Penalty. 'Tis on the fir≈øt part that this Action is grounded; and ≈øo it was in the Earl of Northampton's Ca≈øe, in that Report which goes under the name of the Lord Coke's 12th. Report, where by the Re≈øolution of all the Iudges in England, except Flemming who was ab≈øent; it was adjudged that it was not nece≈ø≈øary that any particular Crime ≈øhould be fixed on the Plaintiff, or any Offence for which he might be indicted.

So are the Authorities in all the Ca≈øes relating to this Action. In the Lord4 Co. 13. b. 2 Cro. 196. Cromwel's Ca≈øe for the≈øe Words, You like tho≈øe who maintain Sedition. In the Lord of Lincoln's Ca≈øe, My Lord is a ba≈øe Earl, and a paultry Lord, and keepeth none but Rogues and Ra≈øcals like him≈øelf. In the Duke of Buckingham's Ca≈øe, He has no more Con≈øcience than a Dog. In the LordHill. 16 Car. 2 Rot. 1269. Affirmed in a Writ of Error in B R. Marque≈øs of Dorche≈øter's Ca≈øe, He is no more to be valued than the Black Dog which lies there. All which Words were held actionable, and yet they touch not the per≈øons in any thing concerning the Government, or charge them with any Crime, but in point of Dignity or Honour; And they were all villifying Words, and might give occa≈øion of Revenge.

And ≈øo are the Words for which this Action is brought, they are rude, uncivil, and ill natured; Unworthy is as much as to ≈øay ba≈øe and ignoble, a contemptible Per≈øon, and a Man of neither Honour or Merit. And thus to ≈øpeak of a Nobleman, is a Reflection upon the King, who is the Fountain of Honour, that gives it to ≈øuch per≈øons who are (in his Iudgment) de≈øerving, by which they are made capable of advi≈øing him in Parliament, and it would be very di≈øhonourable to call unworthy Men thither.

'Tis likewi≈øe a di≈øhonour to the Nobility to have ≈øuch a per≈øon to fit among them as a Companion, and to the Commons to have their proceedings in Parliament tran≈ømitted to ≈øuch Pe√©rs: ≈øo that it tends to the di≈øhonour of all Dignities, both of King, Lords and Commons, and thereby di≈øcords may ari≈øe between the two Hou≈øes, which is the Mi≈øchief intended to be remedied by this Act.

Then the following Words are as ≈øcandalous; for to ≈øay A Man acts again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon, imports ≈øeveral ≈øuch acts done; a Man is not denominated to be unworthy by doing of one ≈øingle Act; for in the≈øe Words more is implied, than to ≈øay he hath done an unworthy thing; for the Words ≈øeem to relate to the Office which the Plaintiff had in the Country, as Lord Lieutenant, which is an Office of great Honour, and can any thing tend to cau≈øe more di≈øcord and di≈øturbance in the Kingdom, than to ≈øay of a great Officer, That he acts according to the dictates of his Will and Plea≈øure? the con≈øequence of which is, that he will be rather ≈øcorned than obeyed.
It hath been objected, that the Words are general, and charge him not with any act.

An≈øw. The Scandal is the greater; for 'tis not ≈øo bad to ≈øay A Man did ≈øuch a particular thing again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon; as to ≈øay, He acts again≈øt Law; which is as much as to ≈øay, his con≈øtant cour≈øe and practice is ≈øuch: And to ≈øay that the Words might be meant of breaking a Penal Law, that is a foreign Con≈øtruction; for the plain ≈øen≈øe is, he acts again≈øt the known Laws of the Kingdom, and his practice and de≈øigns are ≈øo to do, for he will be guided neither by Law or Rea≈øon.
Object. It has been objected that the Scandal mu≈øt be fal≈øe: But whether true or not, there can be no ju≈øtification here, becau≈øe they are ≈øo general, that they cannot be put in I≈ø≈øue.

An≈øw. He agreed that no Action would lye upon this Statute if the words were true; but in ≈øome Ca≈øes the divulging of a Scandal was an Offence at the Common Law; now to argue (as on the other ≈øide) that the Defendant cannot ju≈øtifie, and therefore an Action will not lye, is a fal≈øe Con≈øequence; becau≈øe words may be ≈øcandalous and derogatory to the dignity of a Peer, and yet the ≈øubject matter may not be put in I≈ø≈øue.

He agreed al≈øo that occa≈øional Circum≈øtances may extenuate and excu≈øe the Words, though ill in them≈øelves; but this cannot be applied to the Ca≈øe in que≈øtion, becau≈øe the Words were not mitigated: The Defendant pleaded Not Guilty, and in≈øi≈øted on his Innocence; the Iury have found him Guilty, which is an aggravation of his Crime; if he would have extenuated them by any occa≈øion upon which they were ≈øpoken, he ≈øhould have pleaded it ≈øpecially, or offered it in Evidence, neither of which was done.

This Act is to be taken favourably for him again≈øt whom the Words are ≈øpoken; becau≈øe 'tis to prevent great Mi≈øchiefs which may fall out in the Kingdom, by rude and uncivil di≈øcour≈øes; and in ≈øuch Ca≈øes 'tis u≈øual for Courts rather to enlarge
the remedy than to admit of any extenuation; for which rea≈øons he prayed that the Plantiff might have his Iudgment.
It was argued by Serjeant Calthrop on the ≈øame ≈øide, and to the ≈øame effect.

Afterwards this Term, all the Iudges argued this Ca≈øe,Argument at the Bench. ≈øeriatim at the Bench. And fir≈øt Iu≈øtice Scroggs ≈øaid, That the greatne≈øs of the Damages given ≈øhould not prevail with him, either on the one ≈øide or the other; at the Common Law no Action would lye for ≈øuch Words, though ≈øpoken of a Peer, for ≈øuch Actions were not formerly much countenanced; but now ≈øince a Remedy is given by the Statute, Words ≈øhould not be con≈øtrued either in a rigid or mild ≈øen≈øe, but according to the genuine and natural meaning, and agreeable to the common under≈øtanding of all Men.

At the Barr the ≈øtrained ≈øen≈øe for the Plaintiff is, that the≈øe Words import He is no Man of Honour; and for the Defendant, that they import no Scandal; and that no more was meant by them, but what may be ≈øaid of every Man.

'Tis true, in re≈øpect of God Almighty, we are all Vnworthy, but the ≈øub≈øequent Clau≈øe explains what unworthine≈øs the Defendant intended, for he infers him to be Unworthy, becau≈øe he acts again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon.

Now whether the Words thus explained fix any Crime on the Plaintiff, is next to be con≈øidered; and he was of Opinion that they did fix a Crime upon him; for to ≈øay He is an unworthy Man, is as much as to ≈øay, He is a vitious per≈øon, and is the ≈øame as to call him a corrupt Man, which in the Ca≈øe of a Peer is actionable; for general words are ≈øufficient to ≈øupport ≈øuch an Action, though not for a common per≈øon.

To ≈øay, a Man acts again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon, is no Crime, if he do it ignorantly; and therefore if he had ≈øaid My Lord was a weak Man, for he acts again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon; ≈øuch words had not been actionable; but the≈øe Words as ≈øpoken do not relate to his Vnder≈øtanding, but to his Morals; they relate to him al≈øo as a Peer (though the contrary has been objected) that they relate to him only as a Man, which is too nice a di≈øtinction; for to di≈øtingui≈øh between a Man and his Peerage, is like the di≈øtinction between the per≈øon of the King, and his Authority, which hath been often exploded; the words affect him in all qualities, and all relations.

It has been al≈øo objected, that the Words are too general; and like the Ca≈øe of the Bi≈øhops Return, that a Man is crimino≈øus,
which is not good: But though they are general in the Ca≈øe of a Peer, they are actionable; for to ≈øay of a Bi≈øhop That he is a wicked Man, the≈øe are as general words, and yet an Action will lye.

It has been al≈øo objected, That general Words cannot be ju≈øtified; but he was of another Opinion, as if the Plaintiff, who was Lord Lieutenant of the County, had laid an unequal charge upon a Man, who upon complaint made to him, ordered ≈øuch charge to ≈øtand, and that his will in ≈øuch ca≈øe ≈øhould be a Law: If the per≈øon ≈øhould thereupon ≈øay That the Lord had done Unworthily, and both again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon; tho≈øe words might have been ju≈øtified, by ≈øhewing the ≈øpecial matter, either in Pleading or Evidence.

'Tis too late now to examine whether an Action will lye upon this Statute, that mu≈øt be taken for granted, and therefore was not much in≈øi≈øted on by tho≈øe who argued for the Defendant, for the Authorities are very plain, that ≈øuch Actions have been allowed upon this Statute.

The Words, as here laid to be ≈øpoken, are not ≈øo bad as the Defendant might ≈øpeak, but they are ≈øo bad that an Action will lye for them; and though they are general, yet many Ca≈øes might be put of general words which import a Crime, and were adjudged actionable.

The Earl of Leice≈øter's Ca≈øe, He is an Oppre≈ø≈øor: The Lord of Winche≈øter's Ca≈øe, He kept me in Pri≈øon 'till I gave him a Relea≈øe; the≈øe words were held actionable, becau≈øe the plain inference from them is, That they were Oppre≈ø≈øors: The Lord Abergavenny's Ca≈øe, He ≈øent for me and put me into Little Ea≈øe: It might be pre≈øumed, that that Lord was a Iu≈øtice of Peace, as mo≈øt Peers are in their Counties, and that what he did was by colour of his Authority; ≈øo are all the Ca≈øes cited by tho≈øe who argued for the Plaintiff, in ≈øome of which the words were ≈øtrained to import a Crime, and yet adjudged actionable; e≈øpecially in the Ca≈øe of the Lord Marque≈øs of Dorche≈øter, He is to be valued no more than a Dog, which are le≈øs ≈ølanderous Words than tho≈øe at the Bar, becau≈øe the ≈ølander is more direct and po≈øitive.

It appears by all the≈øe Ca≈øes, that the Iudges have always con≈øtrued in favour of the≈øe Actions, and this has been done in all probability to prevent tho≈øe dangers that otherwi≈øe might en≈øue if the Lords ≈øhould take revenge them≈øelves; for which rea≈øons he held the Action will lye.

Atkyns Iu≈øtice contra. This is not a common Action upon the Ca≈øe, but an Action founded upon the Statute of the 2 of R. 2. upon the Con≈øtruction whereof the Re≈øolution of this Ca≈øe will depend, whether the Action will lie or not. And as to that he con≈øidered,
1. The Occa≈øion.
2. The Scope.
3. The parts of the Statute.

1. The occa≈øion of it is mentioned in Cotton's Abridgment of the Records of the Tower f. 173. nu. 9 and 10. At the ≈øummoning of this Parliament, the Bi≈øhop of St. Davids declared the Cau≈øes of their meeting, and told both the Hou≈øes of the Mi≈øchiefs that had hapned by divers ≈ølanderous Per≈øons, and ≈øowers of Di≈øcord, which he ≈øaid were Dogs that eat raw Fle≈øh; the meaning of which was, that they devoured and eat one another; to prevent which the Bi≈øhop de≈øired a Remedy, and his Reque≈øt ≈øeemed to be the Occa≈øion of making this Law; for ex malis moribus bonae na≈øcuntur Leges.

2. The Scope of the Act was to re≈øtrain unruly Tongues from rai≈øing fal≈øe Reports, and telling Stories and Lyes of the Peers and Great Officers of the Kingdom; ≈øo that the de≈øign of the Act was to prevent tho≈øe imminent dangers which might ari≈øe and be occa≈øioned by ≈øuch fal≈øe Slanders.
3. Then the parts of the Act are three, viz. reciting the Offence and the Mi≈øchief, then mentioning the ill Effects, and appointing of a Penalty.
From whence he Ob≈øerved.
1. That here was no new Offence made or declared; for nothing was prohibited by this Statute, but what was ≈øo at the Common Law before.

The Offences to be puni≈øhed by this Act, are mala in ≈øe, and tho≈øe are Offences again≈øt the Moral Law; they mu≈øt be ≈øuch in their nature, as bearing of fal≈øe Witne≈øs; and the≈øe are Offences again≈øt a common Per≈øon, which he admitted to be aggravated by the eminency of the per≈øon again≈øt whom they were ≈øpoke; but every uncivil Word, or rude Expre≈ø≈øion ≈øpoken, even of a Great Man, will not bear an Action; and therefore an Action will not lie upon this Statute for every fal≈øe Lye, but it mu≈øt be horrible as well as fal≈øe, and ≈øuch as were puni≈øhable in the High Commi≈ø≈øion Court, which were enormous Crimes, 12 Co. 43.

By this de≈øcription of the Offences, and the con≈øequences and effects thereof, he ≈øaid he could better judge whether the
Words were actionable or not; and he was of Opinion, that the Statute did not extend to Words of a ≈ømall and trivial nature, nor to all Words which were actionable, but only to ≈øuch which were of a greater magnitude, ≈øuch by which Di≈øcord might ari≈øe between the Lords and Commons, to the great peril of the Realm, and ≈øuch which were great Slanders, and horrible Lies, which are words purpo≈øely put into this Statute, for the aggravation and di≈øtinction of the Crime; and therefore ≈øuch Words which are actionable at the Common Law, may not be ≈øo within this Statute, becau≈øe not horrible great Scandals.

He did not deny, but that the≈øe were undecent and uncivil words, and very ill applied to that honourable per≈øon of whom they were ≈øpoken, but no body could think that they were horrible great ≈ølanders, or that any debate might ari≈øe between the Lords and Commons, by rea≈øon ≈øuch words were ≈øpoken of this Peer, or that it ≈øhould tend to the great peril of the Kingdom, and the quick de≈øtruction thereof, ≈øuch as the≈øe were not likely to be the effects and con≈øequences of the≈øe Words, and therefore could not be within the meaning of the Act, becau≈øe they do not agree with the di≈øcription given in it.

2. Here is no new puni≈øhment inflicted on the Offender, for at the Common Law, any per≈øon for ≈øuch Offences as herein are de≈øcribed might have been Fined and Impri≈øoned, either upon Indictment or Information brought again≈øt him, and no other puni≈øhment is given here but Impri≈øonment.

Even at the Common Law ≈øcandal of a Peer might be puni≈øhed by Pillory and lo≈øs of Ears, 5 Co. 125. De Libellis Famo≈øis, 12 Co. 37. 9 Co. 59. Lamb's Ca≈øe. So that it appears this was an Offence at the Common Law, but aggravated now, becau≈øe again≈øt an Act of Parliament, which is a po≈øitive Law; much like a Proclamation which is ≈øet forth to enforce the execution of a Law, by which the Offence is afterwards greater.

He did agree, that an Action would lie upon this Statute, though there were no expre≈øs Words to give it to a Peer, becau≈øe where there is a Prohibition, and a Wrong and Damage ari≈øes to the Party, by doing the thing prohibited; in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Common Law doth intitle the Party to an Action, 10 Co. 75. 12 Co. 100, 103. And ≈øuch was the Re≈øolution in the Earl of Northampton's Ca≈øe, upon con≈øtruction of the Law as incident to the Statute; and as the Offence is greater becau≈øe of the Act, and as the Action will lie upon the Statute, ≈øo the Party injured may ≈øue in a qui tam, which he could not have done before the making this Law.

3. But that ≈øuch words as the≈øe were not actionable at the Common Law, much le≈øs by the Statute; for the Defendant ≈øpoke only his Iudgment and Opinion, and doth not directly charge the Plaintiff with any thing, and might well be re≈øembled to ≈øuch Ca≈øes as are in Rolls Abridgm. 1 part 57. pl 30. which is a little more ≈øolemn, becau≈øe adjudged upon a ≈øpecial Verdict; the Words were ≈øpoken of a Iu≈øtice of Peace, Thou art a Blood-Sucker, and not fit to live in a Commonwealth. The≈øe were not held actionable, becau≈øe they neither relate to his Office, or fix any Crime upon him. Fol. 43. in the ≈øame Book, Thou de≈øerve≈øt to be hanged, not actionable, becau≈øe it was only his Opinion.

So, where the Words are general without any particular Circum≈øtances, they make no impre≈ø≈øion and gain no credit; and therefore in Cro. Car. 111. 1 Roll. Abridgm. 107. pl. 43. You are no true Subject to the King; the Action would not lie.

In this Ca≈øe 'tis ≈øaid, the Plaintiff acts again≈øt Law, which doth not imply a Habit in him ≈øo to do; and when Words may as well be taken in a mild, as in a ≈øevere Sen≈øe, the Rule is quod in mitiori ≈øen≈øu accipienda ≈øunt. Now the≈øe Words are capable of ≈øuch a favourable con≈øtruction; for no more was ≈øaid of the Plaintiff, than what in ≈øome ≈øen≈øe may be ≈øaid of every per≈øon what≈øoever; for who can boa≈øt of his Innocency? who keeps clo≈øe in all his actions to Law and Rea≈øon? and to ≈øay A Man acts again≈øt both, may imply that he departed from tho≈øe Rules in ≈øome particular Ca≈øes, where it was the Error of his Iudgment only.

In the Duke of Buckingham's Ca≈øe, Sheppard's Abridgment 1 part, f. 28. Viz. You are u≈øed to do things again≈øt Law; and mentions a particular fact there indeed, becau≈øe of U≈øage; of the ill practice it was held that an Action lies; but if he had been charged for doing a thing again≈øt Law but once, an Action would not lie.

He then ob≈øerved how the Ca≈øes which have been adjudged upon this Statute, agree with the Rules he had in≈øi≈øted on in his Argument, which Ca≈øes have not been many, and tho≈øe too of late times; in re≈øpect of the Antiquity of the Act, which was made almo≈øt 300 hundred years ≈øince, Anno 1379. and for 120 years after no Action was brought, the fir≈øt that is Reported was 13 H. 7. Keilway 26. So that we have no contemporanea expo≈øitio of the Statute to guide an Opinion, which would be a great help in this Ca≈øe; becau≈øe they who make an Act be≈øt under≈øtand the meaning; but now the meaning mu≈øt be
collected from the Statute it ≈øelf, which is the be≈øt Expo≈øition, as the Rule is given in Bonham's Ca≈øe, 8 Co. Vide the Ca≈øe in 13 H. 7.

The next Ca≈øe in time is the Duke of Buckingham's Ca≈øe, 4 H 8. Cromp Jur. of Courts, f. 13. You have no more Con≈øcience than a Dog. Lord Abergavenny again≈øt Cartwright, in the ≈øame Book, You care not how you come by Goods; in both which Ca≈øes the Words charge the Plaintiff with particular matter, and give a Narrative of ≈øomething of a fal≈øe Story, and do not barely re≈øt upon an Opinion. In the Bi≈øhop of Norwich his Ca≈øe, Cro. Eliz. 1. Viz. You have writ to me that which is again≈øt the Word of God, and to the maintainance of Super≈øtition. The≈øe were held actionable, becau≈øe they refer to his Function and greatly defame him, and yet he had but 500 Marks Damages. 29 & 30 Eliz. 1 Cro. 67. The Lord Mordant again≈øt Bridges, My Lord Mordant did know that Prude robbed Shotbolt, and bid me compound with Shotbolt for the ≈øame, and ≈øaid, he would ≈øee me ≈øatisfied for the ≈øame, though it co≈øt him an hundred pounds; which I did for him being my Ma≈øter, otherwi≈øe the Evidence I could have given would have hanged Prude: The≈øe Words were held actionable and 1000 l. Damages given; and in all the other Ca≈øes which have been mentioned upon this Statute, and where Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, the Words always charge him with ≈øome particular Fact, and are po≈øitive and certain, but where they are doubtful and general, and ≈øignifie only the Opinion of the Defendant, they are not actionable.

The Words in the Ca≈øe at Bar, neither relate to the Plaintiff as a Peer, or a Lord Lieutenant, and charge him with no particular Crime; ≈øo that from the authority of all the≈øe Ca≈øes he grounded his Opinion, that the Action would not lie; and he ≈øaid, If Laws ≈øhould be expounded to wrack People for Words, in≈øtead of remedying one Mi≈øchief, many would be introduced, for in ≈øuch Ca≈øe they would be made Snares for Men.

The Law doth bear with the Infirmities of Men, as Reliligion, Honour and Vertue doth in other Ca≈øes; and among≈øt all the excellent Qualities which Adorn the Nobility of this Nation, none doth ≈øo much as forgiving of Injuries; Solomon ≈øaith, That 'tis the Honour of a Man to pa≈øs by an Infirmity. Which if the Plaintiff ≈øhould refu≈øe, yet the Defendant (if he thinks the Damages exce≈ø≈øive) is not without his remedy by Attaint, for he ≈øaid he could ≈øhew where an Attaint was brought again≈øt a Iury for giving 60 l. Damages.

He farther ≈øaid, that he could not find that any Iudgment had been either rever≈øed or arre≈øted upon this Statute, and therefore it was fit that the Law ≈øhould be ≈øetled by ≈øome Rule, becau≈øe 'tis a wretched condition for People to live under ≈øuch Circum≈øtances, as not to know how to demean them≈øelves towards a P√©er; and ≈øince no Limits have been hitherto pre≈øcribed 'tis fit there ≈øhould be ≈øome now, and that the Court ≈øhould go by the ≈øame Rules in the Ca≈øe of a Peer, as in that of common per≈øon, that is, not to con≈øtrue the Words actionable without ≈øome particular Crime charged upon the Plaintiff, or unle≈øs he alledge ≈øpecial damages; for which Rea≈øons he held that this Action would not lye.
Wyndham Iu≈øtice accorded with Scroggs; and the Chief Iu≈øtice North agreed with them in the ≈øame Opinion; his Argument was, viz.

Fir≈øt, he ≈øaid that he did not wonder that the Defendant made his Ca≈øe ≈øo ≈øolemn, being loaded with ≈øo great damages; but that his Opinion ≈øhould not be guided with that or with any Rules, but tho≈øe of Law, becau≈øe this did not concern the Plaintiff alone, but was the Ca≈øe of all the Nobility of England; but let it be never ≈øo general, and the Conveniences or Incoveniences never ≈øo great, he would not upon any ≈øuch con≈øiderations alter the Law.

He ≈øaid that no Action would lie upon this Statute, which would not lie at the Common Law; for where a Statute prohibits a thing generally, and no particular Man is concerned, an Offence again≈øt ≈øuch a Law is puni≈øhable by Indictment; but where there is a particular damage to any per≈øon by doing the thing prohibited, there an Action will lie upon the Statute, and ≈øo it will at the Common Law.
The Words therefore which are actionable upon this Statute are ≈øo at the Common Law.

This Statute extends only to Peers or other great Officers; now every Peer as ≈øuch is a great Officer, he has an Office of great Dignity, he is to ≈øupport the King by his advice, of which he is made capable by the great Eminency of his Reputation, and therefore all Words which reflect upon him as he is the Kings Councellor, or as he is a Man of Honour and Dignity, are actionable at the Common Law.

In the ordinary Ca≈øes of Officers 'tis not nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øay that the Words were ≈øpoken relating to his Office, as to ≈øay of a Lawyer that He is a Sot or an Ignoramus; or of a Trade≈øman, He is a
Bankrupt, the Action lies though the Words were not ≈øpoken of either as a Lawyer or Trade≈øman.

He did not think that Iudges were to teach Men by what Rules to walk other than what did relate to the particular matter before them, all other things are gratis dicta; neither would he allow that di≈øtinction, that an Action would not lie where a Man ≈øpoke only his Opinion; for if that ≈øhould be admitted, it would be very ea≈øie to ≈øcandalize any Man, as I think ≈øuch a Judge is corrupt, or I am of Opinion that ≈øuch a Privy Councellor is a Traytor; and can any Man doubt whether the≈øe or ≈øuch like Words are actionable or not, becau≈øe ≈øpoken only in the ≈øen≈øe of the per≈øon? 'Tis true, in ≈øome Ca≈øes where a Man ≈øpeaks his own particular di≈øe≈øteem an Action will not lie, as if I ≈øay, I care not for ≈øuch a Lord, but that differs much where a Man ≈øpeaks his Opinion with reference to a Crime; for Opinions will be ≈øpread, and will have an implicit Faith, and becau≈øe one Man believes it another will; and 'tis upon this ground that all the Ca≈øes which have been ≈øince the Statute are ju≈øtified; and ≈øo was the late Ca≈øe ofSid. 233. the Marque≈øs of Dorche≈øter, He is no more to be valued than the Black Dog which lies there which were Words of di≈øe≈øteem, and only the Opinion of the Defendant, in which Ca≈øe Iudgment was affirmed in a Writ of Error.
Object. If it be objected to what purpo≈øe this Statute was made if no Action lies upon it, but what lay at the Common Law.

An≈øw. The Plaintiff now upon the Statute mu≈øt pro≈øecute tam pro Domino Rege quam pro ≈øeip≈øo, which he could not do at the Common Law. And it has be√©n held in the Starr-Chamber that if a Scandalum Magnatum be brought upon this Statute the Defendant cannot ju≈øtifie, becau≈øe 'tis brought qui tam, &c. and the King is concerned; but the Defendant may explain the Words and tell the occa≈øion of ≈øpeaking of them, if they are true, they mu≈øt not be publi≈øhed becau≈øe the Statute was to prevent Di≈øcords.
Object. The≈øe Words carry in them no di≈øe≈øteem.

An≈øw. According to a Common Vnder≈øtanding they are Words of di≈øre≈øpect and of great di≈øe≈øteem; for 'tis as much as to ≈øay, that the Plaintiff is a Man of no Honour; he is one who lives after his own Will, and ≈øo is not fit to be employed under the King; if any precedent di≈øcour≈øe had qualified the ≈øpeaking the≈øe Words it ought to have been ≈øhewn by the Defendant, which is not done, and therefore he concluded that the Words notwith≈øtanding
what was objected were actionable; and ≈øo by the Opinion of him, Wyndham and Scroggs Iu≈øtices, Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.
Atkins Iu≈øtice of a contrary Opinion.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: AN Action of A≈ø≈øault, Battery,Amendment after a Demurrer joyned and before Judgment given, good. Wounding and fal≈øe Impri≈øonment for an hour was brought again≈øt the Defendant, who pleads quoad venire vi & armis Not-Guilty; and as to the Impri≈øonment he ju≈øtified as Servant to the Sheriff attending upon him at the time of the A≈ø≈øize, from whom he received a Command to bring the Plaintiff (being another of the Sheriffs Servants) from the Conventicle, where finding of him, he (to wit the Defendant) did molliter manus imponere upon the Plaintiff, and brought him before his Ma≈øter, quae e≈øt eadem tran≈øgre≈ø≈øio; To this the Plaintiff demurred and ≈øhewed for Cau≈øe,

1. That the Sub≈øtance of the Iu≈øtification is not good,2 Cro. 360. becau≈øe the Servant could not thus ju≈øtifie though his Ma≈øter might; for the Lord may beat his Villain without a Cau≈øe, but if he command another to do it, an Action of Battery lies again≈øt him, 2 H. 4. 4. But though this might have been good, if well pleaded, yet 'tis not good as pleaded here; for

2. The Defendant ≈øaith quoad venire vi & armis Not-Guilty,Harding and Ferne, Po≈øtea. but ≈øaith nothing of the wounding which cannot be ju≈øtified, and therefore this Plea is not good; for which rea≈øon it was clearly re≈øolved that the Plea was ill, but the Court inclined that the Sub≈øtance of the Plea was well enough.

The Chief Iu≈øtice and Iu≈øtice Scroggs were of Opinion that a Man may as well ≈øend for his Servant from a Conventicle as from an Alehou≈øe, and may keep him from going to either of tho≈øe places: And the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid that he once knew it to be part of a Marriage Agreement that the Wife ≈øhould have leave to go to a Conventicle.

But in this Ca≈øe Leave was given to amend the Plea,Sid. 107. and put in quoad vulnerationem Not-Guilty; and it was held that though the Parties had joined in Demurrer, yet the Defendant might have Liberty to amend before Iudgment given.

div.head: Singleton ver≈øus Bawtree Executor.
div.p: Traver≈øe mu≈øt be where the Charge in the Declaration is not fully an≈øwered. AS≈øump≈øit again≈øt the Defendant as Executor, who pleads the Te≈øtator made one J. S. Executor, who proved the Will and took upon him the Execution thereof, and admini≈øtred the Goods and Chattels of the Te≈øtator, and ≈øo concludes in Abatement Et petit Judicium de Brevi, with an Averment that J. S. Super≈øtes & in plena vita exi≈øtit.

To this Plea the Plaintiff demurred, becau≈øe the Defendant ought to have traver≈øed ab≈ø
que hoc that he was Executor, or admini≈øtred as Executor, and ≈øo are all the Pleadings, 9 H. 6. 7. 4 H. 7. 13. 7 H. 6. 13.

But Serjeant Pemberton for the Defendant ≈øaid, that there is a difference when Letters of Admini≈øtration are granted in ca≈øe the Party die inte≈øtate, and when a Man makes a Will and therein appoints an Executor, for in that Ca≈øe the Executor comes in immediately from the death of the Te≈øtator; but when a Man dies inte≈øtate the Ordinary hath an Intere≈øt in the Goods, and therefore he who takes them is Executor de ≈øon tort, and may be charged as ≈øuch; but 'tis otherwi≈øe generally, where there is a Will and a rightful Executor, who proveth the ≈øame, for he may bring a Trover again≈øt the Party for taking of the Te≈øtators Goods though he never had the actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of them; and therefore the taking in ≈øuch ca≈øe will not make a Man Executor de ≈øon tort, becau≈øe there is another lawful Executor; but 'tis true, that if there be a ≈øpecial Admini≈øtration 'tis otherwi≈øe; as if a Stranger doth take upon him to pay Debts or Legacies; or to u≈øe the Inte≈øtates Goods; ≈øuch an expre≈øs Admini≈øtration will make him Executor de ≈øon tort, and liable, as in Read's Ca≈øe, 5 Co.

So in this Ca≈øe the Defendant pleads that J. S. was Executor, which prima facie di≈øcharges him; for to make him chargeable the Plaintiff ought in his Replication to ≈øet forth the ≈øpecial Admini≈øtration, that though there was an Executor, yet before he a≈ø≈øumed the Execution or proved the Will, the Defendant fir≈øt took the Goods, by which he became Executor of his own Wrong, and ≈øo to have brought him≈øelf within this di≈øtinction, (which was the truth of this Ca≈øe) and that would have put the matter out of di≈øpute, which not being done, he held the Plea to be good; and ≈øo prayed Iudgment for the Defendant.

The Court were of Opinion that prima facie this was a good Plea; for where a Man2 Sand. 28. confe≈ø≈øes and avoids, he need not traver≈øe, and here the Defendant had avoided his being chargeable as Executor de ≈øon tort, by ≈øaying that there was a rightful Executor who had admini≈øtred the Te≈øtators whole E≈øtate; but the Surmi≈øe of the Plaintiff and the Plea of the Defendant being both in the2 Cro. 579. pl. 9. Sid. 341. 1 Sand. 338. affirmative no I≈ø≈øue can be joined thereon; and therefore the Defendant ought to have traver≈øed that he was Executor, or ever admini≈øtred as Executor, the rather becau≈øe his Plea gives no full An≈øwer to the Charge in the Declaration, being charged as Executor, who pleads that another was Executor, and both the≈øe matters might be true, and yet the Defendant liable as Executor de ≈øon tort, which (notwith≈øtanding Iniquum non e≈øt prae≈øumendum) may be well intended here; and ≈øo Iudgment was given again≈øt the Defendant that this was no good Plea.

div.head: Adams ver≈øus Adams.
div.p: DEBT upon Bond to perform an Award,Award, Exceptions thereunto overruled. ≈øo that it be made before or upon the 22d day of December, or to choo≈øe an Vmpire.
The Defendant pleads no Award made: The Plaintiff replies and ≈øets forth an Award, and a≈ø≈øigns a Breach: The Defendant demurrs.

1. That here is no good Award,Mod. Rep. 274. becau≈øe the Arbitrators were to make it before or upon the 22d day of December, and if they could not agr√©e, to choo≈øe an Vmpire:2 Sand. 133. Now the Award ≈øet forth in the Replication was made by an Vmpire cho≈øen after the 22d day of December, which the Arbitrators had not power by the Submi≈ø≈øion to choo≈øe, Sed non allocatur, becau≈øe they might have made their Award upon the 22d. of December, and therefore could not choo≈øe an Vmpire till afterwards; for their Power was only determined as to the making an Award.
2.Antea. Becau≈øe the Vmpire recites that the Parties ≈øubmitting had bound them≈øelves to ≈øtand to his Award which is not true, Sed non allocatur, becau≈øe 'tis but Recital.

3. The Award is that the Defendant ≈øhould pay the Plaintiff two Sums at ≈øeveral times, and that ≈øeveral Relea≈øes ≈øhall be given pre≈øently, and ≈øo the Bond and the Mony would be di≈øcharged; and for that rea≈øon the Awarding the Relea≈øe was void again≈øt the Plaintiff, and by con≈øequence there is nothing on
his ≈øide to be done; and the Court were all of Opinion that for this la≈øt rea≈øon the Award was not good.

Serjeant Baldwyn who was of Council for the Plaintiff, ≈øaid that it was an Exception which he could not an≈øwer if true, but ≈øaid that the Award was not that Relea≈øes ≈øhould be given pre≈øently, but that the Mony ≈øhould be paid and Relea≈øes given, by which it appears by the very Method and Order of the Award, that the general Relea≈øes were not to be given till after the Mony paid; and that being the Ca≈øe the Court were clear of Opinion, that it was well enough; and ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Brook ver≈øus Sir William Turner.
div.p: Feme Covert made a Will and di≈øpo≈øed of her E≈øtate, and good.IN a Prohibition to the Spiritual Court to prove the Will of Philippa Brooks by Sir William Turner her Executor.

A Tryal at the Barr was had, in which the Ca≈øe was, viz. That James Phillips, by Will in Writing dated 24 Aprilis, 1671. inter alia gave to Philippa for Life, in lieu and full of her Dower, all his Hou≈øes in Three Crown Court in Southwark, purcha≈øed by him of one Mr. Keeling; another Hou≈øe in Southwark purcha≈øed of one Mr. Bowes, and all his Hou≈øes in New Fi≈øh≈øtreet, Pudding-Lane, Buttolph Lane, Beer Lane, Duxfield Lane and Dowgate London; and died.

That afterwards there being a Treaty of Marriage between the Plaintiff Mr. Brooks and Philippa Phillips, it was agr√©ed that all the ≈øaid Hou≈øes and Rents, and Profits thereof, and all Debts, Ready Mony, Iewels and other real and per≈øonal E≈øtate what≈øoever, or wherein Philippa, or any in Tru≈øt for her, were intere≈ø≈øed or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, ≈øhould at any time as well before as after the Marriage be di≈øpo≈øed in ≈øuch manner as ≈øhould be agreed on between them.

And thereupon by Indenture tripartite between Mr. Brook of the fir≈øt part, the ≈øaid Philippa Phillips of the ≈øecond part, and William Williams and Francis Gillow of the third part, reciting the ≈øaid Will of James Phillips and the ≈øaid Agr√©ement, the ≈øaid Philippa in con≈øideration of a Shilling paid to her by Williams and Gillow did with the full and free Con≈øent of the ≈øaid Edward Brook the now Plaintiff, grant, bargain and ≈øell to the ≈øaid Williams and Gillow all the ≈øaid Hou≈øes devi≈øed by the la≈øt Will of the ≈øaid James Phillips, in Tru≈øt that the ≈øaid Tru≈øtees ≈øhould permit her to receive and enjoy the whole Rents and Profits of all
the Hou≈øes purcha≈øed of Mr. Keeling, and of all the Hou≈øes in Beer Lane, and of two of the Hou≈øes in Broad≈øtreet in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of James and Wor≈øley, and the Quarters Rent only due at Chri≈øtmas then la≈øt pa≈øt, and no more, ≈øaving to Philippa all former Rents and Arrears thereof to be received by her, and not by Mr. Brook, and to be imploied as therein after was mentioned.
