And upon this farther Tru≈øt, that after Mr. Brooks death in ca≈øe the ≈øaid Philippa ≈øurvived, that then the Tru≈øt√©es ≈øhould permit Philippa and her A≈ø≈øigns from time to time to grant, ≈øell and di≈øpo≈øe of the re≈øt of the Premi≈ø≈øes, and all others whereof ≈øhe was ≈øei≈øed or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, as ≈øhe ≈øhould think fit; and al≈øo to receive, di≈øpo≈øe of and enjoy all the Rents and Profits of the Premi≈ø≈øes (not thereby appointed to be received by the Plaintiff) for her only particular and ≈øeparate u≈øe, and not for the u≈øe of the Plaintiff, without any account to be given for the ≈øame, and not to be accounted any part of Mr. Brook's E≈øtate; and that the Acquittances of the ≈øaid Philippa be good di≈øcharges again≈øt the Plaintiff; and the ≈øaid Tru≈øtees to joyn with Philippa in the Sale and di≈øpo≈øition of the Premi≈ø≈øes.

And Philippa in farther con≈øideration of the ≈øaid Marriage agreed to pay to Mr. Brook on the day of Marriage 150 l. and to deliver him ≈øeveral Bonds and Securities for Mony in the ≈øaid Indenture particularly named.

And the ≈øaid Philippa in farther pur≈øuance of the ≈øaid Agreement, and in con≈øideration of a Shilling paid to her by the ≈øaid Tru≈øtees, did with the like a≈ø≈øent a≈ø≈øign to them all her Iewels, Rings, Mony, &c. and other her real and per≈øonal E≈øtate, upon Tru≈øt that they ≈øhould permit her to enjoy the ≈øame to her own ≈øeparate and di≈øtinct u≈øe, and to di≈øpo≈øe thereof from time to time as well before the ≈øaid Marriage as afterwards, as ≈øhe ≈øhould think fit without any Accompt, and for want of ≈øuch Limitation or Appointment, in Tru≈øt for her, her Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns; and the Plaintiff not to hinder or impeach the ≈øame, and not to be taken as any part of his E≈øtate, or be ≈øubject to his Debts, Legacies or Engagements.

And the Plaintiff covenanted, that if the Marriage took effect, the Tru≈øtees ≈øhould quietly enjoy the Premi≈ø≈øes, and Philippa to di≈øpo≈øe thereof without trouble or mole≈øtation by him, his Executors, &c. and that Philippa (notwith≈øtanding the Marriage) ≈øhould at any time either before or after, have liberty by Deed or Will in Writing by her publi≈øhed in the pre≈øence of two or more credible Witne≈ø≈øes, or otherwi≈øe how≈øoever, at her plea≈øure to give and di≈øpo≈øe all her real and per≈øonal E≈øtate, Goods, Chattels, &c. whereof ≈øhe was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed before the ≈øaid intended Marriage,
or at any time after, or any other per≈øon in Tru≈øt for her (except ≈øuch part thereof as was thereby agreed to be paid to, and received by the Plaintiff) to ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons, and to ≈øuch u≈øe and u≈øes, intents and purpo≈øes as ≈øhe ≈øhould think fit, and that the Plaintiff ≈øhould a≈ø≈øent thereunto, and not impeach the ≈øame in Law or Equity.

The Marriage ≈øhortly afterwards took effect, and Philippa by Will in Writing gave all her E≈øtate away in Legacies and Charitable V≈øes, and ≈øhe devi≈øed to the Plaintiff 20 l. to buy him Mourning, and gave to Sir William Turner the Defendant 100 l. and made him Executor; and ≈øhe devi≈øed to Mr. Hays and to Mr. Grace 20 l. apiece, whom ≈øhe made Over≈øeers of her Will, and died. There was neither Date or Witne≈ø≈øes to this Will, ≈øave only the Month and Year of our Lord therein mentioned; and that this Will not being proved in the Spiritual Court, the Plaintiff moved for a Prohibition, and the Defendant took I≈ø≈øue upon the Sugge≈øtion.
In which Ca≈øe the≈øe Points were re≈øolved by the Court.

Mod. Rep. 211.1. If there be an Agreement before Marriage that the Wife may make a Will, if ≈øhe do ≈øo, 'tis a good Will, unle≈øs the Husband di≈øagre√©s; and his Con≈øent ≈øhall be implyed till the contrary appear. And the Law is the ≈øame though he knew not when ≈øhe made the Will, which when made 'tis in this Ca≈øe, as in others, ambulatory till the death of the Wife, and his di≈ø≈øent thereunto; but if after her death he doth con≈øent he can never afterwards di≈ø≈øent, for then he might do it backwards and forwards in infinitum.
2. If the Husband would not have ≈øuch Will to ≈øtand he ought pre≈øently after the death of the Wife to ≈øhew his di≈ø≈øent.

3. If the Husband con≈øent that his Wife ≈øhall make a Will, and accordingly ≈øhe doth make ≈øuch a Will and dieth, and if after her death he comes to the Executor named in the Will, and ≈øeems to approve her choice, by ≈øaying, He is glad that ≈øhe had appointed ≈øo worthy a Per≈øon, and ≈øeemed to be ≈øatisfied in the main with the Will, and recommended a Coffin-maker to the Executor, and a Gold≈ømith for making the Rings, and a Herald Painter for making the E≈øcutcheons, this is a good a≈ø≈øent and makes it a good Will, though the Husband when he ≈øees and reads the Will (being thereat di≈øplea≈øed) oppo≈øes the Probate in the Spiritual Court by entring Caveats and the like; and ≈øuch di≈øagre√©ment after the former a≈ø≈øent will not hurt the Will, becau≈øe ≈øuch a≈ø≈øent is good in Law, though he know not the particular Beque≈øts in the Will.

4. When there is an expre≈øs Agreement or Con≈øent that a Woman may make a Will, a little proof will be ≈øufficient to make out the continuance of that Con≈øent after her death; and it will be needful on the other ≈øide to prove a Di≈øagreement made in a ≈øolemn manner; and tho≈øe things which prove a di≈ø≈øatisfaction on the Husbands part may not prove a di≈øagreement, becau≈øe the one is to be more formal than the other; for if the Husband ≈øhould ≈øay that he hoped to ≈øet a≈øide the Will, or by a Suit or otherwi≈øe to bring the Executor to terms, this is not a di≈ø≈øent.

div.head: Sir Robert Howard ver≈øus the Queens Tru≈øtees and the Attorney General. In the Dutchy.
div.p: UPON a Bill exhibited in the Dutchy Court; Jones 126. The Que≈øtion was, whether the Steward≈øhip of a Mannor was grantable in Rever≈øion or not?

The Attorny General and the Queens Council, Butler and Hanmore, held that it was not: But Serjeant Pemberton and Mr. Thur≈øby would have argued to the contrary; for they ≈øaid it might be granted in F√©e, or for any le≈øs E≈øtate, and ≈øo in rever≈øion, for it may be executed by Deputy.

But this Que≈øtion ari≈øing upon a Plea and Demurrer the Debate thereof was re≈øpited till the hearing of the Cau≈øe, which was the u≈øual Practice in Chancery, as North Chief Iu≈øtice, who a≈ø≈øi≈øted the Chancellor of the Dutchy, informed the Court.

And he ≈øaid that in all Courts of Equity the u≈øual cour≈øe was; when a Bill is exhibited to have Mony decreed due on a Bond upon a Sugge≈øtion that the Bond is lo≈øt; there mu≈øt be Oath made of it, for otherwi≈øe the Cau≈øe is properly triable at the Common Law; and ≈øuch cour≈øe is to be ob≈øerved in all the like Ca≈øes, where the Plaintiff by ≈øurmi≈øe of the lo≈øs of a D√©ed draws the Defendant into Equity; but if the Ca≈øe be proper in its own nature for a Court of Con≈øcience, and in ca≈øe where the D√©ed is not lo≈øt, the Remedy de≈øired in Chancery could not be obtained upon a Trial at Law, there though it be alledged that the D√©ed is lo≈øt, Oath need not be made of it; as if there be a D√©ed in which there is a Covenant for farther A≈ø≈øurance, and the Party comes in Equity, and prays the thing to be done in ≈øpecie, there is no need of an Oath of the lo≈øs of ≈øuch Deed, becau≈øe if it 'tis not lo≈øt the Party could not at Law have the thing for which he prayed Relief, for he could only recover Damages.

Note al≈øo, That he ≈øaid in the Ca≈øe of one Oldfeild that it was the con≈øtant practi≈øe where a Bill is exhibited in Equity to foreclo≈øe the right of Redemption, if the Mortgagor be foreclo≈øed he pays no Co≈øts; and though it was urged for him that he ≈øhould pay no Co≈øts in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe the Mortgagee was dead, and the Heir within Age, and the Mony could not ≈øafely be paid without a Decree, yet it being nece≈ø≈øary for him to come into Equity, he mu≈øt pay for that nece≈ø≈øity.
Note al≈øo, the difference between a Mortgage in Fee, and for Years; for if 'tis in Fee, the Mortgagor cannot have a Reconveyance upon payment of the Mony, till the Heir comes of Age.

It was agreed in this Ca≈øe by the Court, that if there be Tenant for Life, Remainder in Fee, and they joyn in a Deed purporting an ab≈øolute Sale, if it be proved to be but a Mortgage he ≈øhall have his E≈øtate for Life again, paying pro rata, and according to his E≈øtate; and ≈øo it ≈øhall be in the Ca≈øe between Tenant in Dower and the Heir.

div.head: Loyd ver≈øus Langford.
div.p: Le≈ø≈øee for Years makes an A≈ø≈øignment of his Term where Debt lies upon the Contract, and where not.IN a ≈øpecial Verdict the Ca≈øe was: Viz. A. being Tenant in Fee of Lands, demi≈øed the ≈øame to B. for ≈øeven years, B. re-demi≈øes the ≈øame Lands to A. for the ≈øaid Term of ≈øeven years, re≈øerving 20 l. Rent per Annum. A. dyes, his Wife enters as Guardian to the Heir of A. her Son, and receives the Profits. B. brings Debt again≈øt her as Executrix de ≈øon tort, in the debet and detinet, and whether this Action would lie or not was the Que≈øtion.

Serjeant Baldwyn, who argued for the Plaintiff, held that it did lie, for though the Rent in this Ca≈øe re≈øerved did not attend the Rever≈øion, becau≈øe the Le≈ø≈øee had a≈ø≈øigned over all his Term, yet an Action of Debt will lie for that Rent upon the Contract, Cro. Jac. 487. Witton ver≈øus Bye 45 Ed. 3. 8. 20 E. 4 13. Covevenant will lie upon the Words Yeilding and Paying.
If then here is a good Rent re≈øerved, the Wife who receives the Profits, becomes Executrix de ≈øon tort, and ≈øo is lyable to the payment.

It hath been held there cannot be an Executor de ≈øon tort of a Term, but the Modern Opinions are otherwi≈øe; as it was held in the Ca≈øe of Porter and Sweetman, Trin. 1653. in B. R. And
that an Action of Debt will lie again≈øt him. Indeed ≈øuch an Executor cannot be of a Term in futuro, and that is the Re≈øolution in Kenrick and Burge≈ø≈øes Ca≈øe, Moor Rep. Where in Ejectment upon Not Guilty pleaded, it appeared that one Okeham had a Lea≈øe for years of the Lands in que≈øtion, who dyed Inte≈øtate, which Lea≈øe his Wife a≈ø≈øigned by parol to Burge≈øs; and then ≈øhe takes out Letters of Admini≈øtration, and a≈ø≈øigns it again to Kenrick, who by the Opinion of the Court had the be≈øt Title.

But if one enter as Executor de ≈øon tort, and ≈øell Goods, the Sale is good; which was not ≈øo in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe there was a Term in Rever≈øion, whereof no Entry could be made, for which rea≈øon there could be no Executor de ≈øon tort to that, and therefore the Sale to Burge≈øs before the Admini≈øtration, was held void.

And that there may be an Executor de ≈øon tort of a Term, there was a late Ca≈øe adjudged in Trin. 22 Car. 2. between Stevens and Carr, which was, Le≈ø≈øee for years rendring Rent dies Inte≈øtate, his Wife takes out Letters of Admini≈øtration, and afterwards Marries a ≈øecond Husband, the Wife dies, and the Husband continues in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and receives the Profits: It was agreed, that for the Profits received he was an≈øwerable as Executor de ≈øon tort, and the Book of 10 H. 11. was cited as an authority to prove it.

Pemberton Serjeant for the Defendant,Ex parte Def. would not undertake to an≈øwer the≈øe Points which were argued on the other ≈øide, but admitted them to be plain again≈øt him, for he did not doubt but that Debt would lie upon the Contract, where the whole Term was a≈ø≈øigned, and that there may be an Executor de ≈øon tort of a Term; but he ≈øaid, that which was the principal point in the Ca≈øe was not ≈øtirred: The que≈øtion was, whether an Action of Debt will lie again≈øt the Defendant as Executor de ≈øon tort where there is no Term at all; for 'tis plain there was none in being in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe when the Le≈ø≈øee Re-demi≈øed his whole Term to the Le≈ø≈øor, that was a Surrender in Law, and as fully as if it had been actually ≈øurrendred; and therefore this was quite different from the Ca≈øe, where Le≈ø≈øee for years makes an A≈ø≈øignment of his whole Term to a Stranger, Debt will lie upon the Contract there, becau≈øe an Intere≈øt pa≈ø≈øes to him in Rever≈øion, and as to this purpo≈øe a Term is in e≈ø≈øe by the Contract of the Parties, and ≈øo it would here again≈øt the fir≈øt Le≈ø≈øor, who was Le≈ø≈øee upon the Re-demi≈øe; but now becau≈øe of the Surrender, the Heir is intituled to enter, and the Mother,
who is the Defendant, enters in his Right as Guardian, which ≈øhe may lawfully do.

If therefore Debt only lies upon the Contract of the Te≈øtator, as in truth it doth where the whole Term is gone, the Plaintiff cannot charge any one as Executor de ≈øon tort in the debet and detinet.

And the whole Term is gon here by the Re-demi≈øe, which is an ab≈øolute Surrender, and not upon Condition, for in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Surrenderor might have entred for non-performance, and ≈øo it might have been revived: And of this Opinion was the whole Court in both points, and would not hear any farther Argument in the Ca≈øe; the Plaintiff having no remedy at Law, the Court told him that he might ≈øeek for relief in Chancery, if he thought fit.

div.head: Harman's Ca≈øe.
div.p: IN Covenant the breach a≈ø≈øigned was, that the Defendant did not repair; He pleads generally quod reparavit & de hoc ponit ≈øe ≈øuper patriam, this was held good after a Verdict.

div.head: Quadring ver≈øus Downs, & al'.
div.p: Ward≈øhip cannot be where there is no de≈øcent.IN a Writ of right of Ward, the Ca≈øe was, Viz Sir William Quadring being ≈øei≈øed of Lands in Fee, by Deed and Fine ≈øettles them upon his Son William and his Wife for their Lives, the Remainder to the ≈øecond Son in Tail, with divers Remainders over. The Grandfather dyes, the Father and Mother dyes, the elde≈øt Son dyes without I≈ø≈øue, and ≈øo the Land came to the ≈øecond Son.

The Plaintiff intitles him≈øelf as Guardian in Socage to the Ward≈øhip both of the Per≈øon and Lands of the Infant, whom the Defendant detained, and Serjeant Newdigate for him demurred, becau≈øe where there is no de≈øcent there can be no Ward≈øhip, for the ≈øecond Son is in by purcha≈øe and not by de≈øcent, for here is no mention of the Rever≈øion in Fee, and therefore it may be intended that it was conveyed away; and be≈øides, if it ≈øhould be intended to continue to Sir William Quadring the Grandfather after this Settlement, yet it cannot be thought to
de≈øcend to the Ward, becau≈øe 'tis not ≈øaid who was Heir; for though it be ≈øaid that the Father of the Ward was Son to Sir William, yet 'tis not ≈øaid Son and Heir, and of that Opinion was the whole Court in both points; for there mu≈øt be a de≈øcent or el≈øe there can be no Ward≈øhip; and it doth not appear that any de≈øcent was here, becau≈øe 'tis not ≈øaid that the Rever≈øion did de≈øcend, nor who was Heir to Sir William, which the Plaintiff perceiving, prayed leave to amend, and it was granted.

In this Ca≈øe it was ≈øaid at the Bar, that one might be a Ward in Socage, though he be in by Purcha≈øe, for the Guardian is to have no profit, but is only a Curator, to do all for the benefit of the Ward; and ≈øo there need be no de≈øcent, as is nece≈ø≈øary in the Ca≈øe of a Ward in Chivalry; for that being in re≈øpect of the Tenure, the Guardian is to have profit.
The Lord Chief Iu≈øtice North ≈øaid,Nota. he knew where there was ≈øome doubt of the ≈øufficiency of the Guardian in Socage, that the Court of Chancery made him give good Security.

div.head: Harding ver≈øus Ferne.
div.p: IN an Action of A≈ø≈øault, Battery and Impri≈øonment, Antea Anonymus. 'till the Plaintiff had paid 11 l. 10 s. The Defendant pleads and ju≈øtifies by rea≈øon of an Execution, and a Warrant thereupon for 11 l. and doth not mention the 10 s. And upon demurrer for this Cau≈øe, Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff upon the fir≈øt opening, becau≈øe it appeared the Defendant took more than was warranted by the Execution.

div.head: Ellis ver≈øus Yarborough Sheriff of York≈øhire.
div.p: IN an Action of E≈øcape the Plaintiff ≈øets forth that the Defendant Arre≈øted a Man upon a Latitat directed to him at the Suit of the Plaintiff,Ca≈øe lies not again≈øt the Sheriff though he take in≈øufficient Bail, but mu≈øt be amerced if the Defendants do not appear. Mod. Rep. 227. Antea. and afterwards ≈øuffered him to go at large.
The Defendant pleads the Statute of 23 H. 6. cap. 10. that the took good and ≈øufficient Bail within the County according to the Statute.

The Plaintiff replies, that he let him go at large, ab≈ø
que hoc that he took good and ≈øufficient Bail within the County. To this the Defendant demurred.

This Ca≈øe was argued this Term by Serjeant Skipwith and Baldwyn for the Defendant, and by Serjeant Barrel and George Strode for the Plaintiff; and in their Arguments for the Defendant it was ≈øaid,Ex parte Def. Sid. 23. 2 Sand. 60. Cro. Eliz. 624. That the Plaintiff in this ca≈øe cannot maintain an Action of E≈øcape, for where the Sheriff takes Bail, no E≈øcape will lie again≈øt him.
1. Becau≈øe he is compellable by the Statute to let the Defendant to Bail.
2. If he have not the Defendant ready at the return of the Writ, he may be amerced, which is the proper remedy.

3. This precept of letting the Defendant to Bail, being by Act of Parliament, is intended by the direction of the Plaintiff him≈øelf, becau≈øe all people are Parties to the making of an Act of Parliament.

Many Actions have been brought again≈øt Sheriffs, upon Sugge≈øtions that no Bail have been taken,Antea, Page and Tul≈øe. and for which an Action on the Ca≈øe will lie; but where there is Bail taken, the Sheriff hath done his duty which he is commanded to do by the Statute; and if the Defendant doth not appear, the Sheriff is to be amerced, and he is the proper Iudge of the Bail; the Plaintiff is no ways concerned therein whether good or bad.

At the Common Law the Defendant was to continue in Pri≈øon till he had ≈øatisfied the Plaintiff, to whom no benefit was intended by this Statute, but rather an ea≈øe to the Defendant, that he ≈øhould be from thence di≈øcharged, giving good Bail; and the rea≈øon why the Statute mentions ≈øuch Bail is in favour of the Sheriff al≈øo,Cro Eliz. 672. to ≈øecure him from Amerciaments; the Bail being then for his Indempnity, he is the ≈øole Iudge both of their per≈øons, number, and ability, for the Statute requires two Sureties, and that they ≈øhall be Men within the County; yet if there is but one, and he not of the County, and if the Bond taken by the Sheriff for the appearance of the Defendant be but 40 l. and the Debt due to the Plaintiff be 400 l. 'tis well enough,2 Cro. 286. becau≈øe the Statute doth not re≈øtrain him to any Sum or Sureties, for he may take what Sum he plea≈øe to force the Defendant to appear.

And when this Security is taken, the Sheriff is neither compellable to a≈ø≈øign it to the Plaintiff, or he to take it. Tis true, he doth u≈øually a≈ø≈øign it, but that is to di≈øcharge him≈øelf of the Amerciaments, which is the way that the Plaintiff ≈øhould pur≈øue where he doth imagine the Bail to be in≈øufficient.

If therefore this Statute was made for the benefit and ea≈øe of the Defendant, the Security therein directed is for the indempnity of the Sheriff; and therefore if no Action will lie again≈øt him for taking of in≈øufficient Bail, 'tis as rea≈øonable that no Action ≈øhould lie again≈øt him when he hath taken Bail, which he is compelled to do, and ≈øo the Traver≈øe in this Ca≈øe is immaterial, and Iudgment ought to be given for the Defendant.

On the other ≈øide it was argued,Ex parte Quer. That an Action of E≈øcape would lye again≈øt the Sheriff, if he did not take good Bail, which matter may be traver≈øed; and though here if the Defendant had rejoyned, the I≈ø≈øue had been, whether ≈øufficient Bail within the County or not, yet that part of the I≈ø≈øue had not been material, for the only matter had re≈øted upon the ≈øufficiency or in≈øufficiency of the Bail in general. Like a Ca≈øe adjudged in Mich. 14 Car. 2. in B. R. where a Woman had power given her by her Husband to make a Will in the pre≈øence of two credible Witne≈ø≈øes: It was pleaded that ≈øhe made a Will in the pre≈øence of A. and B. credible Witne≈ø≈øes, and I≈ø≈øue was thereupon joyned,Antea. and it was found to be made in the pre≈øence of C. and D. who were credible Witne≈ø≈øes, and this was held to be good, becau≈øe the ≈øub≈øtance was found, Viz. That it was made in the pre≈øence of two credible Witne≈ø≈øes.

The Defendant therefore here ought to have taken good and ≈øufficient Bail to bring him≈øelf within the Statute, and that is traver≈øable, and the Pleadings are well enough, for if there be good Bail, 'tis not material in what County they live.

Vpon the fir≈øt Argument of this Ca≈øe, the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice inclined that an Action of E≈øcape did lie at the Common Law again≈øt the Sheriff; for it was clear that he was to keep the Party arre≈øted in Pri≈øon 'till the Debt was ≈øatisfied, and that if he had gone at large, it had been an E≈øcape; the Sheriff then hath no excu≈øe but by this Statute, and to entitle him≈øelf to any benefit thereby, he mu≈øt pur≈øue the very directions therein pre≈øcribed, and therefore ought to take good and ≈øufficient Bail, for otherwi≈øe the Statute would be eluded, if it be left in his power to take what Bail he plea≈øes; and he was of Opinion, that the Plaintiff had an Intere≈øt in the Security, and therefore the Sheriff was lyable, if it was not good when fir≈øt taken, but not if by any accident afterwards the Bail mi≈øcarry or become in≈øolvent.

And Iu≈øtice Wyndham was of the ≈øame Opinion, that the Sheriff was lyable; he differed only as to the manner of the
Action, which he held ≈øhould be a ≈øpecial Action on the Ca≈øe, ≈øetting forth the whole matter, and alledging that the Defendant did not take ≈øufficient Bail.

Iu≈øtice Atkyns ≈øaid, the Ca≈øe depends upon the con≈øtruction of that23 H. 6. cap. 10. Statute, which is very ob≈øcure, and the Opinions various which have been upon it; 'tis plain the Sheriff is compellable to take Bail, and that an Action lies again≈øt him if he refu≈øes ≈øuch as are ≈øufficient when tendred; but the que≈øtion was now whether it will lie again≈øt him fortaking tho≈øe who are in≈øufficient; and as to that he ≈øaid that many Authorities were in our Books, that the taking of Bail is left to the Sheriffs di≈øcretion, and he is thereby to provide for his own indempnity; for he mu≈øt return a Cepi Corpus upon the Writ, he cannot return that he let him to Bail according to the Statute, and therefore inclined that the Action did not lie.

Scroggs Iu≈øtice contra. He ≈øaid that this Statute de≈øigned the benefit of the Creditor, that he might either get the Sheriff amerced or have an Action, in both which Ca≈øes he might indempnifie him≈øelf by the Security he had taken. Tis true, he may let the Party to Bail, but 'tis ≈øub modo, it mu≈øt be upon good Bail; and if the Sheriff be Iudge of the Security, 'tis an Argument that he is lyable, for if he was not in danger, he need not take Security.
But afterwards upon the ≈øecond Argument, the Chief Iu≈øtice and the whole Court were of Opinion, that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Defendant.

North Chief Iu≈øtice. The Common Law was very rigorous as to the execution of Proce≈øs; the Capias was ita quod habeas the Body at the day of the Return, and if the Sheriff had arre≈øted one, it had been an E≈øcape to let him go. Before the making of this Statute the Sheriff u≈øually took Sureties for the appearance of the Pri≈øoner, and by this means u≈øed great Extortion and took great Sums of Mony; to prevent which Mi≈øchiefs this Statute was made and ≈øo de≈øigned.
1. For the ea≈øe of the Pri≈øoner, the Sheriff being now compellable to take Security, which he was not obliged to do before.
2. To prevent Extortion, and therefore directs that a Bond ≈øhall be taken in ≈øuch manner and with ≈øuch conditions as is therein mentioned.

But the Plaintiff ≈øince the Statute is much in the ≈øame condition
as before, for he is to make the ≈øame Return of Cepi Corpus: 'Tis true, he may now let him go upon Bail, but as to the Creditor he is to have him in Court to an≈øwer his Suit as before, and ≈øhall be amerced if he doth not appear at the Return of the Writ, ≈øo that tho' this Statute be an ea≈øe to the Defendant, yet 'tis a burthen to the Sheriff, who runs a greater hazard ≈øince the making of this Act than before; becau≈øe then he might keep him in pri≈øon till the Debt was ≈øatisfied, but now he is obliged to let him at large upon Bail, from whom he is directed to take a Bond, which he may keep in his own hands to indempnifie him≈øelf: The Court can only amerce him, if the Defendant do not appear at the Return of the Proce≈øs, and 'tis not material to the party whether the Sheriff take one or more Security, that being in his di≈øcretion; ≈øome he mu≈øt take, for otherwi≈øe 'tis directly in oppo≈øition to the Statute; neither is it material to the party whether they are ≈øuch as are ≈øufficient, for if they are not, and the Defendant is thereupon di≈øcharged, this will not amount to an E≈øcape; becau≈øe nothing is done but what is pur≈øuant to the Statute, and therefore he is no otherwi≈øe chargeable than by Amerciaments.

The Statute was made and intended for the benefit of the Debtor, not of the Creditor, and there might be ≈øome colour for the Action if the Sheriff might Return that he let him to Bail, for then it might have been nece≈ø≈øary to have alledged the ≈øufficiency of them, which might have been traver≈øed; but now he mu≈øt pur≈øue the ≈øub≈øtance of the Statute ≈øo far as to take Bail; he is the proper Iudge of the ≈øufficiency, and when the Bail is taken he mu≈øt return a Cepi Corpus, ≈øo that he is only to be amerced till he bring in the Body, but an E≈øcape will not lie again≈øt him.

div.head: Long's Ca≈øe.
div.p: ONE Long was arre≈øted in the Pallace-Yard, Priviledge of an Attorny. not far di≈øtant from the Hall Gate, the Court being then ≈øitting, and being an Attorny of this Court, he, together with the Officer, was brought into Court, and the Officer was committed to the Fleet, that he might learn to know his di≈øtance; and becau≈øe the Plaintiff was an Attorny of the Court of Kings-Bench, who informed this Court, that his cau≈øe of Action was for 200 l. therefore the Court ordered that another of the Sheriffs Bayliffs ≈øhould take charge of the Pri≈øoner, and that Mr. Robin≈øon the Chief Prothonotary ≈øhould go along with him to the Court of Kings-Bench, which was done, and that Court being informed how the Ca≈øe was, di≈øcharged the Defendant upon filing of common Bail.

The Writ upon which this Long was arre≈øted was an Attachment of Priviledge, which the Court ≈øuppo≈øed to be made on purpo≈øe to ou≈øt him of his Priviledge; for there was another Writ again≈øt him at the Sheriffs Office at the Suit of another per≈øon.

div.head: The Counte≈øs of Northumberland's Ca≈øe.
div.p: Knights mu≈øt be of the Jury where a Peer is concerned.ADjudged that where a P√©er is Party either Plaintiff or Defendant, two or more Knights mu≈øt be returned of the Iury; and it was ≈øaid that in Cumberland there was but one Free-holder who was a Knight, be≈øides Sir Richard Stote, a Serjeant at Law; and the Court were of Opinion that rather than there ≈øhould be a failure of Iu≈øtice a Serjeant of Law ought to be returned a Iuryman, for his Priviledge would not extend to a Ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity.

div.head: Bell ver≈øus Knight, In Banco Regis.
div.p: Smiths Forges are chargeable with the Duty of Fire-hearthIN an Action of Trover; Vpon Not Guilty pleaded the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict, in which the Point was upon the Con≈øtruction of the Statute of 14 Car. 2. c. 10. for the e≈øtabli≈øhing of an additional Revenue upon the King, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors for the better ≈øupport of his and their Crown and Dignity, by which it is Enacted, That for every Fire-Hearth and Stove in every Hou≈øe the yearly Sum of 2 s. ≈øhall be paid to the King, other than ≈øuch as in the ≈øaid Act are exempted: Then comes a Provi≈øo which ≈øaith, That this Act ≈øhall not extend to charge any Blowing Hou≈øe, Stamp, Furnace or Kilne, &c. And the Que≈øtion now was, whether a Smiths Forge ≈øhall be charged with this Duty.

Winnington Sollicitor General conceived that all Fire-Hearths are liable within the Body of the Act, and there is nothing to exempt them but what is in the Exception; and that a Smiths Forge cannot be called a Blowing Hou≈øe within the intent of the Act, notwith≈øtanding the Iury have found that Smiths u≈øe Bellows to blow their Forges: For by Blowing Hou≈øes ≈øuch Hou≈øes are meant as are in Stafford≈øhire and Suffolk for the making of Iron, the≈øe were the Blowing-Hou≈øes intended by the Parliament to be excepted, and no other; for if Smiths Forges had b√©en meant thereby, tho≈øe would have been in≈øerted in the Provi≈øo as well as the other things therein mentioned.
Words are to be taken in a common Vnder≈øtanding; for if a Traveller ≈øhould enquire for a Blowing Hou≈øe, no Body would ≈øend him to a Smiths Forge.

By the Opinion of the whole Court,Curia. it was adjudged upon the fir≈øt Argument that Smiths Forges are liable to this Duty; and ≈øo the Sollicitor ≈øaid it had been lately adjudged in this Court by the Opinion of Twi≈øden, Wyld and Rainsford; and that my Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Hale was of the ≈øame Opinion; but Twi≈øden ≈øaid that neither the Chief Iu≈øtice or him≈øelf gave any Iudgment upon the Merits, but upon a Point in Pleading.

div.head: Stroud ver≈øus the Bi≈øhop of Bath and Wells, and Sir George Horner. In Communi Banco.
div.p: IN a Quare Impedit the Plaintiff alledges that Sir George Horner was ≈øei≈øed in Fe√© of the Mannor of Dowling, Traver≈øe ≈øhall not be upon a Traver≈øe, &c. Mod. Rep. 230. to which the Advow≈øon was appendant, and that being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed he pre≈øented one Harding, and then granted the next Avoidance to the Plaintiff.
That the Church became void by the death of the ≈øaid Harding, and that now it belonged to him to pre≈øent.
The Bi≈øhop pleads that he claimed nothing, but as Ordinary; and the Incumbent pleads that at the time of the bringing of this Writ the Church was full by the Collation of the Bi≈øhop upon a Lap≈øe.

The Plaintiff replies that Sir George Horner being ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the ≈øaid Mannor of Dowling, to which the Advow≈øon of the Church was appendant, did tali die & anno apud, &c. pre≈øent him as Clerk ab≈øque hoc that the Church was full by Collation.

The Defendant rejoyns prote≈øtando that the Church was full tali die; and for Plea ≈øaith that it was full upon the Collation of the Bi≈øhop, ab≈øque hoc that Sir George Horner did tali die & anno, &c. pre≈øent the Plaintiff as his Clerk, and ≈øo traver≈øeth the Inducement which the Plaintiff had made to his Traver≈øe; and to this the Plaintiff demurred.
And Serjeant George Strode took three Exceptions to this Rejoinder.Ex parte Quer.

1. That when the Defendant pleads a Matter in Barr, and the Plaintiff hath taken a Traver≈øe upon that, the Defendant ≈øhould then take I≈ø≈øue upon that Travers, and ≈øo have maintained
his Barr,Vaugh. 62. 1 Sand. 21, 22. from which he had departed here by traver≈øing another Matter.

In a Quare Impedit the Plaintiff declares that Sir Thomas Chichely granted an Advow≈øon to one Ea≈øt and another in Fe√©, to the V≈øe of the Wife of the Plaintiff for her Iointure, and that ≈øhe ought to pre≈øent.

The Defendant pleads that he is Par≈øon impar≈øonee ex prae≈øentatione Regis, for that Sir Thomas Chicheley died ≈øei≈øed as afore≈øaid of the Mannor and Advow≈øon held in Capite by Knights Service, which de≈øcended to his Son an Infant, and by Office found of the Tenure and de≈øcent the King was ≈øei≈øed, and pre≈øented him, ab≈øque hoc that Sir Thomas granted to Ea≈øt.

The Plaintiff replies, Non habetur tale Recordum de inqui≈øitione; and upon Demurrer it was held that this Traver≈øe of the Inqui≈øition was not good;Hob. 104. 1 In≈øt. 282. b. Vaugh. 62. for there ≈øhall not be a Traver≈øe upon a Traver≈øe but where the Traver≈øe in the Barr is material to the Title of the Plaintiff, and in ≈øuch Ca≈øe he is bound up to it, Cro Car. 104, 105.

Antea. Yelv. 122.2. In his Traver≈øe he hath made the Time parcel of the I≈ø≈øue, viz. ab≈øque hoc that tali die & anno prae≈øentavit, whereas it ≈øhould have been modo & forma only, and ≈øo is the Ca≈øe of Lane and Alexander, 2 Cro. 202. where the Defendant intituled him≈øelf by Copy of Court of Roll, 44 Eliz. The Plaintiff replies that a Copy was granted to him 1 Junii 43 Eliz. The Defendant maintained his Bar and traver≈øeth the Grant 1 Junii modo & forma; and upon a Demurrer it was ≈øaid that the Rejoynder was not good, becau≈øe the day and year of granting of the Copy was not material, if it was granted before the Defendant had his Copy; and ≈øo the Traver≈øe ought to have been ab≈øque hoc that the Queen granted modo & forma.

1 Sand. 14. 2 Sand. 295. Cro Car. 501.But it was adjudged that the day ought not to be made parcel of the I≈ø≈øue, and the traver≈øing of it when it ought not ≈øo to be, makes it Sub≈øtance and not Form, ≈øo as to be aided by the Statute of 27 Eliz.

3. As the Defendant hath joyned they can never come to an I≈ø≈øue, for he concludes his Traver≈øe Et hoc paratus e≈øt verificare, unde petit Judicium, whereas he ≈øhould have concluded to the Country.

Ex parte Def. Barton Serjeant; admitting the Pleadings are not good, yet if the Plaintiffs Count is ≈øo likewi≈øe, he cannot have Iudgment; and that it was ≈øo, he ≈øaid appears in that the Plaintiff had not ≈øet forth a ≈øufficient Title; for he hath alledged that Sir George Horner was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, and pre≈øented the Plaintiff, who was in≈øtituted
and inducted,Old Nat. Br. 25. 1 In≈øt. 249. but doth not ≈øay that the Pre≈øentation was tempore pacis, and therefore it ≈øhall be pre≈øumed mo≈øt ≈øtrongly again≈øt him≈øelf to be tempore belli, and a Pre≈øentation mu≈øt be laid tempore pacis, and ≈øo is the Writ of A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Darrein Pre≈øentment, F. N. B. 31.

The Court held that the Pleadings were not good, and that the Count was good; for 'tis true, if a Man count that he and his Ance≈øtors were ≈øei≈øed in Fee of an Advow≈øon, but declares of no Pre≈øentation made by him or them; or if he declare of a Pre≈øentation without an E≈øtate, in both Ca≈øes it is naught, and good Cau≈øe of Demurrer;Vaugh. 57. Hob. 101. but here the Count is both of an E≈øtate and a Pre≈øentation. And this difference was taken, if a Man gets a F√©e by Pre≈øentation, which is his Title, he mu≈øt alledge it to be tempore pacis; but if it be in pur≈øuance of a Right, as if an Advow≈øon be appendant to a Mannor, and he who hath Right to the Mannor, pre≈øents, ≈øuch Pre≈øentation is good in time of War; and ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Stevens ver≈øus Au≈øtin.
div.p: ADjudged, that if a Man hath Common for a certain number of Cattle belonging to a Yard Land, he need not ≈øay Levant upon the Yard Land; ≈øed aliter, if it were for a Common ≈øans number.

div.head: The Ma≈øter, Warden and Company of Ironmongers ver≈øus Naylor, and others, Defendants. In B. R.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs. The Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict;Jones 85. 1 Ventris 311. they find ≈øeveral Acts of Parliament, viz. 14 Car. 2. cap. 10.15 Car. 2. cap. 13. and another Act for the better direction of the collecting of the Duty ari≈øing by Hearth-Mony by Officers to be appointed by the King; and this was the Act of 16 Car. 2. cap. 3. which provides, That if the Party refu≈øes to pay the Duty by the ≈øpace of an hour, that then the Officers with the Con≈øtable may di≈øtrain.

They find that the Company was ≈øei≈øed in F√©e of five Me≈ø≈øuages in which were 35 Fire Hearths in the Month of April, 1673. And that the Company did never fini≈øh the≈øe Me≈ø≈øuages, and that from the time of the building they ≈øtood all void, and unoccupied by any Tenant or Tenants what≈øoever.

Then they find that the Collectors were lawfully authori≈øed, and that ≈øuch a day they demanded the Duty for the Fire-Hearths in each of the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuages, which they al≈øo demanded of the Company, and which they refu≈øed to pay, and thereupon they took the di≈øtre≈øs and kept it till the Company paid the ≈øaid Duty, and ≈øo make a general Conclu≈øion, &c.
The Que≈øtion was, whether the Owner of a new Hou≈øe uninhabited from the time of the building thereof ought to pay this Duty during all that time?
Mr. Pollexfen and Mr. Symp≈øon argued that they ≈øhall not be chargeable with this Duty; their general Rea≈øon was, becau≈øe no Duty ≈øhould ari≈øe to the King without ≈øome benefit to the Subject.

And as to that it was ≈øaid, that in this Ca≈øe both the Revenue of the Crown and the Property of the Subject are concerned, from which, as from a Root, all the≈øe Impo≈øitions ari≈øe to ≈øu≈øtain the publique Charge. And therefore
It hath been the way of Iudges in the Interpretations of Statutes, not only to con≈øider the benefit of the Crown, but to regard what is convenient for the Subject.
There are two Rea≈øons for Impo≈øitions.
1. Such as are Cu≈øtoms, viz. Tunnage and Poundage and private Tolls, which come in lieu of other things, and ≈øo are quid pro quo.
2. Sub≈øidies or Grants from the People, which naturally ari≈øe in ≈øome proportion from a benefit to the Subject.

And under the la≈øt of the≈øe Rea≈øons falls the pre≈øent Duty given by the Act of 14 Car. only to proportion the Revenue to the publique Charge of the Crown; and therefore 'tis not to be thought that the Parliament ever intended a Duty to the King where the Subject had no benefit, for ex nihilo nihil fit; and how can it be thought that a Duty ≈øhould be paid before the Subject hath any Rent, which is the Mother of the Duty; for if a Man expends 1000 l. in building, which is all he is worth, and the Hou≈øes ≈øhould happen not to be let, how can he then rai≈øe ≈øuch a Sum as mu≈øt be paid to the King? And 'tis an Objection of no weight to ≈øay, if this Duty mu≈øt not be paid till the Hou≈øes are let, then the Revenue of the King depends upon a Contingency; becau≈øe all Duties which come to the Crown do depend upon ≈øuch.
The next thing to be con≈øidered is the Act it ≈øelf, and as to that,

1. It mu≈øt be taken as an Act which gives a new Duty to the Crown, and thereupon ≈øuch Con≈øtruction ought to be made that the Subjects E≈øtate be not charged further than the Words will bear; and for that rea≈øon it is to be taken in an ordinary ≈øen≈øe, and not to be ≈øtrained, though it had been in the Ca≈øe of an old Duty; and for that the7 Co. 21. Lord Ander≈øon's Ca≈øe is a good Authority, viz. The Statute of 33 H. 8. cap. 30. makes all Mannors (which de≈øcend to any Heir who≈øe Ance≈øtor was indebted to the King by Judgment, Recogni≈øance, Obligation or other Specialty) chargeable for payment of the Debt. Tenant in Tail is bound in a Recognizance to S. who is attainted; then Tenant in Tail dies and his I≈ø≈øue aliens bona fide, the King cannot extend the Lands ≈øo ≈øold, becau≈øe the Act ≈øhall not be con≈øtrued to mean all Recognizances for the Kings Debts though the Words are general enough; and though 'tis not ≈øaid which way the Debts ≈øhall come to the King, either by Forfeiture, Attainder, &c. yet they ≈øhall be taken in an ordinary ≈øen≈øe, viz. ≈øuch debts as were due to the King originally; for which rea≈øon it has been always held where an Act gives any thing to the King and lays a Charge upon the Subject, in ≈øuch Ca≈øe it ought to have a moderate con≈øtruction.

And that this Duty is a Gift cannot be denied, for 'tis called ≈øo in the very Act, therefore ≈øuch ought the Con≈øtruction to be, and the rather becau≈øe it is more for the Kings Honour it ≈øhould be ≈øo; and both in this Ca≈øe as well as in Con≈øtructions of his Grants the Law hath more regard for his Honour than for his Profit.

2. This being ≈øo called, a Duty or Tax by the very Words of the Act, doth in the natural ≈øen≈øe import a proportion out of that in which the Subject hath a benefit; and it will be ≈øcarce found that there hath been a general Tax given to the King where the Subject has rather received a lo≈øs than any profit out of the thing taxed, becau≈øe it would be very hard to pay where a Man cannot receive.

In the Ca≈øe of Tunnage and Poundage provi≈øion is made that the Party ≈øhall have Allowance if the Goods be lo≈øt by Pyracy, which was mentioned to ≈øhew how unlikely it was that the Parliament ≈øhould intend a Duty where the Subject had a lo≈øs.

Ever ≈øince the making the Statute of 43 Eliz. cap. 2. Hou≈øes that lay void and untenanted have neither paid to Church or Poor, which al≈øo ≈øhews how the V≈øage hath be√©n in Ca≈øes almo≈øt of the like nature.
The next thing con≈øidered were the Clau≈øes in this Act of 14 Car. 2. cap. 10.
1. The fir≈øt Clau≈øe gives a Duty, viz. That every Chimny and Stove ≈øhall pay 2 s.

2. The next Clau≈øe is to bring this Duty into a way of Charge, viz. That every Owner or Occupier ≈øhall give unto the Con≈øtable an accompt of the number of Hearths in Writing, and the Con≈øtables to tran≈ømit ≈øuch Accompts to the Se≈ø≈øions, there to be enrolled by the Clerk of the Peace, and a Duplicate to be ≈øent into the Exchequer.

From which it is to be ob≈øerved that where mention is made of bringing this Duty into a Charge, both Owners and Occupiers are named, but the Owner is not named in any place where the payment of the Duty is mentioned, but the Occupier only; ≈øo that from the very intent and rea≈øon of the Act he cannot be chargeable.

The Accompt thus tran≈ømitted is to charge the Inheritance, and therefore it concerns the Owner to look after the Charge; but for empty Hou≈øes he cannot be charged, becau≈øe the Act takes no notice of them in the Clau≈øe of Payment, but are purpo≈øely omitted that being laid on the Occupier, and this appears by the Provi≈øo which is ≈øtrongly penned for the Subject.

Viz. Provided that the Payments and Duties hereby charged ≈øhall be charged only upon the Occupier for the time being, &c. and not on the Land-Lord who lett and demi≈øed the ≈øame; ≈øo that by the Body of the Act every Hou≈øe is charged, which being general might have given ≈øome colour to charge the Owner, but by the Provi≈øo the Payment is re≈øtrained to the Occupier, and if there be no ≈øuch, there ≈øhall be no Payment.

It was ≈øaid that it cannot be in≈øi≈øted upon that an Owner is an Occupier, becau≈øe the legal acceptance of the Word Occupation doth only intend an actual Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and not a Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in Law, and ≈øuch is the meaning of the Statute by charging the Occupier for the time being.

If therefore the Provi≈øo extends to Ca≈øes where Tenants run away and pay no Rent, (as it certainly doth) becau≈øe there is no Occupier then in being; what difference can there be between that and this Ca≈øe where the Land-Lord in both hath no Rent? for if he ≈øhall not pay where he cannot receive Rent, why ≈øhould he pay where he hath none to receive?

And that this was the meaning of the Parliament may further appear by a Clau≈øe in the Act of 16 Car. 2. cap. 3. made for collecting this Duty by Officers appointed by the King, which doth not inlarge the former Statutes, and by which 'tis Enacted, That if any Occupier ≈øhall leave his Hou≈øe before any of the half yearly Fea≈øts, whereon this Duty is appointed to be paid,
that the next Occupier ≈øhall be chargeable with the ≈øame for the ≈øaid half year.

Which Clau≈øe had been altogether vain and of no u≈øe, if empty Hou≈øes had been chargeable with this Duty; for to what purpo≈øe was it to charge a ≈øucceeding Occupier when the Hou≈øe it ≈øelf, though untenanted, was chargeable before?

In this Act al≈øo, which ≈øupplies the defects of the former, this Duty is made payable unto the Officer upon demand at the Hou≈øe where the ≈øame ≈øhall ari≈øe and grow due, and that in ca≈øe of refu≈øal by the ≈øpace of an hour the Officer may di≈øtrein, which ≈øhews a Demand mu≈øt be where there may be a Refu≈øal, and no Refu≈øal can be where there is no Occupier.

There is al≈øo another Clau≈øe which mentions both Owner and Occupier in this Act, and which ≈øaith, That no Proprietor, Owner or Occupier, ≈øhall be mole≈øted or charged, unle≈øs within two years after the Duty accrewed; ≈øo that where-ever a charge is laid, or an ea≈øe is given to the Subject, the Word Occupier and ≈øometimes both Occupier and Owner promi≈øcuo≈ølly are u≈øed; but where a payment is to be made, the Owner is never mentioned, and if ≈øo, nothing ≈øhall be intended within either of the Statutes, to enlarge this Duty upon the Subject, beyond the Words and plain meaning thereof.

2. There is another Point in this Ca≈øe which concerns the King and all the People of England, that is, whether the Defendant here can be charged with a Di≈øtre≈øs (≈øuppo≈øing this Duty is to be paid to the King) before any account of the≈øe Hearths is tran≈ømitted into the Exchequer, which fir≈øt ought to be done; or otherwi≈øe the con≈øequence will be, that the Officer may demand and take as much as he will at his plea≈øure, and the King may be likewi≈øe prejudiced in his Revenue; for as the Collector may have from the Subject more than he ought, and more than he is empowered to take by the Law, ≈øo he may pay the King le≈øs.

The Act directs, That an Account ≈øhall be taken by the Officers, and examined by the Con≈øtables; then to be tran≈ømitted to the Se≈ø≈øions, there to be enrolled, and from thence ≈øent into the Exchequer; now what occa≈øion was there of all this Solempnity, if that the King was entituled to a Di≈øtre≈øs upon a bare refu≈øal?

This being a Rent Charge upon a Mans Inheritance, the King ≈øhall not be entituled to it but by matter of Record; for he cannot take or part with any thing, neither can he have any E≈øtate or Profit rendered him out of another Mans E≈øtate, but by matter of Record; ≈øo that it ≈øeems by the Act that this accompt is nece≈ø≈øary to be tran≈ømitted into the Exchequer; and
that the King is not entituled to a Di≈øtre≈øs for this Duty until that be actually done, which is not only matter of Information to the Crown, but in ≈øome mea≈øure intitles him to it, becau≈øe there is a Penalty of five pounds laid upon the Officer, who ≈øhall neglect to bring in ≈øuch accompt, which ≈øhews that the Subject ought not to be charged before; for which rea≈øons Iudgment was prayed for the Plaintiff.

Ex parte Def.But on the other ≈øide it was argued by Mr. Holt and the Attorny General, that empty Hou≈øes ≈øhould pay this Duty: For the Attorny General ≈øaid, that the Words in the Act were ≈øo expre≈øs, that he was of Opinion that the very reading of them would clear the Point in que≈øtion.
In their Arguments two things were con≈øidered upon the Statute of 14 Car. 2.
1. Fir≈øt the general Clau≈øe which gives the Duty in the Body of the Act.
2. The di≈øcharge in the Provi≈øo.

And if this be in the Body of the Act, and not excepted in the Provi≈øo, then the Duty is to be paid; and as to that it was ≈øaid, that this Duty was given in general Words, by which it appears, that there was a de≈øign and intent to charge empty Hou≈øes, for every dwelling Hou≈øe, Edifice, or Hou≈øe what≈øoever is to pay this Duty; and that if every Hou≈øe, why not an empty Hou≈øe?

'Tis true, a Dwelling Hou≈øe is not a Hou≈øe wherein there hath not been an Inhabitant, but wherein ≈øome body doth actually live; and if a Man furni≈øhes a Hou≈øe very well, if 'tis not inhabited, it is notwith≈øtanding an empty Hou≈øe, and ≈øuch a Hou≈øe as to ≈øome purpo≈øes in the Law is not a dwelling Hou≈øe; for 'tis not a Man≈øion Hou≈øe, ≈øo as to make it Burglary for the breaking of it open.

By the ≈øecond Clau≈øe, Every Owner or Occupier is to ≈øub≈øcribe the Account to be ≈øent into the Exchequer, by which it appears that tho≈øe Words Owner and Occupier are not there u≈øed in a different ≈øen≈øe, for if the Occupier were only lyable, the Owner need not look after the ≈øigning the accompt of every Hearth.

The third Clau≈øe takes notice, That if it ≈øhould happen there be no Occupier, then the Officer may go into the empty Hou≈øe to examine if the account given him be true; now if an account is to be taken of ≈øuch Hou≈øes as are charged by this Act, and an account is directed to be taken of empty Hou≈øes, then ≈øuch empty Hou≈øes mu≈øt be charged; and this ≈øeemed to them to be
the intent and meaning of the Parliament, for there being a Return to be made of empty Hou≈øes, if ≈øuch had not been intended to be charged, they would have directed a Return al≈øo to have been made of the non-inhabitancy.

And therefore they thought that ≈øomething more than an Occupier was here meant, for otherwi≈øe the Word Owner had not been put in; the meaning of which mu≈øt be that dwelling Hou≈øes come within the charge of Occupiers, and empty Hou≈øes within the charge of the Owners.

Then as to the Provi≈øo, That the Duty hereby ari≈øing ≈øhall be charged only upon the Occupiers and Dwellers of ≈øuch Hou≈øes, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators, that can in no ≈øort extend to di≈øcharge an empty Hou≈øe, becau≈øe 'tis not the ≈øubject matter of the Provi≈øo; for the de≈øign and purpo≈øe of it was not to di≈øcharge the Duty, but to transfer the charge upon the Tenant where the Hou≈øe was inhabited; for if a contrary con≈øtruction ≈øhould be made, then no Duty ≈øhould be paid at all by the Owner him≈øelf if he ≈øhould live in his own Hou≈øe.
In the Ca≈øe of a Modus decimandi 'tis payable by the Occupier and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of the Hou≈øe, and the Landlord is never charged but where there is no Occupier.

As to the Objection, That 'tis hard to pay a Duty where a Man has no Profit; it was an≈øwered, That the Act took care that Men ≈øhould not ≈øtop up their Chimnies when once made, and that this Duty was paid for many Chimnies which were never u≈øed, and what Profit can a Man have of a Chimny he never u≈øeth? If there had been an Act that ≈øo much ≈øhould be paid for every Window, 'tis all one whether it had been for profit or plea≈øure, or whether the Window had been u≈øed or not; and there is as much rea≈øon that a Man ≈øhould pay for Hou≈øes never Inhabited, as for ≈øuch as have been Inhabited and are afterwards without Tenants.

This Act ought therefore to receive a favourable Con≈øtruction; the Preamble whereof mentions that it was for the encrea≈øing of the Kings Revenue, which is pro bono publico, and which is for the Peace and Pro≈øperity of the Nation, and the protection of every ≈øingle per≈øon therein; and though a particular Inconvenience may follow, the Party ought to ≈øubmit. When a Man builds a Hou≈øe, he propo≈øes a Profit, and 'tis not fit the Kings Duty ≈øhould be contingent and depend till he has provided him≈øelf of a Tenant.

Object. As to the other Objection that was much relied on, viz. where the Act ≈øpeaks of an Accompt to be given, it mentions both Owner and Occupier; but where it directs the Payment of
the Duty the Occupier only is named, by which it was inferred that he alone was chargeable.

An≈øw. In 16 Car. 2. cap. 3. Owner, Proprietor and Occupier are u≈øed promi≈øcuou≈øly, wherein it is provided that they ≈øhall not be charged unle≈øs within two years after the Duty accrued; now if the Owner was not chargeable, why is he mentioned there?

As to the ≈øecond Point, they conceived that the Duty being payeable to the King, he had a remedy by di≈øtre≈øs before the Accompt was certified into the Exchequer; for the Return was to inform the King what advantage he maketh of his Revenue, and no Proce≈øs i≈ø≈øued upon it; be≈øides the Act ve≈øts the Duty in him from Lady-day 1662. And by rea≈øon of that he may di≈øtrain. The King hath no benefit by returning of the Account, that being only intended to prevent his being cheated, ≈øo that 'tis not to entitle but to inform him; 'tis only to return a ju≈øt and true account; not but that it may be levied, and the King entitled before; and 'tis no inconvenience to the Subject, if there be no ≈øuch Account returned, for if the Officer di≈øtrain for more Hearths than in truth there are, the Subject has a proper remedy again≈øt him.

The King ≈øuffers when Returns are not made of ≈øuch Duties as he ought to have for the ≈øupport of his Dignity; and becau≈øe he is lyable to be defrauded in the managing of his Duty, is it rea≈øonable that he ≈øhould lo≈øe all?

As to what was ≈øaid of the Kings taking by matter of Record; 'tis true, if he dive≈øt an Inheritance, as in ca≈øe of Attainder, it mu≈øt be by Record; but here the very Duty is given to him by the Act it ≈øelf, which makes it a different Ca≈øe.

If the King ≈øhould be ≈øei≈øed in Fee of a great Wa≈øt, which happens to be improved by his Tenants, and thereby Tythes become due, it may be as well ≈øaid, that he ≈øhall have no Tythes without Record, as to ≈øay he ≈øhall have no Hearth-Mony for Hou≈øes newly erected, whereby his Revenue is increa≈øed. For which Rea≈øons Iudgment was prayed for the Defendant, and upon the ≈øecond Argument Iudgment was given accordingly for him,Curia. That empty Hou≈øes are ≈øubject and lyable to this Duty.

div.head: A≈øtry ver≈øus Ballard.
div.p: IN an Action of Trover and Conver≈øion for the taking of Coals, upon Not-Guilty pleaded,Grants mu≈øt be taken according to common intendment. Jones 71. the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict. The Ca≈øe was thus.

Viz. That one J. R. was ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the Manor of We≈øterly, and being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed did demi≈øe all the Me≈øuages, Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments that he had in the ≈øaid Manor, for a Term of years to N. R. in which demi≈øe there was a recital of a Grant of the ≈øaid Mannor, Me≈øuages, Lands, Tenements, Commons, and Mines, but in the Lea≈øe it ≈øelf to R. the Word Mines was left out. Afterwards the Rever≈øion was ≈øold to the Plaintiff A≈øtry, and his Heirs by Deed enrolled; and at the time of this demi≈øe there were certain Mines of Coals open, and others which were not then open; and the Coals for which this Action of Trover was brought, were digged by the Le≈ø≈øee in tho≈øe Mines which were not open at the time of the Lea≈øe; and whether he had power ≈øo to do, was the Que≈øtion.

It was ≈øaid, That when a Man is ≈øei≈øed of Lands wherein there are Mines open, and others not open; and a Lea≈øe is made of the≈øe Lands in which the Mines are mentioned.Antea. 'Tis no new Doctrine to ≈øay, that the clo≈øe Mines ≈øhall not pa≈øs; Mens Grants mu≈øt be taken according to u≈øual and common intendment, and when Words may be ≈øatisfied, they ≈øhall not be ≈øtrained farther than they are generally u≈øed, for no violent Con≈øtruction ≈øhall be made to prejudice a Mans Inheritance, contrary to the plain meaning of the Words.

A Mine is not properly ≈øo called 'till it is opened, 'tis but a Vein of Coals before; and this was the Opinion of my Lord Coke in point, in his fir≈øt In≈øt. 54. b. Where he tells us,5 Co. 12. Sanders Ca≈øe Roll. Abr. 2 part 816. that if a Man demi≈øes Lands and Mines, ≈øome being opened and others not, the Le≈ø≈øee may u≈øe the Mines opened, but hath no power to dig the unopened Mines, and of this Opinion was the whole Court; and Iu≈øtice Twi≈øden ≈øaid, That he knew no rea≈øon why my Lord Coke's ≈øingle Opinion ≈øhould not be as good an Authority as Fitzherbert in his Nat. Br. or the Doctor and Student.

div.head: Ip≈øley ver≈øus Turk.
div.p:
IN a Writ of Error upon a Iudgment in an Inferiour Court,What is admitted in pleading ≈øhall not be a≈ø≈øigned for Error. Jones 81. the Error a≈ø≈øigned was, That the Mayor, who was Iudge of the Court, did not receive the Sacrament at any Pari≈øh
Church, nor file any Certificate, ≈øo that he was not Mayor; and Iudgment being given again≈øt the Defendant before him, it was therefore Coram non Judice, like the Ca≈øe of Hatch and Nichols Roll. Abr. 1 part tit. Error 761. Where, upon a Writ of Error brought upon a Iudgment in an Inferiour Court, the Error a≈ø≈øigned was, that the Stile of the Court was Curia tentÃÑ coram J. S. Sene≈øchallo, who was not Steward, and that was held to be an Error in fact.

But on the other ≈øide it was in≈øi≈øted that this was not Error, becau≈øe the Acts of the Mayor ≈øhould not be void as to Strangers. The Statute of 25 Car. 2. cap. 2. for preventing of dangers which may happen from Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, di≈øables the Party who is not qualified according to the Act to hold an Office, and if he execute the ≈øame, afterwards upon complaint made, and Conviction he ≈øhall forfeit 500 l. ≈øo that as to him≈øelf, whatever he doth in his Office is void; but it was never the intent of the Act to work a Mi≈øchief or Wrong to Strangers, for the Law favours what is done by one in reputed authority; as if a Bi≈øhop be created, who upon a Pre≈øentation made admits a Par≈øon to a Benefice or collates by Lap≈øe, the former Bi≈øhop not being deprived, or removed, ≈øuch acts are good and not to be avoided, Cro. Eliz 699.

Cro Car. 97. 2 Cro. 260.But admitting it to be an Error, it cannot now be a≈ø≈øigned for ≈øuch, becau≈øe the Parties in Pleading have allowed the proceedings to be good upon Record, and there is Iudgment again≈øt the Defendant, but if he had been taken upon that Iudgment, he might have brought an Action of fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, 2 Cro. 359. Cro. Eliz. 320.

Wild Iu≈øtice, You ≈øhall not a≈ø≈øign that for Error which you might have pleaded, e≈øpecially having admitted it by pleading; and one Mu≈øgrave's Ca≈øe was cited, which was, that there is an Act of Parliament which lays a Tax upon all Law proceedings, and makes them void, if the Kings Duty be not paid, and it was adjudged, That if the Duty was not paid, but admitted in pleading, you ≈øhall not afterwards alledge what before was admitted, viz. That the Duty was not paid.

Vpon a Writ of Error in Parliament it cannot be a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that the Chief Iu≈øtice of the Kings-Bench, had not taken this Oath; the ≈øame might be al≈øo of a Writ of Error in the Exchequer Chamber, for an Error in Fact cannot be there a≈ø≈øigned;Sid. 253. but at the la≈øt the Iudgment was Rever≈øed: See the Rea≈øons thereof by the Chief Iu≈øtice Jones in his Reports, folio 81.

div.head: Higgin≈øon ver≈øus Martin, in C. B.
div.p: IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs and fal≈øe Impri≈øonment,If Cau≈øe of Action doth not ari≈øe within the Juri≈ødiction, tho' Judgment is given below, an Action will lie here. the Defendant ju≈øtifies by Proce≈øs i≈ø≈øuing out of the Court of Warwick, upon a Iudgment obtained there, and ≈øets forth, that there was a Plaint there entered in placito tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis, to which the Defendant appeared, ≈øuper quo taliter proce≈ø≈øum fuit, that Iudgment was given again≈øt him, upon which he was taken and Impri≈øoned.
The Plaintiff replies, That the Cau≈øe of Action did not ari≈øe within the Iuri≈ødiction of that Court.

The Defendant rejoyns, that the Plaintiff is now e≈øtopped to ≈øay ≈øo, for that the Declaration in the Inferiour Court again≈øt the now Plaintiff, did alledge the cau≈øe of Action to be infra juri≈ødictionem of the Court, to which he pleaded, and Iudgment was given again≈øt him: The Plaintiff demurrs.
And Newdigate Serjeant took Exceptions to the Plea.
1. Ex parte Quer. 'Tis ≈øaid a Plaint was entered in placito tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis but 'tis not ≈øaid what kind of Tre≈øpa≈øs it was, whether a clau≈øum fregit or other Tre≈øpa≈øs.

2. 'Tis ≈øaid that the Defendant appeared, ≈øuper quo taliter proce≈ø≈øum fuit, that Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff,Antea. and no mention was made of any Declaration; and the pleading taliter proce≈ø≈øum e≈øt in an Inferiour Court, is not good.

3. The Iu≈øtification is ill, becau≈øe the Inferiour Court had no Iuri≈ødiction, and ≈øo the Proceedings are coram non Judice, for the Plaintiff in his Replication ≈øaith, That the Tre≈øpa≈øs for which the Recovery was had in the Court of Warwick, Moor 422. Latch 180. Cro. Jac. 184. was done at a place out of the Iuri≈ødiction of the Court, which the Defendant hath admitted, by relying on his Plea by way of E≈øtoppel.
4. It did not appear by what Authority the Court at Warwick was held whether by Grant or Pre≈øcription.

The≈øe Exceptions were an≈øwered by Serjeant Hopkins, Ex parte Def. and fir≈øt he ≈øaid, That the Plaintiff there ≈øets forth that levavit quandam querelam in placito tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis, which was well enough.

Secondly, taliter proce≈ø≈øium fuit is the ≈øhorter and better way of Pleading, and therefore in a Scire Facias nothing is recited but the Iudgment; 'tis true, in a Writ of Error the whole Record mu≈øt be ≈øet out, but that is not nece≈ø≈øary here.

Thirdly, 'tis too late now to que≈øtion the Iuri≈ødiction of the Inferiour Court, after the Party hath admitted it below; he ought fir≈øt to have pleaded to the Iuri≈ødiction, but now is E≈øtopped by his own admittance there; and ≈øince Iudgment is given upon it, 'tis not now to be que≈øtioned; but however, this being in the Ca≈øe of an Officer, if it was out of the Iuri≈ødiction he is bound to execute the Proce≈øs of the Court, and ≈øo this is a good excu≈øe for him, Dyer 61. 10 Co. 77.

But let the Pleadings be good or bad, if the Declaration here be ill, the Plaintiff cannot have Iudgment; and that it was ≈øo, he ≈øaid that the Writ alledged an Impri≈øonment generally, but the Count an Impri≈øonment donec he paid 5 l. 10 s. which is variant, and the Prothonotaries ≈øaid, that the Writ u≈øed always to mention donec, &c.

Curia.But the Court were all of Opinion, that the Count was well enough, for there was no matter therein contained which was not in the Writ; the Impri≈øonment was the Gi≈øt of the Action, and the donec, &c. might have been given in Evidence, becau≈øe 'tis only an aggravation and a con≈øequence of the Impri≈øonment, ≈øo that the Count is not larger, but more particular than the Writ: And as to the two fir≈øt Exceptions, the Court was al≈øo of Opinion, that there was no difficulty in them, or in the la≈øt Exception, but thought the Plea was well enough as to tho≈øe: And they al≈øo agreed that the Officer in this Ca≈øe was to be di≈øcharged, for though the Proce≈øs be erronious, yet he is to obey and not to examine, 2 Cro. 3. Weaver ver≈øus Clifford: The great doubt in this Ca≈øe was upon the third Exception as to the point of Iuri≈ødiction,Sid. 151. Latch 181. and whether the other Defendant, who was the Plaintiff below, ≈øhould be likewi≈øe di≈øcharged, was the Que≈øtion.

And as to that, the Chief Iu≈øtice, and Wyndham Iu≈øtice were of Opinion, That this was no good ju≈øtification as to the Plaintiff below; for if the cau≈øe of Action did ari≈øe without the Iuri≈ødiction, of which he is bound to take notice, the proceedings quoad him, are all coram non Judice, and he cannot ju≈øtifie the ≈øerving of any Proce≈øs; ≈øo that if the Tre≈øpa≈øs was done out of the Iuri≈ødiction of the Court, the Defendant below may bring an Action again≈øt the Plaintiff, and is not concluded here by the proceedings there, but may alledge the cau≈øe of Action to ari≈øe out of the Iuri≈ødiction; and as to his being E≈øtopped by admitting of the Iuri≈ødiction below, that cannot be, becau≈øe an admittance cannot give the Court a Iuri≈ødiction where it had none originally, and ≈øo he ≈øaid it was re≈øolved in one Squib's Ca≈øe, in a ≈øpecial Verdict.

He who ≈øues in an Inferior Court is bound at his peril to take notice of the Bounds and Limits of that Iurisdiction; and if the Party after a Verdict below prays a Prohibition, and alledges that the Court had no Iurisdiction, a Prohibition ≈øhall be granted; and 'tis no E≈øtoppel that he did not take advantage of it before, 1 Roll. Abr. 545.

But Iu≈øtice Atkins and Scroggs were of another Opinion, they agreed that if an Action be brought in an Inferior Court, if it be not ≈øaid to be infra Jurisdictionem Curiae they would never pre≈øume it to be ≈øo, but rather to be without, if not alledged to be within the Iurisdiction, and here in the Plea 'tis not ≈øhewn at all; ≈øo that as the Ca≈øe ≈øtands upon the Plea the Proce√©dings are coram non Judice, and there is no legal Authority to warrant them, and by con≈øequence the Officer is no more to be excu≈øed than the Party, becau≈øe al≈øo 'tis in the Ca≈øe of a particular Iurisdiction: And ≈øo it hath b√©en adjudged upon an E≈øcape brought again≈øt an Officer of an Inferior Court, wherein the Plaintiff declared that he had brought an Action upon a Bond again≈øt S. in the Court of King≈øton, and that he had Iudgment and Execution, and the Defendant ≈øuffered him to e≈øcape; this Declaration did not charge the Defendan, becau≈øe the Bond was not alledged to be made infra Juri≈ødictionem Curiae; for though ≈øuch an Action is tran≈øitory in its nature, yet the Proceedings in an inferior Court upon it are coram non Judice, if it doth not appear to be infra Juri≈ødictionem, 1 Roll. Abr. 809. though in the Ca≈øe of a general Iurisdiction it might be otherwi≈øe.

But here the Rejoynder doth help the Plea; for the Plaintiff having replied that the Tre≈øpa≈øs was committed out of the Iurisdiction, and the Defendant having rejoyned that he had alledged in his Declaration below that the Tre≈øpa≈øs was done within the Iurisdiction, 'tis now all one Plea, and the Plaintiff hath confe≈ø≈øed it by his Demurrer; ≈øo that in regard it was alledged below and admitted there, 'tis a good Plea both for Officer and Party, and the Plaintiff cannot now take advantage of it, but is concluded by his former admittance, and it ≈øhall not be enquired now whether true or fal≈øe.
And as to the taliter proce≈ø≈øum fuit they all held it well enough, and that there was no nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øetting out all the Proceedings here as in a Writ of Error.
And as to the la≈øt Exception 'tis ≈øaid that the Burrough of Warwick is antiquus Burgus, and that the Court is held there ≈øecundum con≈øuetudinem, which is well enough.

div.head: Jones's Ca≈øe.
div.p: Common Pleas cannot grant Habeas Corpus in Criminal Ca≈øes.IT was moved for a Habeas Corpus for one Jones, who was committed to New Pri≈øon by Warrant from a Iu≈øtice of Peace for refu≈øing to di≈øcover who intru≈øted him with the keeping of the Keys of a Conventicle, and for that he had been in≈øtrumental to the E≈øcape of the Preacher; he was asked by the Iu≈øtice to give Security for his Good Behaviour, which he al≈øo refu≈øed, and thereupon was committed.

The Chief Iu≈øtice doubted that a Habeas Corpus could not be granted in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe it was in a criminal Cau≈øe of which the Court of Common Pleas hath no Iurisdiction, and that ≈øeemed to be the Opinion of my Lord Coke, Vaugh. 157. 2 In≈øt. 53. 2 In≈øt. 55. where he ≈øaith it lies for any Officer or priviledged Per≈øon of the Court.

There are three ≈øorts of Habeas Corpus in this Court; one is ad re≈øpondendum, Mod. Rep. 235. which is for the Plaintiff, who is a Suitor here again≈øt any Man in Pri≈øon, who is to be brought thereupon to the Barr and remanded if he cannot give Sureties.

There is another Habeas Corpus for the Defendant ad faciend' & recipiend'; as to this the ≈øame Iurisdiction is here as in the Court of Kings Bench; if a per≈øon be near the Town by the cour≈øe of the Court he may be brought hither to be charged and then the Habeas Corpus is returnable immediate; but if he be remote, it mu≈øt then be returnable in the Court at a certain day; the≈øe are the Habeas Corpus's which concern the Iurisdiction of this Court, and are incident thereunto.

There is another which concerns Priviledge, when the Party comes and ≈øubjects him≈øelf to the Court to be either bailed or di≈øcharged, as the Crime is for which he ≈øtands charged; and if he be priviledged, this Court may examine the Ca≈øe and do him right; if a private man be committed for a criminal Cau≈øe we can examine the Matter and ≈øend him back again. Before King James's Reign there was no Habeas Corpus but recited a Priviledge, as in the Ca≈øe of Priviledge for an Attorny; ≈øo that if this Court cannot remedy what the Party complains, 'tis in vain for the Subject to be put to the trouble when he mu≈øt be ≈øent back again; neither can there be any failure of Iu≈øtice, becau≈øe he may apply him≈øelf to a proper Court; and of the ≈øame Opinion were Wyndham and Scroggs.
But Iu≈øtice Atkins was of another Opinion, for he could ≈øee no Rea≈øon why there ≈øhould not be a Right to come to this Court as well as to the Kings Bench.
And that Vaughan, Wild and Archer Iu≈øtices, were of Opinion that this Court may grant a Habeas Corpus in other Ca≈øes be≈øides tho≈øe of Priviledge.

Afterwards the Pri≈øoner was brought to the Court upon this Habeas Corpus, but was remanded, becau≈øe this Court would not take Sureties for his Good Behavior: The Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid that when he was not on the Bench he would take Sureties as a Iu≈øtice of Peace: And Monday, late Secondary informed him that Iu≈øtice Wild when he ≈øate in this Court did once take ≈øuch Sureties as a Iu≈øtice of Peace.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: IT was the Opinion of the Chief Iu≈øtice North, In Replevin both are Actors. that in a Replevin both Parties are Actors; for the one ≈øues for Damages, and the other to have the Cattle, and there the place is material; for if the Plaintiff alledges the taking at A. and they were taken at B. the Defendant may plead Non cepit modo & forma, but then he can have no Return; for if he would have a Retorn' Habend' he mu≈øt deny the taking where the Plaintiff hath laid it, and alledge another place in his Avowry.

div.head: Sir Osborn Rands ver≈øus Tripp.
div.p: THE Plaintiff was a Tobacconi≈øt and lived near Guild-Hall, London; he married the Daughter of the Defendant,New Trial granted. who was an Alderman in Hull, and had 400 l. Portion with her; after the Marriage the Defendant ≈øpoke merrily before thr√©e Witne≈ø≈øes, That if his Son-in-Law would procure him≈øelf to be Knighted, ≈øo that his Daughter might be a Lady, he would then give him 2000 l. more, and would pay 1000 l. part thereof pre≈øently upon ≈øuch Knighthood, and the other 1000 l. within a year after: (it being intended when the Plaintiff ≈øhould by his Trade get an E≈øtate ≈øufficient to qualifie him for the Dignity of a Knight.)

The Son-in-Law without acquainting the Defendant did about nine Months afterwards procure him≈øelf to be Knighted, and brought an A≈ø≈øump≈øit for the 2000 l. which was tried before the
Chief Iu≈øtice North at Guild-Hall, and the Iury gave 1500 l. Damages.

And now Serjeant Maynard moved for a new Tryal upon the Affidavit of the Defendant that he had found out material Witne≈ø≈øes ≈øince the Trial, and that ≈øuch Witne≈ø≈øes, as he had ready at the Trial, could not get into Court; becau≈øe of the great Tumult and Di≈øorder there with a Multitude of People, by rea≈øon whereof his Council could not be heard from the noi≈øe, and when they offered to ≈øpeak were as often hi≈ø≈øed.

The Chief Iu≈øtice thought it was a hard Verdict, for he was not clearly ≈øatisfied that the Agreement was good, it being only for Words which were ≈øpoken by the Old Man when he had but a weak Memory; and thereupon a new Tryal was granted, becau≈øe the Chief Iu≈øtice thought it was fit ≈øo to be.

div.head: Basket ver≈øus Basket.
div.p: Disjunctive Condition, one part is di≈øcharged by the Obligee, the other part ≈øhall not be performed by the Obligor. Mod. Rep. 264.DEBT upon a Bond with a Condition to make an A≈ø≈øurance of an Annuity of 20 l. per annum to the Plaintiff within ≈øix Months after the death of M. B. and if he refu≈øe when reque≈øted by the Plaintiff, then to pay 300 l. and if he fail in payment thereof the Bond to be forfeited.
The Defendant pleads that all the ≈øix Months he was a Pri≈øoner at Morocco in Barbary, and that after his Return he reque≈øted the Defendant; and to this Replication the Defendant demurred.
And Serjeant George Strode maintained the Demurrer.

The Que≈øtion was, whether the Plaintiff by neglecting to tender a Grant of the Annuity to the Defendant hath not di≈øpen≈øed with the whole Condition; and he held that it was di≈øpen≈øed withal, and that no Reque≈øt being made the Bond could not be ≈øued at the Common Law, and therefore the Replication was ill.

'Tis not ≈øo much a disjunctive Condition to do one thing or another, but the la≈øt Clau≈øe is a Penalty to inforce the fir≈øt; for ≈øeeing the Annuity is to be but 20 l. per annum for a Life, and yet that 300 l. is to be paid in ca≈øe that be not granted, this proves it to be only a Penalty, becau≈øe Annuities at the highe≈øt value are but at eight years purcha≈øe, whereas this is fift√©en years purcha≈øe, ≈øo that the 300 l. could never be intended as a
Recompence for the Annuity; neither could the Defendant po≈ø≈øibly ≈øave the Condition, becau≈øe the ≈øame time is limited both for the Paymenr of the 300 l. and granting of the Annuity, viz. within ≈øix Months; and the Plaintiff hath to the utmo≈øt time to reque≈øt the executing the Grant,1 Sand. 287. and therefore the other cannot pay the Mony before.

But taking the Ca≈øe to be that this is a disjunctive Conditions; yet ≈øince Conditions are always made in favour of the Obligor, the power of Election even in ≈øuch Ca≈øes is left wholly in him; but according to ≈øuch Con≈øtructions, as would be made for the Plaintiff, the Election is gone from the Defendant,Wright and Bull, Po≈øtea. and left in the Oblig√©e; for if he do not reque≈øt the Annuity, then the 300 l. is to be paid, and this is directly again≈øt the Rules of disjunctive Conditions; and the Ca≈øe ofCor. Eliz. 396 539. 1 Roll. Abr. 447. Poph. 98. Goldsb. 142. Greeningham and Ewre is expre≈øs in Point, where the Condition of a Bond was, that if the Obligor delivered to the Plaintiff thr√©e Bonds by ≈øuch a day, or gave him ≈øuch a Relea≈øe of them, as the Plaintiffs Council ≈øhould advi≈øe, before the ≈øaid day, that then, &c.

The Defendant pleads nothing as to the delivery of the Bonds, but ≈øaith, that the Plaintiffs Council advi≈øed no Relea≈øe; and upon a Demurrer this was adjudged for the Defendant, becau≈øe in all Obligations with a Penalty the Election is always in the Obligor; and this being a disjunctive Condition each part is likewi≈øe in his Election; for if the Obligee ≈øhould not tender the Relea≈øe, the other is not bound to deliver the Bonds; and if he ≈øhould tender it, then the Obligor may either deliver the Bonds or execute the Relea≈øe, which he plea≈øeth, 4 H. 7. 4.

If a Man enter into Bond with Condition to marry Jane by ≈øuch a day, and the Obligee marry her before the day,1 Roll. Abr. 455. the Condition is ≈øaved; but 'tis otherwi≈øe if a Stranger had married her before that day: The Act of God and the Act of the Oblig√©e in many Ca≈øes di≈øpen≈øe with Conditions, as 5 Co. 21. b. if a Par≈øon be bound in a Bond conditioned to re≈øign his Church to A. in con≈øideration of a certain Pen≈øion agreed on, and the Par≈øon refu≈øes; the Court was of Opinion that he need not re≈øign till he was ≈øure of his Pen≈øion by Deed which they held ought to be fir≈øt tendred unto him.

So a Man covenants to grant ≈øuch an E≈øtate to his Wife or to leave her worth ≈øo much Mony, if ≈øhe ≈øurvive him, if ≈øhe dies before him the Condition is not broken, though he did not make ≈øuch Grant: In the Ca≈øe of Warren and White it was lately adjudged in the Kings Bench, that where Warren was indebted to Warner, and White became bound with him to pay the Mony before the 25th day of December then next following;
but if he did not pay it, that then Warren ≈øhould appear the next Hillary Term following to Warner's Action; Warren dies after the 25th of December, but before the Term; and it was held that the Bond was not forfeited,1 Rol. Abr. 451. becau≈øe the Obligor had Election to do either the one or the other, and the performance of the one becoming impo≈ø≈øible by the Act of God, the Obligation was ≈øaved.

Moor 645.If the Ca≈øe of Moor and Moorcomb, Cro. Eliz. 864. ≈øhould be objected, where the Condition of the Bond was, that the Defendant ≈øhould deliver to the Plaintiff a Ship before ≈øuch a Fea≈øt, or in default thereof pay at the ≈øame Fea≈øt ≈øuch a Sum as a third per≈øon therein named ≈øhould adjudge, which third per≈øon appointed no Sum to be paid, and yet there it was adjudged for the Plaintiff that it did not di≈øpen≈øe with the whole Condition.

Which Ca≈øe he agreed to be Law, becau≈øe there the valuation and worth of the Ship and the Mony to be paid was by the appointment of a Stranger, and the Condition being for the benefit of the Defendant he is to procure the Stranger to make an appointment what Sum ≈øhould be paid, or to deliver the Goods, otherwi≈øe the Bond is forfeited, and he hath expre≈øly agreed to do the one or the other.

But this is not like the Ca≈øe at the Barr, where 'tis not a Stranger, but the Obligee him≈øelf that mu≈øt procure the Conveyance; for 'tis to be advi≈øed by his Council, and to be done at his Co≈øts; and therefore in5 Co. 23. Lamb's Ca≈øe it was held that if a Man be bound to give ≈øuch a Relea≈øe before ≈øuch a day as the Iudge of the Admiralty ≈øhall direct; there 'tis no Plea to ≈øay that he appointed none, for the Iudge being a Stranger to the Condition,1 Roll. Abr. 452. lit. L. placito 6. the Defendant is to apply him≈øelf to him, having undertaken to perform it at his peril, which is the ≈øame Re≈øolution with Moor's Ca≈øe in Crook.

So that he took it for a Rule in all Ca≈øes, that where the Act of God or of the Oblig√©e di≈øcharges the Obligor from one part of a disjunctive Obligation, that the Law di≈øcharges him of the other; and therefore prayed Iudgment for the Defendant, Dyer 361.

Ex parte Quer.Serjeant Pemberton contra. It appears that one thing or the other was to be done in this Ca≈øe; for if the Plaintiff demanded and tendred an Annuity, the Defendant was to ≈øeal it; and if he did not tender it, then likewi≈øe the Defendant was to do ≈øomething, viz. to pay 300 l. So that the Plaintiff was either to have the Annuity or the Mony.
He agreed that where the Obligor hath the Election, if in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Oblig√©e ≈øhall wilfully determine it, that the Bond is thereby di≈øcharged.
But if a Stranger take away the Election, 'tis no di≈øcharge, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe the other part is to be performed.

In this ca≈øe the Plaintiff hath done no wilful Act to determine the Defendants Election, but all which is pretended is that he hath not done ≈øomething nece≈ø≈øary to be performed, which is, that he hath not made a reque≈øt.

But by his omi≈ø≈øion thereof, the Defendants Election is not taken away, for though no reque≈øt was made within the ≈øix Months, yet the Defendant might have prepared a Grant of the Annuity him≈øelf, and have offered it to the Plaintiff, within the ≈øix Months, upon the la≈øt part of the day; and if he had thus ≈øet forth his ca≈øe, and alledged that the Plaintiff made no reque≈øt, nor tendered him a Grant of the Annuity to Seal, this had been a good performance of the Condition, for he had done that which was the ≈øub≈øtance, which, though it was to be done at the Plaintiffs charge, yet the Defendant might have brought an Action for ≈øo much Mony by him laid to the u≈øe of the other; and the Ca≈øes put in the principal Ca≈øe in Moor 645. are expre≈øsly for the Plaintiff in this Ca≈øe, where the Iudgment was, That if there be a Statute with a Defeazance, to make ≈øuch Conveyance as the Council of the Conu≈øee ≈øhall direct, the Cogni≈øor mu≈øt prepare the Conveyance, if the other doth not; and there is a Ca≈øe put where a thing was to be done at the Co≈øts of the Plaintiff, yet the Defendant did it at his own Charge, which he recovered of the other.
