North Chief Iu≈øtice,Judgment. and the whole Court were of Opinion that the Plea was good, becau≈øe the Defendant had the benefit of Election, and the Plantiff not making the reque≈øt within the ≈øix Months, had di≈øpen≈øed with one part of the Condition, and the Law hath di≈øcharged the Defendant of the other part; and they relied upon the Ca≈øe of Grenningham and Ewre, which they held to be good Law, and an Authority expre≈øs in the very point.

In this Ca≈øe the Obligee was to do the fir≈øt act, Viz. To make the reque≈øt. Where the Condition is ≈øingle concilium non dedit advi≈øamentum is a good Plea to di≈øcharge the Defendant; ≈øo here the Condition is but ≈øingle, as to the Defendant; for though it be di≈øjunctive, yet the Plaintiff hath taken away the benefit of Election from the Obligor of doing the one, and therefore he ≈øhall be excu≈øed from doing the other.

The Pleading as alledged by the Council of the Plaintiff, would not have been a good performance of the Condition, for if one be bound to Convey as the Council of the other ≈øhall
advi≈øe, and he makes the Conveyance him≈øelf, this is not ≈øuch a Deed as was intended by the Parties, and ≈øo no performance of the Condition.
But however the Defendant need not plead it, for he is not bound ≈øo to do.

Here if the Plaintiff had reque≈øted the Sealing of ≈øuch a Grant of an Annuity, even the Defendant had liberty either to execute it, or to pay the 300 l. and where the Election is on the Obligors part, neither the act or neglect of the Obligee ≈øhall take it away from him; for it would be unrea≈øonable that the Obligee ≈øhould have his choice, either to accept of the Annuity or the 300 l. when 'tis a known Rule, That all Conditions where there is a Penalty in the Bond, are made in favour and for the benefit of the Obligor, and the 300 l. in this ca≈øe to be paid upon the refu≈øal of the Defendant to make ≈øuch Grant, is in the nature of a Penalty to enforce him to do it.

The principal Ca≈øe in Moor 645. was agreed to be Law, but the Rule there put was denied, as not adequate to the pre≈øent Ca≈øe, which was, that if by the Act of God, or of the Party, or through default of a Stranger, it becomes impo≈ø≈øible for the Obligor to do one thing in a disjunctive Condition, he is notwith≈øtanding bound to do the other.

This is true only as to the la≈øt Ca≈øe, but not to the two fir≈øt; and for an Authority5 Co Laughter's Ca≈øe was full in the Point, which is, that when a Condition con≈øi≈øts of two parts in the disjunctive, and both are po≈ø≈øible at the time of the Bond made, and afterwards one becomes impo≈ø≈øible by the Act of God, or of the Party, the Obligor is not bound to perform the other part.
And Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Smith ver≈øus Tracy. In Banco Regis.
div.p: Di≈øtribution ≈øhall be equally made among≈øt the Children of the whole and half Blood. Mod. Rep. 209. Jones 93. 1 Ventris 307IN a Prohibition; The Ca≈øe was: A Man dies inte≈øtate having three Brothers of the whole Blood, and a Brother and Si≈øter of the half Blood; and the Que≈øtion was whether they ≈øhall be admitted to a di≈øtribution in an equal degre√©.

Mr. Holt argued that they were all in aequali gradu, becau≈øe before the Act of Di≈øtribution the Ordinary had power to compel the Admini≈øtrator to give and allot filial Portions to the Children of the decea≈øed out of his E≈øtate. And by the Civil Law ≈øuch provi≈øion is made for the Children of the Inte≈øtate that the Goods, which either the Father or Mother brought to each other
at the Marriage, ≈øhall not remain to the Survivor, but the u≈øe and occupation of them only during Life, for the Property did belong to the Children.

'Tis no Objection to ≈øay, that becau≈øe the Law rejects the half Blood as to Inheritances, therefore it will do the ≈øame as to per≈øonal E≈øtates, becau≈øe ≈øuch E≈øtates are not to be determined by the Common but by the Canon or Civil Law, and if ≈øo, the half Blood ≈øhall come in for di≈øtribution, for this Act of Parliament confirms that Law.

Winnington Sollicitor General contra. He agreed that before this Act the half Blood was to have equal ≈øhare of the Inte≈øtates E≈øtate; but that now the Ordinary was compelled to make ≈øuch di≈øtribution, and to ≈øuch per≈øons as by the Act is directed, for he had not an original power to grant Admini≈øtration in any ca≈øe that did belong to the Temporal Courts,Sid. 370, 371. but it was given to him by the Indulgence of Princes, not quatenus a Spiritual Per≈øon, Hen≈øloes Ca≈øe, 9 Co. Bendl. 133.

And if he had not power in any Ca≈øe, he could not grant to whom he plea≈øed. But admitting he could, his power is now abridged by this Statute, and he cannot grant but to the Wife and Children or next of Kin in equal degr√©e or legally repre≈øenting their Stocks.

Now ≈øuch legal repre≈øentation mu≈øt be according to the Rules of the Common, and not of the Civil Law; for if there be two lawful Brothers and a Ba≈øtard eigne, and a Que≈øtion ≈øhould ari≈øe concerning the di≈øtribution of an Inte≈øtates E≈øtate, the ≈øub≈øequent Marriage according to the Law in the Spiritual Court would make the latter legitimate, and if ≈øo a legal Repre≈øentative among≈øt them; but this Court will never allow him ≈øo to be.

But the Court were all of Opinion that in re≈øpect of the Father the half Blood is as near as tho≈øe of the whole, and therefore they are all alike and ≈øhall have an equal di≈øtribution; and that ≈øuch Con≈øtruction ≈øhould be made of the Statute as would be mo≈øt agreeable to the Will of the dead per≈øon, if he had devi≈øed his E≈øtate by Will; and it was not to be imagined if ≈øuch Will had been made, but ≈øomething would have been given to the Children of the half Blood: And thereupon a Con≈øultaion was granted.

div.head: Anonymus. In C. B.
div.p: FAux Judgment: viz. Serjeant Turner took this Exception, that the Plaintiff in the Court below had declared ad damnum 20 l. whereas it not being a Court of Record, and being ≈øine Brevi the Court could not hold Plea of any Sum above 40 s. and for this Cau≈øe the Iudgment was rever≈øed.

div.head: DE Termino Pa≈øchae Anno 29 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Southcot ver≈øus Stowel. Intrat' Hill. 25 & 26 Car. 2. Regis Rot. 1303.
div.p: IN a Special Verdict in Ejectment; The Ca≈øe was,Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed, how it differs from a Conveyance at the Common Law. Mod. Rep. 226. Thomas Southcot having I≈ø≈øue two Sons, Sir Popham and William, and being ≈øei≈øed in F√©e of a Farm called Indyo, (the Lands now in que≈øtion) did upon the Marriage of his elde≈øt Son Sir Popham, covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Farm to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Sir Popham Southcot, and the Heirs Males of his Body on Margaret his Wife to be begotten; and for want of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue, to the Heirs Males of the Covenantor; and for want of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue, to his own right Heirs for ever.
Sir Popham had I≈ø≈øue begotten on his Wife Margaret, Edward his Son, and five Daughters, and dies.
Thomas, the Covenantor, dies.
Edward dies without I≈ø≈øue.
And whether the five Daughters, as Heirs general of Thomas, or William their Vncle, as ≈øpecial Heir Male of Thomas per formam doni, ≈øhall inherit this Land was the Que≈øtion.
Two Objections were made again≈øt the Title of William, the Vncle.

1. Vaugh. 49. Becau≈øe here is no expre≈øs E≈øtate to Thomas the Covenantor, for 'tis limited to his Heirs Males, the Remainder to his own right Heirs; ≈øo that he having no E≈øtate for Life, the E≈øtate Tail could not be executed in him, and for that rea≈øon William cannot take by de≈øcent.
2. He cannot take by Purcha≈øe, for he is to be Heir of Thomas, and Heir Male, the Limitation is ≈øo; but he cannot be Heir, for his five Nieces are Heirs.
In an≈øwer to which, the≈øe A≈ø≈øertions were laid down.

1. That in this Ca≈øe Thomas the Covenantor hath an E≈øtate for Life by implication, and ≈øo the E≈øtate Tail being executed in him comes to William by de≈øcent and not by purcha≈øe; for though the Covenantor had departed with his whole E≈øtate, and limited no V≈øe to him≈øelf, yet he hath a Rever≈øion, becau≈øe he can have no right Heir while he is living; and therefore the Statute of 27 H. 8. Hob. 30. creates an V≈øe in him till the future u≈øe cometh in e≈ø≈øe, and by con≈øequence the right Heirs cannot take by purcha≈øe; for wherever the Heir takes by purcha≈øe, the Ance≈øtor mu≈øt depart with his whole Fee, for which rea≈øon a Fee cannot be rai≈øed by way of purcha≈øe to a Mans right Heirs, by the name of Heirs, either by Conveyance of Land or by V≈øe or Devi≈øe, but it works by de≈øcent, 1 In≈øt. 22. b.

And that V≈øes may ari≈øe by Implication by Covenants to ≈øtand ≈øeized, the Authorities are very plentiful, Moor 284. 1 Co. 154. Lord Paget's Ca≈øe cited in the Rector of Cheddington's Ca≈øe, Cro. Eliz. 321. 1 Roll. Rep. 239, 240, 317, 438. Lane ver≈ø. Pannel.

Cor. Car.And in the Ca≈øe of Hodgkin≈øon and Wood, in a Devi≈øe there was the ≈øame limitation as this; the Ca≈øe was, Thomas being ≈øei≈øed in Fee had I≈ø≈øue Francis and William, by ≈øeveral Venters, and devi≈øed Land to Francis his elde≈øt Son for Life, then to the Heirs Males of his Body, and for default of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue, to the Heirs Males of William, and the Heirs Males of their Bodies for ever, and for default of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue to the u≈øe of the right Heirs of the Devi≈øor; then he made a Lea≈øe to William for 30 years, to commence after his death, and dies: William Enters and Surenders this Lea≈øe to Francis, who Enters and makes a Lea≈øe to the Defendant, and dyes without I≈ø≈øue, and William Enters and makes a Lea≈øe to the Plaintiff; it was adjudged for William, becau≈øe he being Heir Male of the Body of the Devi≈øor, had by this Limitation an E≈øtate Tayl, as by Purcha≈øe, and that the Inheritance in Fee ≈øimple did not ve≈øt in Francis.

2. If Thomas the Covenantor had no E≈øtate executed in him, yet William his Son in this Ca≈øe may take by way of future ≈øpringing u≈øe, becau≈øe the Limitation of an E≈øtate upon a Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed, may be made to commence after the Ance≈øtors Death, for the old Sei≈øin of the Covenantor is enough to ≈øupport it.

There is a great difference between a Feoffment to V≈øes, and a Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed, for by the Feoffment the E≈øtate is executed pre≈øently, 1 Co. 154. Rector of Cheddington's Ca≈øe; So if there be a Feoffment to A. for Life, Remainder to B. in
Fee, if A. refu≈øe B. ≈øhall enter pre≈øently, becau≈øe the Feoffor parted with his whole E≈øtate; but if this had been in the Ca≈øe of a Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed, if A. had refu≈øed, the Covenantor ≈øhould have enjoyed it again till after the death of A. by way of ≈øpringing u≈øe, like the Ca≈øe of Par≈øons and Willis, 2 Roll. Abr. 794. Where a Man Covenants with B. That if he doth not marry, he will ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of B. and his Heirs, B. dies, the Covenantor doth not marry; this V≈øe ari≈øes as well to the Heir of B. as to B. him≈øelf, if he had been living, and he ≈øhall have the Land in the nature of a de≈øcent.
But if William cannot take it either by purcha≈øe or by de≈øcent, he ≈øhall take it,

3. Per formam doni as ≈øpecial Heir to Thomas: This Ca≈øe was compared to that in Littleton Sect. 23. If Lands are given to a Man, and the heirs Females of his Body, if there be a Son, the Daughter is not Heir; but yet ≈øhe ≈øhall take it, for voluntas donatoris, &c.

So if Lands are given to a Man, and the Heirs Males of his Body, the younge≈øt Son ≈øhall have it after the death of the elde≈øt, leaving I≈ø≈øue only Daughters, for the≈øe are de≈øcents ≈øecundum formam doni.
So in this Ca≈øe the E≈øtate Tail ve≈øted in Edward, and when he died without I≈ø≈øue, it comes to William per formam doni.

Object. The Ca≈øe of Gre≈øwold in 4 & 5 Ph. & Mariae, Dyer 156. ≈øeems to be expre≈øs again≈øt this Opinion, which was, that Gre≈øwold was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, and made a Grant for Life, the Remainder to the Heirs Males of his Body, the Remainder to his own right Heirs; he had I≈ø≈øue two Sons, and dyed; the elde≈øt Son had I≈ø≈øue a Daughter, and dyed; and if the Daughter or her Vncle ≈øhould have the Land was the que≈øtion in that Ca≈øe: And it was adjudged that the Limitation of the Remainder was void, becau≈øe Gre≈øwold could not make his right Heir a Purcha≈øor, without departing with the whole Fee;Po≈øtea. Brittain and Charnock. and therefore Iudgment was given again≈øt the ≈øpecial Heir in Tail, for the Heir general, which was the Daughter.

An≈øw. Admit that Ca≈øe to be Law (yet the Iudges there differed in their Arguments,) 'Tis not like this at Bar, for that Ca≈øe was not upon a Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed, but upon a Deed indented, and ≈øo a Conveyance at the Common Law: But for an Authority in the point, the Ca≈øe of Pybus, and Mitford was cited and relied on, which was Trin. 24 Car. 2. Rot. 703. Mod. Rep. 159. 1 Ventris 372. adjudged by Hales Chief Iu≈øtice, Rainsford and Wild, but Iu≈øtice Twi≈øden was of a contrary Opinion.
Serjeant Stroud, who argued on the other ≈øide, made three Points.
1. Whether this Limitation be good in its creation.
2. If the E≈øtate Tail be well executed in Thomas the Covenantor.
3. If it be good and well executed, whether when Edward died without I≈ø≈øue, the whole E≈øtate Tail was not ≈øpent.

1. And as to the fir≈øt Point, he held that this Limitation to the Heirs Males of Thomas was void in the creation, becau≈øe a Man cannot make him≈øelf or his own right Heir a Purcha≈øor, unle≈øs he will part with the whole E≈øtate in Fee, Dyer 309 b.

If A. being ≈øei≈øed in Fee, makes a Lea≈øe for Life to B. the Remainder to him≈øelf for years, this Remainder is void; ≈øo if it had been to him≈øelf for Life, becau≈øe he hath an E≈øtate in Fee, and he cannot re≈øerve to him≈øelf a le≈ø≈øer E≈øtate than he had before, 42 A≈ø≈ø. 2.

If I give Lands to A. for Life, the Remainder to my ≈øelf for Life, the Remainder in Fee to B, after the death of A. in this Ca≈øe B. ≈øhall enter, for the Remainder to me was void, 1 H. 5. 8. 42 Edw. 3. 5. Bro. E≈øtate 66. Dyer 69. b.

'Tis true, the≈øe Ca≈øes are put at the Common Law, but the Statute of V≈øes makes no alteration; for according to the Rules laid down in Chudleigh's Ca≈øe, by my Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Popham, 1 Co. 138.
1. V≈øes are odious, and ≈øo the Law will not favour them.
2. A Rule at Common Law ≈øhall not be broke to ve≈øt an V≈øe, and the V≈øes here cannot ve≈øt without breaking of a Rule in Law.
3. V≈øes are rai≈øed ≈øo privately, that he who takes them may not know when they ve≈øt, and for that rea≈øon they are not to be favoured.
4. The Statute annexes both the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and the V≈øe together, as they ve≈øt and dive≈øt both together, Moor 713. 2 Co. 91. Co. Lit. 22. Moor 284.

2. As to the ≈øecond Point, The E≈øtate is not executed in Thomas, and therefore William cannot take it by de≈øcent; Heirs of his Body or Heirs Male, are good Words of Limitation to take by Purcha≈øe from a Stranger, but not from an Ance≈øtor, for there he ≈øhall take by de≈øcent, and for this there is an Authority, Co. Lit. 26. b. John had I≈ø≈øue by his Wife Roberga, Robert and Mawd; John dies, Michael gave Lands to Roberga, and to the Heirs of her Husband on her Body begotten;
Roberga in this Ca≈øe had but an E≈øtate for Life, for the Fee Tail ve≈øted in Robert, and when he died without I≈ø≈øue his Si≈øter Maud was Tenant in Tail, per formam Doni, and in a Formedon ≈øhe counted as Heir to Robert, which ≈øhe was not, neither was ≈øhe Heir to her Father at the time of the Gift, yet it was held good; for the Words, Viz. Heirs of the Body of the Father, were Words of Purcha≈øe in this Ca≈øe.
If therefore no V≈øe for Life ve≈øted in Thomas, then William cannot take by de≈øcent, Dyer 156. Co. Lit. 22. Hob. 31. Dyer 309. 1 Co. 154. Lord Paget's Ca≈øe, cited in Hob. 151.
3. To the third Point, Admitting both the former to be again≈øt him, yet ≈øince Edward is dead without I≈ø≈øue, the E≈øtate Tail is ≈øpent.

But the whole Court were of Opinion,Judgment. That William ≈øhould Inherit this Land in que≈øtion; for though at the Common Law a Man cannot be Donor and Donee, without he part with the whole E≈øtate, yet 'tis otherwi≈øe upon a Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to V≈øes: And if any other Con≈øtruction ≈øhould be made, many Settlements would be ≈øhaken, in which nothing was more u≈øual now, than to Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the V≈øe of him≈øelf, and the Heirs Males of his Body, &c.

They all agreed al≈øo, That the E≈øtate being well limited, William ≈øhould take per formam Doni as ≈øpecial Heir, for Voluntas Donatoris in charta manife≈øte expre≈ø≈øa ob≈øervetur; and 'tis apparent Thomas intended that William ≈øhould have it, or el≈øe the Limitation to his Heirs Males had been needle≈øs.

So that taking it for granted, that the E≈øtate Tail once ve≈øted, is not ≈øpent by his dying without I≈ø≈øue, but it comes to William by de≈øcent, and not as a Purcha≈øor, for ≈øo he could not take it, becau≈øe he is not Heir, and till Thomas be dead without I≈ø≈øue, the Tail cannot be ≈øpent, ≈øo there was no difficulty in that Point.

And they held the Opinions of Dyer and Saunders in Cre≈øwold's Ca≈øe to be good Law, who were divided from the other Iu≈øtices, but they doubted of Pybus and Mitford's Ca≈øe, whether it was Law or not; they doubted al≈øo whether by any Con≈øtruction Thomas could be ≈øaid to have an E≈øtate for Life by implication; they doubted al≈øo of the ≈øpringing V≈øe, but they held that this Limitation was good in its creation, and Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: Cockram Executor ver≈øus Welby.
div.p: Statute of Limitations not pleadable by a Sheriff, who levied mony by fi. fa. and nine years pa≈øs. Mod. Rep. 245.IN Debt, the Plaintiff declared that his Te≈øtator recovered a Iudgment in this Court, upon which he ≈øued out a Fieri facias, which he delivered to the Defendant being Sheriff of Lincoln, and thereupon the ≈øaid Sheriff returned Fieri feci, but that he hath not paid the Mony to the Plaintiff, per quod actio accrevit, &c.
The Defendant pleaded the Statute of Limitations, to which the Plaintiff demurred.
And the que≈øtion was, whether this Action was barely grounded on the Contract, or whether it had a Foundation upon matter of Record?

If on the Contract only, then the Statute of 21 Jacobi cap. 16. is a good Plea to barr the Plaintiff of his Action, which Enacts That all Actions of Debt, grounded upon any Lending or Contract, without Specialty, ≈øhall be brought within ≈øix years next after the Cau≈øe of Action doth accrew; and in this Ca≈øe nine years had pa≈ø≈øed.
But if it be grounded upon matter of Record, that is a Specialty, and then the Statute is no barr.

Serjeant Barrel held this to be a Debt upon a Contract, without ≈øpecialty, for when the Sheriff had levied the Mony, the Action cea≈øes again≈øt the Party, and then the Law creates a Contract, and makes him Debtor, as it is in the Ca≈øe of a Tally delivered to a Cu≈øtomer.
It lies again≈øt an Executor, where the Action ari≈øes qua≈øi ex contractu, which it would not do if it did not ari≈øe ex maleficio as in the Ca≈øe of a Deva≈øtavit.

'Tis true, The Iudgment recovered by the Te≈øtator, is now ≈øet forth by the Plaintiff Executor, but that is not the ground but only an inducement to the Action, for the Plaintiff could not have pleaded nul tiel Record, ≈øo that 'tis the meer receiving the Mony which charges the Defendant, and not virtute Officii upon a fal≈øe return; for upon the receipt of the Mony he is become Debtor, whether the Writ be returned or not, and the Law immediately creates a Contract; and Contracts in Law are as much within the Statute, as Actual Contracts made between the Parties.

All which was admitted on the other ≈øide; but it was ≈øaid that this Contract in Law was chiefly grounded upon the Record, and compared it to the Ca≈øe of Attornies Fees, which hath been adjudged not to be within the Statute, though it be qua≈øi ex contractu, becau≈øe it depends upon Matter of Record, Rolls Abridg. tit. Debt 598. pl. 17.

And afterwards in Michaelmas-Term following by the Opinions of the Chief Ju≈øtice, Wyndham and Atkins Iu≈øtices, it was held that this Ca≈øe was not within the Statute, becau≈øe the Action was brought again≈øt the Defendant as an Officer, who acted by vertue of an Execution; in which Ca≈øe the Law did create no Contract, and that here was a Wrong done, for which the Plaintiff had taken a proper remedy, and therefore ≈øhould not be barred by this Statute.
Iu≈øtice Scroggs was of a contrary Opinion; for he ≈øaid if another received Mony to his u≈øe due upon Bond, the Receipt makes the Party ≈øubject to the Action, and ≈øo is within the Statute.
But by the Opinions of the other Iu≈øtices Iugdment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Major ver≈øus Grigg. In Banco Regis.
div.p: THE Plaintiff brought an Action,Covenant to ≈øave harmle≈øs, and the Plaintiff ≈øets forth no Title in the di≈øturber, good after Verdict. Cro. Eliz. 914. Cro. Jac. 315, 425. Vaugh. 120, 121. 2 Sand. 178. Mod. Rep. 66. for that the Defendant Non indempnem con≈øervavit ip≈øum de & concernente occupationÃÑ quorundam clau≈øorum, &c. ≈øecundum formam agreamenti, and ≈øets forth a di≈øturbance by one who commenced a Suit again≈øt him in ≈øuch a Term concernente occupationÃÑ clau≈øorum praed', but doth not ≈øet forth that the per≈øon ≈øuing had any Title, which (it was ≈øaid) ought to have been ≈øhewn; as if a Man makes a Lea≈øe for years and covenants for quiet enjoyment, in an Action brought by the Le≈ø≈øee upon that Covenant it mu≈øt be ≈øhewn that there was a lawful Title in the per≈øon, who di≈øturbed, or el≈øe the Action will not lie.

But this being after a Verdict, and the Plaintiff ≈øetting forth in his Declaration, that the di≈øturber recovered per Judicium Curiae, the Court now were all of Opinion that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Taylor ver≈øus Baker. In Banco Regis.
div.p: Payment to the Mar≈øhal no di≈øcharge to the Plaintiff at who≈øe Suit the Defendant was in Execution. Jones 97.THE Ca≈øe was; viz. a Man being in Execution doth actually pay the Mony to the Mar≈øhal, for which he was impri≈øoned, and thereupon was di≈øcharged; and whether he ≈øhould pay it again to the Plaintiff upon a ≈øecond Execution was the Que≈øtion?
Sanders argued that he ≈øhould not pay it again; he ≈øaid this Ca≈øe was never adjudged, and therefore could produce no Authority in Point to warrant his Opinion, but parallel Ca≈øes there were many.

As if the Sheriff take Goods in Execution by vertue of a Fieri Facias, whether he ≈øells them or not, yet being taken from the party again≈øt whom the Execution was ≈øued, he ≈øhall plead that taking in di≈øcharge of him≈øelf, and ≈øhall not be liable to a ≈øecond Execution, though the Sheriff hath not returned the Writ; and the rea≈øon is becau≈øe the Defendant cannot avoid the Execution, and he would therefore be in a very bad condition, if he was to be charged the ≈øecond time.

And if the Sheriff ≈øhould die after the Goods are taken in Execution, his Executors are liable to the Plaintiff to ≈øatisfie the debt, for they have paid pro quo, and 'tis in nature of a Contract rai≈øed by Law.

By the Words of the Capias ad ≈øatisfaciend' it doth appear that the de≈øign of the Writ is to enforce the Payment of the the debt by the Impri≈øonment of the Defendant: The Sheriff thereupon returns that he hath taken the Body, and that the Defendant hath paid the Mony to him, for which rea≈øon he di≈øcharged him; and for this Return he was amerced, not becau≈øe he di≈øcharged the Party, but becau≈øe he had not brought the Mony into the Court; for the Law never intended that a Man ≈øhould be kept in Pri≈øon after he had paid the debt.

In this Ca≈øe the Defendant can have no remedy to recover it again of the Mar≈øhal, becau≈øe it was not a bare Payment to him, but to pay it over again to the Plaintiff, and likewi≈øe in con≈øideration that he ≈øhould be di≈øcharged from his Impri≈øonment.

If it ≈øhould be objected by the Mar≈øhal that the Plaintiff hath an Action of E≈øcape again≈øt him, and likewi≈øe by the Plaintiff that he did not make the Gaoler his Steward or Bayliff to receive his Mony.

An≈øw. The Gaoler is made his Bayliff to keep the Party in Execution, and it would be very hard that when the Pri≈øoner will lay down his Mony in di≈øcharge of the Debt, that the Gaoler ≈øhould not have full power to di≈øcharge him.

If he had come in Michaelmas-Term after the long Vacation, and informed the Court that he had offered to pay the Execution Mony to the Mar≈øhal, and that he would not take it, and that the Plaintiff could not be found, the Court would have made a Rule to help him.
Mr. Holt contra. If the Payment had b√©en good to the Sheriff or Mar≈øhal, yet 'tis not pleadable to the ≈øecond Execution becau≈øe 'tis matter in fact.

That which hath been objected that the Party ≈øhall plead to a ≈øecond Execution, that his Goods were taken by a former Fieri Facias cannot be; for no ≈øuch Plea can be good, becau≈øe by that Writ the Sheriff hath expre≈øs Authority to levy the Mony; and the Plea is not Payment to the Sheriff, but that the Mony was levyed by him by virtue of the Writ, which ought to be brought into the Court, and an Audita Querela lies again≈øt the Plaintiff, and then the Defendant is to be bailed, 1 Leon. 141. Askew ver≈øus the Earl of Lincoln.

Jones and Rainsford were of Opinion, that the Defendant might have remedy again≈øt the Mar≈øhal to recover his Mony again, and that the Payment to him was no di≈øcharge to the Plaintiff at who≈øe Suit he was in Execution: But Iu≈øtice Wyld was of another Opinion: Quaere.

div.head: The Lord Marque≈øs of Dorche≈øter's Ca≈øe. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
IN a Scandalum Magnatum.
Vi≈øne not changed in a Scandalum Magnatum. Serjeant Pemberton moved to have good Bail, which the Court denied, and ≈øaid that in ≈øuch Ca≈øe Bail was not requirable, but notwith≈øtanding the Defendant con≈øented to put in 50 l. Bail.

And then upon the u≈øual Affidavit moved to change the Vi≈øne the Action being laid in London, which was oppo≈øed by the Serjeant, who de≈øired that it might be tried where it was laid; but he ≈øaid in this Ca≈øe that the Vi≈øne could not be changed.
1. Becau≈øe the King is a Party to the Suit, for 'tis tam pro Domino Rege quam pro ≈øeip≈øo.

2. The Plaintiff is a Lord of Parliament which is adjourned and will meet, and therefore it would be inconvenient to try the Cau≈øe in the Country, ≈øince the Service of the King and Kingdom both require his Attendance here; and he ≈øaid that upon the like Motion in B. R. between the Lord Stamford and Needham, the Court would not change the Vi≈øne.

North Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid that he always took it as a current Opinion, that in a Scandalum Magnatum the Vi≈øne could not be changed; for ≈øince it was in the nature of an Information it being tam quam, 'twas advi≈øable whether it was not within the Statute of 21 Jac. which doth appoint Informations to be tried in their proper Counties.

But Iu≈øtice Atkins inclined that the Vi≈øne might be changed, for though by the Wisdom of the Law a Iury of the Neighbourhood are to try the Cau≈øe, yet in point of Iu≈øtice the Court may change the Vi≈øne; to which it was objected, that then there would be no difference between local and tran≈øitory Actions.
Actions of Debt and Accompt ≈øhall be brought in their proper Counties 6 R. 2. and it was agreed that an Attorney is ≈øworn to bring Actions no where el≈øe.
But the Court not agr√©eing, at la≈øt the Defendant was willing that the Cau≈øe ≈øhould be tried in London, if the Plaintiff would con≈øent not to try it before the fir≈øt Setting in the next Term.

And as to that rea≈øon offered, why the Vi≈øne ≈øhould not be changed, becau≈øe the Plaintiff was a Lord of Parliament, Iu≈øtice Atkins ≈øaid that did not ≈øatisfie him; it might be a good ground to move for a Trial at the Barr; to which it was an≈øwered, that in the Ca≈øe of the Earl of Shaft≈øbury the Court would not grant a Tryal at the Barr without the Con≈øent of the Defendant.
The Vi≈øne was not changed.

div.head: Beaver ver≈øus Lane.
div.p: COvenant made to Baron and Feme, Covenant to Baron and Feme, the Baron alone may bring the Action. the Husband alone brings the Action quod teneat ei conventionem ≈øecundum formam & effectum cuju≈ødam Indenturae inter Querentem ex una parte & Defendentem ex altera parte confect', and this was for not repairing his Hou≈øe: After Verdict for the Plaintiff it was moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment becau≈øe of this variance.

But the Court Ordered that the Plaintiff ≈øhould have his Iudgment, for the Indenture being by Baron and Feme it was therefore true, that it was by the Baron, and the Action being brought upon a Covenant concerning his Hou≈øes, and going with them though it be made to him and his Wife, yet he may refu≈øe quoad her, and bring the Action alone: And the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that he remembred an Authority in an old Book, that if a Bond be given to Baron and Feme the Husband ≈øhall bring the Action alone, which ≈øhall be looked upon to be his refu≈øal as to her.

div.head: Calthrop ver≈øus Phillips.
div.p: THE Que≈øtion was, Super≈øedeas mu≈øt be delivered by the old Sheriff to the new one. Mod. Rep. 222. in regard a Super≈øedeas is not returnable in the Court, whether the old Sheriff is bound to deliver it over to the new one or no; and it was urged that it ought not, becau≈øe the old Sheriff is to ke√©p it for his indempnity, and he may have occa≈øion to plead it.

But on the other ≈øide it was in≈øi≈øted by Serjeant George Strode, that it ought to be delivered to the new Sheriff, and that there was a Writ in the Regi≈øter, which proved it, fol. 295. and if it ≈øhould be otherwi≈øe the≈øe inconveniences would follow.

1. It would be inconvenient that the Capias again≈øt the Defendant ≈øhould be delivered to the new Sheriff, and not the Super≈øedeas which was to admit the Charge, and not the Di≈øcharge, We≈øtby's Ca≈øe, 3 Co. 73. And it was the con≈øtant practice not only to deliver the Super≈øedeas, but the very Book in which 'tis allowed; and this he ≈øaid appeared by the Certificates of many Vnder-Sheriffs, which he had in his hand.

2. If the Sheriff hath an Exigent again≈øt B. who appears and brings a Super≈øedeas to the old Sheriff, and then a new Sheriff is made, if he hath not the Super≈øedeas he may return him outlawed by vertue of the Exigent; ≈øo in the Ca≈øe of a Iudgment ≈øet a≈øide for Fraud or Practice, and a Super≈øedeas granted; and the like in the
ca≈øe of an E≈øtrepment which is never returned; and it would be an endle≈øs work upon the coming in of every Sheriff to renew this Writ.

As to the Objection that the old Sheriff may have occa≈øion to plead it: As often as ≈øuch occa≈øion happens he may have recour≈øe to it in the Office of the new Sheriff; and he can have no Title to it by the direction of the Writ, for that is Vicecomiti Berks, and not to him by expre≈øs Chri≈øtian and Sirname; and of that Opinion was all the Court, and Iudgment was given accordingly ni≈øi cau≈øa, &c.

div.head: Hamond ver≈øus Howel Recorder of London.
div.p: An Action will not lie again≈øt a Judge for what he doth judicially tho' erroniou≈øly. Mod. Rep. 184. FAl≈øe Impri≈øonment. The Defendant pleads ≈øpecially; the Sub≈øtance of which was, that there was a Commi≈ø≈øion of Oyer and Terminer directed to him among≈øt others, &c. and that before him and the other Commi≈ø≈øioners Mr. Penn and Mr. Mead two Preachers, were indicted for being at a Conventicle; to which Indictment they pleaded Not-Guilty, and this was to be tried by a Iury, whereof the Plaintiff was one; and that after the Witne≈ø≈øes were ≈øworn and examined in the Cau≈øe, he and his Fellows found the Pri≈øoners, Penn and Mead, Not-Guilty, whereby they were acquitted, & quia the Plaintiff male ≈øe ge≈ø≈øerit in acquitting them both again≈øt the direction of the Court in Matter of Law, and again≈øt plain Evidence; the Defendant and the other Commi≈ø≈øioners then on the Bench fined the Iury 40 Marks a-piece, and for Non-payment committed them to New-gate, &c.
The Plaintiff replies de injuria ≈øua propria ab≈øque hoc that he and his Fellows acquitted Penn and Mead again≈øt Evidence; and to this the Defendant demurred.

Serjeant Goodfellow, who would have argued for the Defendant, ≈øaid that he would not offer to ≈øpeak to that Point, whether a Iudge can fine a Iury for giving a Verdict contrary to Evidence, ≈øince the Ca≈øe was ≈øo lately and ≈øolemnly re≈øolved by all the Iudges of England, inVaugh. 146. Bu≈øhel's Ca≈øe, that he could not fine a Iury for ≈øo doing.

But admit a Iudge cannot fine a Iury, yet if he doth, no Action will lie again≈øt him for ≈øo doing, becau≈øe 'tis done as a Iudge, 12 H. 4. 3. 27 A≈ø≈ø. pl. 12. 1 Roll. Abr. 92. Liter. Q. pl. 1. But the Court told him that he ne√©d not to labour that Point, but de≈øired to hear the Argument on the other ≈øide what could be ≈øaid for the Plaintiff.
Serjeant Newdigate argued that this Action would lie.

1. It mu≈øt be admitted that the Impri≈øonment of the Iury was unlawful, and then the con≈øequence will be, that all that was done at that time by the Commi≈ø≈øioners or Iudges was both again≈øt Magna Charta and other Acts of Parliament, the Petition of Right, &c. and therefore their Proceedings were void, or at lea≈øt very irregular to impri≈øon a Iury-man without Pre≈øentment or due Proce≈øs in Law, and con≈øequently the party injured ≈øhall have an Action for his fal≈øe Impri≈øonment.

In 10 H. 6. f. 17. In an Action brought for fal≈øe Impri≈øonment the Defendant ju≈øtifies the Commitment to be for Su≈øpicion of Felony; but becau≈øe he did not ≈øhew the ground of ≈øuch Su≈øpicion the Iu≈øtification was not good.

The Trial of Penn and Mead and all incidents thereunto, as ≈øwearing the Iury, examining of the Witne≈ø≈øes, taking of the Verdict and acquitting the Pri≈øoner were all within the Commi≈ø≈øion; but the fining of the Iury and the impri≈øoning of them for Non-payment thereof was not ju≈øtifiable by their Commi≈ø≈øion, and therefore what was done therein was not as Commi≈ø≈øioners or Iudges.

If this Action will not lie then the Party has a Wrong done, for which he can have no remedy; for the order for paying of the Fine was made at the Old-Bayly, upon which no Writ of Error will lie; and though the Objection that no Action will lie again≈øt a Iudge of Record for what he doth quatenus a Iudge, be great, the Rea≈øon of which is, becau≈øe the King him≈øelf is de jure to do Iu≈øtice to his Subjects, and becau≈øe he cannot di≈øtribute it him≈øelf to all per≈øons, he doth therefore delegate his Power to his Iudges, and if they misbehave them≈øelves the King him≈øelf ≈øhall call them to account and no other per≈øon, 12 Co. 24, 25.

But that concerns not this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe what was done here was not warranted by the Commi≈ø≈øion, and therefore the Defendant did not act as a Iudge; and this difference hath be√©n taken and allowed, that in the Ca≈øe of an Officer, if the Court hath Iurisdiction of the Cau≈øe no Action will lie again≈øt him for doing what is contrary to his Duty; but if all the Proce√©dings are coram non Judice and ≈øo void, an Action doth lie, 10 Co. 77.
So in the Ca≈øe of a Iu≈øtice of the Peace or Con≈øtable, where he exc√©eds his particular Iurisdiction; ≈øo if a Iudge of Ni≈øi Prius doth any thing not warranted by his Commi≈ø≈øion, 'tis void.

And that the Commi≈ø≈øioners here had no power to impo≈øe this Fine, he argued from the very nature of the pretended Offence, which was neither a Crime or in any wi≈øe puni≈øhable, becau≈øe what the Plaintiff did was upon his Oath; and for that rea≈øon it hath
b√©en adjudged in the Ca≈øeBridgman 131. Agard and Wild, that an Action would not lie again≈øt one of the Grand Iury after an acquittal, for procuring one to be indicted for Barretry, becau≈øe he is upon his Oath, and it cannot be pre≈øumed that what he did was in Malice.

The Habeas Corpus gives the Party Liberty but no Recompence for his Impri≈øonment, that mu≈øt be by an Action of Fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, if otherwi≈øe, there would be a failure of Iu≈øtice; and it might encourage the Iudges to act ad libitum, e≈øpecially in inferior Courts, where Mayors and Bayliffs might puni≈øh Iuries at their plea≈øures, which would not only be a grievance to the Subject, but a prejudice to the King him≈øelf, becau≈øe no Iuries would appear where they are ≈øubject to ≈øuch arbitrary Proc√©edings.

An Action on the Ca≈øe lies again≈øt a Iu≈øtice of the Peace for refu≈øing to take an Oath of a Robbery committed, 1 Leon. 323. and yet it was objected that there he was a Iudge, Quaere, Brook 204. March 117. for which Rea≈øons he prayed Iudgment for the Plaintiff.

Curia.But the whole Court were of Opinion that the bringing of this Action was a greater Offence that fining of the Plaintiff, and committing of him for Non-payment, and that it was a bold attempt both again≈øt the Government and Iu≈øtice in general.

The Court at the Old-Bayly had Iurisdiction of the Cau≈øe and might try it, and had power to puni≈øh a Misdemeanour in the Iury; they thought it to be a Misdemeanour in the Iury to acquit the Pri≈øoners, which in truth was not ≈øo, and therefore it was an Error in their Iudgments, for which no Action will lie: How often are Iudgments given in this Court, rever≈øed in the Kings Bench? And becau≈øe the Iudges have been mi≈øtaken in ≈øuch Iudgments mu≈øt that needs be again≈øt Magna Charta, the Petition of Right and the Liberties of the Subject? The≈øe are mighty words in ≈øound but nothing to the Matter.

There hath not b√©en one Ca≈øe put which carries any re≈øemblance with this; tho≈øe of Iu≈øtices of the Peace and Mayors of Corporations are weak in≈øtances; neither hath any Authority been urged of an Action brought again≈øt a Iudge of Record for doing any thing quatenus a Iudge.

That Offences in Iury-men may be puni≈øhed without Pre≈øentment is no new Doctrin, as if they ≈øhould either eat or drink before they give their Verdict, or for any contempt what≈øoever; but 'tis a new Doctrin to ≈øay, that if a Fine be ≈øet on a Iury-man at the Old-Bayly, he hath no remedy but to pay it; for a Certiorari
may be brought to remove the Order by which it was impo≈øed, and it may be di≈øcharged if the Court think fit.

As to what hath been Objected concerning the Liberty of the Subject, that is abundantly ≈øecured by the Law already; a Iudge cannot impo≈øe upon a Iury for giving their Verdict contrary to Evidence; if he doth any thing unju≈øtly or corruptly, complaint may be made to the King, in who≈øe Name Iudgments are given, and the Iudges are by him delegated to do Iu≈øtice, but if there be Error in their Iudgments, as here, 'tis void; and therefore the Barons of the Exchequer might refu≈øe to i≈ø≈øue Proce≈øs upon it, and there needs no Writ of Error, for the very E≈øtreats will be vacated.

Though the Defendants here acted erroneou≈øly, yet the contrary Opinion carried great colour with it, becau≈øe it might be ≈øuppo≈øed very inconvenient for the Iury to have ≈øuch liberty as to give what Verdicts they plea≈øe; ≈øo that though they were mi≈øtaken, yet they acted judicially, and for that Rea≈øon no Action will lie again≈øt the Defendant; and Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: The Ca≈øe of the Warden of the Fleet.
div.p: COmplaint was made by Serjeant Turner on the part of the Pari≈øhioners of St. Brides London, again≈øt the Warden of the Fleet and his Pri≈øoners, for that he ≈øuffered ≈øeveral of them to be without the Walls of his Pri≈øon, in Taverns and other Hou≈øes adjoyning to the Pri≈øon and fronting Fleet-Ditch, where they committed Di≈øorders, and when the Con≈øtable came to keep the Peace, and to execute a Warrant under the Hand and Seal of a Iu≈øtice of Peace, they came in a tumultuous manner, and hindered the execution of Iu≈øtice, and re≈øcued the Offenders, and often beat the Officers, the Warden often letting out 20 or 30 of his Pri≈øoners upon any ≈øuch occa≈øion to inflame the Di≈øorder.

It was prayed therefore, That this Court, to which the Pri≈øon of the Fleet doth immediately relate, might give ≈øuch Directions to the Warden, that the≈øe Mi≈øchiefs for the future might be prevented, and that the Court would declare tho≈øe Hou≈øes out of the Pri≈øon to be ≈øubject to the Civil Magi≈øtrate.

The Court were all of Opinion (but Iu≈øtice Atkins, Curia. who doubted) that nothing can properly be called the Pri≈øon of the Fleet,
which is not within the Walls of the Pri≈øon, and that the Warden cannot pretend an exemption from the Authority of the Civil Magi≈øtrate, in ≈øuch places as are out of the Pri≈øon Walls, though Hou≈øes may be built upon the Land belonging to the Fleet; for the pre≈øervation of the Kings Peace is more to be valued than ≈øuch a Private Right.

But Iu≈øtice Atkyns ≈øaid, if ≈øuch places were within the Liberties of the Fleet, he would not give the civil Magi≈øtrate a Iuri≈ødiction in prejudice of the Warden, but thought it might be fit for the Court to con≈øider upon what rea≈øon it was that the Warden of the Fleet applied ≈øuch Hou≈øes to any other u≈øes than for the benefit of the Pri≈øoners; whereupon the Court appointed the Prothonotaries to go thither and give them an account of the matter, and they would take farther Order in it.

div.head: St. Mary Magdalen Bermond≈øey Church in Southwark: In Scaccario.
div.p: Rate for Building a Church ≈øhall be ≈øet by the Pari≈øhioners. Jones 89. Mod. Rep. 236.IN a Prohibition, it was the Opinion of the whole Court, That if a Church be ≈øo much out of Repair, that 'tis nece≈ø≈øary to pull it down, and that it cannot be otherwi≈øe repaired, that in ≈øuch ca≈øe upon a general warning or notice given to the Pari≈øhioners, much more if there be notice given from Hou≈øe to Hou≈øe, the major part of the Pari≈øhioners then pre≈øent, and meeting according to ≈øuch notice, may make a Rate for pulling down of the Church to the Ground, and Building of it upon the old Foundation, and for making of Vaults where they are nece≈ø≈øary, as they were in this Church, by rea≈øon of the ≈øpringing Water; and though the Rate be higher than the Mony paid for doing all this, yet 'tis good, and the Churchwardens are chargeable for the Overplus, they not being able to compute to a Shilling.

That if any of the Pari≈øhioners refu≈øe to pay their Proportion according to the Rate, they may be Libelled again≈øt in the Spiritual Court; and if the Libel alledge the Rate to be pro reparatione Eccle≈øiae generally, though in ≈øtrictne≈øs Eccle≈øia contains both the Body and Chancel of the Church; yet by the Opinion both of the Court of Common Pleas and of the Exchequer, It ≈øhall be intended, that the Rate was only for the Body
of the Church; but in this Ca≈øe it was made appear clearly that the Rate was only for the Body, and that the Mini≈øter was at the charge of the Chancel.

And both Courts agreed, That when a Prohibition is moved and de≈øired on purpo≈øe to ≈øtop ≈øo good a Work as the Building a Church, the Court will not compel the Parties to take I≈ø≈øue upon the Sugge≈øtion, when upon examination they find it to be fal≈øe, and therefore will not grant a Prohibition; for if the Rate be unduly impo≈øed, the Party grieved hath a Remedy in the Spiritual Court, or may Appeal if there be a Sentence again≈øt him.

The Bi≈øhop or his Chancellor cannot ≈øet a Rate upon a Pari≈øh, but it mu≈øt be done by the Pari≈øhioners them≈øelves; and ≈øo North Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that it had been lately ruled in the Common Pleas.

Afterwards the Court of Kings-Bench was moved for a Prohibition in this Ca≈øe, and it was denied, ≈øo that in this Ca≈øe there was the Opinion of all the three Courts. This matter was ≈øo much laboured becau≈øe twenty four Quakers were reported to be concerned in the Rate, and they were unwilling to pay towards the Building of a Church.

div.head: Paget ver≈øus Vo≈ø≈øius. In B. R.
div.p: A Trial at the Bar in Ejectione Firmae, Judgment given upon the Con≈øtruction of words in a Will. Jones 73. 1 Ventris 325. in which the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict: The Ca≈øe was, Viz. That Dr. Vo≈ø≈øius the Defendant, being an Alien, and a Subject of the States of Holland, falling into Di≈øgrace there, had his Pen≈øion taken from him by Publick Authority: Afterwards he came into England, and contracted a great Friend≈øhip with one Dr. Brown a Prebendary of Wind≈øor; Then a War broke out between England and Holland, and the King i≈ø≈øued forth his Proclamation, declaring the ≈øaid War, and the Hollanders to be Alien Enemies.

Dr. Brown being ≈øei≈øed of the Lands now in que≈øtion, being of the value of 200 l. per Ann. and upwards, made his Will in the≈øe words in Writing, Inter alia, Viz. Item I give all my Mannour of S. with all my Freehold and Copyhold Lands, &c. to my dear Friend Dr. I≈øaac Vo≈ø≈øius, during his Exile from his own Native Country; but if it plea≈øe God to re≈øtore him to his Country, or take him
out of this Life, then I give the ≈øame immediately after ≈øuch re≈øtoration or death, to Mrs. Abigal Hevenigham for ever.

A Peace was afterwards concluded between England and Holland, whereby all Intercour≈øes of Trade between the two Nations became lawful; but Dr. Vo≈ø≈øius was not ≈øent for over by the States, nor was there any offer of kindne≈øs to him, but his Pen≈øion was di≈øpo≈øed of and given to another.
That the Doctor might return into his own Country when he plea≈øed, but that he ≈øtill continued in England.
And whether he or the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff Mrs. Heveningham had the better Title, was the que≈øtion?
Nota, Dr. Vo≈ø≈øius was enabled to take by Grant from the King.

Ex parte Quer. Pemberton Serjeant for the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, argued that the E≈øtate limited to the Defendant is determined, which depended upon the con≈øtruction of this Devi≈øe. He did agree that the Will was ob≈øcure, and the intent of the Devi≈øor mu≈øt be collected from the circum≈øtances of the Ca≈øe; and it is a Rule, That according to the2 Cro. 62, 371, 416. intent of the Parties a Will is to be interpreted.

'Tis plain then that the Devi≈øor never intended the Defendant an E≈øtate for Life ab≈øolutely, becau≈øe it was to depend upon a Limitation, and the Words are expre≈øs to that purpo≈øe, for he devi≈øes to him during his Exile, &c.
Now the Que≈øtion is not ≈øo much what is the genuine and proper ≈øence and ≈øignification of tho≈øe Words, as what the Te≈øtator intended they ≈øhould ≈øignifie.

1. Therefore the mo≈øt proper ≈øignification of the Word Exile, is a penal Prohibiting a per≈øon from his Native Country; and that is ≈øometimes by Iudgment or Edict, as in the ca≈øe of an Act of Parliament; and ≈øometimes 'tis cho≈øen to e≈øcape a greater Puni≈øhment, as in ca≈øes of Abjuration and Tran≈øportation, &c.

But he did not think that the Te≈øtator took the Word Exile in this re≈øtrained ≈øen≈øe, for Dr. Vo≈ø≈øius was never formally or ≈øolemnly Bani≈øhed; if that ≈øhould be the ≈øen≈øe of the Word then nothing would pa≈øs to the Doctor by this Will, becau≈øe the Limitation would be void; and like to the Ca≈øe of a Devi≈øe to a Married Woman durante viduitate, and ≈øhe dies in the life-time of her Husband; or to a Woman Sole during her Coverture, or of a Devi≈øe to A. the Remainder to the right Heis of B. and A. dies living B, ≈øo that this could not be his meaning.

2. The Word Exile in common parlance is taken only for ab≈øence from ones Native Country; but this is a very improper ≈øignification of the Word, and nothing but a Catachre≈øis can ju≈øtifie it; and therefore the Te≈øtator could not intend it in this ≈øen≈øe; 'tis too loo≈øe and incon≈øiderable an Interpretation of the Word for the Iudgment of the Court to depend on, unle≈øs there were circum≈øtantial Proofs, amounting almo≈øt to a Demon≈øtration that it was thus meant: But it plainly appears by the following Words this was not the meaning of the Te≈øtator, for 'tis ≈øaid, If it plea≈øe God to re≈øtore him to his Country; which ≈øhews that there was ≈øome Providence or other which ob≈øtructed his return thither, and ≈øo could not barely intend a voluntary ab≈øence; for if ≈øo, he might have expre≈ø≈øed it; viz. during his ab≈øence from his Country, or till his return thither, or whil≈øt he ≈øhould ≈øtay in England, and not in ≈øuch doubtful Words.

3. By the Word Exile is meant a per≈øons lying under the di≈øplea≈øure of the Government where he was born, or of ≈øome great per≈øons who have an Influence upon the Government, or have an Authority over him; which makes him think convenient (con≈øidering ≈øuch circum≈øtances) to withdraw him≈øelf, and retire to ≈øome other place; and this is a ≈øen≈øe of the Word between both the former, and even in the Common Law we are not ≈øtrangers to the acceptation of the Word in that ≈øen≈øe. There is a Ca≈øe omni exceptione major in the Writ of Wa≈øte, which is, fecit va≈øtum de domibus, venditionem de bo≈øcis, & exilium de hominibus, 'tis in the Regi≈øter, and in the Writ on the Statute of Marlebridge cap. 24. where by the exilium de hominibus is meant the hard u≈øage of Tenants, or the menacing of them, whereby they flie from their Habitations, 2 H. 6. 11.

'Tis found in this Ca≈øe that the Defendant was under the di≈øplea≈øure of his Governours, the War broke out, and therefore it might not then be ≈øafe for him to return; and for that rea≈øon he might think it ≈øafe for him≈øelf to abide here, and this Dr. Brown the Te≈øtator might know, which might al≈øo be the rea≈øon of making the Will.

But now all acts of Ho≈øtility are pa≈øt, and ≈øo the Defendants rece≈øs is open, and it hath plea≈øed God to re≈øtore the Doctor, but he is not plea≈øed to re≈øtore him≈øelf, for the Iury find he is not returned; now if a Man hath an E≈øtate under ≈øuch a Limitation to do a thing which may be done when it plea≈øeth the party; in ≈øuch ca≈øe if he neglect or refu≈øe to do the thing, the E≈øtate is determined, 15 H. 7. 1.

If I grant a Man an Annuity till he be promoted to a Benefice, and I provide a Pre≈øentation for him, and he will not be In≈øtituted and Inducted, the Annuity cea≈øes; ≈øo ≈øhall the E≈øtate in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe the Devi≈øor ≈øeems to appoint it to the Defendant till he may return.
Ex parte Def.Mr. Holt contra, held that the E≈øtate is not determined, but had a continuance ≈øtill. In his Argument he con≈øidered the≈øe four things.
1. Whether upon Dr. Vo≈ø≈øius's coming into England (being under the di≈øplea≈øure of the Government where he was born) he was an Exile.

And he held that he was an Exile, which Word in plainne≈øs of Speech, doth not only concern a per≈øon prohibited to live in his Native Country, by act of State, but one who leaves his Country upon other occa≈øions; and Calvin the Civilian in his Lexicon tells us, That an Exile is one qui extra ≈øolum habitat, and in all the de≈øcriptions of exilium 'tis divided into voluntary and involuntary; Plutarch and Livy u≈øe it in the ≈øen≈øe of a voluntary leaving of a Native Country, where 'tis ≈øaid of Petrellus in voluntarium profectus e≈øt exilium.

If a Man leaves his Country upon the di≈øplea≈øure of the Governours, or fearing any Danger of Life, or even upon the Lo≈øs of his Livelyhood, this is little different from involuntary Exile, and this is the Ca≈øe of the Defendant; who, though he is not prohibited to continue in ≈øuch Exile, yet he is di≈øabled to return, and though he is not puni≈øhed for ≈øtaying, yet if he return, he is in danger of being ≈øtarved.

As for the Ca≈øe of exilium de hominibus, it makes for the Defendants purpo≈øe, for in the 1 In≈øt. 53. b. 'tis ≈øaid, if Tenants be impoveri≈øhed, that is an Exilium, and have not the States taken away the Doctors Livelyhood and impoveri≈øhed him as much as they can? and therefore he had good cau≈øe to ≈øeek relief el≈øewhere.

Now the ≈øame cau≈øe continues ≈øtill, for 'tis not found by the ≈øpecial Verdict that there was any reconciliation betw√©en the States and him, or that he may have his Pen≈øion again, if he ≈øhould return, but on the contrary, that 'tis di≈øpo≈øed of to another; and 'tis apparent that there was a great Friend≈øhip between the Te≈øtator and the Defendant, who took notice of the Circum≈øtances of Dr. Vo≈ø≈øius's condition at that time, which is in no ≈øort altered from what it was at the time of the making of the Will; ≈øo that by the Word re≈øtored nothing el≈øe could be intended by Dr. Brown, than when his Friend ≈øhould have the favour of the States, and a comfortable ≈øub≈øi≈øtence in his own Country.

2. Dr. Vo≈ø≈øius is not to be con≈øidered with any relation to the War, becau≈øe he came into England before the War proclaimed; neither doth it appear by the ≈øpecial Verdict that he was any wi≈øe concerned in it: If a Subject of England go into Holland, and a War break out, 'tis no re≈øtraint of his per≈øon if he be not active in it, for he may return as he hath opportunity ≈øo to do.

3. Admitting Dr. Vo≈ø≈øius to be concerned in the War, yet the Peace en≈øuing can be no Re≈øtitution of him to his Country, that only extingui≈øhes the Ho≈øtility between the two Nations, and doth not re≈øtore the Doctor, who during the War adhered to the King of England, and ≈øo was a Rebel to the States; and for that rea≈øon a Peace ≈øhall not extend to pardon him.

4. Admitting the Doctor to be no Exile, then the Limitation in the Will is void, and a void Limitation is like a void Condition, and then the E≈øtate is ab≈øolute in him; if it had been a Condition precedent, as a Devi≈øe to him in ca≈øe he was not an Exile, that had prevented the ve≈øting of the E≈øtate; but if the ≈øub≈øequent Limitation be impo≈ø≈øible, they mu≈øt ≈øhew on the other ≈øide that the E≈øtate is determined.

Rainsford Chief Iu≈øtice was clear of Opinion, that the E≈øtate doth continue in the Defendant by this Limitation, until the Circum≈øtances of his Ca≈øe, (as to the Favour of the States, and the offer of his Pen≈øion, or ≈øome competent way of Livelyhood) differ from what they did at the time of the making of the Will; and it doth not appear that there was any alteration of his Condition, nor any expectation of a Pen≈øion from the States now, more than he had at that time.
Whereupon in Michaelmas-Term following Iudgment was given for the Defendant Vo≈ø≈øius by the Opinion of the whole Court of King's Bench.

div.head: Strangford ver≈øus Green.
div.p:
IN an Action on the Ca≈øe for Non-performance of an Award;Award that all Suits ≈øhall cea≈øe amounts to a Relea≈øe. the Defendant having in behalf of him≈øelf and his Partner, referred all Differences and Controver≈øies between the Plaintiff and them to Arbitrators, and promi≈øed to perform their Award; which was, that all Suits which are pro≈øecuted by the Plaintiff again≈øt the Defendant ≈øhall cea≈øe, and that he ≈øhall pay the Plaintiff ≈øo much, &c. And for Non-payment this Action was
brought upon this ≈øpecial Declaration, to which the Defendant did demurr.
2 Cro. 639, 6631. Becau≈øe the Submi≈ø≈øion was only of Matters concerning the Partner≈øhip, and the Award was that all Suits ≈øhall cea≈øe.
2. It was of all Matters between the Plaintiff and the Partner, and the Award is, that all Suits pro≈øecuted again≈øt the Defendant only ≈øhall cea≈øe.
3. The Award is not mutual; for the Defendant is to pay Mony, but the Plaintiff is to give no Relea≈øe, 'tis only ≈øaid that all Suits ≈øhall cea≈øe.
4. The other Partner is not made a Party to the Submi≈ø≈øion.

2 Cro. 663.But the≈øe Exceptions were not allowed; for no difference ≈øhall be intended but what concerned the Plaintiff and the Defendant, as the Defendant was concerned with his Partner in Trade only, unle≈øs the contrary did appear; and if any ≈øuch were they ≈øhould be ≈øhewn on the other ≈øide.

And it ≈øhall be intended likewi≈øe that all Suits ≈øhall cea≈øe only between the Plaintiff and the Defendant, and that was an Award on both ≈øides; for the awarding that all Suits ≈øhall cea≈øe hath the effect of a Relea≈øe, and the Submi≈ø≈øion and Award may be pleaded in di≈øcharge as well as a Relea≈øe; and likewi≈øe the Defendant may undertake for his Partner, and having engaged for him and promi≈øed that he ≈øhould perform the Award on his part (notwith≈øtanding the Partner is not bound ≈øo to do,) yet if he refu≈øe 'tis a Breach of the Defendants promi≈øe, and ≈øo the Plaintiff had Iudgment upon the fir≈øt Argument.

div.head: Sir John Shaw again≈øt a Burge≈øs of Colche≈øter.
div.p: THIS was upon a Tryal at the Barr wherein the Ca≈øe was this, viz. The Plaintiff was a Serjeant at Law and Recorder of Colche≈øter, and the Defendants re≈øolving to turn him out, procured Articles of Misdemeanour to be drawn again≈øt him, and then all who had liberty to vote proceeded to vote for and again≈øt him, and a Poll was granted to decide the Controver≈øie, it not appearing upon the View which had the Majority of Votes; but before the Plaintiff had taken all the Names, and whil≈øt he was taking of the Poll the Defendants took away the Paper, and would not ≈øuffer him to proceed; the Iury gave him 300 l. damages.

div.head: Trotter ver≈øus Blake. In Scaccario.
div.p: THIS was the Ca≈øe of my Lord Hollis upon a Tryal at the Barr in the Exchequer in an Ejectione firmae, Ejectment will not lie for a Forfeiture where the Tenant refu≈øed to pay a Fine being doubtful. wherein the Ca≈øe was this, viz.

The Lord Hollis was ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of Aldenham in the County of Hartford in Fee, and the Lands in que≈øtion were held of the ≈øaid Lord by Copy of Court Roll, and are parcel of the afore≈øaid Mannor.

That the Defendant was admitted Tenant, and a Fine of 8 l. impo≈øed upon him for ≈øuch admittance payable at three di≈øtinct payments; that the 8 l. was per≈øonally demanded of him by the Lord's Steward, and he refu≈øed payment; whereupon the Lord enters and ≈øei≈øes the E≈øtate for a Forfeiture, which he would not have in≈øi≈øted on, but that the ob≈øtinacy of the Defendant made it nece≈ø≈øary for him to a≈ø≈øert his Title and Right.

Mr. Walker, the Lord Hollis his Steward, being ≈øworn gave Evidence that a Fine of 8 l. was ≈øet upon the Defendant when he was admitted, and that the Lands to which he was admitted were u≈øually lett for 7 l. per annum, ≈øo that the Fine was but a little more than a years value: That he him≈øelf demanded the 8 l. of the Defendant being a Seafaring-man who refu≈øed to pay it. That he knew the Defendant to be the ≈øame per≈øon who was admitted to this Copyhold: That the Demand was made at the Stewards Chamber in Staple Inn, and becau≈øe it was payable at three ≈øeveral days, he then demanded of him only 2 l. 13 s. 4 d. as a third part of the 8 l. and that he did enter upon the 25th day of November la≈øt for Non-payment of the ≈øaid 2 l. 13 s. 4 d.

The Council for the Defendant in≈øi≈øted that the Steward ought to produce an Authority in Writing given to him by the Lord to make this Demand and Entry upon refu≈øal,Ex parte Def. for the Lords owning it afterwards will not make a Forfeiture.

But the Court held clearly that there was no need of an expre≈øs Authority in Writing,Curia. and that it was not nece≈ø≈øary for the Steward to make a Precept for the ≈øeizure, but that it was nece≈ø≈øary that the Demand ≈øhould be per≈øonal.

The Rea≈øon why the Defendant refu≈øed to pay this Fine was, becau≈øe he ≈øaid that by a Decree and Survey made of this Mannor in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, the Fine to be paid for this Copyhold was ≈øetled, and it was but 3 l. and no more.

And Sir Francis Winnington Solicitor General ≈øaid for the Defendant, that the Ca≈øe was very penal on his ≈øide, but that he would make it clear that there was no colour for the bringing of this Action either as to the Matter or the Form.

He ≈øaid that the Mannor of Aldenham had not been long in this noble Lord, he came in as Purcha≈øer or a Mortgagee under the Family of the Harvies who≈øe Inheritance it was anciently; and there has been ≈øome doubt whil≈øt it was in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion what Fines were cu≈øtomary to be paid upon De≈øcents and Alienations, but that is now ≈øettled, and the Defendant was in the Ca≈øe of a de≈øcent for which the Fine is not to be arbitrary at the Will of the Lord; but is reduced to a certainty in Queen Elizabeth's Reign by Con≈øent and Agreement between the Lord and Tenants; and that a Survey was then made by vertue of a Commi≈ø≈øion directed to ≈øome Men of Credit and Worth in tho≈øe days, who were impowred to ≈øet forth the quantity of Land and the value thereof, which was done accordingly; and it was then agreed that a year and an halfs value in ca≈øe of a De≈øcent, and two years value in ca≈øe of an Alienation ≈øhould be paid as a Fine to the Lord, and the proportion of the value was then computed by the Commi≈ø≈øioners, and decreed by the Court of Chancery to be binding to the Lords and Tenants for ever.

The Que≈øtion now is, how this years value ≈øhall be computed, the Lord would have it according to the improved value; the Tenant will pay according as it was rated in Queen Elizabeth's time by tho≈øe Commi≈ø≈øioners: Now if this Land had decayed in value the Tenant had ≈øtill been obliged to pay a Fine according to the valuation of that time; and if ≈øo, it would be very unrea≈øonable to make him pay for his Indu≈øtry and Improvement of the Land now it is rai≈øed in value, becau≈øe that was done by his Labour and at his expence; ≈øo that the doubt being what Fine ≈øhall be paid, an Ejectione firmae will not lie, becau≈øe the Matter is doubtful, and the Law gives the Tenant Liberty to conte≈øt it with the Lord and will never let him be under the peril of a Forfeiture becau≈øe he will not comply with the Lord to give up his Right without Law.

But the Lord hath another and a more proper remedy, for he may bring an Action of Debt for the Fine thus impo≈øed, which will try the Right; and is not ≈øo penal to the Copyholder, which Point was lately re≈øolved: And that if a Copyholder had a probable cau≈øe to induce him to believe that he ought not to pay the Fine demanded, (let the Right be as it would) yet no Ejectment will lie; for it mu≈øt be only in a plain Ca≈øe that the Lord can enter for a Forfeiture.

For no Man forfeits his E≈øtate, but by a wilful default in him≈øelf, ≈øuch a Forfeiture as is done and pre≈øumed to be committed upon his own knowledge, but want of under≈øtanding cannot be made a wilful neglect. 'Tis true, the Decree in Chancery made here cannot vary the Law, but it may be Evidence of the Fact; for prima facie it ≈øhall be intended that ≈øuch values have been paid time out of mind, becau≈øe the Court have ≈øo decreed; but then when the Fine was declared to be certain, a doubt did ari≈øe how the years value ≈øhall be reckoned, which has been ≈øetled al≈øo by another Decree, and from that time all the re≈øpective Lords of this Mannour have taken Fines according to that value which is mentioned in the Survey, and this Lord him≈øelf hath taken Fines in pur≈øuance of the ≈øame, ≈øo that 'tis clear the Fine cannot be Arbitrary; but be it ≈øo or not, 'tis not material to this purpo≈øe, becau≈øe the Tenant hath a good and colourable ground to in≈øi≈øt upon the Decree and Survey, and con≈øequently there is no wilful Forfeiture.

The Lord Chief Baron agreed, That if it be a doubt, and the Tenant gives a probable Rea≈øon to make it appear that no more is due, than what he is ready to pay, 'tis no Forfeiture; but the Law in general pre≈øumes that the Fine is incertain, if the contrary is not ≈øhewed; now if the Tenants doubt did ari≈øe upon the equitablene≈øs of the Fine, in ≈øuch ca≈øe if he refu≈øe to pay, 'tis a Forfeiture; but here it was whether it ≈øhall be paid according to the computed or improved value, and therefore he inclined that the Action would not lie.

The Exemplification of the Decree was offered to be read, which being oppo≈øed, Serjeant Maynard informed the Court that nothing was more u≈øual, than to read a Sentence in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, or a Decree in Chancery as Evidence of the Fact: It being allowed to be read, the Council for the Defendant took notice that the Commi≈ø≈øion was therein mentioned which was returned into Chancery, and burned when the Six Clerks Office was on fire, in the year 1618. but a Duplicate thereof was produced which the Defendant had from the Heir of the Harveys, and ≈øo the Survey was praied to be read, which was opop≈øed by Sir William Jones, for he ≈øaid that it was no Duplicate, the Commi≈ø≈øioners Names being all written with one Hand, and no proof being made that it was a true Copy of that which was returned; he likewi≈øe ob≈øerved upon the reading of the Decree, that it was an Evidence for the Plaintiff, becau≈øe if there had been a ≈øetled Rule for payment of the Fines, there had been no occa≈øion to ≈øeek relief in Equity, and that there
was no rea≈øon that the Defendant ≈øhould come into a Court of Law to prove ≈øuch Settlement by a Decree in Chancery, for if there be ≈øuch a Decree his Remedy is proper there; be≈øides, the Decree it ≈øelf only mentions the years value, which was to be ≈øetled by the Commi≈ø≈øioners, and which he ≈øaid was never done, ≈øo that the Decree which appointed the Commi≈ø≈øion was not compleated, and therefore being but executory, is of no force even in Equity.

The Court were doubtful in the matter, and Baron Thurland ≈øaid, That no Action of Debt would lie for this Fine, becau≈øe it was neither upon the Contract, nor as ex qua≈øi contractu: But as to that Serjeant Maynard an≈øwered, That many Re≈øolutions had been made in his time of Ca≈øes, wherein the Old Books were ≈øilent.
Vpon the whole, the Court thought this to be a proper Ca≈øe for Equity, and ≈øo directed a Iurour to be withdrawn, which was accordingly done.

div.head: DE Term. Sanctae Trin. Anno 29 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Addi≈øon ver≈øus Sir John Otway.
div.p: IN a ≈øpecial Verdict in Ejectione firmae, A Pari≈øh and a Vill within the Pari≈øh of the ≈øame Name; a Recovery is ≈øuffered of Lands in the Vill, and in the Deed to lead the U≈øes, the Pari≈øh is named, they make but one Conveyance, and the Lands in the Pari≈øh do pa≈øs. Mod. Rep. 250. the Ca≈øe was thus, Viz. There was the Vill of Rippon, and the Pari≈øh of the ≈øame Name; and likewi≈øe the Vill of Kirkby, and the Pari≈øh of the ≈øame Name in the County of York. And Thomas Brathwaite being Tenant in Tail of the Lands in que≈øtion, lying in the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes of Rippon and Kirkby; did by Bargain and Sale convey the ≈øame, lying (as in truth they did) in the Pari≈øhes of Rippon and Kirkby, to the intent to make a Tenant to the Praecipe in order to ≈øuffer a Common Recovery, and thereby he did Covenant to ≈øuffer the ≈øame, which Recovery was afterwards ≈øuffered of Lands in Rippon and Kirkby, but doth not ≈øay (as he ought) in the Pari≈øhes of Rippon and Kirkby; and the Verdict in effect found, That he had no Lands in the Vills; but farther, that it was the intent of the Parties, that the Lands in the Pari≈øhes ≈øhould pa≈øs; and whether they ≈øhould or not was the Que≈øtion?
It was ≈øaid for the Defendant, That by this Indenture and Common Recovery the Lands which lie in the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes ≈øhall pa≈øs.

1. Suppo≈øing this to be in the Ca≈øe of a Grant, there if the Vill is only named, yet the Lands in the Pari≈øh of the ≈øame Name ≈øhall pa≈øs, becau≈øe the Grant of every Man ≈øhall be taken ≈øtronge≈øt again≈øt him≈øelf, Owen Rep. 61.

So where part of the Lands lie in B. and the Grant is of all the Lands in D. all the Lands in the Pari≈øh of D. ≈øhall pa≈øs, becau≈øe in that Ca≈øe the Pari≈øh ≈øhall be intended; and if the
Law be thus in a Grant a fortiori in the Ca≈øe of a Common Recovery,Po≈øtea Barker and Keat. which is the Common A≈ø≈øurance of the Land.

2. The Verdict hath found that the Defendant had no Lands in the Vills of Rippon and Kirkby, and the Court will not intend that he had any there, if not found; ≈øo that nothing pa≈ø≈øes by the Recovery, if the Lands in the Pari≈øhes do not pa≈øs, which is contrary to the intention of the Parties, and to the Rules of Law in the like Ca≈øes; for if a Man devi≈øeth all his Lands in Dale, and hath both Free-hold and Lea≈øe-hold there, by this Devi≈øe the Freehold only pa≈ø≈øes, but if no Free-hold the Lea≈øes ≈øhall pa≈øs, Cro. Car. 293. So adjudged in the Ca≈øe of Ro≈øe and Bartlet, for otherwi≈øe the Will would be void.

3. The Pari≈øh and Vill ≈øhall be both intended to ≈øupport a Trial already had; as where a Venire facias ought to i≈ø≈øue from the Pari≈øh of Dale, and it was awarded from Dale generally, 'tis well enough,1 Roll. Rep. 21, 27, 293. Hob. 6. 2 Cro. 263. 1 Roll. Rep. 27. A fortiori to ≈øupport a Common Recovery, which has always been favourably interpreted, and yet a new Tryal will help in the one ca≈øe, but a Man cannot command a new Recovery when he will; and therefore the Iudges u≈øually give Iudgments to ≈øupport and maintain Common Recoveries, that the Inheritances of the Subject might be pre≈øerved; for if there be Tenant in Tail, the Rever≈øion in Fee, or if Baron and Feme ≈øuffer a Recovery, this is a bar of the Rever≈øion, and the Dower, and yet the intended Recompence could not go to either, Pl. Com. 515. 2 Roll. Rep. 67. 5 Co. Dormer's Ca≈øe.

5. The Lands in the Pari≈øhes pa≈øs,1 Ander≈ø. 83. becau≈øe the Deed and Common Recovery make but one Conveyance and A≈ø≈øurance in the Law; and therefore as a Con≈øtruction is not to be made upon part, but upon the whole Deed, ≈øo not upon the Deed or Recovery alone, but upon both together, 2 Co. 75. Lord Cromwel's Ca≈øe.

6. Antea. 'Tis the Agreement of the Parties which governs Fines and Recoveries, and Lands ≈øhall pa≈øs by ≈øuch Names as are agreed between them, though ≈øuch Names are not proper; and therefore a Fine of a lieu conus is good, though neither Vill or Pari≈øh is named therein, Poph. 22. 1 Cro. 270, 276, 693. 2 Cro. 574.

So if a Fine be levied of a Common of Pa≈øture in Dale, Cro. Car. 308. Winch 122. Sid. 190, 191. Antea. 'tis good, though Dale be neither Vill or Hamlet, or lieu conus out of a Vill 2 Roll. Abr. f. 19. So in Sir George Symonds his Ca≈øe, Lands as parcel of a Mannor were adjudged to pa≈øs, though in truth they were u≈øed with the Manor but two years; and the rea≈øon of all the≈øe Ca≈øes is becau≈øe it was the Agreement of the Parties that they ≈øhould pa≈øs.
Object. If it be objected, That all the≈øe Authorities are in Ca≈øes of Fines, but the Ca≈øe at Bar is in a Common Recovery, which makes a great difference.

An≈øw. The proceedings in both are amicable, and not adver≈øary, and therefore as to this purpo≈øe there is no difference between them, and for an Authority in the point, the Ca≈øe of Lever and Ho≈øier was cited, which was adjudged in this Court, Trin. 27 Car. 2 Where the Que≈øtion was,Antea. whether upon a Common Recovery ≈øuffered of Lands in the Town of Sale or the Liberty thereof, Lands lying in Dale, being a di≈øtinct Vill, in the Pari≈øh of Sale ≈øhould pa≈øs or not; and after divers Arguments it was allowed to be well enough, being in the Ca≈øe of a Common Recovery: And ≈øo was the Ca≈øe, Pa≈øch. 16 Car. 2. in B. R. In a ≈øpecial Verdict the Ca≈øe was, That Sir Thomas Thinn being ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of Buckland in Tail, and of twenty Acres of Land, called and known by a particular name, which twenty Acres of Land were in Ed. the 6th's time reputed parcel of the ≈øaid Mannor, and always u≈øed with it;Sid. 190. ≈øold the ≈øaid Mannor and all the Lands reputed parcel thereof, with the Appurtenances, of which he did ≈øuffer a Common Recovery; and it was adjudged upon great con≈øideration, that though the Recovery did not mention the twenty Acres particularly, yet it did
dock the Entail thereof, becau≈øe the Indenture which leads the V≈øes of the Recovery was of the Lands reputed parcel thereof, or enjoyed with it, and that the ≈øhortne≈øs in the Recovery was well ≈øupplied by the Deed; in which Ca≈øe the Court were guided by the re≈øolution in Sir George Symond's Ca≈øe. Vide 6 Co. Sir Moyle Finch's Ca≈øe.
The Authorities again≈øt this Opinion are two.

Antea, Lever and Ho≈øie ‚Ä¢
1. That of Stock ver≈øus Fox, Cro. Jac. 120. There were two Vills, Walton and Street in the Pari≈øh of Street, and a Fine was levied of Lands in Street; it was adjudged that the Lands in Walton did not pa≈øs by this Fine.

But there is another Report of this very Ca≈øe, by my Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Roll in his Abr. tit. Grants 54. where 'tis ≈øaid, if there be in the County of Somer≈øet the Vill of Street, and the Vill of Waltham within the Pari≈øh of Street, and a Man being ≈øei≈øed of Lands in the Vill of Street, and of other Lands in the Vill of Waltham, all within the Pari≈øh of Street; and he Bargains and Sells all his Lands in Street, and having Covenanted to levie a Fine, doth accordingly levie it of Lands in Street, and doth not mention either in the Indenture or in the Fine any Lands in Waltham, the Lands lying there ≈øhall not pa≈øs; from which Report there may be a fair Inference made, That it was the Lord Rolls his Opinion, that if Waltham had been named in the Indenture, though not in the Fine, the Lands would have pa≈ø≈øed; and in this Ca≈øe the Pari≈øhes are named in the Indenture of Bargain and Sale; but be≈øides in that Ca≈øe the Party had Lands both in Street and Waltham, and ≈øo the Conveyances were not in vain, as they mu≈øt be here if the Lands in the Pari≈øhes do not pa≈øs.
Antea. 2. The other Ca≈øe is that of Baker and John≈øon in Hutton 106.

But this Ca≈øe is quite different from that, becau≈øe there was neither Vill or Pari≈øh named in the Indenture; but here the Indenture was right, for the Lands are mentioned therein to lie in the Pari≈øhes, &c. And for the≈øe Rea≈øons Iudgment was prayed for the Defendant.
This Ca≈øe was afterwards argued in Michaelmas-Term following, by Serjeant Pemberton and Maynard for the Plaintiff, who ≈øaid,

Ex parte Quer.That the Government of this Nation was Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Civil; the Eccle≈øia≈øtical runs by Pari≈øhes, and the Civil by Vills; That a Pari≈øh is con≈øtituted by the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Power, and may be altered by the King and Ordinary of the place, that the Par≈øon was ≈øuperintendent of the Pari≈øh, and the Con≈øtable of the Vill, which was al≈øo con≈øtituted by the Civil Magi≈øtrate;
and from hence it is, that in real Actions which are adver≈øary, Lands ought not to be demanded as lying in a Pari≈øh, but within a Vill, that being the place known to the Civil Iurisdiction; and if a Tre≈øpa≈øs which is local be laid at Dale generally, there being both the Pari≈øh and Vill of Dale, the proof of the Tre≈øpa≈øs done in the Pari≈øh is not good, for it mu≈øt be at the Vil.

They agreed, that in conveying of Lands a Fine or Common Recovery of Lands in a Pari≈øh or Lieu conus was good, 2 Cro. 574. But if there be both a Vill and a Pari≈øh of the ≈øame Name and ≈øeverally bounded, if the Vill be only named without the Pari≈øh, nothing doth pa≈øs, but what is in the Vill, becau≈øe where a place is alledged in Pleading it mu≈øt be of a Vill, Moor 710. 1 In≈øt. 125. b. 2 Cro. 121.

And this was the ancient way of demanding Lands in a Praecipe quod reddat, becau≈øe of the Notoriety of Vills from whence Vi≈ønes do ari≈øe; and becau≈øe the Vill is more particular and of more certainty than a Pari≈øh, and therefore 'tis requi≈øite that the Demandant ≈øhould be very particular in his Demand, that the Tenant may know how to make his defence, and the Sheriff of what to deliver po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

Be≈øides a Vill is more ancient than a Pari≈øh, and Lands have been demanded within them time out of mind, ≈øo that the Demand (when 'tis doubtful of what 'tis made) ≈øhall be ≈øuppo≈øed of that which is mo≈øt ancient; and ≈øuch Con≈øtruction is mo≈øt conformable to the like Ca≈øes, for Additio probat Minoritatem; and therefore if Father and Son are both of one Name, and mention is made of one without an addition of Junior the Law intends the Father; ≈øo the Vill being more ancient than the Pari≈øh, that ≈øhall be intended if the Pari≈øh is not named.

In 2 Ander≈øon 124. Hartwel, Rode and A≈øhen were ≈øeveral Vills in the Pari≈øh of Rode, the King granted all his Tythes in Rode and A≈øhen in tenura Richardi Wake, and at the time of the Grant the Tythes of Hartwel were in the Tenure of Wake; it was adjudged in the King's Bench that the Tythes in Hartwel did pa≈øs, but that Iudgment was rever≈øed in the Exchequer Chamber, becau≈øe Rode could not beIn a Praecipe it mu≈øt be intended a Vill if a Pari≈øh be not named, becau≈øe Vills are known at the Common Law, but not Pari≈øhes, tho≈øe were con≈øtituted by the Council of Lyons, but 'tis otherwi≈øe in Grants. Owen 61. intended a Pari≈øh and ≈øo to comprehend Hartwel, but mu≈øt be intended a Vill di≈øtinct from a Pari≈øh; and ≈øo the Tythes of Hartwel being al≈øo a Vill could not pa≈øs by the Grant of them in Rode; this al≈øo was the Opinion of Popham, Owen 60. But Gawdy and Fenner were of another Opinion.

As to the finding of the Iury, that doth not help if the Recovery be not full, for they may expound, but they cannot enlarge
each other; In a Formedon, nient compri≈øe in the Record and not what is compri≈øed in the Deed is the Plea. Things upon a Record are open to the View of all People, but a Deed is a Pocket Record, and the per≈øons whom it concerneth cannot come at the ≈øight of it; ≈øo Fines are open and to be ≈øeen by all, and are to be proclaimed, but according to this Interpretation D√©eds ≈øhould be al≈øo proclaimed.

And there is a manife≈øt difference between things conteined in a Fine and in a D√©ed; for a Fine of a Tenement is not good, but a Deed of a Tenement is well enough, but will not help the Fine; and therefore Men ≈øhould not go out of the Rules of the Law to help a Mi≈øtake: For which Rea≈øons they prayed Iudgment for the Plaintiff.

But the whole Court were of Opinion that the Lands in the Pari≈øhes did well pa≈øs; for as Fines and Recoveries did grow in u≈øe, and are now become Common A≈ø≈øurances, they are to be favoured in the Law: And it hath been a Rule, that even in doubtful things Con≈øtructions ≈øhall be made to ≈øupport a Deed if po≈ø≈øible, Ut res magis valeat quam pereat, Co. Lit. 183.
By Rippon generally the Vill ≈øhall be intended, but ≈øtabitur prae≈øumptio donec probetur in contrarium, and that is proved by the Deed which ≈øhews where the Lands lye.

Indenture by an Infant to declare U≈øes of a Fine or Recovery, make but one Conveyance, otherwi≈øe he might avoid it as he may a Deed by Infancy. Hob. f. 6. 2 Cro. 676Both the Indenture and Recovery being one Conveyance, mu≈øt be expounded ≈øo that every part may ≈øtand; be≈øides 'tis apparent by the intent of the Parties (which the Iury have al≈øo found) that the Lands in the Pari≈øhes ≈øhould pa≈øs.

In the Ca≈øe of Brock and Spencer a Tre≈øpa≈øs was laid in Hur≈øly, and it was not ≈øaid whether Vill or Pari≈øh; the Defendant pleaded that the Lands were held of the Mannor of Marden in the Pari≈øh of Hur≈øley, &c. and the Venire Facias was de Vicineto only, and not de Vicineto Parochiae Hur≈øley, and it was adjudged good, for the Vill and the Pari≈øh ≈øhall be under≈øtood to be the ≈øame.
