And as to this purpo≈øe they were all of Opinion that there was no difference between a Fine and Recovery; 'tis true, the Law originally took notice of a Vill only, becau≈øe the divi≈øion of a County into Pari≈øhes was of Eccle≈øia≈øtical di≈øtribution; but now by proce≈øs of time that di≈øtinction is taken notice of in in Civil Affairs; and the Law hath great regard to the V≈øage and Practice of the People, the Law it ≈øelf being nothing el≈øe but common V≈øage, with which it complies, and alters with the exigency of Affairs; it was but lately that the Cur≈øitors would put the Word Pari≈øh into a Writ; for if a Note was delivered
to them of Lands in the Pari≈øh of Dale, they u≈øed always to make it of Lands in Dale, till the Court ordered them to do otherwi≈øe; ≈øo that though the Common V≈øage was ≈øo formerly 'tis now otherwi≈øe, and the Rea≈øon of things changing the things them≈øelves al≈øo change.

And if this Recovery ≈øhould not be con≈øtrued to pa≈øs the Lands, the intention of the Parties would faile; 'tis true there is no Authority expre≈øs in the point to guide this Iudgment, nor is there any again≈øt it; but if ≈øuch ≈øhould be, the Opinion of the Court is not to be bound again≈øt apparent Right; and 'tis for the honour of the Law that Men ≈øhould enjoy their Bargains according as they intended; for which Rea≈øons Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Goffe ver≈øus Elkin.
div.p: THE Condition of a Bond was,Affirmative Plea where it ought to be particular, where not. That if the Plaintiff ≈øhall ≈øeal to the Defendant a good and ≈øufficient Conveyance in the Law of his Lands in Jamaica, with u≈øual Covenants in ≈øuch manner as by the Defendants Council ≈øhall be advi≈øed; then if the Defendant ≈øhould thereupon pay unto the Plaintiff ≈øuch a Sum of Mony, &c. the Condition ≈øhould be void: In Debt brought upon this Bond, the Defendant (after Dyer of the Condition) pleads that Mr. Wade a Councellor at Law, did advi≈øe a Deed of Bargain and Sale from the Plaintiff to the Defendant with the u≈øual Covenants, of all his Lands in Jamaica, and tendred the Conveyance to the Plaintiff, who refu≈øed to ≈øeal the ≈øame, and ≈øo would di≈øcharge him≈øelf of the Condition, the Mony being not to be paid unle≈øs the A≈ø≈øurance made.
To this Plea the Plaintiff demurred by Serjeant George Strode.

1. Becau≈øe the Defendant hath not ≈øhewed the Conveyance, and an affirmative Plea ought to be particular, and not ≈øo general as this; for to plead generally quod exoneravit is not good, but it mu≈øt be ≈øhewed how; and ≈øo it was adjudged in the Ca≈øe of2 Cro. 165, 359, 363, 503, 634. Sid. 106. 2 Co. 4. a. Cro. Car. 383, 384. 2 Leon. 214. Hor≈øeman and Obbius, where the Condition was to indempnifie Lands from the yearly Rent of 20 l. during the Demi≈øe; the Defendant pleaded quod √† tempore confectionis ≈øcripti obligatorii hucu≈øque exoneravit, &c. And upon Demurrer as here, it was held no good Plea.

2. The Matter of the Condition con≈øi≈øts both of Law and Fact, and both ought to be ≈øet out; the preparing of the Deed is Matter of Fact, and the Rea≈øonablene≈øs and Validity thereof is Matter of Law, and therefore they ought to be ≈øet forth that the Court may judge thereof.

Hob. 107.In 22 E. 4.40. The Condition of a Bond was, that the Defendant ≈øhould ≈øhew the Plaintiff a ≈øufficient di≈øcharge of an Annuity, who pleaded that he tendered a good and ≈øufficient di≈øcharge in general without ≈øetting it forth; it was not good.
Mod. Rep. 67.3. The Plea is, that the Indenture had the u≈øual Covenants, but doth not ≈øet them forth, and for that cau≈øe 'tis al≈øo too general.

In 26 H. 8. 1. The Condition was for the performance of Covenants, one whereof was, that he ≈øhould make ≈øuch an E≈øtate to the Plaintiff as his Council ≈øhould advi≈øe: The Defendant pleaded that he did make ≈øuch Conveiance as the Council of the Plaintiff did advi≈øe, and the Plea was held ill and too general, becau≈øe he ≈øhewed not the Nature of the Conveyance, and yet performance was pleaded according to the Covenant.

But notwith≈øtanding the≈øe Exceptions the whole Court were of Opinion that this Plea was good; for if the Defendant had ≈øet forth the whole Deed verbatim, yet becau≈øe the Lands are in Jamaica, and the Covenants are intended ≈øuch as are u≈øual there, the Court cannot judge of them, but they mu≈øt be tried by the Iury.

He hath ≈øet forth that the Conveyance was by a Deed of Bargain and Sale, which is well enough; and ≈øo it had been if by Grant, becau≈øe the Lands lying in Jamaica pa≈øs by Grant, and no Livery and Sei≈øin is nece≈ø≈øary; if any Covenants were unrea≈øonable and not u≈øual they are to be ≈øhewed on the other ≈øide: And ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Spring ver≈øus Eve.
div.p:
Verdict cures the mi≈ørecital of the time of the Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament.DEBT upon the Statute of 29 Eliz. cap 4. by the Sheriff for his F√©es for ≈øerving of an Execution: After Verdict for the Plaintiff, it was moved in an arre≈øt of Iudgment by Serjeant Pemberton, becau≈øe the time of holding the Parliament was mi≈ø-recited, being mi≈øtaken in both the Statute Books of Poulton and Keble as it appeared by the Parliament Roll, whereupon Iudgment was ≈øtaied till this Term; and the Court had Copies out of the Rolls of the time when the Parliament was
held, and they were all clear of Opinion that the time was mi≈øtaken in the Declaration, and ≈øo are all the Pre≈øidents; for the Plaintiff here declared, that this Statute was made at a Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament by Prorogation held at We≈øtmin≈øter, 15 Febr. 29 Eliz. and there continued till the di≈ø≈øolution of the ≈øame; whereas in truth the Parliament began 29 Octob. and not on the 15th of February; for it was adjourned from that time to the 15th of February, and then continued till it was di≈ø≈øolved.
My Lord Coke in his 4th In≈øtitutes fol. 7. takes notice of this mi≈øtake in the printed Books.

But the Court were all of Opinion,Curia. that though it was mi≈øtaken and ought to have been otherwi≈øe, yet being afterDyer 95. Yelvert. 127. 2 Cro. 111. pl. 9. Br. Abr. tit. Parl. 87. Verdict 'tis well enough, and the rather becau≈øe this is a particular Act of Parliament, and ≈øo they are not bound to take notice of it; and therefore if it be mi≈øtaken the Defendant ought to have pleaded Nul tiel Record; but ≈øince he hath admitted it by Pleading they will intend that there is ≈øuch a Statute as the Plaintiff hath alledged, and they could not judicially take notice of the contrary.

The Serjeant perceiving the Opinion of the Court de≈øired time to ≈øpeak to it being a new Point, and told the Court that they ought to take notice of the Commencement of private Acts, which the whole Court denyed.

And the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that they were not bound to take notice of the Commencement of a general Act, for the Court was only to expound it; and though this had not been in the Ca≈øe of a particular Act (where 'tis clear the Defendant ought to plead Nul tiel record) yet being after Verdict 'tis well enough, becau≈øe the Party took no benefit of it upon the Demurrer, and becau≈øe of the multiplicity of Pre≈øidents which run that way.

So in the Ca≈øe upon the Statute of Tythes, though it be mi≈øtaken, yet it hath often been held good; as if an Action be brought upon that Statute for not ≈øetting out of Tythes, declaring quod cum quarto die Novembris anno ≈øecundo Edw. 6. It was Enacted, &c. and the Parliament began 1 Ed. 6. and was continued by Prorogation until 4 Novembris, yet this hath often been held good, and Multitudo errantium tollit peccatum.

And though in this Ca≈øe the Parliament was adjourned, but in that upon the Statute of Ed. 6. it was prorogued, yet the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that as to this purpo≈øe there was but little difference between an Adjournment and a Prorogation; for an Adjournment is properly where the Hou≈øe adjourn them≈øelves, and a Prorogation is when the King adjourns them.

But Iu≈øtice Atkins doubted whether the Court ought not to take notice of the Commencement of a general Act, and could have wi≈øhed that there had been no ≈øuch re≈øolution as there was in the Ca≈øe of Partridge and Strange in Pl. Commentaries; for that he was ≈øatisfied with the Argument of Serjeant Morgan in that Ca≈øe, who argued again≈øt that Iudgment, and held that he, who vouched a Record and varies either in the Year or Term hath failed of his Record: But ≈øince there had been ≈øo many Authoritis ≈øince in confirmation of that Ca≈øe he would ≈øay nothing again≈øt it.

But he held that there was a manife≈øt difference betw√©en an Adjournment and a Prorogation; for an Adjournment makes a Se≈ø≈øion continue; but after a Prorogation all mu≈øt begin de novo; and that an Adjournment is not always made by them≈øelves, for the Chancellor hath adjourned the Hou≈øe of P√©ers ex mandato Domini Regis; and Queen Elizabeth adjourned the Hou≈øe of Commons by Commi≈ø≈øion under the Great Seal.4 Iu≈øt. 7

div.head: Mires ver≈øus Solebay.
div.p: Servant ≈øhall not be charged in Trover for taking Goods by the Command of his Ma≈øter.IN a Special Verdict in Trover and Conver≈øion, the Ca≈øe was this, viz.

H. being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of ≈øeveral Sheep ≈øells them in a Market to Al≈øton, but did not deliver them to the Vend√©e, and afterwards in that very Market they di≈øcharge each other of this Contract, and a new Agre√©ment was made between them, which was, that Al≈øton ≈øhould drive the Sheep home and depa≈øture them till ≈øuch a time, and that during that time H. would pay him ≈øo much every Week for their Pa≈øture; and if at the end of that time (then agreed between them) Al≈øton would pay H. ≈øo much for his Sheep (being a price then al≈øo agreed on) that then Al≈øton ≈øhould have them.

Before the time was expired H. ≈øells the Sheep to the Plaintiff Mires, and afterwards Al≈øton ≈øells them to one Marwood, who brought a Replevin again≈øt the Plaintiff for taking of the Sheep; and the Officers together with Solebay the Defendant (who was
Servant to Marwood) did by his Order, and in a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Officers drive the Sheep to Marwood's Grounds where they left them.
The Plaintiff demands the Sheep of Solebay, and upon his refu≈øal to deliver them, brings this Action again≈øt the Servant, and whether it would lye or not was the Que≈øtion.

It was urged at the Barr, that the Action would not lie again≈øt the Defendant, becau≈øe he had not the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Goods at the time of the Action brought; for he pre≈øently put them into his Ma≈øters Ground: And it was ≈øaid, if A. find Goods and S. takes them away before the Action brought Trover will not lie again≈øt A. but 'tis otherwi≈øe, if he ≈øell them.

In this Ca≈øe it would have been a Breach of Tru≈øt in the Servant to have delivered the Goods belonging to his Ma≈øter, to another: 'Tis true, if there be a Conver≈øion, though the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion be removed before the Action brought, yet the Action will lie, but that is becau≈øe of the Conver≈øion.

Many Ca≈øes were put where the Servant is not lyable to an Action for a thing done by the Command of his Ma≈øter; and where a Bayliff, who is but a Servant to the Sheriff, ≈øhall not be charged in a fal≈øe Return made by his Ma≈øter, Cro. Eliz. 181. 1 Roll. Abr. 94, 95. So if a Smiths Man prick an Hor≈øe, the Action lies again≈øt the Ma≈øter and not again≈øt the Servant.
The Court before they delivered any Iudgment in this Ca≈øe premi≈øed the≈øe two things: viz.

1. That 'tis nece≈ø≈øary in Trover to prove a Property in the Plaintiff, and a Trover and Conver≈øion in the Defendant: And it was ≈øaid by Iu≈øtice Atkins (but denied by the Chief Iu≈øtice) that though Goods are ≈øold in a Market, yet the property is not changed till the delivery, for which he cited Keilway 59, 77.

But the Court held clearly in this Ca≈øe, that the fir≈øt Sale to Al≈øton was defeated by the Agreement of the Parties afterwards; for when a Bargain is made, and all the Parties con≈øent to di≈ø≈øolve it, and other Conditions are propo≈øed, the new Agreement de≈øtroys the former Bargain. And the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that if an Hor≈øe was bought in a Market, for which the Vende√© is to pay 10 l. if the ready Mony be not paid the property is not altered, but the Party may ≈øell him to another.

2. This new Agr√©ement to have the Sheep, if Al≈øton would pay ≈øuch a Sum of Mony at a future day, will not amount to a Sale, and the new property is changed, and con≈øequently the Sale by H. to the Plaintiff before the day is good, and ≈øo the property of the Sheep is in him.
But by the Opinion of the whole Court the Action would not lie again≈øt the Defendant.

1. The Defendant could be guilty of no Conver≈øion, unle≈øs the driving the Cattle by vertue of the Replevin would make him guilty; but at that time the Sheep were in cu≈øtodia Legis, and the Law did then pre≈øerve them ≈øo that no property can be changed, and if ≈øo, then there could be no Conver≈øion.

2. The Action will not lie again≈øt the Servant, for it being in Obedience to his Ma≈øter's Command, though he had no Title, yet he ≈øhall be excu≈øed: And this Rule Iu≈øtice Scroggs ≈øaid would extend to all Ca≈øes where the Ma≈øter's Command was not to do an apparent Wrong; for if the Ma≈øter's Ca≈øe depended upon a Title, be it true or not, 'tis enough to excu≈øe the Servant; for otherwi≈øe it would be a mi≈øchievous thing, if the Servant upon all occa≈øions mu≈øt be ≈øatisfied with his Ma≈øter's Title and Right before he obey his Commands; and 'tis very requi≈øite that he ≈øhould be ≈øatisfied if an Action ≈øhould lie again≈øt him for what he doth in Obedience to his Ma≈øter: But it was ≈øaid, theWyne and Rider, antea. Servant cannot plead the Command of his Ma≈øter in Barr of a Tre≈øpa≈øs; and it was likewi≈øe ≈øaid, that in this Ca≈øe the driving of the Cattle by the Servant to the Grounds of his Ma≈øter, or a Strangers helping to drive them without being reque≈øted, is ju≈øtifiable.

3. Becau≈øe what was done by the Defendant was done in Execution of the Proce≈øs of the Law, and he might as well ju≈øtifie as the Officer; for if he forbid the Defendant to have a≈ø≈øi≈øted him, yet his a≈ø≈øi≈øting him afterwards would not have made him guilty, becau≈øe done in Execution of the Law.

4. Becau≈øe 'tis not found that the Servant did convert the Sheep to his own u≈øe; for the ≈øpecial Verdict only finds the Demand and the Refu≈øal, which is no Conver≈øion; and though 'tis an Evidence of it to a Iury, yet 'tis not Matter upon which the Court can give Iudgment of a Conver≈øion, 10 Co. 57.

And therefore the Iury ≈øhould have found the Conver≈øion as well as the Demand and Refu≈øal,2 Bul≈øtr. 313. 1 Roll. Abr. 5. like the Ca≈øe in 2 Roll. Abr. 693. In an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Rent ≈øeek, upon Nul tort pleaded the Iury found a Demand and Refu≈øal, & ≈øic di≈ø≈øei≈øivit; it was held to be no good Verdict, for the Demand ought to have been found on the Land, and ≈øhall not be ≈øo intended unle≈øs found.

The Plaintiff here hath ≈øet forth in his Declaration a Reque≈øt to deliver; then a Refu≈øal and Conver≈øion too, which ≈øhews that they ought to be found, becau≈øe di≈øtinct things; and the finding of the Demand and Refu≈øal was only a pre≈øumptive, not a conclu≈øive
proof of the conver≈øion; and if the Iury them≈øelves know that there was no conver≈øion, yet the Plaintiff hath failed in his Action; as if a Trover be brought for cutting Trees and carrying of them away, and the Iury know that though the Defendant cut them down, yet they ≈øtill lay in the Plaintiffs Clo≈øe, this is no conver≈øion.

And though it hath been ≈øtrongly in≈øi≈øted at the Bar, that the Court ≈øhall intend a conver≈øion unle≈øs the contrary appeared, and are to direct a Iury to find the demand and refu≈øal to be a conver≈øion, and the Opinion of Dodridge and Croke, in 1 Roll. Rep. 60. was much relied on, where Adams recovered again≈øt Lewis 40 l. in the Court of Exon, and three Butts of Sack were taken in Execution, and the Plaintiff depo≈øited 22 l in the Hands of the Defendent to prevent the Sale of the Sack, which was to be a pledge to return it upon reque≈øt, if the Defendant was not paid before the next Court day; the Iury found the Debt was not paid, and that no reque≈øt was made to return the Sack, but that the Plaintiff reque≈øted the Defendant to return the Mony: Yet it was held by tho≈øe two Iu≈øtices, That the Law would ≈øupply the proof of aBul≈øtr. 308. Cro. Eliz. 495. Gold≈ø. 152. Moor 460. Stiles 361. conver≈øion though it was not found, for it ≈øhall be pre≈øumed that the Mony was denied to the Plaintiff, and that the Defendant might u≈øe it him≈øelf; and becau≈øe no other proof could be made, that very denial ≈øhall be a conver≈øion in Law; ≈øo a denial of a Rent Seck after demand is a di≈ø≈øei≈øin,Pl. Com. 92. b. much more in per≈øonal Actions where the ≈øub≈øtance is found, 'tis well enough, 1 In≈øt. 282. a.

But the Court ≈øaid, That notwith≈øtanding this Authority, they would not intend a Conver≈øion, unle≈øs the Iury had found it, e≈øpecially in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe they ought to have found it to make the Servant lyable, for if the conver≈øion was to the u≈øe of his Ma≈øter, there is no colour for this Action to be brought again≈øt the Defendant, but it ought to be brought again≈øt the Ma≈øter.

Whereupon a Ve. fa. de novo was prayed to help the In≈øufficiency of the Verdict, the conver≈øion not being found; but the Court ≈øaid it was to no purpo≈øe to grant a new Tryal, unle≈øs the Plaintiff had a new Ca≈øe; and ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Bill ver≈øus Nicholl.
div.p: Variance between the Record pleaded and the Record it ≈øelf.IN an Action brought in the Court of Exchequer, the Defendant pleaded another Action depending again≈øt him for the ≈øame matter in the Common Pleas, and upon nul tiel Record replied by the Paintiff, a Day was given to bring in the Record, and when it was brought in it appeared that there was a variance between the Record in the Common Pleas, as mentioned in the Defendants Plea, and the Record it ≈øelf; for the Defendant in his Plea had alledged one Gerrard to be Attorny in≈øtead of Gardiner, who was Attorny upon Record, and whether this was a failure or not of the Record, was the que≈øtion.

It was ≈øaid on the Defendants ≈øide, that it was ≈øuch a variance, that it made it quite another Action; and on the Plaintiffs ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that an immaterial variance will not prejudice where the ≈øub≈øtance is found, 7 H. 4. 1. Bro. Failure, pl. 2. 15. Curia advi≈øare vult.

div.head: Fore≈øt qui tam, &c. ver≈øus Wire.
div.p: Action lyes in the Courts at We≈øtmin≈øter, upon the Statute of 5 Eliz. but not an Information. 3 Cro. 316.DEBT upon the Statute of 5 Eliz. cap. 4. for u≈øing the Trade of a Silk Weaver in London, not having been an Apprentice ≈øeven years; the Action was brought in this Court, and laid in London, and tried by Ni≈øi prius, and a Verdict for the Defendant; and now the Plaintiff to prevent the payment of Co≈øts, moved by Mr. Ward again≈øt his own Action, and ≈øaid, that it will not lye upon this Statute in any of the Courts of We≈øtmin≈øter; for 'tis not only to be laid (as here) in the proper County, but 'tis to be brought before the Iu≈øtices in their Se≈ø≈øions, and this is by force of the Statute made 31 Eliz. cap. 4. and 21 Jac. cap. 4. Which Enacts, That all Informations upon Penal Statutes mu≈øt be brought before the Ju≈øtices of the Peace, in the County where the Fact was committed.

But the Court were clear of2 Cro. 178. Stiles 383. By the Opinion of Rolls, Cro. Car. 112. Opinion, That the Action may be brought in any of the Courts of We≈øtmin≈øter, who have a concurring Iuri≈ødiction with the Iu≈øtices, and ≈øo they ≈øaid it hath been often re≈øolved.

div.head: Attorny General ver≈øus Al≈øton.
div.p: AN Inqui≈øition upon an Accompt ≈øtated went out to inquire what Lands one Havers had in the twentieth year of this King, or at any time ≈øince,Where the Kings Title is not precedent to that of the Ter-tenant, the Lands of his Receiver ≈øhall not be liable by the Statute of the 13th Eliz. he being the Receiver General in the Counties of Norfolk and Huntingdon.
The Iury found that he was ≈øei≈øed of ≈øuch Lands, &c. whereupon an Extent goes out to ≈øei≈øe them into the Kings Hands, for payment of 1100 l. which he owed to the King.

Al≈øton the Ter-tenant pleads that Havers was indebted to him, and that he was ≈øei≈øed of tho≈øe Lands in 20 Car. 1. which was before the Debt contracted with him, and that he became a Bankrupt likewi≈øe before he was indebted to the King, and thereupon the≈øe Lands were conveyed to the Defendant by a≈ø≈øignment from the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Bankrupcy, for the Debt due to him from Havers, ab≈øque hoc that he was ≈øei≈øed of the≈øe Lands at the time he became indebted to the King.

The Attorny General replies, That he was ≈øei≈øed of the≈øe Lands before the Commi≈ø≈øon of Bankrupcy i≈ø≈øued, and before he became a Bankrupt, and that at the time of his Sei≈øin he was Receiver, and accountable for the receipt to the King, and being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed in the 20the year of this pre≈øent King, he was found in Arrear 1100 l. for the payment whereof he was chargeable by the Statute of the 13 Eliz. cap. 4. Which ≈øubjects all the Lands of a Receiver which he hath or ≈øhall have in him during the time he remains accomptable, and ≈øo prays that the Kings Hands may not be amoved: To this the Defendant demurred.
And Sawyer for him held, that the Replication was ill both in form and Sub≈øtance.

1. It doth not appear that the Defendant continued Receiver from the time he was fir≈øt made, as it ought to be, or el≈øe that he was Receiver during his Life; for if a Man is Receiver to the King, and is not indebted but is clear, and ≈øells his Land and cea≈øes to be Receiver, and afterwards is appointed to be Receiver again, and then a Debt is contracted with the King, the former Sale is good.

2. The Replication is a departure from the Inqui≈øition, which is the Kings Title, for the Lands of which Inquiry was to be made, were ≈øuch which Havers had 20 Car. 2. And the Defendant ≈øhews that Havers was not then ≈øei≈øed thereof, but makes
a good Title to him≈øelf, by Indenture of Bargain and Sale made to him by the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Bankrupcy, and ≈øo the Attorny General cannot come again to ≈øet up a Title precedent to the Defendant, for that is a departure; 'tis enough for the Defendant that he hath avoided the Kings Title, as alledged; and though Mr. Attorny is not bound to take I≈ø≈øue upon the Traver≈øe, yet he cannot avoid waveing both the Title of the Defendant and the King, by in≈øi≈øting upon a new matter.

It was agreed, That the King had two Titles, and might either have brought his Inqui≈øition grounded upon the Debt ≈øtated, or upon the Statute of the 13th of Eliz. upon Havers his becoming Receiver; but when he hath determined his Election, by grounding it upon the Debt ≈øtated, he cannot afterwards have recour≈øe to the other matter, and bring him to be liable from the time of his being Receiver; as if an Inqui≈øition goes to inquire what Lands the Debtor of the King had ≈øuch a day when he entred into a Bond, if there be an an≈øwer given to that, Mr. Attorny cannot afterwards ≈øet up a precedent Bond, becau≈øe 'tis a departure, and the Statute it ≈øelf ve≈øts no E≈øtate in the King, but makes the Receivers Lands lyable as if he had entred intred into a Statute Staple.

The Inqui≈øition therefore ≈øhould have been grounded upon the Statute, and then the Defendant might have pleaded the Act of Indempnity, of which he might have the benefit, but if not he may be let into the Equity of the Statute of the 33 H. 8. cap. 39. which gives liberty to Purcha≈øers to have contribution, and to plead ≈øufficient matter if they have any in di≈øcharge of the Debt.

Ex parte Quer.But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid that the Replication was good, for if the Sale was after his being Receiver, though before he became indebted, yet by the Statute of the 13 Eliz. the Lands are ≈øubject to a Debt contracted afterwards, becau≈øe it hath a Retro≈øpect to the time he was fir≈øt Receiver.

Pl. Com. 321. Dyer 160.By the Common Law both the Body and Lands of the Kings Debtor were lyable from the time he became indebted; but becau≈øe ≈øuch Debtors oftentimes ≈øold tho≈øe Lands which they had whil≈øt they were Officers, and ≈øo the King was defeated, therefore was this Statute made to ≈øupply that defect of the Common Law, by which Statute all the Lands he had at any time during his continuance in the Office were made lyable.

And though it may be objected, That becau≈øe of this Inqui≈øition the King is limited to a time, Viz. that inquiry ≈øhould be
made what Lands Havers had in the 20th year of the King, yet it was ≈øaid the Inquiry may be general.

The Elegit anciently left out the time, becau≈øe the Law doth determine from what time the party doth become lyable; ≈øo that the que≈øtion is about the King's Title, which if it appear to precede that of the Ter-tenant, then the King's Hands are not to be amoved; and thereupon Iudgment was prayed for him, Bro. Prerogative 59. Curia adver≈øare vult.

div.head: Barker ver≈øus Keat.
div.p: IN a Special Verdict in Ejectione firmae, Re≈øervation of a Pepper Corn a good con≈øideration to rai≈øe an u≈øe to make a Tenant to the Praecipe. Mod. Rep. 262 the Iury made a ≈øpecial Conclu≈øion by referring to the Court, whether there was a good Tenant to the Praecipe or not, which was made by a Bargain and Sale, but no Mony paid, nor any Rent re≈øerved but that of a Pepper Corn, to be paid at the end of ≈øix Months, upon demand, and the Relea≈øe and Grant of the Rever≈øion thereupon was only for divers good Con≈øiderations.

The Que≈øtion was if this Lea≈øe upon which no Rent was re≈øerved, but that of a Pepper Corn, be executed by the Statue of U≈øes or not, if it be,Cro. Jac. 604. Jones 7. 1 Cro. 110. 5 Rep. 124. b. then there is no need of the Entry of the Le≈ø≈øee, for the Statute will put him in actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and then the Inheritance by the Relea≈øe or Grant of the Rever≈øion will pa≈øs.

But if this Lea≈øe be not within the Statute, becau≈øe no V≈øe can be rai≈øed for want of a Con≈øideration, then it mu≈øt be a Conveyance at the Common Law,Lit. Sect. 465. Co. Lit. 46. b. and ≈øo the Le≈ø≈øee ought to make an actual Entry as was always u≈øual before the making of the Statute.

Serjeant Waller and Maynard argued that here was no Con≈øideration to rai≈øe an V≈øe, for the re≈øervation of a Pepper-Corn is no profit to the Le≈ø≈øor, 'tis not a real and good Rent; For ≈øo ≈ømall and trivial a matter is no Con≈øideration, for that which mu≈øt be a good Con≈øideration ought to be Mony, or ≈øome other valuable thing.

Then this Conveyance is not executed by the Statute of V≈øes, and if ≈øo 'tis not good at the Common Law, it being only a Lea≈øe for years, and no Entry, without which there can be no po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and if not then there can be no Rever≈øion upon which the Relea≈øe may operate, 'tis only an interre≈ø≈øe termini, and ≈øo was the Opinion of my Lord Coke ≈øince theCo. Lit. 270. making of this Statute.

1 Leon. 194, 195.And that no V≈øe was rai≈øed here, the Ca≈øe of my Lord Paget was cited, to which this was compared; My Lord being ≈øei≈øed in Fee, Covenanted to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the V≈øe of Trentham and others, in con≈øideration of payment of his Debts out of the Profits of his own E≈øtate, this was adjudged a void V≈øe, becau≈øe there was no con≈øideration on Trentham's part to rai≈øe it, the Mony appointed to be paid, being to be rai≈øed out of the Profits of my Lords E≈øtate.

The Words of the Lea≈øe are Demi≈øe, Grant, &c. which are Words at the Common Law, Co. Lit. 45. b. and 'tis not po≈ø≈øible that a future executory Con≈øideration ≈øhould rai≈øe a pre≈øent V≈øe, for the Pepper Corn is not to be paid till the end of ≈øix Months; and as this Con≈øideration is executory, ≈øo it is contingent too, for the Le≈ø≈øor might have relea≈øed before the expiration of the ≈øix Months.

If the Ca≈øe ofCro. Jac. 604. pl. 32. Lutwitch and Mitton be objected, where it was re≈øolved by the two Chief Iu≈øtices and Chief Baron, that upon a Deed of Bargain and Sale of Lands, where the Bargainee never entred, and the Bargainor reciting the Lea≈øe, did grant the Rever≈øion expectant upon it;Cro. Car. 110, 400. that this was a good grant of the Rever≈øion, from which the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was immediately divided, and was executed and ve≈øted in the Bargainee, by virtue of the Statute of V≈øes.
This is no Objection to the purpo≈øe, becau≈øe in that Ca≈øe the Bargainor was him≈øelf in actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
So that if there be no good Tenant to the Precipe in this Ca≈øe, though all that joyn in it are E≈øtopped to ≈øay ≈øo, yet the Tenant in Tail who comes in above, is not barred, 5 H. 5. 9.

But on the othe ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that the Le≈ø≈øee was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by the Statute, for the Word Grant being in the Lea≈øe, and the re≈øervation being a Pepper Corn, that will amount to a Bargain and Sale, though it hath not tho≈øe preci≈øe words in it, 8 Co. 94.

Pl. Com. 308. Dyer 146. b. contra. But if it ≈øhould not, yet another V≈øe may be averred than what is in this Lea≈øe, like Bedel's Ca≈øe, 7 Co. 40. b. Where a Man in con≈øideration of Fatherly Love to his elde≈øt Son, did covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the V≈øe of him in Tail, and afterwards to the u≈øe of his ≈øecond Son; there, though the con≈øideration re≈øpected his elde≈øt Son only in Words, yet a con≈øideration which is not repugnant to it, may be averred; and though an Entry is not found, yet it ≈øhall not be intended, ≈øince the Iury have not found the contrary.

North Chief Iu≈øtice, At fir≈øt when this ≈øort of Conveyance was u≈øed, the Le≈ø≈øee upon the Lea≈øe for a year, did always make an actual Entry, and then came the Relea≈øe to convey the Rever≈øion; but that being found trouble≈øome, the con≈øtant Practice was to make the Lea≈øe for a year, by the Deed of Bargain and Sale, for the con≈øideration of five ≈øhillings or ≈øome other ≈ømall ≈øum, and this was held and is ≈øo ≈øtill to be good without any actual Entry,2 Cro. 604. and the Bargaine√© thereby is capable of a Relea≈øe (though he cannot bring an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs without Entry) for when Mony is the Con≈øideration of making the Bargain and Sale, 'tis executed by the Statute of V≈øes, and ≈øo the Relea≈øe upon it is good; but if the Deed be not executed, 'tis otherwi≈øe.
But this being to ≈øupport a Common Recovery,Antea Addi≈øon and Otway. was to be favoured; and therefore the Court took time to con≈øider till the next Term; and then

The Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, That if a real Action be brought again≈øt A. who is not Tenant to the Praecipe, and a Recovery be had again≈øt him, the Sheriff can turn him out who is in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; but if he who is not in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion comes in by Voucher, he is e≈øtopped to ≈øay afterwards that he was not party to the Writ, ≈øo that he who is bound mu≈øt be Tenant or Vouchee, or claim under them.
Conveyances have been altered, not ≈øo much by the Knowledge of the Learned, as by the Ignorance of Vnskilful Men in their Profe≈ø≈øion.

The u≈øual Conveyance at Common Law, was by Feoffment, to which Livery and Sei≈øin were nece≈ø≈øary, the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion being given thereby to the Feoffee;Antea Lord Salisburies Ca≈øe. but if there was a Tenant in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and ≈øo Livery could not be made, then the Rever≈øion was granted, and the particular Tenant always attorned, and upon the ≈øame rea≈øon it was that afterwards a Lea≈øe and Relea≈øe was held a good Conveyance to pa≈øs an E≈øtate, but at that time it was made no que≈øtion but that the Le≈ø≈øee was to be in actual Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion before the Relea≈øe.

Afterwards V≈øes came to be frequent, and Settlements to V≈øes were very common, by rea≈øon whereof many inconveniencies were introduced, to prevent which the Statute of the 27th of H. 8. was made, by which the V≈øe was united to the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; for before that Statute V≈øes were to be executed according to the Rules of Equity, but now they are reduced to the Common Law, and are of more certainty, and therefore are to be con≈øtrued according to the Rules of Law.

At the Common Law when an E≈øtate did not pa≈øs by Feffoment, the Le≈ø≈øor or Vendor made a Lea≈øe for years, and the Le≈ø≈øee actually entred, and then the Le≈ø≈øor granted the Rever≈øion to another, and the Le≈ø≈øee attorned, and this was good.
Afterwards when an Inheritance was to be granted, then al≈øo was a Lea≈øe for years u≈øually made, and the Le≈ø≈øee entred as before, and then the Le≈ø≈øor relea≈øed to him, and this was good.

But after the Statute of V≈øes, it became an Opinion, That if a Lea≈øe for years was made upon a valuable Con≈øideration, a Relea≈øe might operate upon that without an actual Entry of the Le≈ø≈øee, becau≈øe the Statute did execute the Lea≈øe and rai≈øed an V≈øe pre≈øently to the Le≈ø≈øee. Sir Francis Moor Serjeant at Law was the fir≈øt who practi≈øed this way.

Nota.But becau≈øe there were ≈øome Opinions that where Conveyances may enure two ways, the Common Law ≈øhall be preferred, unle≈øs it appear that the party intended it ≈øhould pa≈øs by the Statute, thereupon the u≈øual cour≈øe was to put the Words Bargain and Sale into the Lea≈øe for a Year, to bring it within the Statute, and to alledge that the Lea≈øe was made to the intent and purpo≈øe that by the Statute of V≈øes the Le≈ø≈øee might be capable of a Relea≈øe; but notwith≈øtanding this, Mr. Noy was of the Opinion, That this Conveyance by Lea≈øe and Relea≈øe could never be maintained without the actual Entry of the Le≈ø≈øee.

This Ca≈øe goes farther than any that ever yet came into Iudgment, for Mony is not mentioned here to be the Con≈øideration, or any thing which may amount to it, unle≈øs the Pepper Corn, which he held to be a good Con≈øideration.

The Lea≈øe and Relea≈øe are but in nature of one Deed, and then the intent of the Parties is apparent that it ≈øhould pa≈øs by the Satute, and eo in≈øtanti that the Lea≈øe is executed, the Re≈øervation is in force.

The Ca≈øe put by Littleton in Sect. 459. is put at the Common Law, and not upon the Statute; where he ≈øaith, That if a Lea≈øe be made for years, and the Le≈ø≈øor relea≈øeth all his Right to the Le≈ø≈øee before Entry, ≈øuch Relea≈øe is void, becau≈øe the Le≈ø≈øee had only a Right and not the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which my Lord Coke in his Comment upon it, calls an intere≈ø≈øe termini, and that ≈øuch Relea≈øe ≈øhall not enure to enlarge the E≈øtate without the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which is very true at the Common Law, but not upon the Statute of V≈øes.

And therefore Iudgment was given by the whole Court,Judgment. that the Word Grant in the Lea≈øe will make the Land pa≈øs by way of U≈øe; that the Re≈øervation of a Pepper Corn was a good con≈øideration to rai≈øe an V≈øe to ≈øupport a Common Recovery; that this Lea≈øe being within the Statute of V≈øes, there was no need of an actual Entry to make the Le≈ø≈øee capable of the Relea≈øe; for by vertue of the Statute he ≈øhall be adjudged to be in actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øo a good Tenant to the Praecipe; and Iudgment was given accordingly in Michaelmas Term following.

div.head: Kendrick ver≈øus Bartland.
div.p:
THE Plaintiff brought an Action on the Ca≈øe for ≈øtopping the Water going to his Mill with a Continuando, &c.
Continuando laid after a Nu≈øance abated, yet Damages ≈øhall be recovered for what was done before

The Defendant pleads that the ≈øtopping was contra voluntatem, and that tali die, which was betw√©en the fir≈øt and the la≈øt day laid in the Continuando, the Plaintiff him≈øelf had abated the Nu≈øance, and ≈øo he had no cau≈øe of Action.

To this Plea the Plaintiff demurred, and Serjeant Baldwyn, who argued to maintain the Plea, did not relye upon that part of it where the Defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øtopping of the Water was involuntary, becau≈øe he doing the thing it could not be contra voluntatem; but the Que≈øtion would be whether the Plaintiff had any cau≈øe of Action to recover damages after the Abatement of the Nu≈øance; and he ≈øaid that he had abated it before the Action brought, and counted for damages after the Abatement, for which he had no Cau≈øe of Action, and this he had confe≈ø≈øed by his Demurrer.

But the Court were of Opinion, that it was not a good Plea, and took this difference between a Quod permittat, or an A≈ø≈øize for a Nu≈øance, and an Action on the Ca≈øe for the ≈øame; for the end of a Quod permittat or an A≈ø≈øi≈øe was to abate the Nu≈øance,2 Cro. 207, 618 but the end of an Action on the Ca≈øe was to recover damages; therefore though the Nu≈øance was removed the Plaintiff is intituled to his damages that accrued before; and 'tis u≈øual in Actions of this nature to lay theSid. 319. Continuando for longer time than the Plaintiff can prove, but he ≈øhall have damages for what he can prove, and ≈øo here he ≈øhall recover the damages which he ≈øu≈øtained before the Abatement: And thereupon Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Walwyn ver≈øus Awberry, and others.
div.p: Tythes of a Rectory ≈øhall not be ≈øeque≈øtred for Repairs of the Chancel. Mod. Rep. 258.TRe≈øpa≈øs for the taking and carrying away of four Loads of Wheat, and four Loads of Rye, &c.

The Defendants ju≈øtifie, for that the Plaintiff is Rector of the Rectory impropriate of B. and that the Chancel was out of Repair, and that the Bi≈øhop of Hereford, after Monition fir≈øt given to the Plaintiff, had granted a Seque≈øtration of the Tythes of the Rectory for the repairing the Chancel; and that the Defendants were Churchwardens of the Pari≈øh; and that the particulars mentioned in the Declaration were Tythes belonging to the Plaintiff as Rector afore≈øaid; and that by vertue of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øion they took the ≈øame for repairing of the ≈øaid Chancel, and that for the≈øe Tythes ≈øo taken they had accounted to the Bi≈øhop.
To this the Plaintiff demurred.

The Que≈øtion was, whether an Impropriate Rectory be chargeable for the Repairs of the Chancel by the Seque≈øtration of the Tythes by the Bi≈øhop; and tho≈øe who argued in the negative for the Plaintiff could not deny, but that Church Reparations did belong to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Courts, and that as often as Prohibitions have been prayed to that Iurisdiction, Con≈øultations have been as often granted; notwith≈øtanding in many Ca≈øes the Rates for ≈øuch Reparations have been very unequally impo≈øed, and the rea≈øon is becau≈øe tho≈øe Courts have original Iurisdiction of the Matter.

It was admitted al≈øo, that Pari≈øhioners are bound to repair the Church, and the Rector the Chappel, and in this re≈øpect of their Lands; and therefore if a Man hath Lands in one Town and dwell in another, he ≈øhall be contributory to the Reparation of that Church where his Lands are, and not where he inhabits.

And that all this was by the common Cu≈øtom of England long before the making of the Statute of 31 H. 8. cap. 13. by which Par≈øonages were made Lay Fees; but then it mu≈øt be under≈øtood that this was no real Duty incumbent upon them, but was a per≈øonal burden for which every Pari≈øhioner was chargeable proportionably to the quantity of Land which he held in the Pari≈øh; in which Ca≈øe if he refu≈øed to be contributory the Ordinary did never intermeddle with the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, but always proceeded by Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cen≈øures, as Excommunication of the Party refu≈øing, which is the proper remedy.

But in ca≈øe of an Appropriation in the Hands of an Eccle≈øia≈øtical Corporation, as Dean and Chapter, &c. there if a Refu≈øal be to contribute to the Repairs, the Ordinary may ≈øeque≈øter; and the rea≈øon is becau≈øe a Corporation cannot be excommunicated.

The Ordinary may al≈øo ≈øeque≈øter in things of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cognizance, as if the King do not pre≈øent; ≈øo he may take the Profits within the ≈øix Months, that the Patron hath to pre≈øent, and apply them to the Pa≈øtor of the Church by him recommended, becau≈øe the Ordinary hath a provi≈øional Superintendency of the Church; and there is a nece≈ø≈øity that the Cure ≈øhould be ≈øupplyed until the Patron doth pre≈øent, and this is a kind of Seque≈øtration.

But in ≈øome Ca≈øes the Ordinary could not ≈øeque≈øter the Profits belonging to Spiritual Per≈øons, though he was lawfully entituled to them for a particular time and purpo≈øe: For by the Statute of 13 Eliz. cap. 20. 'tis Enacted, That if a Par≈øon make a Lea≈øe of his Living for a longer time than he is re≈øident upon it, that ≈øuch Lea≈øe ≈øhall be void, and he ≈øhall for the ≈øame lo≈øe one years Profits of his Benefice, to be di≈øtributed by the Ordinary among≈øt the Poor of the Pari≈øh.

Now he had no Remedy to recover the Years Profits, but in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court; he could not ≈øeque≈øter, and to give him Authority ≈øo to do a ≈øupplemental Statute was made five years afterwards in the 18th year of the Queens Reign cap. 11. by which Power is given him to grant a Seque≈øtration; ≈øo that if he could not ≈øeque≈øter in a Ca≈øe of which he had a Iurisdiction by a precedent Statute, √† fortiori he cannot in a Ca≈øe exempted as this is from his Iurisdiction.

But admitting a Seque≈øtration might go, then this inconveniency would follow, that if other Lands ≈øhould be ≈øeque≈øtred for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, the former Seque≈øtration could not be pleaded to di≈øcharge them, becau≈øe the intere≈øt is not bound thereby, no more than a Seque≈øtration out of Chancery is pleadable to an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs at the Common Law.

This Ca≈øe cannot be di≈øtingui≈øhed from that of Jefferies in 5 Co. and from what the Civilians te≈øtified to the Court there, viz. That the Churchwardens and greater part of the Pari≈øhioners upon a general warning given may make a Taxation by Law, but the ≈øame ≈øhall not charge the Land, but the per≈øon in re≈øpect of his Land; ≈øo that 'tis he that is chargeable and may be excommunicated in ca≈øe of refu≈øal to contribute, but his Lands cannot be ≈øeque≈øtred, becau≈øe 'tis not the bu≈øine≈øs of the Ordinary to meddle with the temporal po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of Lay-men, but to proceed again≈øt them by Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cen≈øures; and the Pari≈øhioners
Lands may be as well ≈øeque≈øtred for the Repairs of the Church, as the Lands of the Impropriator for the Repairs of the Chappel; for which Rea≈øons it was held that a Seque≈øtration would not lie.

Ex parte Def.But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that before the making of the Statute the Rector was to repair the Chancel under pain of Seque≈øtration, which the Ordinary had power to grant in ca≈øe of refu≈øal; and that his Authority in many Ca≈øes was not abridged by the Statute: The Ca≈øe of2 Cro. 518. Parry and Banks was cited, where in the 24th Year of H. 8. a Par≈øonage was appropriated to the Deanary of St. A≈øaph, and a Vicaridge endowed, which the Bi≈øhop di≈ø≈øolved in the 24th Year of Queen Elizabeth, and Parry pretending that notwith≈øtanding this Di≈ø≈øolution it was in the Kings Hands by lap≈øe obtained a Pre≈øentation; and it was re≈øolved that after the Statute of Di≈ø≈øolutions, which made Par≈øonages Lay Fees, the Ordinary could not di≈ø≈øolve the Vicaridge where the Par≈øonage was in a Temporal Hand, but being in that Ca≈øe in the Hands of the Dean, he might.

The Rector is to repair the Chancel, becau≈øe of the Profits of the Glebe, which is therefore Onus reale impo≈øitum rebus & per≈øonis; and of that Opinion was Johannes de Atkin, who wrote 100 years before Lynwood, where in fol. 56. he ≈øaith, That if the Chancel was out of repair it affected the Glebe.

And that the Con≈øtitution of the Canon Law is ≈øuch will not be denied,Vaugh. 327. and if ≈øo Canons being allowed, are by u≈øe become parcel of the Common Law, and are as much the Law of the Kingdom as an Act of Parliament, for what is Law doth not ≈øu≈øcipere magis aut minus.

Several Ca≈øes were put where the Bi≈øhop doth intermeddle with the Profits of a Par≈øonage, as in the Ca≈øe of a Seque≈øtration upon a Iudgment obtained again≈øt a Spiritual Per≈øon, where a Fi. Fa. is directed to the Sheriff upon that Iudgment, and he returns Clericus beneficiatus non habens Laicum feodum; for which rea≈øon he cannot meddle with the Profits of the Glebe, but the Bi≈øhop doth it by a Seque≈øtration to him directed.
He may likewi≈øe retain for the ≈øupply of the Cure and pay only the re≈øidue, which hath been omitted on the other ≈øide.

As the Ordinary might di≈ø≈øolve a Vicaridge endowed where the Par≈øonage was in the Hands of a Dean, ≈øo he may ≈øeque≈øter an Appropriation in any Spiritual Per≈øon; and there is no Statute which exempts an Impropriation from ≈øuch a Seque≈øtration, becau≈øe 'tis onus reale at the Common Law; and as the Lay Impropriator may ≈øue for Tythes and receive them as before the
making this Statute; 'tis as rea≈øonable ≈øince he hath the ≈øame advantage that he ≈øhould have the ≈øame Charge, and the rather becau≈øe the ≈øaving in the Statute of 31 H. 8. cap. 13. doth ≈øtill continue the ≈øame Authority the Bi≈øhop had before, though the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was thereby given to the King.

The Words of which are, viz. Saving to all and every per≈øon, &c. ≈øuch Right which they might have had as if the Act had not been made, which mu≈øt be the Right of the Ordinary and of no other per≈øon.

An Impropriator pays Synodals and Procurations as well as an Appropriation in the Hands of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Per≈øons, and it would be very inconvenient if a Seque≈øtration ≈øhould not lie which would quicken them more than an Excommunication; and it was ≈øaid, that in England there were above 1000 Appropriations belonging to Corporations aggregate, as Deans and Chapters, which could not be excommunicated; and if the Bi≈øhop could not ≈øeque≈øter, then there was no remedy to repair the Chancel: For which Rea≈øons Iudgment was prayed for the Defendant.

But the whole Court, be≈øides Iu≈øtice Atkins, held that the Lay Impropriation was not to be ≈øeque≈øtred for the Repairs of the Chancel: And the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that the Repair of the Chancel was an Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øe, but that the Rectory and Impropriator were Lay, and not to be ≈øeque≈øtred as the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions in the Hands of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Corporations may, which he did agree could not be excommunicated, but the per≈øons who made up ≈øuch Corporation might.

And as to the Seque≈øtration upon a Iudgment it made nothing for the Matter to entitle the Ordinary to a Seque≈øtration in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe what he doth in that is in the nature of a temporal Officer; for the Seque≈øtration is like the Fieri Facias, and being directed to the Bi≈øhop, he is in that Ca≈øe (if he may be ≈øo called) an Eccle≈øia≈øtical Sheriff, and by virtue thereof may do as the Sheriff doth in other Ca≈øes, that is, he may ≈øei≈øe Eccle≈øia≈øtical things and ≈øell them, as the Sheriff doth Temporal things upon a Fieri Facias; but 'tis to be ob≈øerved that he mu≈øt return Fieri feci, and not Seque≈øtrari feci upon this Writ.

And as to the Saving in the Statute, that doth not alter the Ca≈øe; for if any Right be thereby ≈øaved, 'tis that of the Par≈øon, for the Pari≈øhioners have no right to ≈øit there; indeed the Vicar may, becau≈øe he comes in under the Par≈øon.

So that this Ca≈øe is not to be put as at the Common Law, but upon the Statute of Di≈ø≈øolutions, by vertue whereof the
Rectory being in the Hands of a Lay Per≈øon is become a Lay Fee, and ≈øo cannot be ≈øubject to a Seque≈øtration; if it ≈øhould, the next ≈øtep would be that the Bi≈øhop would increa≈øe Vicaridges as well in the Ca≈øe of an Impropriation as Appropriation, which would le≈ø≈øen the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of ≈øuch as have purcha≈øed under the Act.

But Iu≈øtice Atkins was of a contrary Opinion; he ≈øaid that it was agreed by all that an Impropriator is chargeable with the Repairs of the Chancel; but the Charge was not per≈øonal but in regard of the profits of the Impropriation, which are originally the Debtor according to the fir≈øt Donation. That the primary Rights of Rectories are the performance of Divine Service and the Repairs of the Chancel, and that the Profits, which are over and above, mu≈øt then go to the Imprpriator, and are to be e≈øteemed then a Lay F√©e; but that tho≈øe Duties are the fir≈øt Rights, and therefore mu≈øt be fir≈øt di≈øcharged.

That this Right, this duty of Repairing was certain, and therefore ≈øhall not be taken away by Implication, but by expre≈øs Words in the Act, which if wanting ≈øhall remain ≈øtill, and the Parties ≈øhall be compelled to repair under the ≈øame Penalties as before.

But admitting it ≈øhould be taken away, yet the ≈øaving in the Act extends to the Right of the Pari≈øhioners, which is not to ≈øit in the Chancel, but to go thither when the Sacraments are admini≈øtred, of which they are deprived, when 'tis out of Repair; nor can they have the u≈øe of the Church which properly belongs to them, becau≈øe when the Chancel is out of Repair it not only defaces the Church, but makes it in a ≈øhort time become ruinous.

He denied that a Seque≈øtration in Chancery cannot be pleaded to barr a Tre≈øpa≈øs at the Common Law; for if it be ≈øaid that the Chancery have i≈ø≈øued ≈øuch Seque≈øtrations it will be as binding as any other Proce≈øs i≈ø≈øuing according to the Rules of the Common Law.

And he al≈øo denied the Ca≈øe put by the Chief Iu≈øtice, that the Lands of the Pari≈øhioners might as well be ≈øeque≈øtred for the repair of the Church as tho≈øe of the Impropriator for repair of the Chancel, becau≈øe the Profits of the Rectory might originally be ≈øeque≈øtred, but the Lands of the Pari≈øhioner could not; and ≈øo the Ca≈øes are quite different.
Judgment.But in Ea≈øter Term following Iudgment was given again≈øt the Defendant upon the point of Pleading, which the Court all agreed to be ill.
1. The Defendants ≈øhould have averred that the Chancel was out of repair.
2. That no more was taken than what was ≈øufficient for the repair thereof.

3. For that the Plaintiff had declared for the taking of ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Grain; and the Defendant ju≈øtifies the taking but of part, and ≈øaith nothing of the re≈øidue, and ≈øo 'tis a Di≈øcontinuance; and the general Words quoad re≈øiduum tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis will not help, becau≈øe he goes to particulars afterwards and doth not ennumerate all; and thereupon Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: Edwards ver≈øus Weeks.
div.p: AS≈øump≈øit. Parol di≈øcharge good before breach of Promi≈øe, but not afterwards. Mod. Rep. 262. The Plaintiff declared that the Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff at his Reque≈øt had exchanged Hor≈øes with him, promi≈øed to pay him 5 l. and he alledged a breach in the Non-performance.

The Defendant pleads that the Plaintiff before any Action brought, di≈øcharged him of his Promi≈øe: And upon a Demurrer the Que≈øtion was, whether after a breach of a Promi≈øe a parol di≈øcharge could be good? The Ca≈øe ofCro. Car. 383 Sid. 293. Langden and Stokes was an Authority that ≈øuch a di≈øcharge had been good before the breach: viz. The Defendant promi≈øed to go a Voiage, the breach was alledged in Non-performance; and the Defendant pleaded that before any breach the Plaintiff exoneravit eum; and upon Demurrer it was held good before the breach.

But here was no time agreed for the payment of this 5 l. and therefore it was due immediately upon Reque≈øt, and not being paid, the Promi≈øe is broken, and the parol di≈øcharge cannot be pleaded; and of that Opinion was all the Court, and Iudgment for the Plaintiff, Ni≈øi, &c.
Quaere. If had pleaded ≈øuch a di≈øcharge before any reque≈øt of payment, wheher it had been good.

div.head: Arris & Arris ver≈øus Stukely. In Scaccario.
div.p: Indebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit will lie for the receipt of the Profits of an Office, tho' no contract INdebitatus a≈ø≈øump≈øit for 200 l. in Mony had and received to the u≈øe of the Plaintiffs: Vpon Non a≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded, the Iury find a Special Verdict to this effect; viz. They find that King Charles the Second did on the 17th day of Augu≈øt in the 12th year of his Reign, by his Letters Patents under the great Seal, grant unto the Defendant and another the Office of Comptroler of the Cu≈øtoms at the Port of Exce≈øter, durante bene placito; that the other per≈øon died; and that the King afterwards by other Letters Patents bearing date primo Maii in the 21≈øt year of his Reign, did grant the ≈øaid Office to the Plaintiffs, which was two years before this Action brought; and that the Defendant ≈øtill and for ≈øeven years pa≈øt had exerci≈øed the ≈øame upon pretence of a Right by Survivor≈øhip, and received the Profits thereof; but whether upon the whole Matter the Defendant made any ≈øuch Promi≈øe as in the Declaration, they did not know, Et petunt advi≈øamentum Curiae in praemi≈ø≈øis; and if upon the Matter ≈øo found the Court ≈øhall be of Opinion that the Defendant made ≈øuch Promi≈øe, then they ≈øay, that he did make ≈øuch Promi≈øe and a≈ø≈øe≈øs damages occa≈øione praemi≈ø≈øorum in narratione mentionat' ad 100 l. and Co≈øts to 53 s. and 4 d. &c.

Winnington Sollicitor argued, that the fir≈øt Patent was determined by the death of one of the Patent√©es, and then the ≈øecond Patent takes effect, and ≈øo the Plaintiffs have a good Title; for there ≈øhall be no Survivor≈øhip of an Office of Tru≈øt, no not if the Office had been granted to two for their Lives, if it be not ≈øaid, to the Survivor of them, 11 Co. 34. Auditor Curles Ca≈øe; and of that Opinion was the Court clearly.

But Pollexfen for the Defendant ≈øaid, that he agreed that Point, but that the Plaintiffs Patent was not good; for though there be a general Non ob≈øtante of all the Statutes in it, yet there ought to have been one in particular again≈øt the Statute of 14 R. 2. cap. 10. which Enacts, That no Cu≈øtomer or Comptroler ≈øhall have any Office in the Cu≈øtoms for his Life, 31 H. 6. c. 5. but only during the plea≈øure of the King; which being made for the publique Good, the King cannot by any Non ob≈øtante di≈øpen≈øe with it.

In many Ca≈øes the di≈øpen≈øation of the King by a Non ob≈øtante is good, as where a Statute pre≈øcribes the form of the King's Grant, where it doth not directly prohibit a thing, but only under pain of a Forfeiture; but if it be direct and pro bono publico, there a Non ob≈øtante is not good, and ≈øo is this Statute.

He cannot di≈øpen≈øe with the Statute of 31 Eliz. again≈øt Symony; for the Party being di≈øabled by anHob. 57. 1 In≈øt. 120. Act of Parliament cannot be enabled by a Non ob≈øtante; he cannot di≈øpence with the Statute of Lea≈øes of5 Co. 15. Eccle≈øia≈øtical Per≈øons, nor with the Iurisdiction of the13 R. 2. c. 3. 15 R. 2. c. 5. 2 H. 4 11. 4 In≈øt. 153. Admiralty encroaching upon the Common Law; for the foundation of a Non ob≈øtante is in the Kings Prerogative, and is current in his Grants; but in tho≈øe Statutes the Subject hath an intere≈øt.

The Laws concerning Non ob≈øtantes are none of theDavis Rep 69, 70, 71. Vaugh. 332. Thomas ver≈øus Sorrel. Hob. 146. Colt and Glover. Long 5 E. 4. 33, 34. ancient Laws of this Land, but brought in by the Pope. The Book of 2 H. 7. f. 6. b. and 7. did fir≈øt give ri≈øe to this exorbitant power; yet it is not the Opinion of all, or indeed of any of the Iudges then, as 'tis affirmed to be, for Broke Pat. 45, 109. who abridged that Ca≈øe, took no notice of any Opinion of the Iudges; yet ≈øome grounding them≈øelves on that Book, affirm that the King may di≈øpen≈øe with the Statute of the 23 H. 6. cap. 8. which Enacts, That no Man ≈øhall be Sheriff for above one Year; and that therefore a Patent granted by Ed. the 4th, to the Earl of Northumberland, to be Sheriff of the ≈øame County for Life, was held good, which is a plain mi≈øtake, for there never was any ≈øuch Re≈øolution, neither did the Iudges make any determination upon that Statute, it was only a di≈øcour≈øe obiter by Radcliff (who was then one of the Barons of the Exchequer,) concerning the Statutes of the 14 E. 3. cap. 7. and of the 42 E. 3. cap. 9. which are only prohibitory, That no Sheriff ≈øhall continue in his Office above one year, but have not any ≈øuch Clau≈øe in them as the Statute of 23 H. 6. hath, which ≈øaith, That all Patents made to any to be Sheriff for above a year ≈øhall be void, any Clau≈øe or word of Non ob≈øtante in any wi≈øe put in ≈øuch Patent notwith≈øtanding; this was the mi≈øtake of Baron Radcliff, Po≈øtea. who upon a ≈øudden Di≈øcour≈øe thought there might be ≈øuch Clau≈øes in tho≈øe former Statutes of Ed. 3. and that notwith≈øtanding which, there being a Non ob≈øtante in that Patent to tho≈øe Statutes he held that to be a good di≈øpen≈øation of them; but 'tis plain there are no ≈øuch Clau≈øes in tho≈øe Statutes, and therefore a Non ob≈øtante to them is good, and which was the true rea≈øon why that Patent in H. the 7th's time was held good.
2. Another rea≈øon might be, becau≈øe the Office of Sheriff was grantable for Life, and ≈øo not within the reach of the Prohibition by tho≈øe Statutes.
3. But it if was, yet the Provi≈øo in the Aa of Re≈øumption, of 1 H. 7. protected that Patent, by which the King re≈øumed all Grants made by E. 4. but provides for the Earl's Grant.

But admitting the Statute of R. 2. and of H. 6. may be di≈øpen≈øed withal in this Ca≈øe,Dyer 352. a. 2 Roll. Abr. 193. Cro. Eliz. 513. yet it ≈øhould be more particular than in this Patent to the Plaintiff; for Non ob≈øtante aliquo Statuto generally will not ≈øerve.

2. Point. A general indebitatus a≈ø≈øump≈øit will not lie here for want of2 H. 4. 12. Bro Accompt 24, 65, 89. privity, and becau≈øe there is no contract, 'tis only a tort, a di≈ø≈øei≈øin, and the Plaintiff might have brought an A≈ø≈øi≈øe for this Office, which lies at the Common Law; and ≈øo it hath been adjudged in Jehu Webb's Ca≈øe, 1 In≈øt. 212. 8 Co. 4. Which is al≈øo given by the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. cap. 25. for a profit apprender in alieno ≈øolo.
The Plaintiff might have brought an Action on the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Defendant, for di≈øturbing of him in his Office, and that had been good, becau≈øe it had been grounded on the wrong.

In this Ca≈øe the Defendant takes the Profits again≈øt the will of the Plaintiff, and ≈øo there is no Contract; but if he had received them by the con≈øent of the Plaintiff,6 H. 6.9. 1 Roll. Abr. 597 pl. 5. yet this Action would not lie for want of privity. 'Tis true, in the Ca≈øe of the King where his Rents are wrongfully received, the party may be charged to give an accompt as Bayliff; ≈øo al≈øo may the Executors of his Accomptant, becau≈øe the Law createth a privity; but 'tis otherwi≈øe in the Ca≈øe of a common per≈øon, 10 Co. 114. b. 11 Co. 90. b. Becau≈øe in all Actions of Debt, there mu≈øt be a Contract, or qua≈øi ex contractu; and therefore where Iudgment was had and thereupon an Elegit, and the Sheriff returned that he had appri≈øed the Goods, and extended ≈øuch Lands, which he delivered to the Plaintiff, ubi revera he did not, per quod actio accrevit, which was an Action of Debt; but it was adjudged that it would not lie, becau≈øe the Sheriff had not returned that he medled with the Goods, or with the value of them, and therefore for want of certainty how much to charge him with this Action would not lie, but an Action on the Ca≈øe for a fal≈øe Return; but if he had returned the Goods ≈øold for ≈øo much Mony certain,Godb. 276. 2 Sand. 344. 2 Cro. 566. which he had delivered, then an Action of Debt would lie; for though 'tis not a Contract, 'tis qua≈øi ex contractu, Hob. 206.

3. Point. The Iury find that the Defendant received the Profits for ≈øeven years, and that the Plaintiff had his Patent but two
years, and do not ≈øhew what was received by the Defendant within tho≈øe two years, and then the Court cannot apply it.

But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid by Sawyer, Ex parte Quer. That this Non ob≈øtante was good; for where an Act of Parliament comes to re≈øtrain the Kings power and prerogative, it was always held ≈øo to be and he relied upon the Iudgment of 2 H. 7. f. 6. that the King might di≈øpen≈øe with the Statute of 23 H. 6. Pl. Com. 502. b. Dyer. 303. which he affirmed to be the con≈øtant V≈øage ever ≈øince, and that therefore the Law is ≈øo taken to be at this day.

As to the ≈øecond Point both he and the Sollicitor General Winnington ≈øaid, That an indebitatus a≈ø≈øump≈øit would lie here, for where one receives my Rent, I may charge him as Bayliff or Receiver; or if any one receive my Mony without my order, though 'tis a tort, yet an indebitatus will lie, becau≈øe by the Receipt of the Mony the Law creates a promi≈øe, and the Action is not grounded on the tort but on the receipt of the Profits in this Ca≈øe.

As to the Objection about the finding, they held that to be nugatory and idle; for it cannot be intended that the Damages given were for the time the Defendant received the Profits, before the Plaintiff had his Patent, neither is there any thing found in the Verdict to that purpo≈øe.
In Michaelmas-Term following,Judgment. the Court gave Iudgment for the Plaintiffs.

1. They held that the King might di≈øpen≈øe with this Statute, for the Subject had no intere≈øt, nor was in any wi≈øe concerned in the Prohibition; it was made only for the ea≈øe of the King;Hob. 146. and by the like rea≈øon he might di≈øpen≈øe with the Statute of 4 H. 4. 24. That a Man ≈øhall hold the Office of Dyer 203. Aulnager, without a Bill from the Trea≈øurer; and with the Statute of 31 H. 6. 5. That no Cu≈øtomer or Comptroller ≈øhall have any E≈øtate certain in his Office; becau≈øe the≈øe and ≈øuch like Statutes were made for the ea≈øe of the Sovereign, and not to abridge his Prerogative, and that the general Clau≈øe of Non ob≈øtante aliquo alio Statuto was ≈øufficient.

2. 4 H. 7. 6. b. Moor 458 An Indebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit will lye for Rent received by one who pretends a Title, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe an Accompt will lye; wherever the Plaintiff may have an Accompt, an Indebitatus will lye.

As to the finding 'tis well enough, for the Iury a≈ø≈øe≈øs Damages occa≈øione praemi≈ø≈øorum in narratione mentionat, which mu≈øt be for the time the Plaintiff had the Office, and that a Patent would make a Man an Officer before admittance.

div.head: Steward Executor of Steward, ver≈øus Allen.
div.p: Demand mu≈øt be made where an Intere≈øt is to be determined.DEBT for a Rent re≈øerved upon a Lea≈øe for years, in which there was a Provi≈øo, That if the Rent be behind and unpaid by the ≈øpace of a Month next after any or either of the Daies of payment, then the Lea≈øe to be void.

The Plea was, That the Rent was behind a Month after a day on which it was re≈øerved to be paid, and ≈øo the Lea≈øe is void; to which Plea the Plaintiff demurred, becau≈øe the Defendant did not ≈øay that the Plaintiff demanded the Rent; for though the Rent be due without demand, yet the Intere≈øt ≈øhall not be determined without it, which mu≈øt be expre≈øsly laid in the Pleading; and of that Opinion was the Court, except Iu≈øtice Atkyns, who doubted.

div.head: Searl ver≈øus Long.
div.p: Quare Impedit, real mainpernors mu≈øt be returned upon the Summons, Pone and Grand Cape. 2 In≈øt. 124. Mod. Rep. 248.IVdgment final was given in a Quare Impedit, according to the Statute of Marlebridge, cap. 12. Which Serjeant Pemberton moved to ≈øet a≈øide.

He ≈øaid that at the Common Law the Proce≈øs in a Quare Impedit was Summons, Pone, and Di≈øtre≈øs infinite, which being found mi≈øchievous in re≈øpect of a Lap≈øe, it was therefore provided by this Statute, that if the di≈øturbers do not appear upon the Summons, then they ≈øhall be Attached to appear at another day, &c. Now here upon the Attachment the Sheriff hath returned Attachiatus fuit by John Doe and Richard Roe, who are feigned per≈øons, and not mainpernors; for the Defendant hath made Oath, That he did not know any ≈øuch per≈øons, neither was he ever Attached, ≈øo that 'tis not only a matter of Form, for he ought to have that notice which the Law requires, it being ≈øo penal upon him.

'Tis probable this Mi≈øtake might ari≈øe from Mr. Dalton, who in his Book of the Office of Sheriffs, in the Returns of Writs there, hath put down the≈øe feigned Attachers for Examples ≈øake, from whence the Sheriff in this Ca≈øe might inferr that they need not be real per≈øons, as in truth they ought, both upon the Summons, Pone, and Di≈øtre≈øs; and he cited a Ca≈øe lately adjudged, where the like Return was made upon the Grand Cape, and the Iudgment ≈øet a≈øide; and of this Opinion was the whole Court, and ≈øaid, Where the Proce≈øs is ≈øo fatal, the Party ought to
be duly ≈øerved, and that the Sheriff ought to have gone to the Church and to have ≈øei≈øed the Profits; and if there be nothing, to return a Nihil; and though the Iudgment was given before the Term, or long ≈øince, yet when 'tis Irregular 'tis to be ≈øet a≈øide, and ≈øo it was now; and being moved again, the Court continued of their former Opinion.

The like Ca≈øe was moved in Michaelmas-Term following, between Fleming and Lee, where the Patron Defendant was thus ≈øummoned and never appeared, and the Incumbent did ca≈øt an E≈ø≈øoign; and a Ca≈øe was cited betw√©en Vivian and the Bi≈øhop of London, Mich. 23 Car. 2. in C. B. where the like Iudgment was ≈øet a≈øide.

But on the other ≈øide it was objected, that leaving due notice upon the Summons was as much as was required, for the other Writs are only to give the Defendant time to plead, and therefore 'tis not nece≈ø≈øary that notice ≈øhould be given upon every one of the Writs, for if once ≈øerved 'tis enough, 11 H. 6. 3, 4. 36 H. 6. 23. 8 H. 6. 8. Long 5 to E. 4. 26. 29 E. 3. 42, 43. Doctor and Stud. 125, 126. 21 H. 6. 56.

But the Court were of Opinion that the Defendant having not appeared, nor ca≈øt an E≈ø≈øoign, and Iudgment final being given,Curia. it was rea≈øon that all the Proce≈øs ≈øhould be ≈øerved really, of which there had been no occa≈øion, if he had either appeared or e≈ø≈øoined, and therefore the Proce≈øs not being duly ≈øerved Iudgment was ≈øet a≈øide, Ra≈øt. Ent. 217. And they held that the E≈ø≈øoign of the other Defendant was no wi≈øe binding to the Patron Defendant, becau≈øe they may ≈øever in Pleading, and ≈øo that Iudgment was likewi≈øe ≈øet a≈øide.

div.head: DE Term. Sancti Mich. Anno 29 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Sir John Otway ver≈øus Holdips Executor, &c.
div.p: Bond to pay 40 l. when an Accompt ≈øhall be ≈øtated, 'tis a Covenant and not a Solvendum. DEBT upon Bond brought by the Plaintiff again≈øt the Defendant as Executor, wherein the Te≈øtator did acknowledge him≈øelf to be indebted to the Plaintiff in 40 l. which he thereby did covenant to pay when ≈øuch a Bill of Co≈øts ≈øhould be ≈øtated by two Attornies indifferently to be cho≈øen between them; and ≈øets forth in his Declaration that he named one Attorny, and de≈øired the now Defendant to name another, which he refu≈øed, and ≈øo intitles him≈øelf to this Action.
The Defendant pleads Non detinet, to which the Plaintiff demurred.

But the Plea was not offered to be maintained becau≈øe the Executor cannot plead Non detinet, but where the Te≈øtator him≈øelf might plead Nil debet, which in this Ca≈øe he could not do. But it was in≈øi≈øted, that the Declaration is not good, becau≈øe the Mony was to be paid upon an accompt ≈øtated, which not being done, by the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing 'tis not yet due; and this ought to be taken as penned, viz. Solvendum and not an expre≈øs Covenant.

But on the contrary it was held not to be a Solvendum, but a Covenant to pay the Mony, the Debt and the Duty being in the fir≈øt place a≈øcertained; but if it be a Solvendum and repugnant to the Obligatory Clau≈øe 'tis void, 21 Ed. 4.36.
As the Defendant would have it expounded, it would be in his power totally to defeat the Bond either way; for if he would never chu≈øe an Attorny there could be never any thing due.

The whole Court were of Opinion that it was not a Solvendum, but a Covenant, which did not take away the Duty a≈øcertained by the Obligation; and if it ≈øhould not be a Covenant, but an entire Bond, then it would be in the Power of the Obligor whether ever it ≈øhall be payable; but be it either the one or the other, the Plaintiff having named an Attorny, ought to recover; and Iudgment was accordingly given for him.

div.head: Dunning ver≈øus La≈øcomb.
div.p: DEBT on a Bond, the Condition was to pay Mony when a Ship ≈øhould go from A. to C. and from thence to Bri≈øtol, and ≈øhould arrive there or at any other Port of di≈øcharge in England; the Ship going from A. to C. took in Provi≈øions at Bri≈øtol, but not to be di≈øcharged there, but proceeded in her Voiage to Cales and was ca≈øt away: And by the Opinion of the Court the Mony was not payable; but if he had never intended to perform the Voyage it might have been otherwi≈øe, 1 Roll. Abr. 142. 39 H. 6.10. Iudgment for the Defendant ni≈øi.

div.head: Atkins ver≈øus Bayles.
div.p: AN Information was exhibited again≈øt the Defendant,Outlary pleaded to an Information, good. being a Iu≈øtice of the Peace, for refu≈øing to grant his Warrant to ≈øuppre≈øs a Conventicle.
The Defendant pleads an Outlary in di≈øability; and the Plantiff demurred.
1.3 In≈øt. 194. This Plea is not good becau≈øe the King is intere≈øted qui tam, &c. and therefore where the Informer dies the Attorny General may proceed.
2. The Statute gives power to any per≈øon to inform, &c. by which general Words the Di≈øability of this per≈øon is removed.
But the Court held that there was no colour in either of the≈øe Objections.
3. 'Tis not pleaded ≈øub pede ≈øigilli, ≈øed non allocatur, for it need not be ≈øo pleaded being in the ≈øame Court.

4. 'Tis not averred that the Plaintiff was the ≈øame per≈øon, who was outlawed; but it was an≈øwered that the praedictus makes that certain, and that though the King be intere≈ø≈øed, yet the Informer
only is Plaintiff and intituled to the benefit, and that though he was di≈øabled yet he might ≈øue for the King,Moor 541. Dyer 227. b. Cro. Eliz. 583. but not for him≈øelf; and therefore Iudgment was given that the Plea was good.

div.head: Harwood & Bincks ver≈øus Hilliard, &c.
div.p: Notice, where 'tis agreed to be in writing, mu≈øt be ≈øo pleaded.BY an Agreement between the Plaintiffs and the Te≈øtator of the Defendant a parcel of Lands was to be ≈øold for 400 l. but if it did not ari≈øe to ≈øo much, then they covenanted with each other to repay proportionable to the Abatement; and the Defendant's Te≈øtator covenanted for him≈øelf and his Executors to pay his proportion to the Plaintiffs, ≈øo as the Plaintiffs gave him notice in writing of the ≈øaid Sale by the ≈øpace of ten days, but doth not ≈øay, that ≈øuch notice was to be given to his Executors or Admini≈øtrators.
And now the Plaintiffs averred, that they gave notice accordingly to the Defendant who was Executor, and the breach a≈ø≈øigned was, that he hath not paid, &c.

The Defendant demands Dyer of the Indenture wherein was a variance between the Covenant (which was for notice to be given to the Te≈øtator) and this Declaration (by which notice is averred to be given to the Executor;) and for this rea≈øon he demurred.

And Serjeant Dolben Recorder of London argued for him, that this was in the Nature of a Condition precedent, and therefore they ought to have given the Te≈øtator notice, which according to the Agreement ought al≈øo to have been per≈øonal, which not being done, but only notice given to his Executor, did make a material and fatal difference between the Covenant and this Declaration, 14 H. 6. 1. 1 H. 6. 9.
And that in this Ca≈øe there was no Covenant by the Te≈øtator at all, for all agree to pay their proportions, and the Te≈øtator ≈øhould pay his part, which is not a Covenant.

Barrel Serjeant on the other ≈øide ≈øaid, that the Executor doth repre≈øent the per≈øon of the Te≈øtator; and that though this Covenant was to give notice to the Te≈øtator, yet if the Declaration had been of a Covenant to give notice to him, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, &c. it had been no material variance ≈øo as to prejudice the Action of the Plaintiff, becau≈øe 'tis no more than what the Law implies, Pl. Com. 192.

And upon the fir≈øt opening this Matter this Term the Chief Iu≈øtice and Iu≈øtice Atkins enclined that the notice ought to be per≈øonal, and that the variance was material: But afterwards in Hillary Term following mutata opinione, the whole Court agreed it to be otherwi≈øe, becau≈øe the Covenant runs in Intere≈øt and Charge, and ≈øo the Executor is bound to pay; and therefore 'tis nece≈ø≈øary that he ≈øhould have notice, and that there was no material difference between the Declaration and the Covenant. And la≈øtly,Antea. that the Te≈øtator being a Party to the Deed his Agreement to pay amounts to a Covenant, though the formal Words of Covenant, Grant, &c. were wanting.

But then Serjeant Dolben perceiving the Opinion of the Court in≈øi≈øted, that the Declaration was naught for another rea≈øon, viz. they had not declared, that this notice was given in writing, which is expre≈øly agreed in the Covenant; to which it was an≈øwered that the Defendant having pleaded that he gave notice ≈øecundum formam & effectum Conditionis, it was well enough.

But he ≈øaid that would not help the want of Sub≈øtance,Dyer 243. b. and cited a Ca≈øe where an Action of Debt was brought for the performance of an Award, ≈øo as the ≈øame was delivered in Writing, &c. The Defendant pleaded Non deliberavit in ≈øcriptis, &. The Plaintiff replyed and ≈øet forth the Award in Writing, but did not directly an≈øwer the Plea of delivering it in Writing, only by way of Argument; and upon Demurrer there omnes Ju≈øticiarii contra Querentem; and ≈øo they were in this Ca≈øe, that the notice mu≈øt be pleaded in Writing, and that ≈øecundum formam Conditionis was not good; And ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Frosdick ver≈øus Sterling.
div.p: THE Plaintiff alone brought an Action on the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Defendant, and ≈øets forth,Baron and Feme where the Action, if its not di≈øcharged, ≈øhall ≈øurvive to her, they mu≈øt both join. that he and his Wife in her Right were ≈øei≈øed of a Me≈ø≈øuage, Bake-Hou≈øe and Cole-Yard, &c. and that the Defendant had erected two Hou≈øes of Office ≈øo near the ≈øaid Bake-Hou≈øe that the Walls thereof became foundrous, and the Air ≈øo unwhole≈øome, that he lo≈øt his Cu≈øtom; and that the Defendant had digged a Pit ≈øo near the ≈øaid Cole-Yard that the Walls thereof were in danger of falling; and that he had built another Wall ≈øo near the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, that he had ≈øtopped an old Light therein: Vpon Not-guilty pleaded there was a Verdict for the Plaintiff.

And now Serjeant George Strode moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, for that the Wife ≈øhould have been joyned in this Action, for where ≈øhe may maintain an Action for a tort done in the Life-time of her Husband, if ≈øhe ≈øurvive, and where ≈øhe may al≈øo recover Damages, in ≈øuch Ca≈øes ≈øhe mu≈øt joyn; and it hath been adjudged that ≈øhe ought to joyn with her Husband for ≈øtopping a way upon her Land, Cro. Car. 418.

1 Roll. Abr. 348. pl. 1. 20 H. 6. 1. ‚Ä¢ Ed. 4. 15. Cro. El. 461.So al≈øo for cutting down Trees on the Ioynture of the Wife, made to her by a former Husband, by rea≈øon whereof the pre≈øent Husband lo≈øt the Loppings, they both joyned, for though the wrong was done to his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and he might have Relea≈øed, yet becau≈øe there was al≈øo a wrong done to the Inheritance, they ought both to joyn, Cro. Car. 438.

3 In≈øt. 650.So it hath been adjudged, that the Husband and Wife in Right of the Wife jojned in an Action of Debt upon the Statute of 2 E. 6. cap. 13. for not ≈øetting out of Tythes, and held good, and where the Wife cured a wound,2 Cro. 205, 399. 9 E. 4. 55. both joyned in the Action, 11 H. 4. 16. 46. E. 3. 3.

The Court held, That where the Action (if not di≈øcharged) ≈øhall ≈øurvive to the Wife, they ought both to joyn, which if they had done here, it would have been hard to have maintained this Action, becau≈øe entire Damages are given; and for lo≈øing the Cu≈øtom to his Bake-hou≈øe, the Husband alone ought to have brought the Action. He may bring an Ejectment of the Lands of his Wife; but Iudgment was ≈øtayed, till moved on the other ≈øide.

div.head: Barker ver≈øus Warren.
div.p: Ju≈øtification where 'tis not local, a Traver≈øe of the place makes the Plea naught.AN Action was brought again≈øt a Carrier, and laid in London, for lo≈øing of Goods there which were delivered to him at Beverly in York≈øhire, to re-deliver at London.
The Defendant pleads, That he was robbed of the ≈øaid Goods at Lincoln, ab≈øqe hoc that he lo≈øt them in London. And the Plaintiff demurred.
1. For that Robbery is no excu≈øe for a Common Carrier, ≈øo that the Plea is not good in ≈øub≈øtance.
2. This was no local Iu≈øtification, ≈øo that the Traver≈øe was ill.

But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid by Serjeant Hopkins, that the Plea was good, and that the Defendant might Traver≈øe the place: For in Tre≈øpa≈øs for the taking of Goods in Coventry, the Defendand pleaded that the Plaintiff did deliver the Goods to him at London, to deliver at Dale, by force whereof he took them at London and delivered them at Dale accordingly, ab≈øque hoc that he took them at Coventry, and held good, for by his Plea he hath confe≈ø≈øed the delivery, and the taking both at one time and place; and he could not have pleaded the delivery at London, and ju≈øtifie the taking at Coventry, becau≈øe the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is confe≈ø≈øed by the fir≈øt delivery at London, and therefore the ju≈øtification of the taking at Coventry had been incon≈øi≈øtent, 24 H. 6. 5. But it had been otherwi≈øe, if the Defendant had ju≈øtified, becau≈øe the Plaintiff gave him the Goods at London, by force whereof he took them at London, ab≈øque hoc that he took them at Coventry, becau≈øe by ≈øuch Gift or Delivery, he might ju≈øtifie the taking any where as well as where the delivery was made.

2. That the Declaration was ill, for the Agreement was to deliver the Goods at London, and the breach was that he left them at London, and ≈øo but argumentative, A≈øton pl. Red. 62. Herns Pleader 76. Brownl. Pleadings 139.

But the Court were of Opinion that the Declaration was good, and the Plea was naught in ≈øub≈øtance; but if it had been good, the Traver≈øe notwith≈øtanding had been ill, becau≈øe the ju≈øtification was not local,2 Cro. 45, 372 though Iu≈øtice Scroggs was of a contrary Opinion: And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

Nota, Vi≈øne altered, Propter nece≈ø≈øiatem. The Plaintiff had leave given by the Court to alter the Vi≈øne from London to Middle≈øex, becau≈øe all the Sittings in London were on a Saturday, and his Witne≈øs was a Jew, and would not appear that day.

div.head: Mendyke ver≈øus Stint.
div.p:
PRohibition was prayed to the Sheriffs Court of London: Prohibition to the Sheriffs Court after Verdict and Judgment, comes too late. The Sugge≈øtion was, That the Plaintiff was ≈øued in that Court in an Action on the Ca≈øe, and ≈øets forth the Proceedings at large, that there was a Verdict again≈øt him there, and averred that the Contract upon which he was ≈øued there revera was made in Middle≈øex, and ≈øo the cau≈øe of Action did not ari≈øe within their
Iurisdiction; and upon Demurrer to the Prohibition Serjeant Pemberton argued,

2 In≈øt. 229, 243, 601. We≈øt. 1. c. 35. F. N. B. 45. b. Hob. 106. 1. That a Prohibition doth lie to any Court, as well Temporal as Spiritual (where ≈øuch Courts exceed their Bounds) for both tho≈øe Iurisdictions are united to the Imperial Crown; it may be granted to the Dutchy Court, if they hold Plea of Lands not parcel of the Dutchy.

2.
