Though the Iury have here found that the Defendant a≈ø≈øump≈øit modo & forma, yet ≈øuch finding as to time and place is not material; nor is it any E≈øtoppel in a new Action laid in another County, to aver that it was for the ≈øame thing: 'Tis true, both time and place may be made material by pleading, and ≈øo it had been in this Ca≈øe, if the Iury had found the place preci≈øely, for it would have been an E≈øtoppel.

The Verdict therefore is nothing, and all they have done is coram non Judice. The Ca≈øe ofAntea, Squib and Holt. Squib and Hole he cited as an Authority in point, where it was adjudged no E≈øcape in the Officer, to let a Man at Liberty, who was in Execution upon a Bond, ≈øued in an Inferior Court, the Bond not being made within the Iurisdiction thereof.

Ex parte Def.But Maynard, Dolben, Goodfellow and Symp≈øon Serjeants, contra. They agreed, that where it appears by the Plaintiffs Libel that the Court had no Iurisdiction, there a Prohibition lies at any time; but if what is in the Declaration is laid infra jurisdictionem, there the Party mu≈øt plead extra juri≈ødictionem, and if they refu≈øe to plead to the Plea, a Prohibition will lie after Sentence.

But here is an Action on the Ca≈øe brought, of which the Sheriffs Court can hold Plea, and which is laid to be infra juri≈ødictionem, and not denied by the Plaintiff in his Plea, and therefore now, after Verdict and Iudgment, he comes too late for a Prohibition; and upon this difference Prohibitions have been u≈øually either granted or denied to the Spiritual Courts.

Though the Court hath not cogni≈øance of the Cau≈øe, yet the Proceedings are not coram non Judice; for if it be alledged to be within the Iurisdiction, and the Defendant takes no exception to it, and then Sentence is given again≈øt him, he hath there. by admitted the Iurisdiction.

So where a Man ≈øued for a Legacy in the Prerogative Court, where the Will was proved,Stiles 45. by the Opinion of Rolls C. J. 2 Roll. Abr. 318. and Sentence given, and an Appeal to the Delegates, and Sentence affirmed, and then a Prohibition granted (but without notice) upon the Statute of 23 H. 8. cap. 9. for that the Parties lived in another Dioce≈øs; but the Plaintiff having allowed the Iuri≈ødiction in all the former proceedings,
though the Prohibition was granted, the Court would not compel the Party to appear and plead, but granted a Con≈øultation, Cro. Car. 97. Smith ver≈øus the Executors of Pondrel.

In Hillary-Term 1675. in B.R. between Spring and Vernon, and in Michaelmas-Term in 22 Car. 2. B. R. Buxton's Ca≈øe, and in Hillary Term the 22 & 23 Car. 2. in the ≈øame Court, between Cox and St. Albon Prohibitions were denied after the Iurisdiction adadmitted by Pleading.Mod. Rep. 81.

The Chief Iu≈øtice, Wyndham and Atkyns, upon the fir≈øt Argument enclined that a Prohibition ought to be granted, becau≈øe the admittance of the Party cannot give a Iurisdiction where originally there was none; but afterwards they were all of Opinion, That the Prohibition ≈øhould not go, but ≈øaid, that the Plaintiff in the Inferiour Court ought to have been Non-≈øuited, if it appeared upon the Evidence that the Cau≈øe of Action did ari≈øe extra juri≈ødictionem.
In this Ca≈øe the≈øe things were agreed by the Court.
1. Sid. 151. That if any matter appears in the Declaration which ≈øheweth that the Cau≈øe of Action did not ari≈øe infra juri≈ødictionem, there a Prohibition may be granted at any time.
2. If the ≈øubject matter in the Declaration be not proper for the Iudgment and determination of ≈øuch Court, there al≈øo a Prohibition may be granted at any time.

3. If the Defendant, who intended to plead to the Iuri≈ødiction, is prevented by any Artifice, as by giving a ≈øhort day, or by the Attornies refu≈øing to plead it, &c. or if his Plea be not accepted or is over-ruled; in all the≈øe Ca≈øes a Prohibition likewi≈øe will lie at any time.

And the Chief Iu≈øtice and Wyndham Iu≈øtices were of Opinion that after the Defendant had admitted the Iuri≈ødiction by pleading to the Action, e≈øpecially if Verdict and Iudgment pa≈øs, the Court will not examine whether the Cau≈øe of Action did ari≈øe out of the Iurisdiction or not. But Atkyns and Scroggs Iu≈øtices ≈øaid nothing to this la≈øt point, but that many times an advantage given by the Law was lo≈øt by coming too late, and in≈øtanced that a Vi≈øne may be changed in time, but not if the Party come too late; ≈øo if the time of the promi≈øe be laid above ≈øix years from the time of the Action brought, if the Statute of Limitations be not pleaded, the Defendant cannot take afterwards advantage of it.
Whereupon a Prohibition was denied, and Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Birch ver≈øus Wil≈øon.
div.p: Plea, tho' it amount to a general I≈ø≈øue, if it doth di≈øclo≈øe matter of Law be≈øides, it ≈øhall not be demurred unto.IN an Action on the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared that he was ≈øei≈øed of a Me≈øuage and ≈øeveral Lands in the Pari≈øh of Dale, and that he and all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtate he hath, have u≈øed to have right of Common, for all Commonable Cattle, Levant and Couchant upon the Premi≈ø≈øes, in a certain Meadow there, called Darpmore Meadow, and in a certain place called Cannock Wood. That the Defendant praemi≈ø≈øorum non ignarus, had enclo≈øed the ≈øaid places in which the Plaintiff had right of Common, and likewi≈øe put in his Cattle, as Hor≈øes, Cows, Hoggs, Gee≈øe, &c. ≈øo that he could not in tam amplo & beneficiali modo enjoy the ≈øame.

The Defendant as to the Inclo≈øure and putting in of his Hoggs and Gee≈øe pleaded Not Guilty: And as to the re≈øidue, That the Lord Paget was ≈øei≈øed of a Me≈øuage, 300 Acres of Land, 40 Acres of Meadow, and 100 Acres of Pa≈øture, and likewi≈øe of Darpmore Meadow and Cannock Wood; and being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed did by Deed of Bargain and Sale enrolled, in con≈øideration of 2000 l. convey the ≈øaid Me≈øuage, 300 Acres of Land, 40 Acres of Meadow, and 100 Acres of Pa≈øture, to the Defendant and his Heirs, and by the ≈øame Deed, did Grant unto him all Waies, Commons, and Emoluments what≈øoever, to the ≈øaid Me≈øuage and Premi≈ø≈øes belonging, or therewithal u≈øed, occupied or enjoyed, or taken as part, parcel or member thereof, virtute cujus the Defendant became ≈øei≈øed of the Premi≈ø≈øes; and that the ≈øame were lea≈øed and demi≈øed for years by the ≈øaid Lord Paget, and all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtate he had a tempore cujus contrarii memoria hominum non exi≈øtit; and that the Tenants or Occupiers thereof a tempore cujus, &c. u≈øed to have Common in Darpmore Meadow, and Cannock Wood, for all commonable Cattle Levant and Couchant upon the Premi≈ø≈øes, and u≈øed to put in their Cattle into the ≈øaid places, in which, &c. virtute cujus the Defendant having Right, did put in his ≈øaid Cattle into the ≈øaid Places, to take Common there, and averred, That there was Common ≈øufficient both for the Plaintiff and him≈øelf.
To this Plea the Plaintiff Demurred.

This Ca≈øe was argued by Serjeant Pemberton for the Plaintiff, and by Serjeant We≈øton for the Defendant;Ex parte Quer. and for the Plaintiff it was ≈øaid, That it was no good Plea, but rather a de≈øign to introduce a new way of Common.
The Rea≈øons offered why the Plea was not good, were

1. Cro. Car. 419. That the Defendant could not pre≈øcribe becau≈øe of the Vnity of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, for the Lord Paget had the Premi≈ø≈øes in and to which, &c. and therefore he hath pre≈øcribed by a collateral matter, Viz. by alledging that the Land was u≈øually let to Tenants for years, but doth not ≈øay whether they were Tenants by Copy of Court Roll or not, neither doth he make out any Title in them.

In ≈øome Ca≈øes where a Man is not privy to the Title, he may ≈øay generally that the Owners and Occupiers u≈øed to do ≈øuch a thing, &c. and this way of Pleading may be good; but here the Defendant claiming under them, ought to ≈øet forth their Title, or el≈øe he can have no Right to the Common.

2. By this Plea he intended that the Lord Paget had made a New Grant of this Common; for he ≈øets forth, That he granted the Premi≈ø≈øes, and all Commons u≈øed with the ≈øame, and ≈øo would intitle him≈øelf to a Right of Common in tho≈øe two places, as if Common had been expre≈øsly granted to him there, which if it ≈øhould, 'tis but argumentative, and no direct affirmance of a Grant, upon which the Plaintiff might have replied non conce≈ø≈øit, for no I≈ø≈øue can be joyned upon it.
3. He ought to have ≈øet forth, That the Tenants lawfully enjoyed the Common there; but he lays only an u≈øage to have Common, which may be tortious.

4. He doth not ≈øay, That there is ≈øufficient Common for all the Commoners, but only for the Plaintiff and him≈øelf: 'Tis true, the Owner of the Soil may feed with his Tenant, who hath a Right of Common, but he cannot derogate from the fir≈øt, by ≈øtreightning the Common by a ≈øecond Grant, and ≈øo leave not ≈øufficint for the Tenant.

5. This Plea amounts to the General I≈ø≈øue,Cro. Car. 157. and the Plaintiff hath ≈øpecially a≈ø≈øigned that for a Cau≈øe of Demurrer; for he ≈øaith, That the Defendant, without any Title, put in his Cattle, by which the Plaintiff had not ≈øufficient Common; and the Defendant pleads he put in his Cattle rightfully, and the Plaintiff had Common enough, which if it ≈øignifie any thing, mu≈øt amount to Not Guilty.

Ex parte Def.But on the other ≈øide, the la≈øt Objection was endeavoured to be an≈øwered fir≈øt, becau≈øe if that hold, yet if the Plea be never ≈øo good in Sub≈øtance, the Plaintiff would have Iudgment.

It was agreed that this Plea doth amount to a General I≈ø≈øue, and no more, but that every Plea that doth ≈øo, is not therefore bad; for if it otherwi≈øe contain rea≈øonable matter of Law, which is put upon the Court for their Iudgment, rather than referred to the Iury, there is is no cau≈øe of Demurrer, for it is the ≈øame thing to have the doubt or que≈øtion in Law before the Iudges in Pleading, as to have it before them upon a Special Verdict.
In 2 R. 2. 18. A Retainer was pleaded ≈øpecially by an Admini≈øtrator, which is no more than Plene Admini≈øtravit, yet no Demurrer; but the Book ≈øaith that the Court ought to be moved.

2. The Plea is good as to the matter of it; for the Defendant claims the ≈øame Common by his Grant which had been u≈øed time immemorial, and alledges it to be of all Common u≈øed with the Premi≈ø≈øes, and this was a Common ≈øo u≈øed.

In Tre≈øpa≈øs the Defendant ju≈øtified that Godfrey was ≈øei≈øed in Fee of a Hou≈øe, and of 20 Acres of Land, and that he and all tho≈øe, &c. had Common in the place where, &c. to the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage belonging; and that he made a Feoffment to Brad≈øhaw of the ≈øame, who made a Lea≈øe thereof to the Defendant, with all Profits and Commodities thereunto belonging, vel occupat vel u≈øitat cum praedicto Me≈øuagio: It was adjudged that though the Common was gone and extinct in the Hands of the Feoffor by the unity of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, yet tho≈øe Words were a good Grant of a New Common for the time granted in the Lea≈øe, and that it was qua≈øi a Common in the Hands of Godfrey the Feoffor, Cro. Eliz. 570. Godfrey ver≈øus Eyre.

And though it hath been objected, That this Plea is not formally pleaded, becau≈øe it ought to have been direct in alledging a Grant; whereas it was only argumentative, and brought in by a ≈øide Wind, he ≈øaid, That as bad as it was, 'twas drawn by that Serjeant who argued again≈øt him, and who did very well know that the Averment of ≈øufficiency of Common was needle≈øs.

Curia.The Court were all of Opinion, That though the Plea did amount to the general I≈ø≈øue, yet for that rea≈øon alone the Plaintiff had no cau≈øe of Demurrer; for the Defendant may
well di≈øclo≈øe the matter of Law in Pleading, which is a much cheaper way than to have a Special Verdict, and that this is on the ≈øame rea≈øon of giving of colour; but if the matter by which the Defendant ju≈øtifies, be all matter of Fact and proper for the Tryal of a Iury, then the Dfendant ought to plead the General I≈ø≈øue.

And as to the Matter of the Plea, the Chief Iu≈øtice and Wyndham Iu≈øtice held it to be good; for the Common which was pleaded was a Common by Grant and not argumentatively pleaded; for if the Defendant had pleaded an expre≈øs Grant of Common in tho≈øe two places, and the Plaintiff had demanded Oyer of the Deed, it would have appeared that there was no ≈øuch Deed, and this had been a good cau≈øe of Demurrer.

If this Plea ≈øhould not be good it would be very mi≈øchievous to the Defendant; for there being a perpetual Vnity, as to the Freehold there can be no Pre≈øcription to the Common; but there being a con≈øtant enjoyment thereof by the Tenants, and ≈øo a perpetual V≈øage and a Grant made referring to that V≈øage, 'tis well enough: And ≈øince, whil≈øt the Lands were in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Lord, the Commoners could not complain of a Surcharge; why ≈øhould they, if he grant the Premi≈ø≈øes, the Grante√© being in loco, &c.

In the Ca≈øe of the King a Grant of tot & talia Libertates & Privilegia quot & qualia the Abbot lately had,9 Co. 23. Abbot de Strata Marcella. was held good by ≈øuch general Words: Here the Lord Paget granted to the Defendant that which the Le≈ø≈ø√©es had before, viz. that Common which the Tenants had time out of mind; and it cannot be conceived, but that the Tenants had a Right; for as a Tort cannot be pre≈øumed to be from time immemorial, ≈øo neither ≈øhall it be intended that the Lord gave only a Licence, and permitted his Tenants to enjoy this Common.

But Iu≈øtice Atkins was of Opinion that the Plea was not good; he ≈øaid, he knew not by what Name to call this Common; for it was no more than a Permi≈ø≈øion from the Lord, that the Tenants might put their Cattle into his Freehold, or a Connivance at them for ≈øo doing; and if it be taken as a new Grant, then nothing can pa≈øs, but the Surplus; for the Lord cannot derogate from his former Grant, and the new Grantee ≈øhall not put in an equal proportion with him who hath the Pre≈øcription; for if he may, then ≈øuch Pre≈øcription would be quite de≈øtroyed by ≈øuch pui≈øne Grant; for as the Lord might grant to
one, ≈øo he might to twenty, and then there would not be ≈øufficient Common left for him, who pre≈øcribes to the Right: So that he conceived that the Defendant had no Right of Common, or if he had any, it would not be till after the Right of the Plaintiff was ≈øerved; and he ≈øaid that V≈øage ≈øhall not intend a Right, but it may be an Evidence of it upon a Tryal.

But if there had been an V≈øage 'tis now lo≈øt by the Vnity of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øhall not be revived by the new Grant, like the Ca≈øe of Ma≈ø≈øam and Hunter; Yelv. 189. there was a Copyholder of a Me≈ø≈øuage and two Acres in Fe√©, which the Lord afterwards granted and confirmed to him in Fee cum pertinentiis, it was adjudged that though the Tenant by V≈øage had a Right to have Common in the Lord's Wa≈øt, yet by this new Grant and Confirmation that Right was gone (the Copyhold being thereby extingui≈øhed;) for the Common being by V≈øage and now lo≈øt, the≈øe Words cum pertinentiis in the new Grant will not revive it.
But notwith≈øtanding Iudgment by the Opinion, of the other three Iu≈øtices, was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Week's Ca≈øe.
div.p: A Prohibition was prayed to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court at Bri≈øtol; the Sugge≈øtion was that he was excommunicated for refu≈øing to an≈øwer upon Oath to a Matter by which he might accu≈øe him≈øelf, viz. to be a Witne≈øs again≈øt another; that he him≈øelf was pre≈øent ≈øuch a day, and ≈øaw the other at a Conventicle, which if he confe≈ø≈øed, they would have recorded his Confe≈ø≈øion of being pre≈øent at a Meeting, and ≈øo have proceeded again≈øt him.
The Court granted a Prohibition, but ordered him to appear in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court to be examined as to the other per≈øons being there.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: A Man wins 100 l. of another at play;Gaming not within the Statute, where the Security is given to a third per≈øon. the Winner owed Sharp 100 l. who demanded his Debt; the Winner brought him to the other, of whom he won the Mony at Play, who aknowledged the Debt, and gave Sharp a Bond for the payment of the 100 l. who not being privy to the Matter, or knowing that it was won at Play, accepted the ≈øaid Bond, and for default of payment puts it in Suit; the Obligor pleads the Statute of Gaming.

The Plaintiff in his Replication di≈øclo≈øeth the Matter afore≈øaid and ≈øaith, that he had a ju≈øt Debt due and owing to him form the Winner, and that he was not privy to the Monies being won at Play, &c. and that he accepted of the ≈øaid Bond as a Security for his Debt; and the Defendant demurred.

And the Court were all of Opinion,Hill and Phe≈øant, Antea. that this Ca≈øe was not within the Statute; the Plaintiff not knowing of the Play, and though it be pleaded that the Bond was taken pro Securitate, and not for ≈øatisfaction of a ju≈øt Debt, it was held well enough, like the Ca≈øe of Warns and Ellis, Yelv. 47. Warns owed Alder 100 l. upon an u≈øurious Contract, and Alder owed the Plaintiff Ellis 100 l. for which they were both bound; and in an Action of Debt brought upon this Bond Warns pleads the Statute of V≈øury between him and Alder; and Ellis replyed as the Plaintiff here; and upon a Demurrer it was adjudged for the Plaintiff by thr√©e Iudges, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had a real Debt owing him and was not privy to the V≈øury: And upon this Ca≈øe the Court relyed, and ≈øaid, the Rea≈øon of it governed this Ca≈øe at the Barr; whereupon Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Ti≈ø≈øard ver≈øus Warcup.
div.p: INdebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit for 750 l. laid out by the Plaintiff for the u≈øe of the Defendant: Vpon Non a≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded, there was a Tryal at the Barr; and the Evidence was, that the Defendant and another, now decea≈øed, farmed the Exci≈øe; that the Mony was laid out by the Plaintiff on the behalf of the Defendant and his Partner; and that the Defendant promi≈øed to repay the Mony out of the fir≈øt Profits he received.
Curia.And by the Opinion of the whole Court this Action would not lie.

1. Two Partners being concerned the Action cannot be brought again≈øt one alone; he ought in this Ca≈øe to have ≈øet out the death of the other: But if Iudgment be had again≈øt one, the Goods in Partner≈øhip may be taken in Execution.
1 Cro. 239. Hob. 180. Rol. Rep. 233.2. The Promi≈øe here was not to pay the Mony ab≈øolutely, but ≈øub modo; ≈øo that the Evidence did not maintain the Action; and the Plaintiff was Non≈øuited.

div.head: Nichols ver≈øus Ram≈øel.
div.p:
Relea≈øe of all Demands u≈ø
que
26 Apr. a Bond dated that day is not relea≈øed.TRe≈øpa≈øs done 24 Martii 26 Car. 2. u≈øque 26 Augu≈øti 28 Car. 2. diver≈øis diebus & vicibus, &c.

The Defendant pleaded that on the 24th day of April in the 26th year of King Charles the Second he paid the Plaintiff 6 d. which he received in full ≈øatisfaction of all Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes u≈øque ad the ≈øaid 24th day of April, ab≈øque hoc that he was guilty ad aliquod aliud tempus praeter praedictum 24 Aprilis anno 26 Car. 2. aut aliquo tempore po≈øtea, but leaveth out the 24th day of April; and for that Rea≈øon the Plaintiff demurred, becau≈øe the Defendant had not an≈øwered that day, for the Word u≈øque excludes it.

So where Debt was brought upon a Bond dated 9 Julii, the Defendant pleaded a Relea≈øe of all Actions,Owen '50. 2 Rol. Abr. 521. &c. the ≈øame day u≈øque diem dati eju≈ødem ≈øcripti, the Bond was not di≈øcharged, becau≈øe the Relea≈øe excludes the 9th day, on which it was made.

But Serjeant We≈øton contra. Though generally in pleading the Word u≈øque is exclu≈øive; yet in the Ca≈øe of Contracts, becau≈øe of the intent of the Parties, 'tis inclu≈øive; and therefore in one Nichol's Ca≈øe, 20 Car. 2. in B. R. Rot. 21. (the Term was not named) a Lea≈øe was made Habendum from Lady-day u≈øque Fe≈øtum Sancti Michaelis, 1665. paying the Rent re≈øerved at Michaelmas during the Term; the Rent ≈øhall be paid on Michaelmas-day, 1665. and ≈øo the day ≈øhall not be excluded.

So where a Man pre≈øcribes to put Cattle from and immediately after Lady-day, where they are to ≈øtay till Michaelmas-day; the putting them in on Lady-day and driving them away on Michaelmas-day is not ju≈øtifiable in ≈øtrictne≈øs, yet it hath been allowed good.

So in a Devi≈øe the Que≈øtion was, whether the Te≈øtator was of Age or not; and the Evidence was, that he was born the fir≈øt day of January in the Afternoon of that day, and died in the Morning on the la≈øt day of December: And it was held by all the Iudges that he was of full Age, for there ≈øhall be no fraction of a day.
North Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that prima facie this is to be intended good; for a day is but Punctum temporis, and ≈øo of no great con≈øideration.

But the other three Iu≈øtices were of Opinion, that the Word U≈øque was exclu≈øive; and that the Plaintiff ≈øhould not be put to ≈øhew that there was a Tre≈øpa≈øs done on the 24th of April; and ≈øaid that in a Relea≈øe of all Demands till the 26th of April, a Bond dated that day is not relea≈øed; wherefore Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Trevil ver≈øus Ingram.
div.p: COvenant to pay an Herriot po≈øt mortem J. S. or 40 s. at the election of the Plaintiff;Relea≈øe of all Demands doth not barr a future Duty. Mod. Rep. 216. and ≈øets forth the death of J. S. and that afterwards he cho≈øe to have the 40 s. for which he brought this Action, and a≈ø≈øigns the Breach for Non payment.
The Defendant pleaded that the Plaintiff relea≈øed to him all Actions and Demands, &c. But this Relea≈øe was made in the Life time of J. S. and there was an Exception in it of Herriots.

The Plaintiff demurred, and Serjeant George Strode argued that this Action was not di≈øcharged by that Relea≈øe, and cited Hoes Ca≈øe, 5 Co 70. where it was held, that a Duty incertain at fir≈øt, which upon a Condition precedent was to be made certain afterwards, was but a po≈ø≈øibility which could not be relea≈øed; that the Duty in this Ca≈øe was incertain, becau≈øe the Plaintiff could not make his Election till after the death of J. S.

A Covenant to repair,2 Cro. 170. Roll. Abr. 407. But a Relea≈øe of all Covenants in ≈øuch an Indenture had been a Barr, 5 Co. 71. a. and a Relea≈øe pleaded to it within thr√©e days after the date of the Indenture: And upon a Demurrer it was held, that it being a future Covenant, and not in demand at the time of the Relea≈øe, although it was of all Demands, yet that Covenant was not thereby relea≈øed.

So here neither the Herriot nor the 40 s. were either of them in demand at the time of the Relea≈øe given, and it plainly appears by the Exception in the Relea≈øe that it was the intention of the Parties not to relea≈øe the Herriots;2 Cro. 623. and of that Opinion was the whole Court; whereupon Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

North Chief Iu≈øtice: It is the Opinion ofSect. 508, 510. 2 Roll. Abr. 408. Sid. 141. Littleton, That a Relea≈øe of all Demands doth Relea≈øe a Rent: And of that Opinion was Iu≈øtice Twi≈øden in the Argument of Hen and Han≈øon's Ca≈øe, though it was re≈øolved there, that a Relea≈øe of all Demands did not di≈øcharge a Rent re≈øerved upon a Lea≈øe for years, becau≈øe ≈øuch Rent is executory, and incident to the Rever≈øion,2 Cro. 486. and grows every year out of the Land; but when it is ≈øevered from the Rever≈øion, as by a≈ø≈øigning over the whole Term, then it becomes a Sum in gro≈øs, and is due upon the Contract, and in that Ca≈øe a Relea≈øe of all Demands di≈øcharges a Rent afterwards due.

div.head: DE Term. Sancti Hill. Annis 29 & 30 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Shambrok ver≈øus Fettiplace.
div.p: PRohibition.Pre≈øcription to have an I≈øle in a Church becau≈øe of repairing, no good cau≈øe for a Prohibition. Hob. 69. The Que≈øtion was whether a Pre≈øcription be good to an I≈øle in a Church which he and all tho≈øe, &c. u≈øed to repair, as belonging to a Mannor, where he had no Dwelling Hou≈øe but only Land; and Serjeant Geo. Croke argued that it was good, and cited the Ca≈øe of Boothby and Bayly, where ≈øuch a Pre≈øcription as this was held to be a good ground for a Prohibition, Vide Moor Rep. 878. contra.
The Court inclined that it was not good, but ordered the Prohibition to go, and the Defendant to plead, that it might come Iudicially before them to be argued.

div.head: Da≈øhwood ver≈øus Cooper & alios, in Cammera Scaccarii.
div.p: ERror of a Iudgment in Tre≈øpa≈øs,In a Negative Plea, viz. That three did not ≈øuch a thing, it mu≈øt be ≈øaid nec eorum aliquis. wherein Cooper and others brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt Da≈øhwood for entring into a Brew-hou≈øe and keeping of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and taking away of 50 s.

The Defendant pleaded, That the Plaintiffs had committed an Offence again≈øt the Statute of 12 Car. 2. cap. 23. by which it is Enacted, That all Offences thereby prohibited (except in
London) ≈øhall be heard by two or more of the next Ju≈øtices of Peace, and in ca≈øe of their neglect or refu≈øal by the ≈øpace of 14 days after complaint made, then the Sub-Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Exci≈øe are to determine the ≈øame, from whom no Appeal doth lye to the Ju≈øtices of the Peace at their next Se≈ø≈øions, which Commi≈ø≈øioners of Exci≈øe, Ju≈øtices of the Peace and Sub-Commi≈ø≈øioners among≈øt other things are inabled by the ≈øaid Act, to I≈ø≈øue out Warrants under their Hands, &c. to levie the Forfeitures, and ≈øo ju≈øtified the Entry under a Warrant from the Sub-Commi≈ø≈øioners, three Iu≈øtices having refu≈øed to hear and determine this Offence.

To this Plea the Plaintiffs demurred, and had Iudgment in the Court of Kings-Bench, and a Writ of Inquiry of Damages was Executed, and 750 l. Damages given; and it was alledged that the Defendant could not move to ≈øet a≈øide the Iudgment in that Term it was given, becau≈øe the Writ of Inquiry was executed the la≈øt day of the Term, and the Court did immediatly ri≈øe; and that he could not move the next Term, becau≈øe the Iudgment was given the Term before the Writ of Error was brought.

The Attorny General therefore ≈øaid that this was a hard Ca≈øe, and de≈øired a Note of the Exceptions to the Plea, which he would endeavour to maintain, which Mr. Pollexfen gave him, and then he de≈øired time to an≈øwer them.
The Exception to the Plea upon which the Iudgment was given was this;

Viz. The Act giveth no power to the Sub-Commi≈ø≈øioners to hear and determine the Offences, and ≈øo to i≈ø≈øue out Warrants for the Forfeitures, but where the Iu≈øtices or any two of them refu≈øe: And though it was ≈øaid by the Defendant that three refu≈øed, yet it was not ≈øaid that two did refu≈øe; for there is a great difference between the allegation of a thing in the Affirmative and in the Negative; for if I affirm that A. B. C. did ≈øuch a thing, that affirmation goes to all of them, but negatively it will not hold; for if I ≈øay A. B. C. did not ≈øuch a thing, there I mu≈øt add nec eorum aliquis.

So if an Action be brought again≈øt ≈øeveral Men, and a Nolle pro≈øequi is entred as to one, and a Writ of Enquiry awarded again≈øt the re≈øt, which recites, That the Plaintiff did by Bill implead (naming tho≈øe only again≈øt whom the Inquiry was awarded, and leaves out him who got the Nolle pro≈øequi) this is a variance, for it ≈øhould have been brought again≈øt them all.

'Tis true, where a Iudgment is recited 'tis enough to mention tho≈øe only again≈øt whom it is had, but the Declaration mu≈øt be again≈øt all; ≈øo in a Writ of Error if one is dead he mu≈øt be named; and ≈øo the Iu≈øtices ought all to be named in this Ca≈øe, viz. that the three next Iu≈øtices did not hear and determine this Offence, nec eorum aliquis.

div.head: Wells ver≈øus Wright. In Communi Banco.
div.p: DEBT upon Bond conditioned,Bond with an in≈øen≈øible Condition, good. that if the Oblig√©e ≈øhall pay 20 l. in manner and form following, that is to ≈øay, 5 l. upon four ≈øeveral days therein named; but if default ≈øhall be made in any of the Payments, then the ≈øaid Obligation ≈øhall be void, or otherwi≈øe to ≈øtand in full force and vertue.
The Defendant pleads that tali die, &c. non ≈øolvit 5 l. &c. and upon this the Plaintiff demurred.

Barrel Serjeant. The fir≈øt part of the Condition is good, which is to pay the Mony, and the other is ≈øurplu≈øage void and in≈øen≈øible; but if it be not void it may be good by trans≈øpo≈øing thus, viz. If he do pay, then the Obligation ≈øhall be void; if default ≈øhall be made in Payment then it ≈øhall be good; and for Authority in the Point the Ca≈øe of Vernon and Al≈øop was cited,Sid. 105. 1 Sand. 66. 2 Sand. 79. Hill. 14 Car. 2. Rot. 1786. in B. R. Where the Condition was, that if the Oblig√©e pay 2 s. per Week, until the Sum of 7 l. 10 s. be paid (viz. on every Saturday) and if he fail in Payment at any one day that the Bond ≈øhall be void; and upon the like Plea and Demurrer as here, it was adjudged that the Obligation was ≈øingle, and the Condition repugnant.
The Court were all of Opinion, that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff; and the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that he doubted whether the Ca≈øe of 39 H. 6. 9, 10. was Law.

div.head: Brittam ver≈øus Charnock.
div.p: Where the the Heir takes by the Will with a Charge, he is a Purcha≈øer, and the Lands ≈øhall not be A≈ø≈øets.DEBT upon Bond again≈øt the Defendant as Heir: Vpon Riens per di≈øcent pleaded, the Iury found a Special Verdict, in which the Ca≈øe was: viz.

The Father was ≈øeized of a Me≈ø≈øuage and thr√©e Acres of Land in Fee, and devi≈øed the ≈øame to his elde≈øt Son, (the Defendant) and his Heirs within four years after his decea≈øe, provided the Son pay 20 l. to the Executrix towards the Payment of the Te≈øtators Debts, and then he devi≈øeth his other Lands to be ≈øold for payment of Debts, &c. The Father dies, the Son pays the 20 l. and if this Me≈ø≈øuage &c. was A≈ø≈øets in the Hands of the Defendant, was the Que≈øtion.

Cro. Car. 161. Cro. Eliz. 431. 833. Vaugh. 271.That it was not A≈ø≈øets (it was ≈øaid) becau≈øe the Heir ≈øhall not take by de≈øcent, but by Purcha≈øe; for the Word Paying is no Condition, if it ≈øhould, the Heir is to enter for the breach, and that is the Defendant him≈øelf; and for that rea≈øon it ≈øhall be a Limitation.

Southcot and Stowel, Antea,'Tis true, where there is no alteration of the E≈øtate the Heir mu≈øt take by de≈øcent; but in this Ca≈øe there is an alteration of the E≈øtate from what is directed by the Law, viz. the manner how he ≈øhall come by the E≈øtate, for no Fee pa≈ø≈øeth to him during the four years.

But this was denyed by Serjeant Pemberton, for he ≈øaid, if a Devi≈øe be of Land to one and his Heirs within four years, it is a pre≈øent Devi≈øe, and if ≈øuch be made to the Heir 'tis a de≈øcent in the mean time, and tho≈øe Words (within four years) are void; ≈øo that the Que≈øtion will be, whether the Word Paying will make the Heir a Purcha≈øer; and he held it would not: He agreed, that it was u≈øual to make that a Word of Limitation, and not a Condition when the Devi≈øe is to the Heir; and therefore in a Devi≈øe to the Heir at Law in F√©e he ≈øhall take by de≈øcent, Styles Rep. 148.
But if this be neither a Condition or Limitation, 'tis a Charge upon the Land, and ≈øuch a Charge as the Heir cannot avoid in Equity.
North Chief Iu≈øtice and Atkins. Where the Heir takes by a Will with a Charge, as in this Ca≈øe, he doth not take by De≈øcent, but by Purcha≈øe, and therfore this is no A≈ø≈øets.

div.head: Moor ver≈øus Pit.
div.p: SPecial Verdict in Ejectment; The Ca≈øe was this,Surrender of a Copyhold to a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, whether good to extingui≈øh the Right. viz. A Copyholder for Life, the Remainder for Life, he in Remainder for Life ≈øurrenders the Copyhold to the Lord pro tempore (who was a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor only of the Mannor) ut inde faciat voluntatem ≈øuam; the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor grants it to a Stranger for Life, the Di≈ø≈øei≈øe√© enters, the Stranger dies, and whether the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor or he in the Remainder for Life, who made the Surrender, had the better Title, was the Que≈øtion.

So that the Point was,Cro. Car. 205. 2 Sid. 151. 1 Roll. Abr. 540. whether this Surrender by a Copyholder in Remainder into the Hands of the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor be good, and ≈øhall ≈øo extingui≈øh the Right to the Copyhold, that it ≈øhall not be revived by the Entry of the Di≈ø≈øei≈øee into the ≈øaid Mannor.

It was ≈øaid that in ≈øome Ca≈øes a Surrender into the Hands of a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor was good, that is, when the Surrender is made to him to the u≈øe of another and his Heirs, and he admits him, there the per≈øon admitted claims not under the Lord, but under the Copyholder, who made the Surrender;1 In≈øt. 59. b. for nothing pa≈ø≈øes to the Lord, but only to ≈øerve the Limitation of the V≈øe, 1 Rol. Abr. 503. litt. Q. pl. 1.4 Co. 24.

But in this Ca≈øe the Grant√©e mu≈øt claim from the Lord him≈øelf, and not from the Copyholder, becau≈øe he had but an E≈øtate for his own Life, with which he wholly departed when he made the Surrender to the u≈øe of the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor him≈øelf.
In Trinity-Term following this Ca≈øe was argued by Serjeant Maynard on the other ≈øide.
There are two ≈øorts of Surrenders of a Copyhold.

If a Surrender be to the Lord to the u≈øe of another, this is no proper Surrender; for no E≈øtate pa≈ø≈øeth to the Lord he being only the In≈øtrument to convey it to the Surrendree, and this is but nominal.

But here the Surrender was to the u≈øe of the Lord him≈øelf, which is a proper Surrender, and in ≈øuch Ca≈øe 'tis nece≈ø≈øary that the Lord have a Rever≈øion, for one E≈øtate is to be turned into the other, and there mu≈øt be a continuing of E≈øtates.
But Dominus pro tempore, who is a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor hath no ≈øuch E≈øtate: Executor de ≈øon tort ≈øhall ≈øue, but he cannot retain.

If therefore he is not capable to take a Surrender to him≈øelf, unle≈øs he hath ≈øuch an E≈øtate, then here is no Di≈ø≈øei≈øin of the Copyhold, 'tis only of the Mannor; and then no greater Intere≈øt pa≈ø≈øeth to the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor than to a Stranger, whil≈øt the true Lord had been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, for ≈øo he is quoad this Copyhold if he was not di≈ø≈øei≈øed of it; for if the Copyholder had the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion there could be then no Di≈ø≈øei≈øin; if he was out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion then he had nothing but a Right, and that cannot be ≈øurrendred, for it mu≈øt be an E≈øtate; as if a Le≈ø≈øee for years keep po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, 'tis the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Lord, and the Law is the ≈øame in ca≈øe of a Copyhold, 2 Co. Betti≈øworth's Ca≈øe.
Piggot and Lord Salisbury's Ca≈øe, AnteThe true Owner makes a Feoffment in Fee, if Le≈ø≈øee for years continue in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion no Fr√©ehold pa≈ø≈øeth.
If Tenant at Will of parcel of the Mannor be in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion that prevents a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin of the Freehold, much more in Ca≈øe of a Copyhold.

Le≈ø≈øee for years, the Remainder to B. for Life, the Remainder to C. in Fee; C. by Deed makes a Feoffment to B. and Livery, &c. 'tis a void Conveyance, becau≈øe the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Le≈ø≈øee for years is the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of him in the Remainder for Life, and as long as the Le≈ø≈øee for years is in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the Owner of the Inheritance cannot be out, Lit. 324. cap. Attornment.

North Chief Iu≈øtice and Wyndham enclined that the Surrender was not good; for it was a material di≈øtinction where the Surrender was made to the u≈øe of a Stranger, and where it terminates in the Lord; that a Surrender made by a Copyholder for Life could not transfer, but extingui≈øh his Right; for he could not give a greater E≈øtate than he had; that there mu≈øt be a Rever≈øion in the Lord to make a Surrender to him to be good; and that if a Copyholder keeps in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion there could be no Di≈ø≈øei≈øin.

But Iu≈øtice Atkins contra. That this Surrender mu≈øt have operation to extingui≈øh his Right; for though a Copyholder for Life cannot ≈øurrender for longer time than his own Life; yet if a Surrender be made of ≈øuch a Copyhold to an V≈øe 'tis good, and works by way of Extingui≈øhment of his Right though the V≈øe be void; and if a Copyholder of Inheritance ≈øurrender to a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, ut faciat voluntatem, who regrants to the ≈øaid Copyholder an E≈øtate in Tail according to the Surrender, this ≈øhall bind the Di≈ø≈øei≈øee, 1 Roll. Abridg. 503. pl. 3. Tamen quaere.

The Copyholder in this Ca≈øe might have ≈øold his E≈øtate to the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, and it had b√©en good; and though the Acts of a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor ≈øhall not prejudice the Di≈ø≈øei≈øee, yet he could ≈øee no rea≈øon why the Copyholder, who had parted with his E≈øtate, ≈øhould have it again.

div.head: Taylor ver≈øus Biddal.
div.p: SPecial Verdict in Ejectment: The Ca≈øe was thus;Devi≈øe till he be of Age, then to him in Fee, he dyed within Age, yet a Fee ve≈øted in him pre≈øently. Richard Ben was ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the Lands in que≈øtion, and had a Si≈øter named Elizabeth, formerly married to one Smith, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Augu≈øtine Smith, now Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, and ≈øhe afterwards married one Robert Wharton, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue a Son called Benjamin, and a Daughter called Mary, the now Defendant.

Richard Ben devi≈øed the≈øe Lands to Elizabeth his Si≈øter and Heir, for ≈øo long time, and until her Son Benjamin Wharton ≈øhould attain his full Age of 21 years; and after he ≈øhall have attained his ≈øaid Age, then to the ≈øaid Benjamin and his Heirs for ever; and if he dye before his Age of 21 years, then to the Heirs of the Body of Robert Wharton and to their Heirs for ever as they ≈øhould attain their re≈øpective Ages of 21 years.
Richard the Te≈øtator dies, Benjamin dyed before he came to the Age of 21 years, living Roberr Wharton his Father, afterwards Robert dyed.
And the Que≈øtion was, Whether the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff as Heir to Elizabeth, or Mary either as Heir to her Brother Benjamin, or as Heir of the Body of Robert ≈øhould have this Land?

This Ca≈øe was argued by Serjeant Pemberton this Term,Ex parte Quer. and by Serjeant Maynard in Ea≈øter-Term following for the Plaintiff, and they held that Augu≈øtine Smith, the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, ≈øhould have this Land, becau≈øe no E≈øtate ve≈øted in Benjamin Wharton, he dying before he had attained his Age of 21 years, and the Te≈øtator had declared, that his Si≈øter ≈øhould have it till that time, and then and not before he was to have it; ≈øo that if he never attained that Age (as in this Ca≈øe he did not) the Land ≈øhall de≈øcend to the Heir of the Te≈øtator; that Elizabeth had only an E≈øtate for years, and ≈øo having no Freehold the Contingent Remainder could not be ≈øupported; that Mary could not take by way of Executory Devi≈øe, becau≈øe Robert was living when his Son Benjamin dyed within Age; that therefore 'tis qua≈øi a Condition precedent, Grant's Ca≈øe, 10 Co. cited in Lampet's Ca≈øe. 1 Leon. 101.

There is a difference between Bora≈øton's Ca≈øe and this at the Barr; for that was a Devi≈øe to Executors till Hugh ≈øhall attain his Age of 21 years, and the mean Profits in the mean time to be applyed by them for payment of the Te≈øtators Debts; and becau≈øe he might have computed how long it would be before his Debts could be paid; therefore it was adjudged that after the death of Hugh within Age, the Executors ≈øhould continue in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion till Hugh might have attained his full Age had he lived, and ≈øo a pre≈øent Devi≈øe to them.

But here the Devi≈øe is generally till Benjamin Wharton ≈øhall attain his Age of 21 years, ≈øo that nothing ve≈øted in him until that time, and he dying before, then the E≈øtate ≈øhall de≈øcend to the general Heir, who is the Plaintiff.

2. Admitting this ≈øhould be taken as an executory Devi≈øe, there mu≈øt be ≈øome per≈øon capable to take when the Contingency happens, and there was no ≈øuch per≈øon in this Ca≈øe; for Robert was alive when Benjamin dyed, and Mary could not then take as Heir of his Body, for Nemo e≈øt haeres viventis; like the Ca≈øe of2 Cro. 590. Vaugh. 272. Pell and Brown, viz. Brown had I≈ø≈øue William and Thomas, he devi≈øes Land to his younge≈øt Son Thomas and his Heirs, and if he dye (living William) then to William and his Heirs; Thomas did dye without I≈ø≈øue living William, and it was adjudged that if tho≈øe Words (Living William) had been left out of the Will, Thomas would have a Fee Tail, which he might have docked by a Common Recovery; but by rea≈øon of tho≈øe Words he had only a limited Fee, becau≈øe the Words (viz. If he dyed without I≈ø≈øue) are not indefinite to create a Tail, but are re≈øtrained to his dying without I≈ø≈øue (Living William) which is a limited Fee; and his E≈øtate being determined, William then had a Fee; but if he had died before the Contingency happened, viz. in the Life time of Thomas, and then Thomas had dyed without I≈ø≈øue the Heirs of William would not have an E≈øtate in F√©e for the Rea≈øons afore≈øaid.

If therefore nothing ve≈øted in Benjamin Wharton, nor in Mary his Si≈øter, then the Land de≈øcends to Augu≈øtine Smith as Heir at Law to Elizabeth, who was Heir to the Te≈øtator, and ≈øo the Plaintiff hath a good Title.

Ex parte Def. Newdigate Serjeant contra. Here is only an E≈øtate for years in the Si≈øter of the Te≈øtator, and an E≈øtate in Fee pre≈øently ve≈øted in Benjamin Wharton; and he relyed upon Bora≈øton's Ca≈øe, where the Father having I≈ø≈øue, Humfry and Henry, devi≈øed to his Executors till Hugh his Grand≈øon, the Son of Henry ≈øhould be of Age, and then to him in F√©e; it was there adjudged that the Executors had a Term till Hugh might have attained his full Age, and that
though he dyed at the Age of nine years, yet the Remainder did immediately ve≈øt in him in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion upon the death of his Grandfather, and that by his dying without I≈ø≈øue the Lands did de≈øcend to his Brother.
So here the Fee de≈øcends to Benjamin Wharton in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and he dying without I≈ø≈øue and within Age, the Land ≈øhall then de≈øcend to his Si≈øter and Heir.

The like Iudgment was given in the Ca≈øe of Taylor and Wharton about 12 years ≈øince; and in Dyer 124. a. A Devi≈øe to his Wife till his Son ≈øhall be of the Age of 24 years, then to the Son in Fee; and if he die before 24 years without I≈ø≈øue, then to the Wife for Life, the Remainder to A. &c. The Te≈øtator dyed,2 Leon. 11. pl. 16. Dyer 354. a. it was adjudged that the Son had a Fee ≈øimple pre≈øently, for an E≈øtate tail he could not have till he was 24 years old; and after the death of his Father there was no particular E≈øtate to ≈øupport that E≈øtate in the Remainder till he ≈øhould come to the Age of 24 years, ≈øo that he took by de≈øcent immediately.

So here a Fe√© ve≈øted in Benjamin pre≈øently, and he being dead within Age Mary may take as Heir; however when ≈øhe is of Age ≈øhe ≈øhall take as Heir of the Body of Robert by way of executory Devi≈øe ari≈øing out of the E≈øtate of the Devi≈øor,Stiles 240. Owen 148. which needs no particular E≈øtate to ≈øupport it, as in ca≈øe of a Contingent Remainder; for before Mary was of Age Robert her Father was dead, and ≈øo ≈øhe might well take, Trin. 19 Car. 2. in B. R. Snow ver≈øus Cutler, Rot. 1704.

North Chief Iu≈øtice.Curia. Favourable di≈øtinctions have b√©en always admitted to ≈øupply the meaning of Men in their la≈øt Wills; and therefore a Devi≈øe to A. till he be of Age, then to B. and his Heirs, this is an E≈øtate for years in A. with a Remainder in Fe√© to B And if ≈øuch a Devi≈øe to A. who is al≈øo made Executor or for payment of Debts, it ≈øhall be for a certain Term of years, viz. for ≈øo long as according to computation he might have attained that Age had he lived.

Contingent Remainders are at the Common Law and ari≈øe upon Conveyances as well as Wills; one may limit an E≈øtate to A. the Remainder to another; and ≈øo it may be by Devi≈øe, if the intent of the Parties will have it ≈øo.

But as at the Common Law all Contingent Remainders ≈øhall not be good, ≈øo in Wills no ≈øuch latitude is given, as if none could be bad; they are ≈øubject to the ≈øame Fate in Wills as in Conveyances.

In this Ca≈øe Elizabeth had a Term till Benjamin Wharton be of Age, for ≈øhe is Executrix; ≈øhe was likewi≈øe Heir at Law to the Devi≈øor, and this Land had gone to her, had it not b√©en for this Will; ≈øo that 'tis plain the Te≈øtator never intended that a Fee-≈øimple ≈øhould ve≈øt in her, but ≈øomewhere el≈øe; for he could never intend the De≈øcent of the Inheritance to that per≈øon to whom he had devi≈øed the Term.

It has be√©n argued, that Mary is Heir at Law to Benjamin as well as Heir of the Body of Robert, and ≈øo if ≈øhe can take either way 'tis good; but to make her Heir to Benjamin 'tis nece≈ø≈øary that the E≈øtate ve≈øt in him before he comes to 21 years; and for that Bora≈øton's Ca≈øe was much relyed on, which was al≈øo ≈øaid not to differ from this at the Barr; that an E≈øtate pa≈ø≈øes to Benjamin Wharton in prae≈øenti, and that there was no Incapacity for Mary to take by way of Executory Devi≈øe, as was urged on the other ≈øide, and therefore why ≈øhould ≈øhe not take by way of Executory Devi≈øe as Heir of the Body of her Father, or at lea≈øt, as Heir of Benjamin her Brother?

An Executory Devi≈øe needs no particular E≈øtate to ≈øupport it, for it ≈øhall de≈øcend to the Heir till the Contingency happen; 'tis not like a Remainder at the Common Law, which mu≈øt ve≈øt eo in≈øtanti that the particular E≈øtate determines; but the Learning of Exeecutory Devi≈øes ≈øtands upon the Rea≈øons of the old Law, wherein the intent of the Devi≈øor is to be ob≈øerved: For when it appears by the Will that he intends not the Devi≈øee to take but in futuro, and no di≈øpo≈øition being made thereof in the mean time, it ≈øhall then de≈øcend to the Heir till the Contingency happen; but if the intent be that he ≈øhall take in prae≈øenti, and there is no incapacity in him to do it, he ≈øhall not take in futuro by an executory Devi≈øe.

Sid. 153. pl. 2.A Devi≈øe to an Infant in ventre ≈øa mere is good, and it ≈øhall de≈øcend to the Heir in the mean time; for the Te≈øtator could not intend he ≈øhould take pre≈øently; he mu≈øt fir≈øt be in rerum natura.

3 Co. 20. a. 1 In≈øt. 378. a.If an E≈øtate be given to A. for Life, the Remainder to the right Heirs of B. this is a contingent Remainder, and ≈øhall be governed by the Rules of the Law; for if B. dye during the Life of A. 'tis good; but if he ≈øurvive 'tis void, becau≈øe no Body can be his right Heir whil≈øt he is living; and there ≈øhall be no de≈øcent to the Heir of the Donor in the mean time to ≈øupport this contingent Remainder, that ≈øo when B. dies his right Heirs may take.

In this Ca≈øe a F√©e did ve≈øt in Benjamin pre≈øently, and therefore after his death without I≈ø≈øue the Defendant is his Heir,
and hath a good Title, if not as Heir at Law, yet ≈øhe may take by way of Executory Devi≈øe as Heir of the Body of her Father, which though it could not be whil≈øt he was living, (becau≈øe nemo e≈øt haeres viventis,) yet after his death ≈øhe was Heir of his Body, and was then of Age, at which time, and not before, ≈øhe was to take by the Will.
That Elizabeth the general Heir had only an E≈øtate for years till Benjamin ≈øhould or might be of Age: And ≈øo by the Opinion of the whole Court Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Evered ver≈øus Hone.
div.p: SPecial Verdict in Ejectment; wherein the Ca≈øe was thus, viz.
A Man hath I≈ø≈øue two Sons, Thomas his elde≈øt and Richard his younge≈øt Son.
Thomas hath I≈ø≈øue John.
Richard hath I≈ø≈øue Mary.

The Father devi≈øed Lands to his Son Thomas for Life,Con≈øtructi-of Words in a Devi≈øe. and afterwards to his Grand≈øon John, and the Heirs Males of his Body; and if he die without I≈ø≈øue Male, then to his Grandaughter Mary in Tail, and charged it with ≈øome Payments, in which Will there was this Provi≈øo; viz. Provided if my Son Richard ≈øhould have a Son by his now Wife Margaret, then all his Lands ≈øhould go to ≈øuch fir≈øt Son and his Heirs, he paying as Mary ≈øhould have done.

Afterwards a Son was born, and the Que≈øtion was, whether the E≈øtate limited to Thomas, the elde≈øt Son was thereby defeated: And the Court were all clear of Opinion, that this Provi≈øo did only extend to the Ca≈øe of Mary's being intituled, and had no influence upon the fir≈øt E≈øtate limited to the elde≈øt Son.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: IN the Exchequer Chamber before the Lord Chancellor,Executor of an Executor de ≈øon tort not liable at Law. the Lord Trea≈øurer and two Chief Iu≈øtices, the Ca≈øe was thus: viz. The Plaintiff had declared again≈øt the Defendant as Executor of Edward Nichols, who was Executor of the Debtor.

The Defendant pleads that the Debtor died inte≈øtate, and Admini≈øtration of his Goods was granted to a Stranger, ab≈øque hoc that Edward Nichols was ever Executor, but doth not ≈øay, or ever admini≈øtred as Executor, for in truth he was Executor de ≈øon tort.

The Plaintiff replies, that before the Admini≈øtration granted to the Stranger, Edward Nichols po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, him≈øelf of divers Goods of the ≈øaid Debtor, and made the Defendant Executor, and dyed; and the Defendant demurred; and Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, but rever≈øed here; for an Executor of an Executor de ≈øon tort is not lyable at Law, though the Lord Chancellor ≈øaid he would help the Plaintiff in Equity.
But here Admini≈øtration of the Goods of the Debtor was granted before the death of the Executor de ≈øon tort, ≈øo his Executor≈øhip vani≈øhed and nothing ≈øhall ≈øurvive.

div.head: The Lady Wyndham's Ca≈øe.
div.p: IF Flot≈øam come to land, and is taken by him who hath no Title, the Action ≈øhall not be brought at the Common Law, and no Proceedings ≈øhall be thereon in the Court of Admiralty; for there is no need of Condemnation thereof as there is of Prizes: By the Opinion of the whole Court of Common Pleas.

div.head: Ro≈øe ver≈øus Standen.
div.p: Action where mi≈øconceived by the Plaintiff, and Verdict again≈øt him no Barr to a new Action.IN Accompt for Sugar and Indigoe; the Defendant pleaded, that the Plaintiff brought an Indebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit, a quantum meruit, and an in≈øimul computa≈ø≈øet for 100l. due to him for Wares ≈øold; to which he pleaded Non a≈ø≈øump≈øit, and that there was a Verdict again≈øt him, and then averrs that the Wares mentioned in that Action are the ≈øame with tho≈øe mentioned here in the Action of Accompt: The Plaintiff demurred, and it was ≈øaid for him, that he had brought his former Action on the Ca≈øe too ≈øoon; for if no Accompt be ≈øtated the Action on the Ca≈øe on the In≈øimul computa≈ø≈øet will not lye, and ≈øo the former Verdict might be given again≈øt him for that Rea≈øon.

Ex parte Def.But on the contrary, the Defendant ≈øhall not be twice troubled for the ≈øame thing; and if the Verdict had been for the Plaintiff, that might have been pleaded in Barr to him in a new Action.

Curia. 2 Cro. 284.But the Court were of another Opinion, that this Plea was not good, and that if the Plaintiff had recovered it could not have been pleaded in Barr to him; for if he mi≈øconceives his Action and a Verdict is again≈øt him, and then brings a proper Action; the Defendant cannot plead that he was barred to bring
≈øuch Action by a former Verdict,Antea. Putt and Ro≈øter, Po≈øtea. Ro≈øal and Lamper, Ante. becau≈øe where 'tis in≈øufficient it ≈øhall not be pleaded in Barr; as in Debt upon Bond the Defendant pleaded another Action upon the ≈øame Bond, and the Iury found Non e≈øt factum; the Entry of the Verdict was that the Defendant ≈øhould recover damages, & eat inde ≈øine die, but not quod Querens nil capiat per Breve, ≈øo no Iudgment to barr him, 2 Cro. 284.
But pending one Action another cannot be brought, for they cannot both be true.

If no Accompt be ≈øtated the Action on the Ca≈øe upon an In≈øimul computa≈ø≈øet would not lye; the In≈øimul computa≈ø≈øet implies an Accompt; and upon Non a≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded, the Defendant might have given payment in Evidence, and for that rea≈øon the Iury might find for him. 'Tis true, he might have pleaded Plene computavit, which is the general Plea: But it may as well be pre≈øumed that the Verdict was again≈øt the Plaintiff, becau≈øe the Action would not lye; and the Matter being in dubio the Court will intend it again≈øt the Pleader, he not having averred to the contrary, and ≈øo they held the Plea to be ill.

div.head: DE Termino Pa≈øchae Anno 30 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
Osborn ver≈øus Wright.
div.p: ACtion on the Ca≈øe for words, Viz. The Plaintiff declares that ≈øhe was unmarried, but about to marry one J. S. and that the Defendant, to hinder her Marriage, ≈øpoke the≈øe Words of her, Viz. She is a Whore, a Common Whore, and N's Whore, per quod maritagium ami≈øit. The Iury found the Defendant guilty of ≈øpeaking the Words, but that ≈øhe did not lo≈øe her Marriage thereby; and it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment that the≈øe Words are not actionable, being only Scolding; and of that Opinion was all the Court, and Iudgment was arre≈øted.

div.head: Hambleton ver≈øus Ju≈øtice Scroggs & alios, In Camera Scaccarii.
div.p: Serjeant at Law, whether Priviledge to be Sued only in the Common-Pleas. AN A≈ø≈øault and Battery was brought again≈øt the Defendants in the Kings-Bench, to which one of them pleaded that he was a Serjeant at Law, and ≈øo ought to have his Priviledge to be ≈øued by Bill in the Common Pleas, and in no other Court: To this Plea the Plaintiff demurred; and Iudgment was given in my Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Hales's time by the Opinion of him and the whole Court of Kings-Bench, That a Serjeant at Law might be ≈øued there, and was not ≈øuable in the Court of Common-Pleas only.
2. That in this Action the Defendant ≈øhould not have his Priviledge, becau≈øe it was brought again≈øt him and another.

And afterwards a Writ of Error was brought upon this Iudgment, returnable before the Lord Chancellor, and Chief Iu≈øtices
of the Kings-Bench and Common-Pleas, and the Errors were argued before the two Chief Iu≈øtices at Serjeants-Inn in Chancery Lane.

Mr. Holt for the Plaintiff in the Writ of Error,Ex parte Quer. That a Serjeant at Law is to be ≈øued only in the Court of Common-Pleas, and not el≈øewhere, becau≈øe there is an ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of his Attendance there: He is ≈øworn, and no other per≈øon can plead at that Bar, and therefore if he ≈øhould be ≈øued in any other Court,Vaugh. 155. it would be an Impediment to the Bu≈øine≈øs of that Court, where not only the Officers but their Servants have Priviledge.

In the 11th of E. 4. 2. There was ≈øome di≈øcour≈øe about the Priviledge of Serjeants at Law, where it was held that he is not to be ≈øued in that Court by Bill, but by Original; but either way he is to have his Priviledge. So the Servant of an Officer is not to be ≈øued by Bill,Cro. Car. 84. but he is ≈øtill to have the Priviledge of the Court, and ≈øo had Serjeant Hedley's Clerk in the Reign of King Charles the fir≈øt.

The Serjeants receive a kind of Induction to the Bar, and have a place a≈ø≈øigned them; and that they ought to have Priviledge, the very Words of the Writ are ob≈øervable, Viz. (mentioning a Serjeant at Law) ex officio incumbit in Curia illa.

And though it hath been ≈øaid and given as an an≈øwer to that Ca≈øe in Cro. Car. That where the Serjeants Clerk was Arre≈øted in an Inferior Court (as in that Ca≈øe he was) there he ≈øhall have Priviledge, but not again≈øt the other great Courts in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall; this is a difference never yet taken notice of in any Book, nor doth the Writ warrant this di≈øtinction.

2. He ≈øhall have his Priviledge though he be joyned with another, becau≈øe the Action is joynt and ≈øeveral; and the one may be found guilty and the other acquitted, and it would be an ea≈øie way to ou≈øt a Man of his Priviledge, if it might be done by joyning him with another who hath none, 14 H. 4. 21.
But the Per≈øon with whom the Serjeant is joyned may be ≈øued in the Common-Pleas likewi≈øe, ≈øo that he ≈øhall not hinder him from having Priviledge who of right ought to have it, 10 E. 4. 15.

Offley contra. As to the fir≈øt point,Ex parte Def. the Court of Kings-Bench agreed, that a Serjeant at Law ≈øhall always have the Priviledge of the Court of Common-Pleas again≈øt all Inferiour Courts, but not again≈øt the other Courts in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, for he may be ≈øued in any of them.

A Serjeant is not like the Common Officers of the Court, for they are to be attendant there and no where el≈øe; but a Serjeant at Law is not confined to that Court alone, he may be a≈ø≈øigned of Council in any other Court, and doth u≈øually put his hand to Pleas, both in the Kings-Bench and the Exchequer; but a Philazer or Attorny of that Court cannot practi≈øe in his own Name in any other.
All Ca≈øes of Priviledge ought to be taken ≈øtrictly: And that which was cited concerning the Priviledge of a Serjeants Clerk is not like this, becau≈øe the Arre≈øt was in an Inferiour Court.

In the 11 E. 4. 2. b. The Chief Iu≈øtice of the Kings-Bench came to the Common-Pleas Bar, and told a Serjeant who he had a≈ø≈øigned for a Pauper, That if he would not come into that Court and plead for his Clyent, he would forejudge him; ≈øo that if he could be fetch'd out of the Common Pleas and carried to the Kings-Bench, he is not confined to that Court alone.

In the 5 H. 5. nu. 10. Complaint was made that the Subjects of the King were not well ≈øerved in his Courts, the Parliament thereupon Ordered, that one Martin and others ≈øhould take upon them the Dignity of Serjeants at Law, ≈øo that it appears that their Bu≈øine≈øs lies in other Courts as well as in that of the Common-Pleas.

2. As to the ≈øecond Point: Here is a joynt Action, for any thing that appears to the contrary,2 Rol. Abr. 275. pl. 4. and the Plaintiff may proceed again≈øt one in the Kings-Bench, and therefore the other ≈øhall be ou≈øted of his Priviledge (if he have any) in the Common-Pleas, Moor 556. 20 H. 6. 32.

North Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, That he always took it to be an uncontroverted point, That a Serjeant at Law ≈øhould be ≈øued only in the Court of Common-Pleas by Bill; he is bound by Oath to be there, and when he brings a Writ of Priviledge 'tis always out of that Court, and no other: Curia advi≈øare vult.

div.head: The Attorny General ver≈øus Sir John Read, In Scaccario.
div.p: INformation. A ≈øpecial Verdict was found:Di≈øability by a Statute ought to be removed by the Party to enable him≈øelf to execute an Office. The Ca≈øe was thus:
Viz. Sir John Read 1 Apr. 24 Car. 2. was by Sentence in the Spiritual Court divorced a Men≈øa & Thoro, and for Non payment of Alimony was excommunicated.

Afterwards it was Enacted by the Statute of 25 Car. 2. cap. 2. That all and every per≈øon or per≈øons who ≈øhall have any Office, Civil or Military, ≈øhall take the Oaths of Supremacy and Allegiance, and receive the Sacrament (within the time limited by the ≈øaid Act) or otherwi≈øe ≈øhall be adjudged ip≈øo facto, incapable and di≈øabled by Law, or if he execute any Office after his neglect or refu≈øal to qualifie him≈øelf within the time therein appointed (viz. three Months,) then he ≈øhall be di≈øabled to ≈øue in any Court, and ≈øhall forfeit the Sum of 500 l.

Sir John Read was made High Sheriff of Hartford≈øhire, 12 Novemb. 25 Car. 2. and being ≈øtill under the Sentence of Excommunication, he took upon him the Office and executed it for 3 Months, viz. to the 12th day of February afterwards, and then refu≈øed to ≈øerve any longer; the Iudges came ≈øoon after to keep the A≈ø≈øi≈øes for that County, but there was no Sheriff there to attend them, and the rea≈øon was, becau≈øe if he had executed the Office without taking the Oaths (the time being now expired, wherein he ought to have taken the ≈øame,) then he had ≈øubjected him≈øelf to the forfeiture of 500 l. and he could not receive the Sacrament becau≈øe he was Excommunicated, and therefore ≈øuppo≈øed that after the 3 Months he was ip≈øo facto di≈øcharged by the afore≈øaid Statute; and whether upon all this matter the Defendant be guilty was the Que≈øtion.
Ward and Sir William Jones the Attorny General argued that the Defendant was Guilty.

1. The Oath and Sacrament are nece≈ø≈øary qualifications for all Sheriffs, becau≈øe the Act appoints the≈øe things to be done, and the Penalty therein extends to tho≈øe who execute any Office after the three Months, without doing the ≈øame, but not to ≈øuch who neglect to qualifie them≈øelves.

And though it may be objected, that the Act gives no Penalty for not taking of the Oath, it only enjoyns it to be done, and ≈øubjects
the per≈øon to the forfeiture of 500 l. for executing an Office after three Months, that being not done; ≈øo that this is not to be puni≈øhed by Information, it being no Offence at the Common Law; yet if an Act appoints a thing to be done, the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing of the Law is an Offence at the Common Law, and ought thus to be puni≈øhed, and ≈øo it was adjudged in Ca≈øtle's Ca≈øe, 2 Cro. 643.

1 Roll. Abr. ‚Ä¢ 51, 455.Suppo≈øe the Defendant had given Bond to perform a thing, a di≈øcharge by the Act of God, or by the Obligee had been good, but the Obligor ≈øhould never di≈øable him≈øelf; and if it be ≈øo in private Contracts, much more in the Ca≈øe of the King, becau≈øe our Duty to him is of the highe≈øt nature.

2. Therefore the Excommunication can be no excu≈øe to the Defendant, for though he might have been excu≈øed if he had been under a legal di≈øability, which he could in no wi≈øe prevent; yet here he was able and had time enough, and it was in his power to have di≈øcharged him≈øelf from this Excommunication, and being bound by his Duty and Allegiance to the King to perform the Office, he ought to qualifie him≈øelf for the performance, and either to remove the di≈øability or ≈øhew he had not power to do it.

'Tis his ob≈øtinacy that di≈øables him, and 'tis ab≈øurd to think that this Excommunication which was de≈øigned as a puni≈øhment ≈øhould now be an ea≈øe to him to excu≈øe him from executing this Office, Moor 121. Lacie's Ca≈øe.

3. That the Defendant is puni≈øhable for this neglect, otherwi≈øe the King would lo≈øe the effect of his Subjects Service, if it ≈øhould be in their power to di≈øcharge them≈øelves at plea≈øure; an Act of Parliament cannot, and much le≈øs the Defendant him≈øelf by his own act take away his Duty and Service which he oweth to the King: And therefore, though 'tis Enacted, That a Sheriff ≈øhall be only for one year, yet it has been adjudged that the King by a Non ob≈øtante may di≈øpen≈øe with that Statute,Antea. becau≈øe otherwi≈øe he would be deprived of the Service of his Subjects.

If a Sheriff when he is fir≈øt admitted into his Office refu≈øes to take the Oath of his Office, he is finable, and ≈øo he ought here; if any alteration be made by the King of that Oath, his di≈øobedience afterwards is puni≈øhable,Cro. Car. 26. though a form of the Oath is pre≈øcribed by the Act of Parliament, and there is no other way to puni≈øh the Defendant in this Ca≈øe but by Information, for after the three Months (in ca≈øe he execute the Office not being qualified) the Act gives the Penalty to the Informer; and if he ≈øhould not execute it the inconvenience would be great, becau≈øe 'tis and Office which concerneth the Admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice,
and nece≈ø≈øary for the management and collection of the Kings Revenue.

The Statute extends to Offices of Tru≈øt as well as of Profit, and enjoyns the thing to be done, the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion whereof is an Offence, as well at the Common Law as again≈øt the Statute, and ≈øo puni≈øhable by Information, and therefore they prayed Iudgment again≈øt the Defendant.

Sawyer and Levins contra. Viz. They agreed if the Subject be qualified he ought to accept the Office,Ex parte Def. but the Defendant was not ≈øo qualified, and therefore to be excu≈øed. But before they entred upon the debate whether this was an Offence or not, they took an Exception to the form of the Information.

Viz. That it was not good, becau≈øe it did not conclude contra formam Statuti; for if the Offence be at the Common Law, and a new Penalty is given by the Statute, the Proceedings ought to be either at the Common Law by way of Fine, or upon the Statute for the Penalty; but if the Offence be by the Statute, then it mu≈øt be laid to be contra formam Statuti. Now if this was any Offence in the Defendant, it was becau≈øe he did not receive the Sacrament and take the Oath, which is an Offence again≈øt the Statute, and therefore ought to conclude contra formam Statuti, which is e≈ø≈øential. Then as to the Sub≈øtance;

1. The Information is in≈øufficient, for there is no Offence at all of which the Common Law doth take notice; and though the Con≈øequences of the thing done may be bad, yet no Man ≈øhall be puni≈øhed for that, becau≈øe tho≈øe only aggravate the Offence, if any; neither is this Information true, for it ≈øaith he refu≈øed ab≈øque rationabili cau≈øa, but here was a rea≈øonable cau≈øe: And though it may be objected, that it was only impotentia voluntatis; and that every Subject being disabled, is to remove that di≈øability to ≈øerve the King, this was denied; for a Man who is a Pri≈øoner for Debt is not bound or compellable to be Sheriff, neither is a Man bound to purcha≈øe Lands to qualifie him≈øelf to be either a Coroner or Iu≈øtice of the Peace. By the Statute of 3 Jac. every Recu≈øant is di≈øabled; he may conform, but he is not bound to it, for if he ≈øubmits to the Pemalty, 'tis as much as is required by Law: 'Tis true, a Subject is bound to ≈øerve the King in ≈øuch capacity as he is in at the time of the Service commanded, but he is not obliged to qualifie him≈øelf to ≈øerve in every capacity: Neither doth it appear in this Ca≈øe, that the Defendant was able to remove this Incapacity, and that ≈øhould have been ≈øhewn on the other ≈øide, and all Iudges are to judge upon the Record.

The intent of the Statute is, That if per≈øons will not qualifie them≈øelves, they ≈øhall not execute any Office, and it was made to keep Roman Catholicks out of Places, but not to force them to accept of Offices of Tru≈øt in the Government; and it de≈øigns no puni≈øhment for quitting, but for executing of a place contrary to the Law; but if this be an Offence, this Information will not lie; and for that

2. It was argued, That if a thing be either commanded or forbidden by a Statute, the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion in either Ca≈øe is an Offence puni≈øhable by Information;25 H 6. pl. 9. b. 7 H. 4. 5. but when an Act doth not generally command a thing, but only ≈øub modo, the party offending is puni≈øhable no otherwi≈øe than de≈øigned by that Law; as where the Statute of 18 H. 6. cap. 11. prohibits any Man from being a Iu≈øtice of the Peace, unle≈øs he have 40 l. Íùë AnÃÑ. and the Statute of 5 & 6 E. 6. cap. 16. which makes ≈øuch Bargains as are therein mentioned about buying of Offices void, if ≈øuch Office be forfeitable, then an Information will lie; but when 'tis ip≈øo facto void, as in both the former Ca≈øes, then 'tis otherwi≈øe, becau≈øe the puni≈øhment is executed by the Statute it ≈øelf; and therefore where the avoidance is made by the Act, there is no need of an Information.

And the Objection of impotentia voluntatis is not material to this purpo≈øe, becau≈øe Symony, buying of Offices, not ≈øub≈øcribing the 39 Articles, according to the Statute of the Queen; the≈øe are all voluntary Acts, yet no Information lies again≈øt ≈øuch Offenders, becau≈øe the Statutes execute the puni≈øhment.

The intent of the Parliament is here declared, the di≈øability of the per≈øon makes the Office void; void to all intents, for the Right of Infants or Men in Pri≈øon is not ≈øaved; ≈øo that admitting it to be an Offence, if the Duty be not performed; yet if ≈øuch a qualification be requi≈øit to make a Man to act in ≈øuch an Office, or perform ≈øuch a Duty, if that qualification be wanting, the Party is only puni≈øhable by the lo≈øs of the Office.

The Act doth not di≈øtingui≈øh between Offices of Tru≈øt and Profit: And as to the other Objection, viz. That 'tis in the power of the Defendant to qualifie him≈øelf, the ≈øame might as well be objected again≈øt all the Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, upon the Statute of 3 Jac. and if a Statute doth di≈øable per≈øons or abridge the King of their Services, there is no injury done, becau≈øe the King him≈øelf is party to the Act; but if mi≈øchiefs were never ≈øo great, ≈øince they are introduced by a Law, they cannot be avoided till that Law is changed.

3. But admitting the Information to be good, and that this is an Offence for which it will lie, yet the Excommunication is a
≈øufficient excu≈øe; it appears by the Verdict that the Defendant was ab≈øolutely di≈øabled to be Sheriff, for if he is to take the Oath and receive the Sacrament in order to it, if he cannot be admitted to the Sacrament, as being under the Sentence of Excommunication, that is an excu≈øe.

The Defendant is only argued into a Guilt, for the Iury have not found any; they do not ≈øay, that it was in his power to yield Obedience, or that he might have enabled him≈øelf; they only find his incapacity, and though it was a voluntary Act, which was the cau≈øe of his di≈øability, yet in ≈øuch Ca≈øes the Law doth not look to Cau≈øes ≈øo remote. If a Man be in Pri≈øon for Debt it is his own Act for contracting it and not paying, but yet an Outlary again≈øt him whil≈øt in Pri≈øon ≈øhall be rever≈øed, becau≈øe the immediate Cau≈øe, viz. the Impri≈øonment; and the Iudgment was in invitum, and the Law looks no farther; and ≈øo Iudgment was prayed for the Defendant.

But the Court were all of Opinion, that this Information would lye, and that the Defendant was puni≈øhable for not removing the di≈øability, it being in his power to get him≈øelf ab≈øolved from the Excommunication: And ≈øo Iudgment was given again≈øt him, and a Writ of Error brought, &c.

div.head: Godfrey ver≈øus Godfrey. In Communi Banco. Intrat' Hill. ult. Rot. 321.
div.p: DEBT upon a Bond for performance of an Award,Award of a le≈ø≈øer Sum in ≈øatisfaction of a greater, and good. in which the Arbitrators had taken notice of 72 l. in controver≈øie, and had awarded 50 l. in ≈øatisfaction: The Defendant pleads Nullum fecerunt Arbitrium; the Plaintiff replies an Award, and ≈øets it forth and a≈ø≈øigns a Breach, to which the Defendant demurred, becau≈øe it appeared by the Award that 72 l. was in controver≈øie for Rent due, and that 50 l. was awarded in full ≈øatisfaction of 72 l. and general Relea≈øes to be given; but it did not appear that any other Matter was in Controver≈øie between the Parties though the Submi≈ø≈øion was general; and Arbitrators may reduce incertain things to a certainty, but they cannot make a Debt certain to be le≈øs, except there were other differences for which likewi≈øe this Relea≈øe was to be given, 10 H. 7. 4.

But the whole Court were of Opinion that the Award was good,Curia. for that the Arbitrators might con≈øider other Matters between the
Parties; neither did it appear by the Award that the 72 l. was due, but in demand only; and 'tis unrea≈øonable for him to find fault with his own ca≈øe; for he alledges that he ought to pay 72 l. and complains, becau≈øe the other Party is contented with 50 l. and demands no more. Iudgment for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Wright ver≈øus Bull.
div.p: Condition where 'tis disjunctive 'tis in the Election of the Party to have either.DEBT upon a Bond for payment of 40 l. The Condition whereof was, That if the Defendant ≈øhould work out the ≈øaid 40 l. at the u≈øual Prices in packing, when the Plaintiff ≈øhould have occa≈øion for him≈øelf or his Friends to imploy him therein, or otherwi≈øe ≈øhall pay the 40 l. then the Bond to be void.

The Defendant pleads, that he was always ready to have wrought out the 40 l. but that the Plaintiff did never imploy him; and upon Demurrer the Plea was held ill, becau≈øe the Defendant did not averr, that the Plaintiff had any occa≈øion to make u≈øe of him; and for that it was at his Election either to have Work or Mony,Basket and Basket, Antea. and not having imployed him, but brought his Action, that is a reque≈øt in Law; and ≈øo he hath determined his Election to have the Mony; and Iudgment was accordingly given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Blackbourn ver≈øus Con≈øet.
div.p: Place, where it ≈øhall be intended tho' not laid in the Pleading.IN Replevin, the Avowant pleads an Execution taken out, and that a Term for years was extended, and an A≈ø≈øignment thereof made by the Sheriff, but alledges no place where the A≈ø≈øignment was made: But upon Demurrer it was held good, for it ≈øhall be intended to be a≈ø≈øigned where the Land doth lie.

div.head: Hall ver≈øus Carter.
div.p: Bond to render him≈øelf a Pri≈øoner, good.IN an Action of Debt upon a Bond, the Defendant craves Oyer of the Condition, which was, That if another per≈øon (who was arre≈øted at the Suit of the Plaintiff, (and for whom the Defendant was now bound) ≈øhould give ≈øuch Security as the Plaintiff ≈øhould approve of for the payment of 90 l. to him,Sid. 132. pl. 4. or ≈øhould render his Body to Pri≈øon at the return of the Writ, then the Obligation to be void.

The Defendant pleads the Statute of 23. H. 6. cap. 10. That this Bond was given pro ea≈øimento & favore; And this Ca≈øe coming to be argued upon a Demurrer, the que≈øtion was, whether ≈øuch Bond be within the Statute or not: And the Court were of Opinion that it was not.

If the Sheriff takes Bond in another Man's name, to elude the Statute, ≈øuch Bond is void; but the Plaintiff may give directions to the Officer to take ≈øuch Bond as this to him≈øelf; 'tis only an expedient to prevent a new Arre≈øt, and the Agreement of the Plaintiff makes it good.

If a Capias be taken out again≈øt the Defendant, and a third per≈øon gives the Plaintiff a Bond, that the Defendant ≈øhall pay the Mony, or render him≈øelf at the Return of the Writ; 'tis a good Bond, and not within the Statute, becau≈øe 'tis not by the direction of the Officer, but by the agreement of the Plaintiff; and there is no Law that makes the Agreement of the Parties void; and if the Bond was not taken by ≈øuch Agreement, it might have been traver≈øed.

But Iu≈øtice Atkyns doubted, becau≈øe a Bond to render him≈øelf a Pri≈øoner is void, Bewfages's Ca≈øe, 10 Co. But if it had been to pay the Mony, or appear at the Return of the Writ, it had been good: But notwith≈øtanding Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Shaxton ver≈øus Shaxton.
div.p: THE Condition of a Bond was, Non damnificatus not a good Plea, where the per≈øon and Lands are to be indempnified Antea. That the Defendant ≈øhould ≈øave harmle≈øs Thomas Shaxton, and the Mortgaged Premi≈ø≈øes, and ≈øhould pay the Intere≈øt for the prinicipal Sum.

The Defendant pleads, that Thomas Shaxton non fuit damnificatus, for that the Defendant had paid the 120 l. principal mony, with all the arrears of Intere≈øt due at ≈øuch a day: And upon a Demurrer this was held no good Plea; becau≈øe the fir≈øt matter non damnificatus goes to the Per≈øon and not to the Premi≈ø≈øes: And ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: After acquittal for a Common Tre≈øpa≈øs, an Action on the Ca≈øe will not lie. Sid. 465, 466. Antea.THE Defendant was Indicted for a Common Tre≈øpa≈øs, and Acquitted; and now was Plaintiff in an Action on the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Pro≈øecutor: And by the Opinion of the Chief Iu≈øtice the Action will lie for the Charges and Expences in defending the pro≈øecution, which the acquittal proves to be fal≈øe, and the Indicting him proves to be malicious; for if he had intended any thing for his own benefit or recompence, he might have brought a civil Action, and then if he had been found Not Guilty, he would have had his Co≈øts allowed.

Though the pro≈øecution be for a Tre≈øpa≈øs, for which there is a probable cau≈øe, yet after Acquittal it ≈øhall be accounted malicious; the Difference only is where the Indictment is for a Criminal matter, but where 'tis for ≈øuch a thing for which a Civil Action will lie, the Party can have no rea≈øon to pro≈øecute an Indictment, it is only to put the Defendant to charges, and make to him pay Fees to the Clerk of the A≈ø≈øi≈øes.

div.head: Penrice and Wynn's Ca≈øe.
div.p:
Habeas Corpus may be granted in Civil matters.SErjeant Maynard moved for a Habeas Corpus for them, being committed to the Poultry Compter by the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Bankrupts, for refu≈øing to be examined and ≈øworn touching their Knowledge of the Bankrups E≈øtate: The Proce≈øs again≈øt them in this Court, was an Attachment of Priviledge, which was a Civil Plea, and of which the Court had Iuri≈ødiction, and therefore the Habeas Corpus mu≈øt be granted. And the Chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, that it might be without motion, becau≈øe all the Habeas Corpus's in that Court were ad faciendum & recipiend and they i≈ø≈øue of cour≈øe;Antea. but in the Kings-Bench they are ad ≈øubjiciendum which are in Criminal Cau≈øes, and not to be granted without motion. Then the Serjeant moved that the Sheriff might Return his Writ, which was done, and being filed, he took Exceptions to the Return, by which the ground of the Commitment appeared to be by virtue of a Warrant under the Hands and Seals of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c. which he ≈øaid was ill for want of an Averment of their refu≈øal to come and be ≈øworn; for it did not appear that they did refu≈øe, and they ought not to be committed without refu≈øing, ≈øo that ≈øhould have been po≈øitively averred, viz. That they did refu≈øe and ≈øtill do; for if they are
willing at any time, they ought to be di≈øcharged, and ≈øo they were, but were ordered to put in Bail upon the Attachment.

div.head: Abbot ver≈øus Rugeley.
div.p: THE Plaintiff declared in an Action of A≈ø≈øault and Battery, to which the Defendant pleaded non cul, Plea puis darrein continuance mu≈øt be certified as part of the Record of Ni≈øi prius. and at the A≈ø≈øi≈øes a Plea was put in puis darrein continuance, and a Demurrer thereunto. The Court were clear of Opinion, That if the Plea had been i≈ø≈øuable, it could not have been then tried, neither could the Demurrer be there argued, but mu≈øt be certified up hither by the Iudge of A≈ø≈øi≈øe, as part of the Record of Ni≈øi prius, Yelv. 180. Hawkins ver≈øus Moor.

div.head: Ballard ver≈øus Oddey.
div.p: It was ruled in this Ca≈øe,The Contract it ≈øelf mu≈øt be U≈øurious to make it void. 1 Sand. 295. Mod. Rep. 69. That to avoid a Security by rea≈øon of V≈øury, the Contract it ≈øelf mu≈øt be u≈øurious, for if the Party takes afterwards more than is allowed, that will not make it ≈øo; ≈øo that if the Agreement of the Parties be hone≈øt, but made otherwi≈øe by the mi≈øtake of a Scrivener; yet 'tis not V≈øury: As if a Mortgage be for 100 l. with a Provi≈øo to be void on payment of 106 l. at the end of one year, and no Covenant for the Mortgagor to take the Profits till default be made in paiment; ≈øo that in ≈øtrictne≈øs the Mortgagee is intituled both to the Intere≈øt and the Profits, yet if this was not expre≈øs'd, the Agreement is not V≈øury.

div.head: DE Term. Sanctae Trin. Anno 30 Car. II. in Communi Banco.
The Ca≈øe of one Randal and his Wife, an Admini≈øtrator, &c.
div.p: Judgment may be avoided without a Writ of Error by a Plea, where the Party is a Stranger to it.DEBT upon a Bond again≈øt the Defendant as Admini≈øtrator: They plead a Iudgment recovered again≈øt the Inte≈øtate in Hillary Term 26 & 27 Car. 2. and that they had not A≈ø≈øets ultra. The Plaintiff replies that there was an Action again≈øt the Inte≈øtate, but that he dyed before Iudgment, and that after his death Iudgment was obtained, and kept on foot per fraudem.
