The Defendant traver≈øed the Fraud, but did not an≈øwer the death of the Inte≈øtate; and upon a Demurrer it was ≈øaid for the Plaintiff, that the Iudgment was ill, and that he being a Stranger to it could neither bring a Writ of Error or Deceit, and had no other way to avoid it, but by Plea; and that 'tis put as a Rule, That where Iudgment may be rever≈øed by a Writ of Error, the Party ≈øhall not be admitted to do it by Plea; but a Stranger to it mu≈øt avoid it by Plea, becau≈øe he is no Party to the Iudgment; as if a Scire Facias be brought again≈øt the Bail 'tis a good Plea for them to ≈øay, that the Principal was dead before Iudgment given by way of excu≈øing them≈øelves to bring in the Body; but 'tis not good to avoid the Iudgment, becau≈øe 'tis again≈øt the Record,Cro. Eliz. 199. which mu≈øt be avoided by Writ of Error, 1 Roll. Abr. 449, 742.
The Court were of Opinion, that the Plaintiff might avoid the Iudgment without a Writ of Error, e≈øpecially in this Ca≈øe, where 'tis not only erroneous, but void.

div.head: Hill ver≈øus Thorn.
div.p: IN an Arbitrament it was held by the Court,Rules in an Award. that if two things be awarded, the one within, and the other not within the Submi≈ø≈øion; the later is void, and the breach mu≈øt be a≈ø≈øigned only upon the fir≈øt.

2. If there be a Submi≈ø≈øion of a particular difference, and there are other things in Controver≈øie, if in ≈øuch Ca≈øe a general Relea≈øe is awarded 'tis ill, and it mu≈øt be ≈øhewed on the other ≈øide to avoid the Award for that cau≈øe.

3. If the Submi≈ø≈øion be of all differences till the 10th day of May, 1 Sand. 33. and a Relea≈øe awarded to be given of all differences till the 20th day of May, if there be no differences between tho≈øe two days the Award is good; if any, it mu≈øt be ≈øhewed in Pleading,1 Roll. Abr. 257. otherwi≈øe the Court will never intend it.

4.Smith and Shelbury, Antea. That reciprocal Covenants cannot be pleaded in barr of another, and that in the a≈ø≈øigning of a Breach of Covenant 'tis not nece≈ø≈øary to averr performance on the Plaintiffs ≈øide.

div.head: Staples ver≈øus Alden.
div.p: DEBT upon a Bond conditioned to deliver forty pair of Shooes within a Month at Holborn-Bridge to Henry Knight a Common Carrier to G. for the u≈øe of the Obligee.Tender of Goods to the Man ≈øhall be a Tender to the Ma≈øter.

The Defendant pleaded, that in all that ≈øpace of a Month Henry Knight did not come to London, but that ≈øuch a day at Holborn-Bridge he delivered forty pair of Shooes to A. G. the Carriers Porter: To this Plea the Plaintiff demurred; for that the Condition being to do ≈øomething to a Stranger, the Defendant at his peril ought to perform it;33 H. 6. 13. 4 H. 7. 4. like the Ca≈øe where the Action of Debt was brought upon a Bond conditioned, that the Defendant ≈øhould give ≈øuch a Relea≈øe as the Iudge of the Prerogative Court ≈øhould think fit; the Defendant pleaded that the Iudge did not appoint any Relea≈øe, and it was adjudged no good Plea, becau≈øe the Obligation is on his part, and he ought to tender a Relea≈øe to the Iudge, Cro. Eliz. 716.

But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that a delivery to the Servant is a delivery to the Ma≈øter him≈øelf; and if parcels of Goods are delivered to the Porter and lo≈øt, an Action lies again≈øt the Ma≈øter.

Curia.The Court (ab≈øente North Chief Iu≈øtice) held the Plea to be good, and that ≈øuch a Con≈øtruction was to be made as was according to the intent of the Parties, and that a delivery to the Man was a delivery to the Ma≈øter; whereupon Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Gillmore ver≈øus Executor of Shooter. In Banco Regis.
div.p: A new Act ≈øhall not take away an Action to which the Plaintiff was entituled at the Commencement of the Act. INdebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit. There was a Treaty of Marriage between the Plaintiff, who was of kin to the Te≈øtator, and the Daughter of one Harris, with whom he afterwards had 2000 l. as the Marriage Portion; and Mr. Shooter in his Life time promi≈øed to give the Plaintiff as much, or to leave him worth ≈øo much by his Will.

This Promi≈øe was made before the 24th day of June, before this Action brought; the Marriage took effect, Harris paid the 2000 l. and Shooter dyed in September following, having made no payment of the Mony, or any Provi≈øion for the Plaintiff by his Will.

This Action was commenced after Shooter's death, and upon the Tryal a Special Verdict was found upon the Act of Frauds and Perjuries, 29 Car. 2. c. 29 Car. 2. which Enacts, That from and after the 24th day of June in the year 1677. no Action ≈øhall be brought to charge any per≈øon upon any Agreement made in con≈øideration of Marriage, &c. unle≈øs ≈øuch Agreement be in Writing, &c. And that this was a bare Promi≈øe without Writing.

And by Wyld and Jones (ab≈øente Twi≈øden) Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff; for it could not be pre≈øumed that the Act had a retro≈øpect to take away an Action to which the Plaintiff was then intituled: For if a Will had been made before the 24th day of June, and the Te≈øtator had dyed afterwards, yet the Will had been good though it had not been in pur≈øuance of the Statute.

div.head: A≈øter ver≈øus Mazeen. In C. B.
div.p: IN Covenant,Breach a≈ø≈øigned did relate to three Covenants, the Declaration concludes & ≈øic fregit Conventionem, and good. the Plaintiff declared upon an Indenture in which the Defendant had covenanted that he was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, &c. and would free the Premi≈ø≈øes from all Incumbrances, in which there was al≈øo another Covenant for quiet Enjoyment; and the Breach a≈ø≈øigned was upon an Entry, and Eviction by another, and concludes & ≈øic Coventionem ≈øuam praedictam fregit, in the ≈øingular Number.

And upon a Demurrer to the Declaration Maynard Serjeant ≈øaid, That the Breach did relate to all the three Covenants, and therefore the Conclu≈øion was ill, becau≈øe he did not ≈øhew what Covenant in particular, and if he ≈øhould obtain a Iudgment upon ≈øuch a Declaration, the Recovery could not be pleaed in Barr to another Action brought upon one of the other Covenants.

But Conyers for the Plaintiff ≈øaid, that Conventio is Nomen collectivum, and if twenty Breaches had been a≈ø≈øigned he ≈øtill counts de placito quod teneat ei Conventionem inter eos fact': And of that Opinion was the Court; and that the Breach being of all three Covenants, the Recovery in one would be a good Barr in any Action afterwards to be brought upon either of tho≈øe Covenants.

div.head: Parrington ver≈øus Lee.
div.p: INdebitatus A≈ø≈øump≈øit, Limitation of per≈øonal Actions only extends to accompt between Merchants. Mod. Rep. 268. 2 Sand. 125, 127. Pl. Com. 54. for Mony had and received to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff, a quantum meruit for Wares ≈øold, and an In≈øimul computa≈ø≈øet, &c.

The Defendant pleads the Statute of Limitations (viz.) non a≈ø≈øump≈øit infra ≈øex annos: The Plaintiff replyed, that this Action was grounded on the Trade of Merchants, and brought again≈øt the Defendant as his Factor, &c. The Defendant rejoyns that this was not an Action of Accompt; and the Plaintiff demurred, for that this Statute was made in re≈øtraint of the Common Law, and therefore is not to be favoured or extended by Equity, but to be taken ≈øtrictly; and that if a Man hath a double remedy he may take which he plea≈øeth; and here the Plaintiff might have brought an Action of Accompt, or an Action on the Ca≈øe grounded on an Accompt.

But Baldwyn Serjeant in≈øi≈øted that the Declaration was not full enough, for the Plaintiff ought to ≈øet forth, that the Action did concern Merchants Accompts, and that the Replication did not help it.

The Court were of another Opinion; for that it need not be ≈øo ≈øet forth in the Declaration, becau≈øe he could not tell what the Defendant would plead, ≈øo that ≈øuppo≈øing him to be within the Saving of the Act his Replication is good; and 'tis the u≈øual way of Pleading, and no departure, becau≈øe the Plea of the Defendant gives him occa≈øion thus to reply. But the Saving extends only to Accompts between Merchants their Factors and Servants; and an Action on the Ca≈øe will not lie again≈øt a Bayliff or Factor where Allowances and Deductions are to be made, unle≈øs the Accompt be adju≈øted and ≈øtated, as it was re≈øolved in Sir Paul Neals Ca≈øe again≈øt his Bayliff.

Where the Accompt is once ≈øtated, as it was here, the Plaintiff mu≈øt bring his Action within ≈øix years; but if it be adju≈øted and a following Accompt is added, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Plaintiff ≈øhall not be barred by the Statute,Mod. Rep. 71. becau≈øe 'tis a running Accompt; but if he ≈øhould not be barred here, then the Exception would extend to all Actions between Merchants and their Factors, as well as to Actions of Accompt which was never intended, and therefore this Plea is good, and the Saving extends only to Actions of Accompt; whereupon Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: A≈øtry ver≈øus Ballard. In Banco Regis.
div.p: Principals in Execution the Bail are lyable. 1 Ventris 315THE Defendant became Bail for ≈øix per≈øons, again≈øt whom the Plaintiff got a Iudgment, and two were put in Execution; the Plaintiff afterwards brought a Scire Facias again≈øt the Bail, who pleaded that two of the Principals were taken in Execution before the Scire Facias brought, and whether the Bail was not di≈øcharged thereby was now the Que≈øtion?

It was agreed, that if five had ≈øurrendred them≈øelves after Iudgment,2 Cro. 320. 1 Roll. 897. yet the Bail had been lyable; but are not ≈øo if the Plaintiff (as in this Ca≈øe) hath once made his Election by ≈øuing out Execution again≈øt the Principals, and thereupon two are taken and in Cu≈øtody. Before the Return of the ≈øecond Scire Facias they have Liberty by the Law to bring in the Principals; but the Plaintiff having taken out Execution he hath made it
now impo≈ø≈øible for the Bail to bring them in to render them≈øelves.

But Sypm≈øon argued that the Bail was not di≈øcharged; for he ought to bring in the other four or el≈øe he hath not performed his Recognizance; and ≈øo it was adjudged by the Court,Sid. 107. for the Law expects a compleat ≈øatisfaction: The like Re≈øolution was in this Court between Orlibear and Norris.

div.head: Steed ver≈øus Perryer.
div.p: IN a Special Verdict in Ejectment the Ca≈øe was this,Republication makes it a new Will. viz. Robert Perryer being ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the Lands in que≈øtion, had I≈ø≈øue two Sons, William his elde≈øt, and Robert his younge≈øt Son, and being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed he devi≈øes the≈øe Lands to his younge≈øt Son Robert and his Heirs.
Robert the Devi≈øee dies in the Life time of his Father,Jones 135. 1 Ventris 341 Mod. Rep. 267. and leaves I≈ø≈øue a Son named Robert, who had a Legacy devi≈øed to him by the ≈øame Will.

The Grandfather afterwards annexed a Codicil to his Will, (which was agreed to be a Republication) and then he expre≈øly publi≈øhes the Will de novo, and declared that his Grand≈øon Robert ≈øhould have the Land as his Son Robert ≈øhould have enjoyed it had he lived.
And whether the Grand≈øon, or the Heir at Law, had the better Title was the Que≈øtion?

Pemberton and Maynard Serjeants argued for the Title of the Plaintiff (who was Heir at Law) That if a Devi≈øe be to S. and his Heirs, if S. dye living the Devi≈øor, the Heir ≈øhall take nothing, becau≈øe no E≈øtate ve≈øted in his Ance≈øtor; ≈øo if a Devi≈øe be to the Heirs of S. after his decea≈øe, the Heir ≈øhall take by Purcha≈øe, for he cannot take as Heir for the Rea≈øon afore≈øaid.

By the death of Robert the Son, the Devi≈øe to him and his Heirs was void, and the annexing a Codicile and Republication of the Will cannot make that good which was void before; if it cannot make it good, then the Heir cannot take by Purcha≈øe, and by de≈øcent he cannot take, for his Ance≈øtor had no E≈øtate, and therefore he ≈øhall have none.

Be≈øides, this is not a good Will within the Statute, which requires it to be in Writing: Now the Devi≈øe by the written
Will was to the Son, and the Republication to the Grand≈øon was by Words and not in Writing; ≈øo that if he cannot take by the Words of the Will he is remedile≈øs, and that he cannot take as Heir, becau≈øe his Ance≈øtor dyed in the Life time of the Te≈øtator, Moor 353. Cro. Eliz. 243.

Cro. Eliz. 422. Moor 353, 404. Skipwith and Barrel on the other ≈øide, That the new Publication makes it good, for it makes a new Will in Writing, and it ≈øhall take according to the Publication which makes it have the effect of a new Will. 'Tis true, Deeds ≈øhall not be extended father than the intent and meaning of the Parties at the time of the Delivery, but Wills are to be expounded by another Rule; therefore though by the death of the Son the Will was void, yet by the Republication it hath a new Life, 1 Roll. Abr. 618. 5 Co. 68. 8 Co. 125.

The Chief Ju≈øtice, Wyndham and Atkins Iu≈øtices were of Opinion for the Grand≈øon again≈øt the Heir at Law, viz. That the Republication made it a new Will, and the Grand≈øon ≈øhould take by the Name of Son: And Iu≈øtice Atkins relied on the Ca≈øe of Brett and Rigden in the Commentaries, where new purcha≈øed Lands pa≈ø≈øed by a Republication; but a Writ of Error being brought upon this Iudgment in the Kings Bench, it was rever≈øed.

div.head: Anonymus. In Banco Regis.
div.p: MR. Sanders moved for a Prohibition to the Spiritual Court in the Ca≈øe of the Children of one Collet and Mary his Wife, to ≈øtay Proceedings there upon a Libel again≈øt them; that the ≈øaid Collet had married Anne, the Si≈øter of the ≈øaid Mary. They both appear and confe≈øs the Matter, upon which a Sentence of Divorce was to pa≈øs, whereas in truth Collet was never married to Ann, but it was a contrivance between him and his Wife to get them≈øelves divorced, and the Marriage declared void ab initio to defeat their Children of an E≈øtate ≈øettled upon them in Marriage with Remainders over, by ba≈øtardizing them after they had been married and lived together 16 years. The Rea≈øon why a Prohibition was prayed was, becau≈øe Marriage or no Marriage was to be tried in pais, for that the Inheritance and Freehold of Land were concerned in this Ca≈øe.

The Court directed that they ≈øhould ≈øugge≈øt this Matter,Curia. and that it was a Contrivance to obtain a Sentence of Divorce to defeat them of their E≈øtate entailed on them, and then to move for a Prohibition.

div.head: Smallwood ver≈øus Brickhou≈øe.
div.p: THE Sugge≈øtion was,Spiritual Courts are proper to determine where a per≈øon is capable of making a Will. Godolph. 276. that B. being under the Age of ≈øixteen years had made a Will, and that the Prerogative Court proceeded to the proof of it; whereas by the Common Law a per≈øon is not capable till 17 years; and therefore a Prohibition was prayed.

And that the Common Law hath determined the time my Lord Coke's Comment upon Littleton was cited, 1 In≈øt. 89. b. where 'tis ≈øaid, That at 18 years of Age he may make his Te≈øtament and con≈øtitute Executors; and the Age of a per≈øon is triable al≈øo in pais.

But the Court ≈øaid,Curia. that the Proof of Wills and the Validity of them doth belong to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court; and if they adjudge a per≈øon capable, the Court will not intermeddle, for 'tis within their Iurisdiction to adjudge when a per≈øon is of Age to make a Will; and ≈øometimes they allow Wills made by per≈øons of 14 years of Age, and the Common Law hath appointed no time, it depends wholly on the Spiritual Law; and therefore a Prohibition was denied

div.head: Joan Bailies Ca≈øe.
div.p: NOTA. One Joan Bayly being in Execution,Admini≈øtration was committed to the Debtor in Execution. the Plaintiff dyed inte≈øtate, and the Right of Admini≈øtration came to her, and a Motion was made for a Habeas Corpus to bring her from the Compter into this Court; for that having admini≈øtred to her Creditor ≈øhe might be di≈øcharged; but it was denyed, for ≈øhe could not be thus di≈øcharged, becau≈øe non con≈øtat de per≈øona; neither can ≈øhe give a Warrant of Attorny to acknowledge ≈øati≈øfaction, therefore let her renounce the Admini≈øtration and get it granted to another, and then ≈øhe may be di≈øcharged by a Letter of Attorny from ≈øuch Admini≈øtrator.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: Mandamus. MAndamus to ≈øwear one who was elected to be one of the Eight Men of A≈øhburn Court; it was denyed, becau≈øe it is incertain; for it ought ≈øpecially to be in≈øerted what the Office is, and what is the place of one of the Eight Men of A≈øhburn Court, that it may appear to the Court to be ≈øuch a place for which a Mandamus doth lye; and though ≈øuch a Writ hath been granted for one of the approved Men of Guilford, yet it was ≈øpecially ≈øet forth what his Office was.

div.head: Birch ver≈øus Lingen. Trin. 34 Car. 2. in B. R.
div.p: Di≈øcontinuance where amendable.JVdgment was obtained upon a Bond 25 years ≈øince, and in one of the Continuances from one Term to another there was a blank. The Executors of the Defendant now brought a Writ of Error; and the Plaintiff in the Action got a Rule to amend and in≈øert the Continuance, ≈øugge≈øting to the Court, that it was a Iudgment of a few Terms, and ≈øo aided by the Statute of 16 & 17 Car. 2. cap. 8.

Hughes Abr. tit. Co≈øts 480. 2 Sand. 289. Moor 710. Cro. Eliz. 320, 489, 553, 619. Cro. Jac. 211, 353, 528.Vpon this Rule the Plaintiff fills up the Blank, and the Record was certified ≈øo filled up into the Exchequer-Chamber.

And Mr. Pollexfen moved for the Defendant, that the Record might ≈øtand as it did at fir≈øt, and that the Rule was got by a trick and on a fal≈øe Sugge≈øtion, it being a Iudgment before the Re≈øtoration of this King, and a Di≈øcontinuance not amendable, for 'tis the Act of the Court; and for an Authority in the Point the Ca≈øe of Friend and Baker was cited, where after a Record certified,Stiles 339. a Motion was made to amend it, becau≈øe day was given over to the Parties from Ea≈øter to Michaelmas-Term, and ≈øo Trinity-Term left out, where by the Opinion of Roll Chief Iu≈øtice, that the giving of a day more than is nece≈ø≈øary is no Di≈øcontinuance; but where a day is wanting, 'tis otherwi≈øe.

But Sanders for the Plaintiff ≈øaid, that this was only a Mi≈øpri≈øion of the Clerk and no Di≈øcontinuance, but amendable: The Clerks commonly leave Blanks in the Venires, and if they neglect to fill them up 'tis only a Mi≈øpri≈øion and amendable by the Court; and the Record being now filled up by the Rule of the Court, ought not to be razed to make an Error.

The Chief Iu≈øtice was of Opinion, That this was not a di≈øcontinuance, but an in≈øufficient continuance, and an omi≈ø≈øion of the Clerk only, who if he had filled up this Blank him≈øelf without Rule, it could not afterwards be ≈øet a≈øide.

But Iu≈øtice Jones was of another Opinion, That it was ≈øuch a mi≈øpri≈øion of the Clerk, as was not amendable by the Statute of H. 6. ≈øince it was not the ≈øame Term, and all the Proceedings being in the Brea≈øt of the Court only during the Term, it ought not to be altered, but left in Blank as it was; for where Iudgment is entred for the Plaintiff, the Court may upon ju≈øt cau≈øe alter it the ≈øame Term for the Defendant, but not of another Term, the whole Term being but one day in Law: And though the Writ of Error be returned into the Exchequer, that will make no alteration, for the Record it ≈øelf remains ≈øtill here, and 'tis only a Tran≈øcript that is removed thither. Sed Adjornatur.

div.head: Anonymus.
div.p: TRe≈øpa≈øs for breaking of his Clo≈øe. The Defendants plead,Power where 'tis coupled with an Intere≈øt is a≈ø≈øignable. That the place where were, &c. the Lands of one Martin, who made a Lea≈øe thereof to the Plaintiff, and did thereby except the Trees growing on the ≈øame: In which Lea≈øe the Plaintiff did Covenant with the ≈øaid Martin, his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, that he and they from time to time, during the ≈øaid Lea≈øe, ≈øhould have liberty and full power to Fell the ≈øaid Trees, and root them up, repairing the Hedges where they did grow. That the ≈øaid Martin granted ≈øome of the Trees to the Defendant, by virtue whereof he and the re≈øt of his Servants did cut them down, which is the ≈øame breaking of the Clo≈øe of which the Plaintiff complains: To which Plea Mr. Pollexfen did demurr for the In≈øufficiency, becau≈øe the Defendant did not ≈øhew, that upon cutting down the Trees he did repair the Hedges, as by the Agreement ought to have been done; for this being a limited and qualified power ought to be ≈øet forth at large; and that it was a power only annexed to the Rever≈øion and not a≈ø≈øignable to any one el≈øe, and ≈øo the Defendant hath wholly failed in his Plea; he might have ju≈øtified under Martin, but not in any of their own Rights.

But the Court were of Opinion, That an Action doth lie in this Ca≈øe, both again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øor and his A≈ø≈øignee, acting under his Power; and they agreed that a bare power was not a≈ø≈øignable; but where 'tis coupled with an Intere≈øt, it may be a≈ø≈øigned, and here was an Intere≈øt annexed to the power; for the Le≈ø≈øor might ≈øever the Trees from the Rever≈øion. Whereupon Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head: Scoble ver≈øus Skelton.
div.p: Pre≈øciption mu≈øt be alledged with a Sei≈øin in Fee.THE Plaintiff declared, That he was ≈øei≈øed of a Tenement called Ea≈øt, and the Defendant of another Tenement called We≈øt Travallock; and that he and all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtate he had, did u≈øe to fetch Pot Water from the Defendants Clo≈øe, &c. I≈ø≈øue was taken upon this Pre≈øcription, and a Verdict for the Plaintiff; and Mr. Pollexfen moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, That the Declaration did ≈øet forth generally that he was ≈øei≈øed, and it did not appear it was in Fee; for if it be for Life only, then the Action doth not lie, becau≈øe a Pre≈øcription cannot be annexed to an E≈øtate for Life.

Tremain in≈øi≈øted, that the Declaration was ≈øufficient, and certain enough, for when the Plaintiff doth alledge that he was ≈øei≈øed generally, it ≈øhall be intended a ≈øei≈øin in Fee; e≈øpecially after Verdict.

But the Court held the Declaration to be defective in Sub≈øtance, becau≈øe a Pre≈øcription cannot be annexed to any thing but an E≈øtate in Fee, and therefore 'tis not helped after Verdict. The Iudgment was rever≈øed.

div.head: Putt ver≈øus Ro≈øter.
div.p: A Recovery in Tre≈øpa≈øs, good Plea in bar to an Action of Trover.TRe≈øpa≈øs for taking of his Cattle: The Defendant ju≈øtifies for a Herriot, and upon a Demurrer had Iudgment.

The Plaintiff did afterwards bring an Action of Trover and Conver≈øion for the ≈øame Cattle, and the Defendant pleaded the former Iudgment in Tre≈øpa≈øs, in barr to this Action of Trover, and the Plaintiff demurred.

Serjeant Maynard argued, That the Plea was not good, becau≈øe Tre≈øpa≈øs and Trover are di≈øtinct Actions, and one may be where the other is not; as, if an Infant give Goods to one, an Action of Trover doth lie to recover them, but Tre≈øpa≈øs will not: So if Goods be delivered to another, and he refu≈øe to deliver them upon demand, Trover, but not Tre≈øpa≈øs will lie; and therefore the≈øe being different Actions, a Recovery in one ≈øhall be no barr to the other.
A Formedon brought in the De≈øcender, and Iudgment thereon, is not pleadable in barr to a Formedon in Remainder.

There is a great difference between a barr to the Action,5 Co. 33.6 Co. 37. a. Cro. El. 667. Eo. Entr. 38. b. 2 Cro. 15. pl. 20. Antea. and to the Right; as where an Admini≈øtrator ≈øues, not knowing that he was made Executor, and Iudgment again≈øt him; and he afterwards proved the Will, and brought an Action as Executor; the former Iudgment had again≈øt him as Admini≈øtrator ≈øhall not be a barr to this new Action, becau≈øe 'tis not a barr to the Right, for by mi≈øconceiving his Action the former abated.

But Mr. Holt argued, That the≈øe were Actions of the ≈øame nature, and therfore a Iudgment in one was a good Plea in barr to the other; Tre≈øpa≈øs or Trover lies for taking or carrying away the Goods of another, and when he hath made his Election which to bring, a Recovery there ≈øhall be a perpetual barr to the other.
In an Appeal of Mayhem, 4 Co. 39. the Defendant pleaded a former Recovery in an Action of A≈ø≈øault and Battery, and held good; though one is of a higher nature than the other.

But the Court were of Opinion,Curia. Ro≈øe and Standen, Antea. That an Action of Trover doth lie where a Tre≈øpa≈øs doth not, and if the Plaintiff hath mi≈øtaken his Action, that ≈øhall be no barr to him.

As to the Ca≈øe put of the Mayhem, Rozal and Lampen, Antea. that doth not agree with this, becau≈øe there can be no Mayhem without an A≈ø≈øault, but there may by a Trover without a Tre≈øpa≈øs; and though the Appeal of Mayhem be of a higher nature than the A≈ø≈øault, becau≈øe it doth ≈øuppo≈øe quod felonice Mayhemiavit, yet the Plaintiff can only recover damages in both.

If a Man bring Tre≈øpa≈øs for the taking of a Hor≈øe, and is barred in that Action, yet if he can get the Hor≈øe in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the Defendant in the Tre≈øpa≈øs can have no Remedy, becau≈øe notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch Recovery the Property is ≈øtill in the Plaintiff.

The Defendant in this Ca≈øe hath ju≈øtified the taking of the Cattle for a Herriot, and by the Demurrer the ju≈øtification is
confe≈ø≈øed to be true in fact; now by the taking for a Herriot, the property of the Goods was altered; and wherever the Property is determined in Tre≈øpa≈øs, an Action of Trover will never lie for the ≈øame, but 'tis a good Plea in barr; and ≈øo it was adjudged here.

div.head: James ver≈øus Trollop.
div.p: Pre≈øcription for a Modus good.ERror of a Iudgment in the Common-Pleas on an Action upon a Prohibition, where the Plaintiff did ≈øugge≈øt, That William late Prior of Norbury in Stafford≈øhire, was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Mannor and of the Tythes thereof ≈øimul & ≈øemel, as of a portion of Tythes, &c.

That the ≈øaid Prior 25 H. 1. granted the ≈øaid Mannor and Tythes to William Fitzherbert and his Heirs, rendring Rent: That the ≈øaid Fitzherbert did Enter and was ≈øei≈øed, and held it di≈øcharged of Tythes; that his Heirs afterwards granted two Hides of Land, part of the ≈øaid Mannor, to S. with the Tythes, at 5 s. Rent; and ≈øo draws down a Title by De≈øcent for 300 years to F. who being ≈øei≈øed devi≈øed the ≈øame to Dorothy James, (under whom the Plaintiff in the Prohibition claimed) and then concludes, That Fitzherbert and all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtate, &c. did pay the ≈øaid Rent to the ≈øaid Prior, which ≈øince the Di≈ø≈øolution was paid to the King and his A≈ø≈øigns, in di≈øcharge of all Tythes, &c.
The Defendant having craved Oyer of the Deed demurred to the Sugge≈øtion; and Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff in the Common-Pleas.

And it was now ≈øaid for the Plaintiff in the Errors, That it doth not appear by the Pleadings whether the Plaintiff in the Prohibition would di≈øcharge him≈øelf by a Prae≈øcription in non decimando, or in modo decimandi; for the Grant from the Prior being the foundation of his Title, he could not thereby be di≈øcharged, becau≈øe a Deed before Memory cannot be pleaded, unle≈øs it hath been allowed in a Court of Eyre, or ≈øome Court of Record ≈øince Memory; and this Deed being dated in the Reign of King Henry the I. which was 65 years before the time of Memory by the Common Law, that beginning in the Reign of Richard the I. whatever is before that time cannot be tried by Law; if it had been allowed in Eyre, or in ≈øome of the Courts of Record, it may be pleaded, but no u≈øage in pais can confirm it.

But ≈øuppo≈øing the Deed to be good, the Plaintiff hath alledged a Grant of a portion of Tythes which he cannot have; for at the Common Law a Lay-man was not capable of Tythes in prender, for no one had capacity to take or receive them,Jones 369. 2 Co. 49. ≈øave only ≈øpiritual per≈øons, for which Rea≈øons a Lay-man could not pre≈øcribe in non decimando, but in modo decimandi he might, becau≈øe there is ≈øtill an annual recompence in ≈øatisfaction thereof.

2. 'Tis not alledged, that the place where, &c. was parcel of the Deme≈øus of the Mannor, therefore for what appears it might have been always in Tenancy; and though a Pre≈øcription to a modus by the Lord, for him≈øelf and all his Tenants is good,Cro. Eliz. 599. becau≈øe it might have a lawful beginning, for the Lands at fir≈øt might be all in his Hands before it was a Mannor, and ≈øo much paid for the Tythes thereof, yet ≈øuch a Pre≈øcription by a Tenant is not good.

3. He hath alledged payment to the Prior, and afterwards to the King, and ≈øo would infer a Modus, to which he hath not po≈øitively pre≈øcribed, but by an old Deed upon payment of 5 s. to all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtates, &c. And this will not do, for unle≈øs the Modus doth go to the per≈øon who by Law ought to have Tythes, or unle≈øs it be for his benefit, 'tis not good; as where it was alledged that he ought to be di≈øcharged, becau≈øe time out of memory he employed all the profits of the Land for the Repairs of the Body of the Church, and to find nece≈ø≈øaries, &c. this was not a good Modus, 1 Roll. Abr. 649 placito 8. becau≈øe 'tis no recompence for the Par≈øon.

But it was ≈øaid by Saunders for the Plaintiff in the Prohibition, That by the Sugge≈øtion there was a good Title alledged to be di≈øcharged of Tythes; for 'tis ≈øet forth that the Prior had a portion of Tythes, and the Lands ≈øimul & ≈øemel, and being a Corporation they might pre≈øcribe for Tythes in prender, and the Tythes being well in them, they may well grant it to Fitzherbert paying 5 s. and con≈øtant payment being alledged ever ≈øince, 'tis a good Title.

As to the Deed, tis true, 'tis dated before the time of Memory; but yet 'tis pleadable becau≈øe 'tis a private Deed, and ≈øo need not be allowed in Eyre or in Courts of Record; for ≈øuch as are not to be pleaded unle≈øs allowed there, are only Grants of Franchi≈øes and Liberties from the King, but the confe≈ø≈øion of the Deed to be beyond Memory, and the con≈øtant payment of 5 s. is a ≈øufficient title to the Plaintiff if the Deed is not pleadable, and if it is, then 'tis a good di≈øcharge that way.

And as to the Objection, that the Modus is payable to a wrong per≈øon; there are many ≈øuch which are not paid to the Par≈øon of the Pari≈øh, but to Lay-men: But in this Ca≈øe it doth appear that there was a Modus in the Prior, which being received till it came to the Crown, 'tis good although now paid to others; ≈øo that for that rea≈øon the Spiritual Court ought to be prohibited, and of that Opinion was all the Court; for if a Modus be payable to him, who hath the Right of the Tythes, though it be not to the Par≈øon of the Pari≈øh, 'tis well enough, e≈øpecially where the Plaintiff (as here) alledgeth it to be Portio Decimarum belonging to the Prior, ≈øo that it cannot be ≈øaid that the Par≈øon hath not quid pro quo; for he had nothing at fir≈øt.
This Compo≈øition was made with the Prior, and the Plaintiff is only to ≈øhew payment to him, and to tho≈øe who have his Right.

And as to the date of the Deed, 'tis pleadable though time out of memory, becau≈øe 'tis a private Deed; but Grants of Franchi≈øes and Liberties mu≈øt be allowed in Eyre; and ≈øo is my Lord Rolls to be under≈øtood in his Abridgment; Whereupon Iudgment was affirmed.

div.p: THE Reports of Sir Payton Ventris Knight, late one of the Justices of the Common Pleas, in Two Parts. The fir≈øt Part containing Select Ca≈øes Adjudged in the Kings Bench, in the Reign of King Charles the II. With three Learned Arguments, one in the Kings Bench by Sir Francis North, and two in the Exchequer by Sir Mathew Hale when Lord Chief Baron. The ≈øecond Part containing Choice Ca≈øes Adjudged in the Common Pleas, in the Reigns of King Charles the II. and King James the II. And al≈øo in the three first Years of his now Maje≈øty King William and the late Queen Mary, while he was a Judge in the ≈øaid Court, with the Pleadings to the ≈øame, and al≈øo ≈øome other Remarkable Ca≈øes in other Courts. Printed in Folio, in 1696. With the Allowance and Approbation of the Lord Keeper and all the Judges.
The Lord Coke's Reports in Engli≈øh, Folio.
‚ÄîHis Eleven Reports in French, Fol.
